content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												A clear 2013 Game of the Year candidate, Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a third person puzzle game that gets absolutely everything right.  The story is a simple one - your father needs help desperately, and you have to go find it.  Throughout the journey you'll feel many emotions as you quickly grow attached to the brothers.  This attachment is due to the fact that you control both brothers at the same time and you need to have them work together to fight through adversity and move on in your journey.  The lack of lengthy cut-scenes and a made-up language were interesting choices that also worked 100% with this game.  It makes you become even more involved, not just sit back and watch a movie play out in a game.Graphics-wise, it's visually beautiful without the need of heavy tweaking.  The game environment immerses you to its fantasy world instantly.  Houses, farms, towns, cliffs, castles, mines, caves, water... all the environments are well-made and polished.  The way you get to interact with animals in particular was phenomenal in my opinion.  A lot of small interactions with people, items, and animals are not necessary to move on in your journey, but they add fun and depth to the game experience and gets you even more immersed.It's recommended that you play with a controller, and I could see why.  You control one brother with each joystick, and a lot of times you'll need to interact with both at exactly the same time to solve puzzles.  I thought that the teamwork between the brothers was spectacular, and not something you see every day in a single player game.  No gameplay bugs or annoyances to speak of.  You just need to learn to work together with yourself :)  The puzzles themselves are very simple, yet brilliant in how you go about to solving them.All achievements are fun to attain, not a chore.  If you missed an achievement during your first playthrough, you can go back and play each chapter separately.  I finished the game in 4 hours.  Others have finished it between 2 and 6 hours.  The game was so much fun that I purposely had to put it down so that I didn't play through it in one sit-down.  I'm not going to spoil anything whatsoever regarding the story.  All I'll say is that you'll experience many up's and down's throughout the journey.  Which again, it's something that the game got 100% right.  Right now I can't think of a single negative to speak of.  I guess the game length would be the only negative since it's such a great and fun game that you'll wish the journey had lasted longer.TotalBiscuit called Brothers the best game he's ever played, surpassing his previous choice (Deus Ex).  I also happen to think that Deus Ex is one of, if not the best game ever made.  I do understand why he would place Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons so high up the game ladder.  I haven't played The Last of Us yet, but I would strongly make a case for Brothers as a 2013 Game of the Year candidate.  I'm not a recognized game reviewer person or site, so it's just my humble opinion.  But go ahead and buy Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons if you want a great, emotional gaming experience :)

No matter how hardened you are, the game will find a place in your heart, a door long forgotten, and will kick it open with a bang. But it will give you an experience like no other, the one you will never forget.Emotions. Now I remember them.

												I came into this game knowing it was the single player co-op game, many friends had recommended it, and not much else.  That is the way to do it.  It is absolutely worth the 4-6 hours it will take to complete and every new chapter managed to again take my breath away. Immediately jumps into the top of the "video games as art" conversation.  Play it now.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Oh boy, this game..Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is an amazing journey about those two kids, searching for a cure for their father, since he got sick.You will totally need a controller for this game, but there is a reason. Let's analyze everything, shall we?The gameplay is pretty innovative yet so easy: left stick + L2 to control a brother, right stick + R2 to move the other one. Each of them will have his own ability, like the big brother will move heavy stuff, and the small one will pass through tiny bars. Might look a little too hard to control at the biginning, but you'll get used to it pretty fast. But you'll probably get stuck sometimes or die like an idiot becouse you can't tell witch kid you're actually moving. Probably it was just me becouse I'm terrible with a controller.Anyway, the story itself is pretty easy, but the small events that you will encounter, most of them well hidden, are really well written. Some scenarios are really, really impressive and I think I never saw something like that, like  the Valley of the  dead giants .There aren't many enemies this this game, but a lot of jumping puzzles and puzzles itself. Not much difficult, but still a lot of  fun to play. There will be also some boss battles, but not much of a challange.The music is really great, I love it and really know where to hit the spot. Really well chosen for certain moments.The only thing that kinda disappoint me are some few bugs that I encounter: for exemple, once I got stuck into a rock, and i couldn't move from that. Had to restart from last checkpoint. Immersion broken.In the end, this game get for me a whole 8/10Is great, go get it now. Maybe better get that on sale, is an awesome game, but 15€ might be a little too much, but that won't be a problem.

number of helpful: 14 of 15 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
Brothers is a sublime poignant experience, characterized by its ability to convey affecting emotion without any intelligible dialog. It carries you through a fantastical world never uncertain of what it wants you to see and feel, and does so in such a effective manner that it never needs to say anything to make you connect with your two characters, and leave a lasting impression.Brothers story is not one that can be spelled out on paper, and really does require you to experience it for yourself in order to understand why it is so powerful. The way in which each piece is woven and rewoven together creates a world that feels connected and draw out despite the immense ground covered and the drastic changes undergone by the environment, as well as the short length which leaves little time for exposition. I honestly do not feel capable of doing it any sort of justice with this review, but know that this is the type of narrative journey that comes along rarely for a reason, that being it is very hard to do successfully especially to such a level as is shown here. I once read the way A Tale of Two Sons plays described as "single player co-op" which is the perfect definition for it. You control both brothers concurrently with the two analog sticks and triggers. It's a disorienting rewiring of the motions we've become so accustomed to and requires you use both sides of your brain at once, but once you get accustomed it allows for an array of increasingly ingenious occurrences. The ways in which it forces you to work together (with yourself) are brilliant and within the first opening moments completely sold me on the unusual control scheme and only continued to impress me with the cleverness that the developers managed to play with mechanic.As compelling as I found the gameplay, I was simply struck by the unequivocal beauty of the visuals. The texture work and lighting effects bring the prodigious creativity and imagination to life in a vibrant and ever changing display of wondrous locals and characters. The breathtaking and dramatic soundtrack is perfectly timed to every action that occurs, with a dynamic range of sounds that sweeps you through the world as an irreplaceable part of it.There are few games which I feel deserve the title, but the level at which Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons accomplishes everything it attempts and the skill in which it executes the different components, warrants the term masterpiece. It is an impressive achievement in both interactive storytelling and original game design that left me in a state of wonder with each passing moment. Disregard the fact that you can and likely will complete it in one sitting, Brothers is something that needs to be played and a game I will surely be singing the praises of far into the future.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												In first hour of gameplay, I've thrown a little girls ball down the well, got my petty revenge on ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who made my life difficult, stole not one, but two sheeps and made friends with a benevolent troll. Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons combines a brillianty crafted, surprisingly interactive world, with charming, sympathetic characters and emotional storyline. It's short and very linear, but it's also airtight, perfectly paced and not a moment of it feels superfluous. While platforming is easy and puzzle soultions are almost always very obvious, main challenge comes from mastering games unique dual-control gameplay (you control one brother with each analog stick and that's why GAMEPAD IS A MUST). To me it was relatively easy but some less patient players may be discouraged from properly enjoying it. However, that would be to their own detriment, because despite it's shortness (and subsequently relatively high price) it provides a unique experience and narrative (reactions and dialogue are communicated exclusively through mime and vocal inflections) which should be experienced and appreciated by anyone who loves puzzle-adventures or just wants a well-crafted, story driven game.

number of helpful: 14 of 16 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												This was probably one of the best games I've ever played in all my years of gaming. Great story, amazing graphics, beautiful music, and very rewarding to play. Although people have found ways to make it work without one, you will definitely need a controller to get the full experience (preferably one with feedback/vibration turned on and also 2 analog sticks, I used an Xbox 360 controller). It's a very short game and probably doesn't have a lot of replay value (though I personally may want to play through it again and again every so often, the way you go back and read a book you really love every few years), but it's an experience that I think will stay with you long after you finish playing.At first, I thought the controls were going to be awkward, but the interface is so simple and the story is so compelling that you really do get lost in the game and the controls feel very natural. The puzzles are intuitive and not too difficult, and unlike a lot of games I never found myself frustrated because something was too hard or I couldn't figure out what the next step was. I also never felt like the puzzles were too repetitive (even though some elements do repeat) because the environment keeps changing enough to keep things interesting. Overall this game was a pleasure to play and very very satisfying. If you're on the fence about buying it, don't hesitate. It's a beautiful gaming experience that shouldn't be missed.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Brothers - a tale of two sons


knock knock 
A Screenshot of Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons
By: Sir Strattimus




Who's there? oh well, it's another review of Brothers - a tale of two sons, what else?So, my motivation for playing this game, was basically that I had heard only good things about it. Actually not just "good" things, I had heard great things. So I decided that I wanted to try it out, and now I can only take part in the joy, of confirming the awesomeness that is this game.The only thing, that people kept repeating, that's pulling this game a small bit down, is the fact that it only takes about 3-4 hours to beat. I did it in one sitting, and on one hand, it's great to have a short game, with a nice storyline. It always feels good to finish a game, and it's healthy if you tend to have a quickly growing backlog. But on the other hand, it's also nice to have a game, that's abit long, you get to follow the charaters for longer, and get more into the story. Plus, if it's a good game, then there's the obvious advantage of extra gaming content. (When I'm saying a long game, I'm not talking skyrim long, just with a bit more of an ellaborated story). But in the end, I don't think that this game needs to be any longer, in the matter of a fact, I think it has the perfect length, you get a nice insight in the game and the two brothers' adventure to reach their goal.One thing I found really special and unique in this game, is how it manages to create that feeling, of sympathy, and understanding. Even though it's in a completely foreign language. In fact, I pictured myself in their roles so much, that I even started refering to myself in plural. This is definatly one of the most emotional games, I have ever played. At parts, it got me directly sad.Even though this game at the store page, has a note saying "notice: this game requires a controller" this is actually not the case. I started this game up, using my gamepad, and given you're playing as two charaters, it takes a second to get used to the double controls. Especially when the brothers switch side of the screen. Anyways, half way into the game, i decided "hmm, maybe i should try using my keyboard, just for the sake of testing if it works." And it does, and while many say that the keyboard controls are much more difficult to use, i actually found it completely opposite, and stuck with it for the rest of the game.The graphics in this game is astonishing, and all over fantastic. Brothers is all over a beautiful game 


here, have a free view 
A Screenshot of Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons
By: Sir Strattimus




 and not only that, the tremendous amount of stuff you could interact with, simply made the game even funnier, even the two brothes had different ways of ineraction, it was an exploration in itself, just walking around, and watching them react to stuff.You start the game with a cutscene, where you tragically see the mother die at sea. 


oh wow, 1minute in the game and the mother's tragic dead occur, 
A Screenshot of Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons
By: Sir Strattimus




 Afterwards, you slowly fade back into presence. You're playing as two brothers, who has bring their ill father some healing water from the tree of life (atleast that's what it's called in my head xD). They have to pass and solve countless tests and challenges by the use of teamwork and some nice parkour, you start of in your home town, getting slowed down by a simple town-bully, but are yet to find out there are far worse things to worry about, giant trolls, even bigger spiders, invisble snow creatures and all sorts of monsters awaits the two boys, and before they finally reach the tree, they have to survive all these things. and just when you think all is good, twists are happening all around you (no spoilers, go play for yourself) http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=233640820http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=233641046 While almost everything in this game is perfect, it feels like the devs. has done over one particular bit, abit quickly compared to the rest of the game, I'm talking about the soundtrack, while it too has some cool parts to it, I feel like it lags that one epic track, that makes you wanna play the game, over and over again, just for that track, or simply just makes you hum along to it.All in all, I give this game a 9/10 it's an amazing game, the developers did an incredible job on this game, it has every little aspect needed in my opinion, the only thing keeping it from perfection is the soundtrack.So cheers Starbreeze Studios for this game http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=233640379 also, have a few pics :eng: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=233897403 http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=233653659 http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=233647495

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Brothers is a game where you control two brothers on a quest to save their father. The game is optomized with an Xbox 360 controller in mind, no doubt. Or at the very least, a controller. It can definitely be played with a keyboard and mouse, but I wouldn't recommend.Now that I got that out of the way, I'll let you know why(if you didn't already know) this is one of the best games of the year. The way you control both brothers binds with the story so well its absolutely amazing. We all know when it comes to gaming there are two basic factors that make a video game: Mechanics and story. I think a game can have very little of one or the other, and still be a good game. However, it is extremely rare that the mechanics practically make the story. Its absolutely amazing how well it is done. I'm fairly sure its been done in similar ways before, but not in a way like this, in a way that makes the story what it is. The story wouldn't exist without the mechanics, its amazing how they flow.There is no dialouge, yet the story is one of the best I've played. How the hell does that even happen? It completely took me by surprise. I didn't think that was possible until Journey, and now Brothers has done a very similar thing. To be honest, while the mechanics do make the story, they don't come without bugs and issues. There were several times where the controls got in the way of me being able to complete a task. I don't entirely blame the game, I blame my brain for not always being able to keep track of both characters and coorespond that with the correct stick on the controller. Also, I ran into a few different glitches, but nothing broke my game. However I have heard of glitches forcing some people to restart entire chapters, which is not ideal. I'm not going to tell you this is my favorite game of all time, or even my #1 game of the year, but that doesn't mean the game isn't amazing and plenty of fun. I would have been happy paying the full sale price, but at $4.49, its an absolute steal. Brothers gets my full recommendation. Buy it now(at this time it is 4.49) or at 14.99, it makes little difference. The game is absolutely worth every penny. Play Brothers today to experience one of the best blends of story and mechanics I've ever seen. Buy At Full Price

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												A rare gem of a game based on a modest concept that is executed flawlessly. It doesn't try to appeal to everyone and is better for it. Its main strength is its highly emotional story which is hard to talk about without spoiling anything. I can only say that it managed to surprise me more than once. It's about 3 hours long which might seem short on paper but you won't be bored for a single minute and the impact it makes will stay with you a great deal longer. It's designed to be played as a "single player co-op game" but I played it with my younger brother for an extra layer of immersion and we both had a wonderful time throughout. The game doesn't actually "need" a controller to work but using a keyboard is a bad idea as it takes away much of the gameplay value. I had to use an emulator to get my old controller to work with the game but it was well worth the trouble. All in all I'd say it's more than worth the price and the 3 hours of your life as it will most likely enchant your whole evening like it did mine.

												This game took me completely by surprise.Which is really surprising because, after the first few minutes, it was nearly a disappointment: graphics fine but not sophisticated, a touching story which did not seem very promising and characters too simple. And then I let it drop in a corner of my library and forgot about it until I decided to get back on it more than a year afterwards, mainly because the achievements were easy to get.And finally, this game astonished me and was clearly much better than I expected it to be.I was totally absorbed by the unique atmosphere that characterizes it. I’m not surprised it has the tag "Atmospheric". With the atmosphere somewhat childish of the beginning, I was not expecting to discover a universe both gloomy, melancholic and yet very colorful afterwards. This conjunction of the theme of death on a bright picture painted with softened features worthy of a children's story is quite striking and almost unsettling. And let’s not forget about the history of these very young characters which ends up tearing your guts out.

Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons

By: Helline




~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Si je devais résumer mon sentiment sur ce jeu, je dirais qu’il m’a totalement prise par surprise.Pourtant, après les quelques premières minutes de jeu, j’avais réussi à accrocher tant bien que mal grâce aux graphismes sympathiques mais pas assez aboutis à mes yeux, à une histoire touchante mais qui ne me semblait pas non plus très prometteuse et des personnages que je trouvais plus niais qu’autre chose. Et puis je l’avais laissé choir dans un coin de ma bibliothèque jusqu’à ce que je décide de m’y remettre plus d’un an après principalement pour les succès faciles à obtenir, je l’avoue.Et finalement, contre toute attente, ce jeu a dépassé toutes mes espérances.Je me suis totalement laissée absorbée par l’atmosphère unique qui le caractérise. Pas étonnant d’ailleurs que le tag « Atmosphérique » lui ait été attribué. L’ambiance quelque peu enfantine du début ne laisser en rien présager de l’univers à la fois glauque, mélancolique et pourtant très coloré que l’on découvre par la suite. Cette concomitance du thème de la mort sur un tableau lumineux peint avec des traits adoucis digne d’un conte pour enfant est assez frappant et presque déstabilisant. Et que dire de l’histoire qui finit par vous prendre littéralement aux tripes.


Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons

By: Helline




L’harmonie qui unit les deux frères est au cœur même de cette aventure de par un gameplay assez particulier où l’on doit contrôler les deux personnages en même temps pour pouvoir progresser. Personnellement, je joue au clavier. Il m’a fallu un peu de temps pour m’y habituer surtout que l’un des deux protagonistes est programmé à la base pour un clavier qwerty mais il m’a simplement suffi de le passer manuellement en azerty avec les touches Shift+Alt pour régler ce souci, et le coup de main vient finalement assez vite.En clair, je me suis prise une bonne claque comme cela se fait de plus en plus rarement et je recommande vivement d’acquérir cette petite perle au plus vite.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons opens and closes with death. It’s a game about death. But it isn’t a game about killing. What is between the opening and closing scenes is a dark fairytale world full of mature themes, and the bond of two siblings as they struggle valiantly on a quest to save their withering father. A beautiful and melancholic journey awaits you, and a deep emotional investment will be required. And though brief, this attractive storybook adventure is as dreamlike as it is affecting.Brothers’ appeal lies in what it doesn’t tell you. Cutscenes are used sparingly, with the world itself providing the emotional pull and story. For instance, while I was using the twin-control scheme to explore a town, I was able to steal a ball and throw it down a well, leaving a small girl in tears. The imaginary language used by the characters is universally bolstered by wonderful body language, and the affection and fears that each brother holds for the other. The twin-control scheme is key to the game’s identity. It’s a somewhat clumsy control system, with each brother being assigned to a control stick and a shoulder button. However, Brothers’ generally requires the input of both characters, both to work together and independently, to pass obstacles. It’s a key identifying feature for the game and one that has been cleverly exploited.The obstacles are generally rather easy, and there is only a small amount of room to experiment, with generally one rather obvious solution. The challenge comes in actually performing the actions necessary to pass. As you control both brothers at the same time, and often you need to split them up to do individual tasks, some of which can be timed, it can occasionally feel like trying to pat your head and rub your belly at once. Something that for most of us, we are certainly capable, but it does require a different type of input than we would normally use.And these siblings will certainly have you wringing your hands. Sometimes over the controls, but mostly over their relationship with each other, and in turn, your relationship with them. The epic undertaking they’re on will have them trek over snow-capped mountains, across frozen lakes and an ancient giant’s battlefield – it’s a wonderfully realised world without exposition – it exists and feels real. The settings are as varied as the tasks required of the brothers, and the emotional pull of the game will have you powering on to see what happens next. This is not a game to be played in short stretches, and at just over 3 hours in my playthrough, I completed it in just two sittings.The dark undercurrent of death in this world is never confrontational, it seeps into every pore of the game, and can even be missed. Shortly after leaving a small village, I passed a man attempting to hang himself. Using one brother to prop him up, and another to cut the rope, I left him sitting beneath the tree to sob like a man who had nothing left. Further ahead I found a burnt out homestead, and with the brothers working in tandem, I was able to retrieve a small music-box which seemed to help the man. This sentimental scene is one of many throughout Brothers’ that outright dealt with death in a mature and intelligent fashion, an unusual but fascinating design decision by the developers. I suppose you could say that the true aim of Brothers’ is to make us feel. Of course, there is the adventure, and the smartly designed environmental obstacles, but this is a game where touch isn’t just an afterthought, and death has some permanence, and has some resonance. And while it’s brief, Brothers’ doesn’t outstay it’s welcome, and provides an ambitious, emotionally affecting adventure that while short, is very sweet. Memorable.8.5/10.

Nordic heavy fairy-tale with uncommon controls. Main plot is glorious and consists of different little stories you can discover (or miss) on your way. It also has a lot of symbolism which is often a part of gameplay. Some people say that it's too short (around 5 hours), but in my opinion the length of the game is ideal for the story being told. It brings new elements of gameplay in every chapter, so you simply have no time to get bored with them. It keeps the game interesting until the very end even if you don't like the plot (what is unlikely). The game also provides picturesque landscapes like every 5 minutes.Technically it's a platformer with some little puzzles. Unique feature of the game is controlling two characters at the same time. It can seem difficult at first and it definitely needs more coordination, but controls are simple and very well done. In overall the game isn't hard to beat. Game runs well on old systems (see system requirements). Also it's fully compatible and comfortable to play with keyboard.I highly recommend to play and complete this peace of art.

content:
Posted: January 12
												A nice short little adventure with easy achievements. Really enjoyed it, although there are some minor things that bothered me, which makes the universal praise a bit confusing to me.First off the positive aspects though. The mechanic of controlling each brother individually was definitely unique and entertaining. Sometimes I had to figure out who's who, so I always preferred having the older brother on the left and the younger one on the right, so that they align with the analog sticks they're controlled with, but once you get used to the controls it's somewhat fascinating to play two characters at once. It's surreal to look at the screen and see them move so naturally and despite being in control it disconnects you from what's happening. I felt like I'm watching a movie or something. That's not a bad thing, it only underlines how idiosyncratic the feature is.What I didn't like was the gibberish language they were talking. Growing up in a multicultural area, and being a son of migrants myself, most words sounded familiar, but didn't make sense at all. So it really took a lot of immersion away from the game when they just sounded completely ridiculous in, what supposed to be, moving scenes.It also felt a bit incoherent, because this game got really, really ♥♥♥♥ing dark all of a sudden. At first it was a beautiful hike through the woods, but then it was all about death, halucinations and what not. You could argue the sudden change is an artistic tool to add more weight to the events, but it just felt out of place.Still an enjoyable experience and alone the gameplay mechanics make it worth being played.Review taken from my backlog profile.[backlog-deepness.rhcloud.com]

number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
Explains the plot through gameplay rather than exposition.A lot of classic games either skimped on discussing any plot or simply didn't have the technology to incorporate a complex storyline. By reducing voiced character interaction to a minimum and having them speak in a foreign language, the player is left to interpret the story; a compelling and central aspect to this indie contender. I've been told that this is one of the very finest games ever made and while I understand the appeal and certainly agree its worth your time, I don't think it belongs on the pedastal so many critics have garnished it with. Despite clocking in at three hours, the game felt much shorter as it seemed to just fly by. Every blink I took was accompanied by a huge transition in location. Before I knew it I was adventuring in a completely different place, each one bearing its own set of rules and all goverened by the same overarching objective (venture forth and get your sick dad some medicine). You'll never feel stressed and even dying won't set you back more than a few moments. Progress is blocked by a handful of simple, contextual puzzles. This is the perfect game for relaxing with one day. Perhaps the strongest point and what makes this game so unique is that like Mario and Luigi RPGs you'll be controlling two characters (who can't typically sepraate far from one another). The way they both interact with the expansive world made everything come to life. One brother would kneel down to pet a sheep and the other would pick it up and carry it with him. One would admire the caged bird and the other set him free. This game's been on sale before so try to pick it up on the cheap. I snagged it for about three bucks. You'd have to enjoy a AAA game for sixty dollars proportionately if you wanted that sort of value.

Posted: October 12, 2014
												The only word to describe this game is: beautiful. The art direction, soundtrack, color patterns, interaction with the world, controls... everything is beautiful. Especially interactions and the responses of the items or people (wouldn't like to call them NPC's in such a game) depending on the brother you're interacting at that time makes this game astonishingly brilliant. Being directly involved  in some major happenings (like at the giant tree, near the end of the game) makes it more than a simple platformer and enhances the game's influence on your emotions as you are doing those specific actions.  Preference of using the player's involvement rather than showing those kinds of events as cutscenes turns this simple story to a bond between the game and the gamer.Only negative points are: Mostly holding LT and RT buttons might become tiring for fingers after a while. Controller direction settings are set for XBOX gamepads, which are different than most of the gamepads on the market in terms of locations of digital and analog movement buttons, therefore while you're controlling a brother with analog, you'll control the other with digital and this kinda diminishes the revolutionary control system.Game is too short and would love to play more of this.Puzzles could have been harder (?).At the end, it is a great experience to participate in the tale of two brothers.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Man, where to begin with this one...Story: Two brothers, Naiee and Naia, lost their mother to the sea. Now their father is ill, and according to a local doctor the only thing that can cure him is some healing water far away.In short, the story won't woah you at all, but it's simple enough to get you engaged.Dialog: There is none, you'll either dislike that or you won't mind it. Personally I don't see a reason to complain about it, infact it honestly goes well with this game.Graphics: The visuals and artstyle is definitely one of this game's strongest points, every location you go to throughout this adventure is so beautifully crafted and diverse. Gameplay: I like to compare this game with Prince of Persia but without attacking and you control two characters instead of just one.You control the 2 brothers with your analog sticks, one for each brother. Each brother also uses the triggers for actions in the game, again one for each. This might catch you offguard at first, but you'll get use to it with time and it allows for very interesting puzzle solving.Final note: One thing I would like to mention is that this game is quite short, shorter than what I would like. There is so much potential to have this adventure expand even more in between, but at least it never felt repetitive as it is.Anyways, definitely a Must Buy. Beautiful visuals, engaging gameplay and a lasting impact.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												Brothers is a story-driven action/3D-platformer adventure. You guide two sons across a dark fairy-tale realm, in search of a magical ingredient that will save their widowed father from an illness.- Gameplay is what makes this game unique: You control both brothers with a single gamepad (highly recommended), using the analogue sticks to move the brothers and one button to interact with the world. That's all! You'll need to synchronize the brothers' actions and use each ones advantages to move across the story. You can also play co-op, e.g. one player on keyboard and the other on gamepad. The puzzles are usually pretty simple to figure out, but some can be a bit hard to pull off. But, don't worry, the game autosaves frequently, so you can die as much you want. Finally, note that there's no text in this game, neither written nor spoken: there's some made-up language heard, but you'll only have visual clues about what to do next. - Story is linear, simple but beautiful. The world-theme might seem like a fairy tale, but be warned that there's a lot of mature content in the game. Tears came to my eyes several times, but there was also a few laughs :) Note that the game is a bit short, i.e. it takes 3-5hrs to complete it. I did a second playthrough to get the achievements, which were usually small branches off the main story, that you might not notice.- Visuals are FANTASTIC; Unreal Engine at its best. Can't really describe this, so you'll just have dive into the story and get blown away! The world is magnificent and varying, in the ~8 chapters of the story. The camera-rotation is smooth but might be annoying to some.- Audio is fine in overall. The music is beautiful, but not omni-present in the game; I think it could do with more music. As I said, there's some made-up language used in the game, which might annoy you at times: The brothers have a tendency to call out to one-another when they're separated!I highly recommend this game to lovers of action-adventures, with a sensitive vein. EDIT -- The controls worked right, with the exception of one (non game-breaking) glitch: Sometimes the big brother would interact with the world (thus re-starting small cut-scenes) when I moved both brothers in tight spaces with the analog sticks. This was most likely due to me using x360ce emulator to make my PS-styled gamepad compatible with the game.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												This is a fairy tale of a game. There's nothing terribly complex or unique about it, but at the same time there's something endearing to it. It's a brief experence, to its benefit, and no part of the game overstays its welcome, I feel. Mechanics that utilize the two-character controls are introduced and dropped before they get stale. The general "plot" is pretty unremarkable, but like any fairy tale I wasn't really expecting it to be super special. The artstyle is pretty simple but the landscapes do look pretty great. There's little benches strewn about that do nothing but pan over the vistas, but you'll find youself wanting to sit in them for a bit anyways. The music is also pretty good, especially during chapters 3 and 4. but by the end of the game I found myself wishing there was a little more variety to it.Locales are kind of connected together in a way that doesn't seem terribly cohesive, but the variety in types of places that you visit, especially for such a short game, it pretty nice.  I also like that the achievements are just little extra/optional things that you'll find yourself doing in the world naturally without searching around corners and stuff for game-y collectables or something. Not too much of a time investment to experience and no frustration. I suggest everyone willing just gives it a playthrough to wind down after work one day or something.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												What does Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons have in common with Unreal Tournament, Killing Floor, America’s Army, and Brothers in Arms :Road to Hill 30? Good question being all of the latter are blood filled death fueled first person shooters. Answer :They all use Epic’s Unreal engine. And this threw me for a loop. Being used to playing violent shooters, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons grasped me like any game in recent memory rarely has and captivated me for all of its four and a half hour story. It was like coming from a crash diet of Bawlz or Mountain Dew Amp, and switching to herbal tea. The game concerns a simple story of two sons attempting to find a magic serum to heal their dying father. They meet with misadventure along the way, but never fail to stay the course. Told entirely through exposition (there is no discernable dialogue in the game whatsover) the player uses a gaming controller to control the actions of the two boys. One stick represents the taller and stronger brother who is able to assist his younger smaller brother into high places, and the other stick represents the smaller brother who is able to squeeze into tighter spaces to press levers, open gates, etc. to allow his older brother entry. A charming little tutorial starts the show and gently eases the player into the game mechanics. Don’t worry, it’s far easier than it sounds. I never had to access a walk through, and I only got stuck one time. I took a breath and reapproached the problem and then it came to me. I did die twenty-two times, but not once did I feel the game cheated. Death was usually a lesson learned. And strangely even though I died several times it was a relatively easy game to get through. The story is definitely the thing. Speaking of story, it unfurled before me and captivated me like watching Labyrinth, or The Adventures of Baron Munchausen, or the obscure, The Company of Wolves. These are wonderful fantasy movies I saw in theaters years ago and remember never wanting them to end. This game isn’t a deep game, which isn’t a surprise considering its short playtime. It does, however, exude a wonderful ambience which is augmented by a beautiful soundtrack. If you’re a fan of Stars of the Lid or Sigur Ros you’ll find the soundtrack as splended as I did. At the story’s end I found myself a victim of my own emotions. I find it great that a computer game can make me feel that way. I want to revisit this place especially since it left me painfully pining for more background, lore and history of the wonderful place that could only exist in literature or art. This game is truly a testament to the old maxim, less is more.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a third-person linear co-op game and inspired by games such as Ico and Shadow of the Colossus due to their similarities in gameplay and aesthetics. The premise of the game is following two brothers, Naie (eldest) and Naiee (youngest), through their journey across different lands searching for a magical tree which has the cure that can save their dying father. Being a very narratively driven game, revealing any details about the story would ruin much of the game’s charm since that is its main driving force.The game plays exactly like a co-op puzzle-platformer where you control the two brothers through their journey. Throughout the game, using a controller is strongly recommended as playing it on keyboard, whilst still doable, can result in some awkward coordination between the two controllable protagonists when they start bumping into each other or objects like two drunks. The actual gameplay itself is satisfying due to the nice blend of “puzzles” requiring both brothers’ participation throughout most of the game. The difficulty of these “puzzles” may eventually feel disappointing after a while as they do not provide any concrete challenge to the player(s) (hence the inverted commas), although that might have been deliberate for the integrity of the game’s pace. Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is, indeed, one of those games where the difficulty requires being at a minimum for the narrative to be at full throttle. Remember, no one wants to get constantly stuck solving complex puzzles in a narratively-driven game as it subsequently ruins the game’s pace.However, where it lacks in challenging puzzles or even perhaps rewarding gameplay, it compensates for its narrative which in actual fact is the heart of this game. The journey, albeit disappointedly short, transports you in a world where you believe you are in a place like Middle-Earth; travelling through various mesmerising landscapes on your quest for the cure while the suiting soundtrack plays in the background. All of its narrative is achieved rather through visuals and gestures as there is not any comprehendible dialogue in the entire game. That in itself is commendable as not many games can pull it off as successfully as Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons does. Frankly, each gesture or visual representation is easily and surprisingly understandable. Besides all that, the game also offers in its storytelling a handful of moments of happiness, laughter, seriousness and sadness without feeling schizophrenic with its mood shifts. The game‘s narrative can have some amazing set-pieces, but also a couple of clumsy ones.And that is as much as Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons can offer to players. On top of its colourful charm, or even some of its darker undertones, there are two main complains I personally had with this game in my first playthrough which ultimately felt detrimental to an extent towards my overall enjoyment. On a technical level, I encountered three game-breaking bugs which would not allow me to continue to the next area. Whilst two of them were solved by looking up online forums, the latter required restarting two prior chapters since simply restarting the current one was not sufficient to solve the problem. As of now, I still have no idea how those bugs triggered when it seems that the majority of people never even encountered them in the first place. Still, having to restart two complete chapters is bothersome. Then lastly, the ending. I will honestly be one of those in the minority who was not totally satisfied with the story’s conclusion nor did it have an impact on me. Even as I wish to critically evaluate it in this review, I cannot do that without simply spoiling it. But I will say this: I understood what they tried to achieve with the coming of age approach, but reflecting back through the entire journey, the writing at this point was sloppy and felt more of a cop out in the end to me. It also made me realise how Naie was not fleshed out as a character as much as his younger brother, Naiee, making a certain event not as effective as the developers would have hoped for, to me at least. Perhaps that is because the story might have been moving a bit too fast for things to fully develop.   Conclusively, Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is one those video games where you delve in exclusively for the storytelling experience. Nothing more, nothing less.  Without even sounding remotely pretentious, It is hardly the “masterpiece” everyone clams it to be, although it will definitely, and respectfully, leave a lasting impression for many people regardless, especially for youngsters. But not for everyone. Mechanically, it has a solid co-op experience with extremely easy puzzles to solve and backed up by artistically appealing sceneries, a fitting soundtrack and a simple, yet immersive, narrative despite a few clumsy set-pieces and a somewhat unsatisfying ending. At full price, however, I would definitely not recommend this due to its short length (2-3 hours at most) and limited replayability as there is not much reason to revisit it anytime soon now that you know how the story wraps up. Conversely, considering it always goes as low as £1 during virtually any Steam sales, there is absolutely no excuse not to try this, and that is why I am recommending it in the end. Despite some of its flaws, I truly had fun playing it and thought it managed to do what it was aiming for mostly pretty well, even if I will probably not reflect too much upon it in the near future.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												A remarkable experience, one that I really thought achieved that much sought-after balance between compelling gameplay and compelling story, and like many great stories it's all about the journey. You control two brothers on a quest to find a cure for their ailing father, each brother controlled simultaneously with the left and right analog sticks on your controller (if ever there was an ad for getting a 360 / PS4 controller for your PC, this is it). It doesn't take long for your brain to adjust to this, although I found I had to keep the brothers on the same side as their analog stick to keep up! This isn't just a gimmick either, it really works, even to the extent of serving the story. There were times that I felt this was the best Tomb Raider game I'd played since the first one, that sense of edging around precarious drops and leaping between hand-holds, and the game exploits the co-op nature of your two characters well. It's also really spectacularly beautiful in places, and I kept wishing my Steam screen save button was working, but alas no. The game clocks in at just over three hours, but it feels right, almost like experiencing a great movie. The less said in any review about the actual story, though, the better. Just play it.

												I bought it on sale for $3.39. Definitely worth it. I went through it slowly and I lost a lot of time when I had to restart a chapter due to a glitch. There is probably only really about 4 hours of gameplay. Still, I think I'd have felt satisfied if I had paid full price.The mechanic of playing two characters simultaneously is something new and fun. The puzzles are never too hard and you're not likely to require a walkthrough. It's really pretty. It manages to create a real sense of attachement to the characters as they go through so much to try to save their father.Be warned, however, that it is VERY linear. It is not a wide-open world for you to explore, it is a story for you to play through but there is really one way to play this game. If you can't enjoy that, even with great visuals and storytelling, buy another game.Spoiler Do not read this if you intend to play the game No, really, really don't. It's for people like me, who have finished the game:  When big brother dies and you have to use the controller to controll just little brother for the first time since the beginning of the the game, it's really emotionally affecting. Suddenly playing with just one character now seems as odd as playing with two did at the beginning. That emptiness of somebody who should be there and who isn't is the closest I have ever felt to having a loved one die that didn't actually involve having a loved one die (yes, speaking from experience). Not for everyone, I guess, but a game that does something I've never seen before and made me feel something I didn't think a game could.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
Worth your time, but don't expect a masterpieceI usually don't write reviews, but as I was playing this game, I felt so conflicted about the experience that I had to share my opinion. Perhaps I didn't enjoy the game as much as I could have, because, looking at the reviews, I expected the game to be outstanding, which I don't think it is.I'll skip the basic explanation of the game and jump straight to an overview of what I liked and disliked about Brothers.The review will be free of any explicit spoilers, but if you have not played the game and want to know as little as possible about its content, I suggest you stop reading right here.Pro Atmosphere - Although it could have been a little more diverse in places, the world designed for Brothers is vivid and feels very much alive. The graphical fidelty is pretty average, but the scenery constructed by the designers is downright beautiful at times. It is often highlighted through the use of specific camera angles (e. g. when sitting on benches). Characters - The characters in this game, especially the brothers, are very expressive, despite being somewhat stereotypical. Their character traits and emotions are well portrait through their animations and manner of speech. Storytelling - Brothers relies mostly on visual storytelling, but it also features good voice acting, which makes use of a fantasy language. This puts emphasise on the emotions of the charaters' rather than the content of their utterances. In the game's last chapter, it manages to cleverly use the control scheme and gameplay as a storytelling device, which is arguably its greatest achievement. Gameplay variations - You'll encounter different modes of travel throughout the game, which shake things up a little. When they actually affect the gameplay in a meaningful way, it creates some great moments (e. g. rowing, rope climbing). Checkpoint system - The game auto-saves at checkpoints which are reasonably placed and thus minimize frustation when you die, which happens rarely. The game also allows you to revist specific chapters, without having to play it all over again, which is good. Achievements - The achievements in this game are all actual rewards for doing optional things in the game world. They  are mostly well designed and encourage exploration. And there aren't too many, which allows you to 100% the game without too much effort. Many games get achievements wrong, Brothers really gets this right.Neutral Music - The music in this game is what you would expect. Sometimes it is a little too cliché, but it fits the scenery and story well. Nothing memorable here. Soundeffects - These fit the scenery just fine, but the sounds uttered by the brothers throughout are too repetitive and annoying, whichs degrades the overall impression of the soundeffect quality.Con Puzzles - Most of the obstacles presented to you in this game are puzzle type challenges. But they offer very limited options and are too simplistic. Not once did I stop to think more than a few seconds to solve any given puzzle. The game also utilizes only a handful of puzzle elements and reuses them a bit too often. I suspect they could have gotten more variety out of the mechanics at hand. Difficulty - The challenges presented to you apart from the puzzles are of a platforming nature, except they lack any challenge, as you aren't even allowed to fail in most instances. Altough it is quite clear, that requesting extreme precision as you are controlling two characters is not a good idea, these parts could also have been a bit more challenging. What is the point of slowly balancing over branches or treading along cliffs, when the user input is of no relevance? At no point does the game request any kind of mastery of its unique control scheme, which is a letdown. Length - As a consequence of my last two points and despite the general consesus, I think this game could have actually been shorter. Most of the time is spent walking or climbing and simply offers too little in terms of actual gameplay. Sure, a lot of it contributes to the exploration of the game's interesting world and is part of the visual storytelling, but if all the game wants to offer is a story, why make me walk through it at all? Movies do just fine at visual storytelling. (Minor) Bugs - Besides a few visual inconsistencies I once caused an object to get stuck, which forced me to restart from the last checkpoint.I'm sure I've overlooked an aspect or two, but this should serve as an overview of the game's strenghts and weaknesses and what to expect from it.I may have focused too much on actual gameplay, but I firmly believe that it should be the first concern when designing a truly interactive experience. The streamlined feel of the game and its low difficulty are probably intended to let the player experience the story unobstructed. I still wish it would have been a bit more challenging at times.Overall, Brothers is a precisely crafted and emotional experience well worth the few hours it takes to complete it. It's gameplay, although well polished, would benefit from some added variety and challenge.It is no masterpiece, but on a binary rating scale, it is definitively a 'thumbs up'.I wouldn't say it quite deserves its MetaScore of 90. I would rate it somewhere around 75/100.Still, it's a recommended buy on a discount for everyone that can appreciate a story-driven game.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												I'm not going to surprise anyone, I guess, by saying that I recommend you play this game. No matter who you are and what kinds of games you like, you really should give this one a try. It's a must-play.The game's biggest asset is the story and how the mechanics are interwined with the story. The game never offers too much of a challenge, but its innovative "each-stick-controls-one-character" approach is, at times, challenging enough to get used to. Once you get a hold of that, the puzzles are unlikely to stump you. This is a relaxing experience, which is there to be seen and played by yourself, while focusing on what's going on. Watching a playthrough of this short game is doing yourself an unimaginable disservice.Pretty much everything else also works incredibly well in this game. The art direction and design proves to me again that video games do not need anything more than the tried-and-true Unreal Engine 3 - they "just" need imagination, and vision. Sure, it's easier to say that we need more detailed graphics and lightning effects to convey emotions and atmosphere, because that doesn't demand any artistic input in the game's style... well, Brothers is proof that this standpoint is plain wrong, and if a game has a boring visual design, not even next-gen graphics are going to make it look better than Brothers does. The game is gorgeous, and each of the different locations you'll visit is uniquely attractive, while conveying the theme in a near perfect way.The soundtrack also helps a lot in building the game's atmosphere. It is one of the best I heard in recent years, and definitely unique in its own way. This is the first time I heard an OST so dipped in northern-european themes. The vocals do most of the heavy lifting to establish this feeling, but not a single track sounds like it doesn't fit into the overarching goal of the music. Not only a spot-on supplement to everything else in this game, it is an achievement on its own. You can buy the OST over at BandCamp and I highly recommend you do that.What more is there to say? This may not be the best game of all time, or even the most moving one, or the most influential one - but that doesn't change the fact that it is a must-have.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												"Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons" is a journey through fable-like world that focuses on inducing variety of emotions. The environment is very scenic, often having you traveling high up and admiring beautiful landscapes. It's inhabited with trolls, giants, griffins and other mythical creatures. Everywhere you go there's always something nice to look at. The camera's position often emphasizes the best fragments of a scene. It's not photo-real, but definitely eye pleasing and charming. You control both brothers at once - left hand for the older one, right hand for the younger. Many puzzles rely on syncing them well together. For me that was something new. Personally I had to keep them on the left&right sides of the screen in accordance with the control scheme. Whenever they switched positions due to my running around, my brain just went out of whack and chaos followed. I had to slow down and reposition them to be able to continue comfortably.The puzzles themselves are fairly easy. Some variants are recycled throughout the game. There is no greater planning involved and you solve many as you go. There is also no backtracking, so even if you're not sure how to tackle a specific problem, in most cases solution would present itself after simply going a little further. I feel that puzzles are just meant to be a way of reinforcing the bond between brothers and making player more attached through gameplay. Most of them require both protagonists working at the same time or in a longer alternating sequence.The reception of the story differs from person to person. Many people got their hopes up by other reviews/opinions and were disappointed. Others were ecstatic. For me the general experience is above average, that's for sure. Also the ending squeezed a tear out of me or two, so the narration trough gameplay mostly did it's job. But I didn't experience strong emotional response from the beginning to the end like some. Still I find the whole journey enjoyable and well worth my time.The game is pretty linear. No choices to be made, no events that can be prevented or played out differently. Apart from the main task that the boys are focused on, you can interact with many objects or NPCs and observe separate animations for each brother. Those do not affect anything, but make the world feel more alive and characters more fleshed out. All the inhabitants communicate in a made up gibberish sounding language, so the gestures and body language are especially important.The whole world might look like it's fable-like, but in reality it's quite harsh. Brutal and cruel at times even. Good things happen, then bad things happen. You save someone, someone will die as a direct result of helping you (or even a worse scenario). One has the impression that no good deed goes unpunished. Sometimes you won't be able to help - you'll just witness the effects of a tragedy that already took place. You meet both friendly NPCs, and mean or outright ill willed & hostile ones. Although there are very few moments in the whole game that actually pose any danger (story wise, not from manually letting go a ledge or other mechanics associated deaths).Completing the game takes about 3-4 hours, even when interacting with every possible object/person. So it's quite short. There is no need to replay it, other than experiencing the exact same story again if you really were swept away by it. If you have a chance to grab it on a sale - I wouldn't hesitate, fully recommended. At full price, I would say it's not for everyone. Definitely for people that can appreciate the emotional content and enjoy the journey aspect without making fuss about easy difficulty, length or minor issues - basically, recommended for informed customers :)Subjective Assessment - 7.5 (more than nice, not yet great)[utilizing full 1-10 scale, where 5 means average]

												All I heard abouth Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons were, "its a great game", "good storyline", "a must play game" etc. But what they didn't tell you is that the story will rip your feelings to shreds. It'll bring you to the point of tears more than once with the story. You're happy for a minute then you're absolutely depressed the next.Starbreeze Studios and Josef Fares made a masterpiece of a game here. With excellent graphics, soundtrack, storyline, unique gameplay mechanics and all that it just feels so perfect.The controls for the two brothers is at first a tad confusing (I used PS3 controller) but the gameplay makes you master it with time.There's puzzles, platforming, wonderful/sad story, immersive world, great soundtrack, good game mechanics colorful characters to fall in love with plus you get to ride a Mountain Goat (awesome stuff for real). So be prepared to set some time free to play the game in one sitting to soak in its immersive world.I give this game 9/10 (-1 for bringing a grown♥♥♥♥♥adult on the verge of crying)PS: If Jess Mcdonell says a game is good, then it is good =P And also don't forget to "color" the left out bunnie black!

												An enchantingly lovely storyline that draws you into each scene can only be outdone by illustrations like those in this 4-way winner. Graphics, soundtrack, gameplay, and story are intertwined to provide a strong and unforgettable experience for the adult player, Without spoiling any of the scenes, it is emotion-rich in moments... the everyday moments 2 sons experience, which are usually relived year after year in their own memories, and the memories of those who were witnesses (such as Mothers of sons, like me.) This tale has moments that will surprise and delight you, as well as moments that will make you cry. Beyond all that feel-good stuff is the gameplay. Puzzles and platforming will keep you immersed in this other-world/ other time motif of minecarts and stone walkways until you find yourself at the end of the game with only regrets that it's over. This is my 2nd experience with Brothers, as I already complted it on the PS3 COnsole. I had to have it again on STEAM for the art experience. I hope trading cards are in the works. :)

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												I had been meaning to play this game for a while but never got around to it. It wasn't until a friend of mine posted on my Steam profile telling me to give it a go did I seriously download it on my laptop and made a genuine effort to put some time into it. The first thing that you'll notice about this game is that there's no real spoken dialogue. I mean the characters do make sounds and seem to have some verbal exchanges but it's more like Simlish. If The Sims has taught us anything in the last 20ish years though is that you don't need to understand the language to understand a story. This is actually the biggest lesson I'm reminded of as I live somewhere where I don't understand what 90% of the people around me are saying on a daily basis, but I digress. Brothers features a beautiful rustic fantasy atmospheric adventure almost as if it was straight out of a fairy tale. You and your brother go on a journey across the land to find a tree that could save your dying father's life. Despite it being primarily about our two main characters and their journey you get to meet a lot of different inhabitants that help you along the way. Also you see the relationship and personalities between the younger and older brother in how they interact with each other and those they meet. You'll find both have skills that move the game along. As we all know the older brother excels in strength you find out early on that the little brother also has some advantages due to his size and pulls just as much as weight as his counterpart. Somewhere along the way though you'll find out that despite the cheery magical surroundings that the fairy tale aspect might be more ancient fairy tales where things don't always work out the way you expect it would and not the Disney type where people live happily ever after. That however, makes this game all the more compelling as at some point I was playing through tears. This isn't too much a spoiler but I think when a game can elicit emotional responses without saying a word that speaks volumes of the story and characters.I was sad when my adventure finally came to an end but I felt satisfied and a real sense of growth in the characters without any leveling up system or super powers. Overall you have great graphics, a touching story with endearing characters. It was a pleasure to play, even with the sometimes unfamiliar controller mechanics where you're using each side to move both brothers simultaneously. I wholeheartedly recommend this game as one everyone should experience.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												If there was ever a game to bring up in the "games as art" debate this would be it. Not because of its graphics or story (even tho both are great) but because of the way it uses interactivity to tell its story in a way that no other medium could have done.At its core Brothers is a puzzle game with a unique control scheme. You play as two brothers on a quest to find a cure for their sick dad and each brother is controlled using one of your analog sticks. This takes a little getting used to but once you get the hang of it you get to experience some really cool puzzles that are all based on the fact that you're controlling two characters at the same time.I can't write a review that comes even close to doing it justice so I'll just say that Brothers is one of my favorite games ever made. It's a complete masterpiece and a couple of moments in the game gave me shivers and almost brought me to tears. On the other hand I've seen playthroughs on youtube where the player doesn't have nearly the same reactions as I had to certain key points in the game, but yet they've all agreed that the game is amazing.Just go play the game for yourself. Worst case scenario you won't regret it and at its best it'll make you re-evaluate what can be done with videogames.

												Words cannot describe this game, but I can try to offer some words which can be a bit too shallow for this experience.The game is playable with Keyboard, but using a Controller is best; you should also look into rebinding the keys for a more comfortable layout. number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												A quest of the two eponymous characters to find a magical cure for their ill father, where you get to control both of them at the same time in a sort of puzzle-lite third persons' view co-operating-with-yourself adventure game.It's essentially a very visceral, very interactive fairy tale. The control scheme, the environmental puzzles with quite obvious solutions to push the story forward.. It is all about creating practically a physical bond between you and the brothers, via the controller, to feel their struggle quite personally.The tale takes you to strange places along the way. That also includes variety of emotional places, there are times to be happy, and to be sad, and perhaps to be scared, too. And it can get very intense at all of them. Yes, this is definitely about the journey not the destination. Even the achievements accentuate exploration and doing side activities not on the main storyline - this is exactly what you get rewarded for. You get exactly zero achievements for the main "quest" (which probably also serves to well, avoid spoilers).All this means you are doing everybody a great disservice if you're just watching some let's play or something. I think any single player game with a story is meant to be a GAME, therefore something for you to experience personally not via watching others do it (unless you've done it already and want to relive via someone elses eyes), but this is especially true in this title.It's best experienced in one go, to keep you in the emotional flow, it's at most 4 hours long if you like to smell flowers along the way (you can even literally do just that at places.. well not YOU-you but you know what I mean, the characters you play as) and you probably wouldn't want to leave a movie in the middle and come back later, would you?Also, it's obviously designed with a twin stick controller in mind, controlling each brother with one of the sticks and triggers. For example things like cranking a winch are just felt more personally if you're actually "cranking" your sticks. But - it does have keyboard bindings, WSAD for one brother and arrow keys for the other, so it actually is playable without a controller despite the warning on the Steam page, you're just somewhat missing out and I imagine keyboard control can be rather frustrating, I mean even the twin sticks almost cross that line often but luckily the game isn't hard so that's never an issue.Seriously if you're a PC gamer and do not have a controller yet, then you were asking Santa Klaus or your regional equivalent for wrong things. Because you are missing out in titles that were designed primarily with controllers in mind, and this game is perhaps the best example yet of just how much you're missing (otherwise the design with controller in mind usually just comes from a mild form of consolitis). But mind you, you don't need anything posh and expensive, you're probably somewhat worse by not having things like force feedback but otherwise there are pretty cheap controllers that do the job just as well, you may just need something like x360cemu if it's not an xinput controller.All in all, I highly recommend playing this game. I mean I'm personally not entirely sure why TotalBiscuit hails it as perhaps the best game of all time as far as he is concerned, it must have had much higher impact on him, but nonetheless it is truly a great gem, exemplifying of just how well controls can be integrated into a game, and how a game  can present you various emotional states not just cashing on one.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
In short, is the game good?Yes. Very good.Is it worth my time and money?Yes. While the game is relatively short (can be completed in 4 hours during a normal playthru), the game sells a sense of "woah" to the player in large doses. Definitely worth the money. Alternatively, buy it when it goes on sale (like I did).Is this game for anyone?Yes, anyone can pick this up and play with ease. While the character controls are quite unique, they're pretty straightforward to learn and use. The puzzles aren't really hard, but because of the way they are executed, they bring a feeling of satisfaction.Linear, open-world or something else?Game's very linear. Not many branching paths, aside from a few puzzle sections involving slight backtracking.Gameplay mechanics, gimmicks?You use both analog sticks to move both of the brothers at the same time (left one controls one, right one controls the other). Can be confusing at first, especially when they'll be on the opposite screen-space from which side their analog stick is.Graphical aesthetics, set pieces and world design?Very pretty to look at. The world is stylized to look like something between a fairy-tale fantasy land mixed with real medieval times. It all feels very well crafted and each section of the world smoothly transitions to the next.Audio design and soundtrack?Sound effects and ambiency is done well. A small settlement sounds like a small settlement, while a deserted castle sounds like a deserted castle. Music only plays in key points of the game, such as cutscenes, exposition, etc. but also sounds amazingly well done. A definite addition to the game's tone and atmosphere.Plot, story?Pretty basic, clearly inspired by fairy tales but with a few nice, yet predictable twists. Still, very enjoyable story that feels very well set into the created world. How does the game run?I played and completed the game on my 5 year old PC (Dual Core 2.66GHz, 2GB RAM, vNidia GeForce 9600GT 1GB) and it ran at a pretty stable 40-45fps on 1920x1080 resolution with V-Sync turned off. Expect better results if your PC is newer than mine.Any details, character, motif, etc. you particularly liked?Yes. The flying owl gryphon thing. Anything you didn't like?Yes. Options menu in the launcher is a joke. Definitely needs more graphical settings, especially since this is a Unreal Engine 3 game. Also, game does not support most cheap USB joypads (since the PC version apparently uses XInput signals instead of DirectInput signals). You either use keyboard, a 360 controller or download x360ce (the XBOX360 controller emulator) and configure your joypad through that. Extra hassle that could be easily avoided with a bit more work.Final score?I give Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons a flying owl gryphon thing out of 5.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Let me start off by saying, don't expect much from this game. I feel like it is a game that could be victim to overhype.I went in merely with the intention of clearing some dreaded Steam backlog and hadn't seen anything about the game in over a year, forgetting how nice the screenshots looked.Therefore, going in with no expectations whatsoever, I came away having played one of, if not my favourite, game of all time.This game gets better and better as it goes on, so don't expect to be blown away from the start. It is the grand sense that I really had been on an adventure that was left with me at the end, and being 3-4 hours long it feels like I had taken part in an interactive movie (having played it in one sitting). But it is definitely a game, and the gameplay was just the right amount of fun. A lot of clever design choices means the game continually flows, adding to that sense of adventure. The puzzles aren't particularly difficult, but never did I feel like I was having my intelligence insulted either.  There were times when I anticpated having to do something again, or something similar to what I had just done and had a feeling of tedium, only to be pleasantly surprised that the developers recognised that, and changed it up completely.  I wish more developers would recognise that a game doesn't have to be long and filled with fluff to make it good. Three hours of quality is plenty for someone with limited time to play games.The story isn't complex but it will leave an impression on most people. And how they go about conveying that story was also a clever touch. The game has no understandable dialogue, using only an invented language with no subtitles to get it's message across and I'm surprised at how well it does this when, in my opinion, the character models are the worst part of the game. They look out of place against the fantastic backdrops that make you stop and sit on a bench to look at the vistas, even when you were planning on rushing through a game to get it off your checklist. So at first, I wasn't struck. However, despite this, the sense of emotion you get from the characters is really rather deep and by the end you're completely invested. Most of the game is spent in third person and you won't be up close enough to see the poor character details anyway.The other thing most people will comment on are the controls. You control both brothers, from different sides of the keyboard and I can see why a lot of people will mark them down negatively. It is often difficult to get them both running in merely a straight line. I argue though that the controls are perfect for the type of game it is and add a layer of complexity to it that stops the game feeling too easy. Like I said, the puzzles aren't difficult at all, but the controls make you have to think about what you're doing, and I have to say, the times when you simultaneously have both brothers doing something complex, or even just running down a path and crossing over each other and turning at slightly different times, but doing so accurately, feels really good.There are a few negative points to the game, a couple of which rear their head almost straight away. As mentioned, the character details aren't great. Then, you come to the first puzzle.  You have to raise a platform, and it's immensely tedious, especially if you let go, and you have to start again. This platform raising happens once more in the game, and if  anything is even more tedious. Maybe I did it wrong. But it's over in a couple of minutes and overall doesn't affect the game. Lastly, texture glitches. In two cutscenes, some textures didn't load. It was only a rug and a chest of drawers, so not game breaking, but noticable. Also in one part, a shadow didn't load that was part of the mechanics of the situation, and I died. I didn't realise why until I started again and saw the shadow now loaded.Overall, I can't believe I had this game sitting in my library for so long being unappreciated. I also feel bad for spending so little on it. I can't quite remember what I paid, but it probably wasn't enough. Play this game, don't expect much and you're sure to have a good time.

												One of the finest examples of video games as art (not to be confused with art as video games). Those who played ICO may find Brothers somewhat familiar: two characters with emotional connection helping each other, solving puzzles together, speaking language the player doesn't understand, travelling through breathtakingly beautiful places. With that said, Brothers is definitely not a clone, with its unique "single-player co-op" control scheme, and the story that takes you through the world that is reminiscent of the one from "The Neverending Story". Wonderful graphics that pushes Unreal Engine to the max thanks to the fantastic work of designers, beautiful dynamic soundtrack, emotional story, interesting puzzles and unique controls. Don't miss this gem of a game.
