content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												An emotionally charged coming of age puzzle adventure.  If it doesn't bring tears of happiness / frustration / sorrow / joy to your eyes, I don't know what will!  It's not particularly challenging but buy it when it's on special for the play style, as a unique "single player co-op" (esp. if you have a controller with two sticks), or enjoy it as a simple interactive 2-player story on the same keyboard, as I did with my kids.  Just be aware, it does get quite dark and surreal / scary for kids, with drowning, family member loss and even suicide being very minor themes that might affect people sensitive to that sort of thing.  It is entirely linear, but many incidental obects and people can be interacted with by both brothers in different ways, and there are 12 side achievements you can work towards.  If for no other reason, the visual aesthetics and certain cut scenes are magnificent, making it a most enjoyable 4-6 hour journey.  I thoroughly recommend it!

Posted: November 26, 2015
												BROTHERS: A TALE OF TWO SONS IS AN EMOTIONAL JOURNEY.It’s an immersive, emotional gem that’s not to be missed.This game doesn't have a real dialogue, but it will still draw you out emotionally.Every gesture and interaction makes this game fantastic..Pros:+ Story is told in a fantastic manner.+ Beautiful visuals.+ Great puzzles that require both mind and fingers.+ Mindblowing Soundtrack+ Heart-melting momentsCons:- Contols can be frustrating sometimes...and takes time to get used to it..Anyways Brothers is the best twin stick game ever-played..Kudos...

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2015
												A couple of times you get to play a game that can make you feel completely worn down, emotionally speaking. This game did that for me. It doesn't happen that often, although there are some great titles out there that are as worth it as this one.Let me start by saying that the puzzles are not that difficult, which could be a turn-off for the hardcore gamers, but the game-play (controlling both brothers at the same time), narritive, surroundings and the story itself make up for it and then some.The way the characters just speak in what seems a 'made-up' or 'children's language', which you can understand instantly, is one of those points I really liked. I think it made the story stronger then with actual words in a spoken language.The story is about two brothers (surprise!) that have to work together to get a potion for their father who is sick and on the brink of death. To get this potion they have to travel through forests, mountains and ice-covered seas to get to the 'Tree of life'. On this journey they get help from surprising figures and have to help each other across rivers, canyons and other obstacles.And if any of the players say they did not tear up or even cried big tears at the end... well, they might have lied. I know I cried. Big time. Not with actual sobbing and runny nose, but still... A story about sacrifice, perseverence, hardship and an ending like that... Yeah, that just hit me hard.Nominated for the "I'm not crying, there is something in my eye" award!

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												O jogo é lindo (enredo, paisagens, personagens, cutscenes, tudo). É um jogo curto e simples. Você controla dois irmãos, ao mesmo tempo. Sugiro que jogue com uma manete, por favor! A movimentação não exige muita complexidade, somente as direções, dois botões para mover a câmera e dois para as ações - um botão para cada irmão -, que variam de acordo com a situação. Depois de um tempo você se acostuma muito bem e não buga mais a sua mente controlando os dois garotos.   Você vai em busca de um objetivo, e para alcançá-lo você passa por diversas aventuras. Você está no mundo de Esopo, das fábulas. Todas as histórias que você já leu ou ouviu quando criança (tá, nem todas) estão colocadas de modo fantasioso no jogo, e que baita País das Maravilhas, com certeza.   Você passa por situações diversas, desafios e lugares diversos; e isso te deixa bastante envolvido no jogo de modo que o faça zerar em poucas horas. É muito interessante o modo com que você pode interagir com os personagens, criaturas, animais e objetos do jogo, cada irmão interage de uma forma.Talvez o final possa ser surpreendente para alguns jogadores, para outros não.   P.S: É possível que você tire muitas screenshots.10/10  <3

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
tl;dr version - Go get it! And if you can, play with a controller over a keyboard. (CAN be played with a keyboard despite the way it's been advertised)A beautiful game that's focused mostly on the story and creative ways to play rather than a challenging gameplay. This game can be emotional, funny, mysterious and epic. The whole game can be completed in a single sitting, yes it's short. But that doesn't make the game any less impressive. The story itself revolves around 2 brothers and the way they've implemented the controller to interact with them is simply brilliant. Hence it's highly recommended to be played with a controller over a keyboard. The game has a deep message behind it, about life, morality and overcoming struggles. And the music, I fell in love with it instantly as soon as I heard it. It's absolutely perfect. It knows when it needs to be serious, epic and just downright silly. The art style the devs went for is great as well. Some scenes are completely breathtaking, combined with the beautiful music scores. Not a lot of games could pull off what this game manages to do. Needless to say, this game has become one of my favourite games of all time. When it comes to cons, I don't really have any with this game other than a couple of bug encounters that didn't really pull me out of the game.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												Rating: 9/10What is it?Action/Adventure game where you control two brothers with each joystick on the controller solving puzzles as you progress through the story/enivroments. The Good:+What really stands out for me is the gorgeous graphics,atmoshpere, and beautiful vistas. Its a game where you just want to stop and look at everything. +Varied environments throughout the game make the world feel more real and alive and provide a nice change of scenery +The game feels like a grand adventure in the span of only 3 hours. It does such a good job of the pacing and the puzzles that it feels like you just completed an epic quest. +Controller both brothers at the same time can be frustrating however it adds an extra element to the gameplay, and provides some interesting scenarios and puzzles. +Simple and yet effective story conveyed with no dialogue The Bad-The game is very easy, the puzzles are not to challenging at all. - All achievements are optional and very missable requiring a guide to get them. If you don't care about achievements than this shouldn't be a problem- Although not required, you really need to play this with a controller. ConclusionAn excellent adventure/puzzle game. The game is more about the journey and the adventure rather than the puzzles. Although short it really was a great experience.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												HOLY CRAP THIS GAME!!!! I loved the crap out of this game, and while it is short (it took me about 3 hours to beat the game), I think this is one of my favourite games ever. At least in my top four. 9.8/10 (really crazy good for me). The basic plot: two brothers have to go to a far away land to get a cure for a rare illness their father has. The story adds onto this and has several twists and turns but this is the basis of it. Whats interesting about this game is that there is no actual interpretable dialog. what i mean by that is they make sounds, but its gibberish, and you have to look for context clues and hear the emotion in their voices to understand whats going on. This game is basically a puzzle game with two buttons, analog stick for movement and action buttons to act upon the world (im pretty sure you can only play this game with a controller). the controls are smoothe and the difficulty is good, i failed a few times but no part was frusterating. The graphics are amazing  and the art and world they create will stick with me for months (seriously breathtaking).. If you love art, BUY THIS GAME. if you have emotions, BUY THIS GAME!!!!! basically the only reason i wouldn't say to buy this game is if you just are not that sympathetic. because this game relies on the fact that you WANT the dad to be cured and want these kids to succeed, if you dont give a rats♥♥♥♥♥about the dad or the kids you wont be motivated to play the game and probably wont have that much fun.Like i said before, probably one of my favourite games ever, I would recommend this game to basically anyone. It was short but incredibly sweet, I loved the crap out of this game :)

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												A simple, yet brilliant approach at expressing the bond between two brothers through gameplay mechanics.With a beautifully rendered world and an universal fantasy-appeal, this game will quickly capture the player in its world and soon he will find himself immersed into captivating landscapes. Despite all that beauty, the world of Two Brothers is not easy to traverse and only through teamwork can the brothers succeed. Control the two brothers via a single controller and feel how close these two sons are to each other. Feel their togetherness, wonderfully expressed via gameplay and level design.Highly recommended.I also recommend playing this great, albeit short game in a single session, to really connect to the journey that the two sons, as well as you, have brought behind themselves.

												This is an incredible game! I am happy to see a perfect port from the XBOX 360 version.The style of this game is very unique. Controlling both brothers at the same time might take you some time to get used to, but it is this style of game play that makes you understand how close the brothers are.The story is very heartwarming and presented through a world of fantasy, with breathtaking visuals and an amazing soundtrack. Though the characters in the game speak an unknown language, it is easy to understand what the story is about and what they are communicating with each other about through their physical gestures.The addition of Steam achievements is also a nice bonus.Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
Product received for free
Brothers- A Tale of Two Sons Review  Introduction Brothers A Tale of Two Sons is an atmospheric, adventure, platformer indie game with heart, emotional content, and great sound. We set out on a journey towards uncovering a cure for a man who fell ill. Unfortunately, during this time period that the game takes place in, medieval it looks like most, doctors were not present and medicine was meager; the technology advancements we have in present-day was never present. What is his specific indisposition? We are not clued in towards the specific illness; possibly one could assume hay fever since his deportment facsimiles it as such. Two brothers bond to solve puzzles together, move obstacles, objects in securing the long journey that is brought forth ahead through fantastical enemies, real-life ones, and a secular cult ready to kill us.         A rare cabochon in the indie market and scene comes Brothers A Tale of Two sons predominantly marketed toward drama, tear-jerker, and adventure audiences. It takes the core rudiments from excellent drama movies incorporated in the exemplums of today that relate to real-life quagmires. The main plot centers around a castle and a populace that two brothers burgeoned in all speaking one language. We bring the old man to someone who can help him.      However, he assigns us our extended peregrinate towards finding the only cure. The cure is healing water present in an oasis that is supposed to revive any of all afflictions when drunken. That is after the water has been collected from a flask. We must work together, taking turns with our brother as well as working simultaneously. The little brother has an advantage, such as the ability to slide through small spaces, while his brother is good at swimming, pushing obstacles, and hitting switches.  Presentation     The presentation is opaque; no one word nor sentence can describe the immersive landscape. The graphics are beautiful; rivers with waterfalls flowing into them, bridges, ledges, logs; log branches to walk beyond, and a castle. The snowy environment is found later in the game, while in the beginning, it must be summer because the sun is bright, no waterfall nor rain exist. This is part of the reason we are led to gather this healing water from the oasis because, in our town, it looks like there has been a massive water drought. The environment is heavily inspired by adventure based films tied in with drama. These days, I never watch movies. As a result, I cannot compare it to any specific motion picture. Gameplay/ Mechanics     This game requires a controller all the way through because keyboard controls will, simply not be effective. It is a puzzle based adventure game with platform elements. The platforms, later on, borrows characteristics from Prince of Persia The Forgotten Sands such as wall running, rock climbing, strafing across ledges, and in scaling walls. All puzzles are easy to figure out, mostly levers, pushing objects, turning objects.  Verdict- 7/10- good  Brothers A Tale of Two Sons is a lighthearted journey through joy and happiness at the start, but it gets very emotional, taking a dark turn later on at the point of the climax. The story is told from the first-person perspective. It is worth the money because it is a beautiful, emotional, turbulent indie game with heavily inspired elements that blend in and fit well. I wish I could have gone into more detail with this game. However, it is too short to accurately talk about it more thoroughly without spoiling the whole game for you. Now, if you like these aspects I have highlighted from my own experience, then try it out for yourself. You will not be disappointed if you have a true heart and love for people. Get the tissues ready because some will find the climax and beyond harder to bear, especially when we get to the final ending of the game as well as the ever-present present event that sets it off.Overall ScoresPresentation - 10/10     Graphics are well done, compared to any adventure, drama movies that have come out within the past half decade. There are two seasons in the game, summer, and winter. The characteristics of this are glaciers, ice peaks, waterfalls, torrential rains, a couple of underground tunnels, and grassland. Subtitles were supposed to be present, at least, to my knowledge. However, I never found an option in the menu to display it which would have been nice to include English subtitles as well as other languages so people can understand the dialogue. I am uncertain of the specific language spoken throughout the whole game. Nonetheless, the non-verbal cues we are given incorporated through the dialogue makes every cutscene and conversation in the game understandable. They focused more on emotion in the non-verbal cues to be understood better than the whole story rather fully told verbatim.Gameplay - 10/10     Gameplay fits well using the fundamentals of the platforming across high ledges but adds one new feature; the ability to control both brothers at the same time, working together while strafing buildings. One example of this is near the end of the game when you use the rope to tie yourself together with your brother which functions as a harness. You have to coordinate your movements together with your brother. When you are rock climbing, jumping upwards, you swing one of the brothers through the rope with the proper layout of controls meant only for a controller in mind. You swing until you hit the next small rock, actually more like a little circle of something similar to a pillar, but too insignificant to be considered one.Game Length/Story - 9/10     It follows the length of a conventional drama, however, extends it by double the time spent in this game rather than watching a movie in the same blend of genres. This is appropriate for an adventure game, the emotions of happiness, joy, sorrow, grief, fear, and dread. The story of Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is around three hours through the main story. The story flows in chronological order, including the ability to interact with the dead ( i.e. ghosts of those in the community who have died) while you are sleeping, hearing them call your voice, trying to guide and comfort you within the spiritual realm. It is touching, emotional and a loving repositum to the heart's core. Controls - 7/10     Controls are responsive most times but can become a little awkward in the more difficult sections. Interactions which are sometimes comedic in nature, doing behaviors that are auto scripted, are controlled by the left and right triggers on the controller. In contrast, the movement of both brothers is controlled separately; right movement stick for the young sibling, the left for the older brother.Disclaimer A review copy of Brothers- A Tale of Two Sons was provided by Gamephasis. Gamephasis www.gamephasis.com is a new gaming website featuring a talented team of game writers from around the world. Gamephasis features news, reviews, giveaways and much much more. Please visit us and join our Steam group. We're always looking for more talented gamers and writers to join our team.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												2013 will be remembered as a great year for indie games, and Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons deserves a special spot among ther best games of the year. Graphics are simply awesome, neat and very VERY evocative. Controls are challenging (you will move both characters at the same time using the two gamepad's analog sticks) but once mastered are really fun and rewarding. The puzzles aren't very hard, you'll probably never get stuck for more than a couple of minutes, but the game never gets boring. Story and character design are just wonderful... and considering no one ever speaks (at least not in a real language) I guess we're really really near to perfection in this department. You'll end up caring A LOT about the two brothers and their journey, and if you're a little sensitive you'll probably end up in tears. We need more games likes this.

												This is one of the few games that made me tear up at the end and I'm not that kind of person that needs tissues when I watch dramatic movies.  The plot is about two sons who went on a journey to help their dying father by bringing him medicine from this far and beautiful place, but the road leading to it is full of danger and mystery along the way. The characters in this game don't even speak a comprehensible language which I found strange but they make up for it in terms of hand gestures and interactions between each other. The graphics are charming and breath-taking, the game is filled with puzzles that make you feel smart when you solve them and the stroy is amazing. If you see this game on sale, don't even think about it twice. It's a masterpice, buy it.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												Rating: 10/10 must buy - worth full price and then some ( WORK OF ART status)Summary: Emotionally charged and beautifully designed adventure puzzle game. Can be played without controller but dont do it, use a 2 stick controller. Hits right in the feelings in the best possible way. No one will be left unmoved by the game.Long review (SPOILER FREE):Game is set in a fantasy world in which you play as two brothers on a epic quest to acquire a certain item. It is a very mature tale about growing up, brotherly bonds, effects of  trauma on a young person, overcoming those traumas and acceptance of death as part of life.  Art direction is really good and make the world seem very alive which in turn makes you get really immersed in the game. Game is not long around 2,5h (4h if you stop to take in scenery) but in that short time it will take you on a emotional roller coaster ranging from heartwarming to heartbreaking. You will not feel like you were cheated by how short it is in the end, it will feel perfectly timed. I can honestly say this is one of the few games that ever induced such deep emotions and cathartic feeling at the end. I am talking about The Walking Dead Clementine affection or MGS Sniper Wolf death scene level of emotions. This game will stick with me for the rest of my life. Please play this game in ONE sitting. Characters in this game speak in a made up language and there are no subtitles yet design is so masterful you will never not understand what is happening or get lost or not understand a puzzle. In fact i was impressed that i developed such strong feelings for the brothers despite it. Puzzles range from easy to medium. Sometimes they are a bit "hard" just because you are most likely not used to controlling 2 characters at once using both analog sticks and R2 L2 triggers. Personally i did not find them clunky it worked really well for such a design.Most impressive thing that really hit me in the feels was how the game  managed to incorporate emotions into actuall controls. That blew my mind and if you play until the end you will know what i mean by that.Only criticism i can possibly give would be that you should have a controller. Everything else is perfect at least for me. I will follow future similar releases from this studio. This game is a work of interactive art that can not be done in any other medium except video gaming. GO BUY IT !!!

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												I love absolutely everything about Brothers.1. It's a rejection of every condescending trend in game design from the past 5 years. No hand-holding, no collectables, no constant pats on the back. This is a game that treats its players like adults. Your *special reward* for playing Brothers is the WONDROUS JOY of playing Brothers.2. The developers knew their constraints and made smart decisions with the resources they had. No budget for voice actors? That's fine, the characters will speak their own language. XBLA games have limited graphics? Screw it, we'll pick an art style that looks good at any poly count.3. Did I say "looks good"? Sorry, I meant GORGEOUS. Brothers is flat out beautiful. You'll find yourself constantly stopping to take in jaw-dropping vistas. The game knows it too. The designers sprinkled benches throughout whose only purpose are to let your characters relax and admire the view.4. No English, no problem. You don't need to understand the characters' words to get what they're saying. Everything you need to know comes across in tone, body language, and action. Brothers is the ultimate rejection of the David Cage school of videogame emotion. You don't need to see the individual atoms of NaCl and H2O in a character's tears to inspire empathy.5. I adored the coming-of-age theme. It's done in a way that's entirely unique to the medium, and yet I've never seen another game pull it off the way Brothers does. The game begins in innocence. You're running across verdant hills and through lush fields, playing pranks on local farmers, dodging mean dogs.But the darkness slowly creeps in. First, it's only in the background, and easily ignored by our storybook children on their magical adventure. Soon, though, you'll be neck-deep in the muck, and the green grass will be nothing but a distant memory.For such a short game (3-4 hours), it's incredible to compare where you begin and where you end up. It's the journey in between, the way that the protagonists react in the face of an increasingly adult world, and how they ultimately  learn to live in it—that's what makes Brothers so special.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												It's one of the most gorgeous games I've ever played. The gameplay is definitely the highlight of the game, two hands are like brothers, and this idea is deeply bonded in the story, in the beginning you may think this is interesting, in the end, it's more than just interesting. And the STORY~it's beautiful, sad, dark, and brave. Some stories may be told on purpose, like in this scene we should make it look sad or something, "Brothers" is different, it's plain and pure, honest and sincere, also a bit cold, it's just the way it is. The puzzles are also pretty amazing, not too hard and still interesting and enjoyable, the NPCs are doing a great job.The world inside the game is absolutely beautiful ! Nature was being rendered sooooo well, presenting us tons of delicate details, despite the mission, I really enjoyed lingering around in there.But, it's also the shortest game I've ever played. Took me 2.7 hrs to finished the main story , but I really can't ask for more playing hours, cause it feels like it's almost perfect, everything begins and ends at the right time.The achievements are really worth your time though, totally easy to accomplish, and helps you to check out the interesting details you miss.That's it~just play it.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												this is a beautiful short game that's pieced together admirably, and it's one that i've become enamored with ♥it's certain that the story itself is the pillar of this game's foundation while puzzle-solving stands as an inferior element.  i personally didn't find that to be an issue since i'm not opposed to a non-challenging game as long as it still has its merits, which in this case, it does.  although the playthrough (generally between two to six hours) is quite momentary, the wonderful quality makes it worthwhile.  i was pleased by the unique, simple-to-grasp gameplay and non-complex obstacles that merged flawlessly with the story's fluidity.  each transition was a passage full of adventure-- i found delight in being met with lovely little surprises like riding mountain goats and sailing on a sky glider.  i'd also pace my course throughout the scenic journey so i could appreciate the landscape encompassed by an enchanting ambience.  as for the brothers, they were personable characters with a charm suitable for the heartfelt story.  my fondness towards them progressed alongside the heroic tale, and with that, so did my devotion to their valorous pursuit.  inevitably, this endearing story steadily tugged at my heartstrings until i fell in love with the entirety of it.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												9/10 - This is one of the greatest games with genius story telling.It has beautiful design and unique gameplay mechanics - controlling two characters at the same time in order to solve puzzles and progress further. Storyline is just brilliant. Even the game is short, you get to experience so much in this adventure on every step, and it gets more and more emotional toward the end. Not many games in history achieved such level of involvement.The only bad thing is that its gameplay extremely easy to the degree it is often boring or just inexistent. It is ridiculously linear, you have just one narrow route (or a couple parallel ones) and you can't leave it or fall of a cliff, even characters jump over a pit on your way automatically when you approach it. Despite quite innovative control mechanics and occasional interesting puzzles, you still don't get anything challenging to solve with reasonable amount of effort, everything is pretty much obvious right away. All that almost excludes failure state of the game in practice, even my first death was way past the middle of playthrough.To sum it up - it is a great experience you should not miss if you like games like that, or just want to experience what the game offers. Just don't expect much out of an actual gameplay and ignore linearity - you will be able to appreciate the game to the fullest.

												Absolutely breathtaking game, It's an emotional puzzle game where you take controll of 2 brothers going on an adventure in hope of finding a cure for their dieing father.The one of many intresting things about this game is that you actually play through the whole story without useing a singel word of english, as far as i can tell the actuall speech within the game is utter gibberish. content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												this is a beautiful short game that's pieced together admirably, and it's one that i've become enamored with ♥it's certain that the story itself is the pillar of this game's foundation while puzzle-solving stands as an inferior element.  i personally didn't find that to be an issue since i'm not opposed to a non-challenging game as long as it still has its merits, which in this case, it does.  although the playthrough (generally between two to six hours) is quite momentary, the wonderful quality makes it worthwhile.  i was pleased by the unique, simple-to-grasp gameplay and non-complex obstacles that merged flawlessly with the story's fluidity.  each transition was a passage full of adventure-- i found delight in being met with lovely little surprises like riding mountain goats and sailing on a sky glider.  i'd also pace my course throughout the scenic journey so i could appreciate the landscape encompassed by an enchanting ambience.  as for the brothers, they were personable characters with a charm suitable for the heartfelt story.  my fondness towards them progressed alongside the heroic tale, and with that, so did my devotion to their valorous pursuit.  inevitably, this endearing story steadily tugged at my heartstrings until i fell in love with the entirety of it.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												A charming tale which is told by sight and sound rather than traditional scripting.The two titular sons are brothers who must journey to assist their sick father. A journey that will call upon both of them to work together to overcome the sometimes hostile environment to reach their goal.The mechanics and premise of the game are beautifully simple and excellently excecuted.The left thumbstick of your gamepad controls the movement of the older brother with the left trigger handling any of many interactions with the environment and/or the younger brother. The younger of the two is likewise controlled (you guessed it) by the right thumbstick and trigger.It takes a little bit of getting used to but clicks into place quickly enough and feels really rewarding once you get to grips with it.The puzzles never seem to get too difficult but require enough thought to not seem contrived and they never infuriate.Anyone who has ever played Kuri Kuri mix on the PS2 will enjoy this immediately, as well as feeling right at home. The main difference here being the excellent way the developers have made two main characters that you can instantly empathise with.Ultimately I would recommend this at full price. At the holiday price it is quite simply a steal. Don't miss this one.Additionally I would like to add that I am playing this game using my motherboards onboard graphics. And it runs fine. It should run really well on older systems.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2013
												I'll try to not spoil anything, but I apologise if I end up spoiling something for you, you have been warned... Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is not merely a game, it's a masterpiece of modern gaming and storytelling with the use of a made up language. Considering it's a fairly short title (about 3 hours long), which might put some people off it is surprisingly worth it's value. Brothers presents you astonishing visuals along with one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard in a game. Brothers doesn't really tell you a story like most games out there, it shows you the story by using a made up language, as I mentioned above, you are not presented with a certain and linear story but the way each brother interacts and uses body language to express himself gives you a good feeling of what's going on. Another thing I love about this game is how the developers decided to show you that these two brothers are inseparable, you control each one with a different stick on the controller but yet each puzzle or obstacle cannot be exceeded by using a single brother, one brother needs the other in order to survive... Besides this, everything else I have to say is abunch of spoilers and things that would ruin the way you would experience this game for the first time. I have nothing else to say other than, please buy the game, if not by paying full price atleast try to get it once it's on sale (like I did), we need more games like this, I need more games like this. Definitely one of my favourite games of all time, taking the top 1 place on best storytelling for me and bringing The Walking Dead to top 2. Be amazed by Brothers!

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												This game was simply amazing! Although there are still some things that could be better and need work, the things they did right really stand out and exemplify the game in a great way. First lets talk about the bad things.This game has its bugs and glitches that actually break the game. I was unfortunate enough to encounter one of these that would not allow a cutscene to play causing me to be stuck with no way to progress. 505 support gave me a few solutions that did nothing to help until a friend of mine found a video displaying the same problem I had. (http://youtu.be/c-DJGQ3t3YE if u wanna see it) I was unable to play for weeks emailing 505 asking for help. That was the only game breaking bug i encountered, but there were many graphical glitches and frame lag spikes at the most random of places.One thing I truly enjoyed about his game is that it does not hold your hand. New little mechanics are added into the puzzles and will require you to think a little which is refreshing from 99% of games where everything is handed to you instantly. Another they did correctly was the controls. They were extremely innovative and well made, easy to use and although i would get my thumbs tangled, it felt smooth and overall nice. The story is a cliche, but thru the gameplay and interactions, it really was quite good. The game never truly dragged out when compared to most games and the visuals were nice. They could have done much more with the art, but how it is now is still well done. Overall, this is a solid game with great controls, a moving story, fun puzzles and nice visuals. It does have its bugs and glitches but with some research you should be able to find a fix and continue on your journey. Highly recommend to everyone.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												I can see why this has been on so many GOTY lists. The journey you take with the brothers is extraordinary. Closest thing I can liken it to is Ico, Shadow of the Colossus and Dark Souls, except if those had been made by Astrid Lindgren.A couple scenes had janky animation, and at one time I felt frustration at not knowing what to do, but those issues don't matter on the whole. The world design and story more than make up for it. Critics like Adam Sessler & TotalBiscuit had hyped up the ending quite a bit, and probably as a result I didn't find it outstanding in any way. It ended like it should, but it wasn't the high point for me. The best scenes in the game were the ones which were completely optional. For example at one point you meet a man who has lost his family in a fire and is about to kill himself. Whether you help him or not is optional, and if you do there's a thing you can do for him which helps him deal with his loss. This entire area is off to the side and can easily be ignored if you choose to. But this, and many other areas like it provided the strongest moments in the game for me.I'm glad I played it. I had seen clips from it and heard the hype from those who played it, but it didn't really prepare me from what the game is like. Don't miss it.

Posted: January 18
												Bravo, just bravo. This is the first time I ever write a comment on steam. I just have to say, very well designed game. And to all that´s considering buying it, just do it, it´s a small game with a big impact. And do use a controller to play this game, you can play it with keyboard but it won´t have the same meaning as a controller.  In the beginning, the controling seperately the two brothers with 2 thumbstick on controller was a bit frustrating, but if you have played it, you´d understand what a monumentally impressing design that is for expressing the emotion of the game. Through the whole game, you are telling yourself, left stick is big brother, right stick is little brother, to the point that the controller has intergrated into the storytelling. And in the end when the big brother was incapacitated, you suddenly felt that emptiness on your left hand, and the urge to rush up to the tree and save him. Then you found out he´s already gone, the reassurence of the temporary disabled left hand in your heart became permanent, you geniuenly felt that lost in a way of your own control. However that wasn´t the end of it, the final part when the little brother refuse to step into the water and you can´t seem to find a way to make him do so made me emotionally angry. "Your brother died for this, you gotta get over yourself little dude" I was yelling inside. But no, he just refuse to go on into the water. After several minutes of trying, I was confused, angry, then suddenly I touched the left stick, the one representing the passed away big brother, and the little one moved, struggled through the water with his brother´s strength. I was all tearing up, controlling the little brother using the big brother´s power, pulling lever that was impossible for the little one before or climbing up the cliff too high for him before.... This game definitely deserve a medal.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons was developed by the company Starbreeze Studios, who were responsible for games like The Chronicles of Riddick games, The Darkness and Payday 2 and directed by famous Swedish film director Josef Fares.The two Brothers, Naiee (the younger brother) and Naia (the older brother) become united as one not only by the plot but with the help of the game’s mechanics and narration. Thrust out their village and into a gorgeous and almost realistic storybook, the Brother’s only weapons are their minds and their only resource is each other. The brothers then embark on their epic journey through the beautiful landscape of villages, hills, mountains, caves and even the valley of dead giants and trolls that went to war with each other on a very bloody battlefield. At the same time the Brothers also faced challenges like the local bully, a farmer's aggressive dog, and deadly wolves.  Along with these challenges the Brothers also undertake a journey of self-discovery as they learn to work together to overcome each challenge. They even learn and work out how to help out the various characters they meet during their adventure - like reuniting a friendly pair of trolls, saving a man attempting suicide, aiding an inventor, freeing a badly injured griffin that help them before succumbing to its injures and even a girl from being scarified by a blood cult.The dialogue throughout the game is in an artificial language and there are no signs to really provide any type of information to the player in regards to where you must go. You just follow the path, trusting that the brothers are heading the right way. And this parallels the relationship between the brothers: although you can’t understand what they say to one another, you know they love and look out for one another. The game’s visuals are gorgeous to look at and the game rarely lets a few minutes pass without offering some sort of staggeringly gorgeous landscape to ogle. There are even benches scattered throughout the game for the Brothers to sit on. The player is given permission to stop and enjoy the vistas; which are not only beautiful but ram home how vast a world Naia and Naiee have to traverse and, by extension, how vital their relationship is to their own survival. The game makes it so clear that the characters themselves are impressed by what they see. The soundtrack was equally as gorgeous. The Swedish vocals added that extra charm when it came to cut scenes and often provided the atmosphere and told the player what they should feel at that precise moment.The player controls both brothers simultaneously, each mapped to an analogue stick, as that makes button mashing impossible when it comes to puzzle solving. Every action from "grab the ledge above" to "play the harp" is performed with the triggers. When I first played this game I did find it quite hard to control both the brothers the same time. Usually one would end up running into a wall. Ultimately the control scheme acts as a defining piece of storytelling. The control scheme is actually very simple, though. You control both brothers independently; the older brother’s actions are enacted with the left analogue stick and the younger brother with the right analogue stick. Each brother also has one interactive button that is context sensitive to the area or person it is being used on. There is a very brief introduction to the controls, which becomes a very strong narrative choice because it allows the player to naturally grow with the brothers on their journey and experiment a little more, revealing layers of their characters. Coming back to the point I mentioned about the Brother’s communication is almost psychic, we eventually learn that due to the control scheme of this game that the brothers are sharing a brain; which is in fact the player’s brain. But a curious thing happens as you help the siblings solve puzzles and work in concert to skirt danger. You learn. You get better at controlling these two disparate entities and, in turn, they appear to work together more seamlessly. (WARNING: SPOILERS ALERT) So after the brothers save the girl from the blood cult’s ritual they decide to ally with her. They reach a point in their journey where the girl urges the Brothers to enter a cave which they presume is the direction that they must head in order to reach the Tree of Life.Before Naia enters the claustrophobic tunnel, Naiee become hesitant, pulling Naia’s hand and tries to convince him that this is not a good idea, foreboding that something bad is about to happen. Naia insists that nothing is going to happen and since Naiee is too weak to go on by himself he follows both Naia and the girl into the tunnel. As the brothers shuffle forward, you start to notice what appear to be victims mummified in web. Something doesn’t seem right.In an instant, the girl exposes her true, evil arachnid form and imprisons the brothers in a web and slowly pulls them upwards to feast on.  As Naiee awakes, the brothers devise a plan to escape. To defeat this she-spider Naiee must ram into her while Naia tears off each of her limbs. The fight is pretty easy and feels quite satisfying. As Naia rips off the last leg he is pierced by the spider’s venomous pincher and loses colour of his skin simultaneously. Now Naiee must carry Naia for the remaining way to the Tree of Life, where Naiee must now collect the Water of Life to save not only their father, but Naia’s life too.As you’re controlling Naiee throughout the Tree of Life using only the right side of your controller, you start to feel alone and awkward. Normally the right analogue stick is used to look around in a game; not to move about. It’s weird, unnatural and disjointed. The control scheme is now missing something and you as the player are not use to using the right side of the controller to move around. What you are feeling is exactly how Naiee is feeling in the story but for different metaphorical reasons. The use of only the right side of the controller is symbolic for the emptiness inside of Naiee. And to top it all off, even after Naiee retrieves the Water of Life you find out it’s too late to save Naia and ends up dying in Naiee arms in the most heart wrecking scene I have ever witness. And it doesn’t end there!The emotional knife digs in as you control Naiee, again only with the right side of your controller, to bury Naia, a character that even you as the player, have become emotional attached to. And despite never understanding the dialogue in this game you cannot help but empathise with Naiee.  And even after that, Naiee rushes home to deliver the Water of Life to his father. However Naiee must cross the shoreline before doing so. He is faced with his greatest fear! The flashback to his mother’s death at the beginning of the game explains this phobia, and without Naia there to carry him across like he has been throughout the entire game. Using the right trigger only makes Naiee steps back from the water. But as you realise that the ghost of Naia is with Naiee you also realise that he is also in your controller; and by pressing the left trigger Naiee gathers the strength and determination to swim across the shore, climb up the mountain, use the machinery to reach his father. Even though Naia was not physically there to help Naiee or for you to control with the left analogue stick, it didn’t matter at all. He was still there to use in the left trigger button; which then become symbolic for the brother’s true strength. As for what happens after Naiee reaches his father, I’m not going to say. All I will say is it’s better to experience the ending on your own.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												This is my first proper recommendation of a game on Steam. Because no other game that I have ever played has provoked my emotions in a way Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons has.The story of two brothers against the world, fighting to save their father. A simple story, but the way it is told has to be one of the most breath-taking experiences a video game can muster. I can't say much with regards to the story except that if story-driven games are your thing, you have to play.Every little aspect of this game, from the game controls to the language spoken by the brothers helps you connect with them, their troubles, their fears, their emotions. No game has so far captivated me this quickly and this deeply, although I am probably feeling this way because I just finished it. And that's just fine. This game is a masterpiece that everyone should experience. Some brief review notes: Do not judge the game solely based on the first few minutes of gameplay, as the puzzles and co-operative mechanics develop at an amazing pace. The ideas in the game are innovative, not repetitively used and are a lot of fun to experience.Controls-wise, this game definitely has to be played with a controller with two joysticks to get the most out of the game. The keyboard controls are manageable but a controller is best. However, there are times where you are required to hold down the buttons for minutes on end which is quite stressful on the fingers. The graphics and art are nothing special, although some of the scenes do inspire some awe in you. The game isn't about the art however and the deciding factor in whether you want to play a game should almost never be graphical quality.Brothers makes use of the controller in a way no other game I've played has ever done. That could be my inexperience talking, but the innovative way you control the two brothers using a joystick and shoulder pad each pulls you into the game and doesn't let go. It takes some getting used to of course, but a helpful tip is to try and keep the younger brother on the right as much as possible as it helps coordinate better early on.The speech in the game is no known language. And this is one of the best features of this game. The story does not rely on voice acting or script, but the true weight and emotion of the story itself as well as the body language and gestures of the characters. Very few games have managed to pull this off to the degree that Brothers has and I fear no other would be able to live up to this quality of story for a long time.Puzzle platformer games are nothing new. Many games have a tried and tested formula to them. Brothers on the other hand is a game that no other game would make you go: "Oh, this is just like that other game." No. That will never happen. Because the mechanics of the game, they way you solve every problem, the satisfaction of achieving the goal while controlling both brothers at the same time is a unique experience in itself.TL;DR If you love video games for what they truly are, you owe it to yourself to play this game. No game will ever be like this game. Ever. Bros before hoes.Nominated this for an award. Worth it.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												While from the perspective of level design and gameplay mechanics this title leaves a bit to be desired (indeed, many of the obstacles are overcome with much the same solution), the stunning beauty and artistry presented more than compensate, rendering this more an interactive story than a game in the normal sense.  There are no side-quests, nor is there any real purpose in honing one's skills, at least not beyond learning how to control the two characters simultaneously.  However, if you enjoy contemplative nature hikes, appreciate minutiae, and are even remotely of an empathic disposition, this one is definitely worth your time.  There are moments that will stay with you well past the meager 3-hour duration.From a technical standpoint, the game ran with barely a hiccup on my 8-year-old laptop, so just about anything with at least an integrated graphics chipset should have no trouble.  While a controller is not strictly necessary, it is important to note that the keyboard configuration cannot be changed (wasd+space and arrow keys+right control); since you will be controlling both characters at once, this requires a keyboard that supports many concurrent key presses.  Though it is playable, the recommendation of having a controller is a good one.

												Summary: Brothers is an engaging, fun, frustrating and immersive afternoon's fun - requiring a pad.It's a tough thing to talk much about Brothers - A Tale Of Two Sons. The game is compact; so there's little you can draw reference to without spoiling anything, and to ruin this beautiful little tale would do the reader a great disservice. That in itself should serve as a recommendation, though it comes with several caveats.Firstly, there is only one reason why you would logically ever play Brothers twice, and that's to get achievements. As sad a statement as that is in many games, here it's in the games' favour, as the achievements here take the form of vignettes which occur off Brother's beaten (and entirely linear) path. These brief scenes take a variety of tones and forms, and some are more enjoyable than others (of course). The merit of this approach is that the achievements enhance the game rather than detract from it, and for this Brothers should be applauded. Find all of these asides from the main tale though, and that's it - nothing more to see here.So, the game itself. Brothers is an isometric overhead adventure, in which you guide the titular big and little brothers (who call one another Naia and Naiee in the game world's language, whatever those words may mean) around various obstacles on their journey to find a cure for their ailing father. As we have come to expect, the game and soundtrack are both beautiful, with a visually realised and aurally rounded world waiting to be explored. The manner of exploration is probably the most talked about and easily discussed mechanic of the game, which to summarily recap, involves simultaneous control of both brothers. On a standard gamepad set-up, the left stick controls the big brother, right stick the little brother, with left and right triggers serving as each character's action/interaction button, and left/right bumper rotating the camera. This control scheme may be both the game's key draw and most off-putting mechanic depend on how you personally handle the remapping of ingrained controller use - the operation is fairly fluid and has a gentle enough curve to allow you to get used to it, and I personally found the system engaging and enjoyable, but I can see the same aspects frustrating and annoying many gamers. Nonetheless, overcome the fact that you WILL at times be constantly running one brother into a wall while the other calls out to his counterpart for no reason, simply because the little brother is positioned to the left of the big brother and your mind has once again mapped the left stick to the left character and vice-versa, and you have a wonderful ride ahead of you.And you will need a controller. Yes, the game has keyboard controls. Be aware however that the game itself will warn you that it is designed, specifically, to be controlled with a pad. On a keyboard certain tasks requiring rotation of both thumbsticks simultaneously... do not map well. I can't honestly recommend the game to anyone without a controller.As to the story, events and specifics of the world - they should all be experienced for oneself. So long as you have some sort of empathy within you, this is a great little journey which will draw you in fully for three to four hours. The puzzles aren't particularly challenging at any part, there's no choices or branching story lines - and you won't mind. It's refreshing how streamlined and conservative Brothers is with it's mechanics, puzzles and set-pieces, and it deserves to be played both for and because of these aspects. The tone, whist initially whimsical, darkens considerably, to the point where I'd advise against playing the game with younger children. To give it a cinematic comparison, it starts off in Jim Henson's Labyrinth, moves into The Never-Ending Story, and ends... not joyfully. However; I wouldn't change a thing about it.It is also very worth saying that just because you'll see the entire game in one or two play-throughs, it is still extremely re-playable and enjoyable each time. I fired up the game to check out the keyboard controls while writing this review and I felt an urge to play again immediately, which would make a fourth run at the game.This really is a beautiful, innovative and rollicking yarn which asks for very little from the player and gives a ton back. The only hold-ups are the aforementioned potential control frustrations, and for those to whom it's a factor, the price. Not wishing to seem ♥♥♥♥♥rdly, for your average player, £12 for a three-hour game isn't great. When you take into account what you get for that price of entry, I'd have to say that yes, it is worth it, but I can't say I paid that for it as I picked up a cheap key. At half price this game is an absolute steal and should be purchased without reservation, at full price, give the points raised here a little thought before committing.8.5/10He Ain't Heavy

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Wow.. I cannot find the best way to explain my experience from this game, but I have been moved and feel unable to truly express what a gem of a game this has been for me. The steam winter sales of 2013 had Brothers on sale and not having heard of it, I decided to watch the trailor.. Already I felt "This looks like it'll be good", and I instantly snagged myself a copy. I installed and played Brothers in one sitting, unable to stop myself from progressing through the game.I felt such intrigue and splendor as I navigated the beautiful levels and explored some of the secrets and easter eggs hidden in each world. The main characters themselves, Nyaa and Naiee are loveable but disticntly different. The older Naiee is mature and respectful whilst the juvenile Naiee is cheeky but adoreably curious all the same. And despite the fact that all the dialogue in the game is in tongue, the body language and emotions portrayed by the characters alone is more than enough to understand.My only qualm with this game is that it felt that it cut short too quickly.. And the hope I had towards the end of the narative didn't come true, yet I can accept it. I just wish I wasn't feeling so.. robbed of my happiness.. Regardless of this though, the loss any player might feel as the tale of two sons concludes, the grief felt is shouldered by the in game characters and it's hard to not feel like you the player aren't there with them mourning.What ever the case, the journey and excitement of Brothers makes it truly a game experience I won't forget, and one I hope everyone can share and be a part of. I've been moved to the point where I already purchased a second copy for a friend's wishlist. Have fun playing "Brothers"!

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												There are people who very heavily complain about stories and games. They say "if I wanted stories, I'd go watch a movie". Other people just feel that games without a story are unengaging and arid. To both groups I recommend Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons. Both will gain a new perspective.Rarely a game manages to deliver such rich, emotional and well-developed storytelling. As a lifelong gamer, voracious reader and a professional that understands the power of drama, I can tell you that this game has it all. Every single element shows the maximum attention to detail, storywise. Careful planning and masterful presentation are noticeable at every single moment. Only a master storyteller, playwright or writer can achieve this. Music, setting, colors, sounds, environment, level design, camera angles, zooming, pacing, "dialogue" and a hint of mystery here and there make this game a superb and very enjoyable experience. The world is rich and interesting and the characters are empathic and show more personality in 3 hours' worth of playing than most others from famous lengthy franchises or dull modern novels/movies. In a time and age of predictable endings, cookie-cutter stories, boring conventional scripting, forced and faked emotional stimuli and lame plot twists, Brothers brings a breath of fresh air.Yes, the game is quite short for today's gaming standards. Bear in mind though that the narrative is excellent and the duration is perfect. Think theater or cinema: more than 3 hours would be just too much. This is more akin to that than to Call of Duty, Minecraft or Super Mario.The controls at first are awkward but soon you'll get used to them. A gamepad is strongly recommended, and there's a reason for that.I am quite sure that you've never played a game like this. Bought it on sale; after finishing I would have gladly paid twice the regular price. The developers deserve it. It is that good. Maybe not a game for everyone, but definitely one worth playing.Unconditionally recommended.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												The game surprised me multiple times along the way - even last seconds of final cutscene.Right from the beginning it surprises by its visual quality - it is very beautiful, by attention to detail - there are tons of details and tiny cute content you can miss by just running along the path, by its technical quality - very polished and almost flawless.Later it suprises by original and imaginative world and strange big and little details. And as you get closer to the end it gets more and more gruesome and morbid. Although first it seems like a fantasy game for children, especially due to casual gameplay and visual style, I'm not sure I can recommend a child play it.Gameplay-wise it is very casual and will not make you replay long sequences or test your hardcore gamer skills. But it's not mindless either. The balance is very precise to make it a game but not allow gameplay overshadow story or visual/audio beauty and immersiveness.I feel that creators were influenced by many classic games, and weave the influences very organically into the game. There is definitely strong influence from Ico in castle chapters. There is also very deep controller trick reminiscent of Metal Gear's one.Overall, this game seems perfect labor of love with no visible flaws. Except that in my opinion it's a mature game which can be easily mistaken for a child game, so the target audience will most probably not play it.Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is essentially a very story driven experience with some interesting puzzle elements to break up the gameplay. I don't want to say much more than that as the 'game' is very much the experience rather than the gameplay. The use of the dual analog sticks to control both the Sons independently is a nice twist, and something I'd like to see more of (even if at times it was slightly confusing). In fairness it's only one of the bold decisions the developers made with Brothers, and for me most (if not all) of them worked.The use of dual analog sticks; the belief in their storytelling being strong enough to not include subtitles to translate the pseudo-langauge they created within the game; and ultiamtely the story you experience. It's a short review for a short game that lasted just shy of 3 hours in total, and the only thing I can really end this recommendation is:If you enjoy indie games and the 'Art' experience they often deliver this for you. If you prefer deeper gameplay than this might not be what you're looking for, but it's still a worthwhile purchase for the narrative and platform-puzzle elements it provides.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												This game features a beautiful fairy tale, which tells a story about two Brothers trying to find a cure for their dying father. Swedish film director J. Fares and Starbreeze studio really managed to make this fantasy world alive, set in varied and beautiful locations. Story is simple, but emotionally strong and creates a bond between two brothers similar to ICO. Gameplay is kind of original and lets you control both brothers at the same time. It works rather well except some awkward controls in a few levels. Sound simply can not be missed. You won't understand what characters say, but animations, gestures tell that with no words. Music is very well done and is a huge part of the atmosphere.And don't forget to collect all achievements, they add even more to the story.At the end, Brothers is truly a work of art and despite a short length it is a journey you will be immersed and won't forget. Yeah, it`s one of the best games in this year.ReDiR's rating: 9.2

												I am in the minority who did not enjoy this game. Perhaps it was because of all the hype I had heard about it, but I felt deeply disappointed. I knew it was a short game, but I don't mind that if the story is good enough. That is however where I found the game lacking the most. I found the game extremly predictable. Call me jaded if you like but the "twists" were not emotional to me. Perhaps it was because the gameplay did not draw me in, but I suspect it was primarily because the game chose to use a gibberish language and rely only on visual emotional appeal. And that is where it failed me.All in all, the best I would say is pick it up cheap if you really need to see for yourself, but I think my own time might have been better spent watching someone else play it, which is why I personally cannot recommend it.

												Alright, I read some reviews before I bought it, just now finished it. And I pretty much agree with the positive and the negative reviews ;)Very linear, puzzles rather easy, replayability kinda low, sometimes a bit clunky controls. And the camera is at times very annoying.On the other hand, stunning visuals, especially in the latter part, fascinating and gripping, a bit like a movie, well worth the discounted price in the summer sale imho.It is also true that the game has some disturbing parts that are not exactly that well suited for very little children for example.Anyway, I don't regret getting it, any game that makes me go "woaaah" while I play is good. I mean, if you just shrug away every visual here, you have to be dead inside. Okay, it also had some parts where I just shook my head, but, eh, if you take it for what it is, more like a moviepuzzle-experience, it's certainly worth getting. If, however, you expect a very engaging puzzle-platformer, this is probably not the game for you. Also the plot might not be to everyones liking. Whether good or bad, you'll probably keep this one somewhere in your memory.Good, albeit short experience and definitely worth getting on sale if you are not sure if you'll enjoy the style or expect more freedom and harder puzzles.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is often named as one of the best example of games that use the tools proper of the video game medium in a way that no other does.The main "gimmick" of the game is the fact that you control the titular two brothers at once, using one analog control stick and one "action" button for each. This mechanic, alien at first, quickly becomes second nature, letting you fully enjoy your travels through beautiful scenery following the brothers on a quest to find a cure for their dying father.Talking about storytelling, that's another way Brothers sets itself apart from most other games, as the simple, fable-like story is told using gameplay and rare in-engine cutscenes.You find out the personality and quirks of each brother by the way they interact with each other and with the people and creatures they encounter during the journey. You understand the power of their brotherly bond by the way they help each other out solving puzzles or getting out of difficult situations. All of this without ever having to read or hear a single word.I would 100% recommend Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons if it wasn't already clear enough, as the way the game marries its storytelling to its mechanics is truly fascinating and definitely worth the 2 to 4 hours needed to complete it.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Sometimes you want to play a fairy tale, a simple but beautiful story of basic human values, of self-improvement and of what truly matters to everyone. You want to see some adventures of characters, who you can (or want to) relate to. It's an old formula, take some kids and send them for a quest for the sake of the family, on a road where they will face scary monsters and challenges and overcome their fears.What most prefer to ignore is that fairy tales are pretty gruesome. Someone alwayse dies in those stories, be it an old king or a dragon, and dies in a rather displeasing way. It's not a fairy tale without a pinch of sorrow in it, and not everything is well after the happy end - monsters and kings remain pretty much dead anyways.With this game I managed to look at Starbreeze studios from a very different point of view. It is a beautiful game with a distinct fairytaleish athmosphere and a bit naive, but touching story.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												This game made me cry. Twice. Which is a good thing - I like it when fictional stuff elicits tears from my eyes; I call it ‘resonating with art’. (What? It’s better than that ‘ninjas cutting onions’ cliche people always use... right?)On the subject of cliches, this game has many: a convenient sunset, a generic premise to set up a generic conflict, a flashback recalling happier times, and at some point a backstabber.The game is also linear, and short (3 hours). But hey, sometimes it’s fun to play a linear and short game. (People complain about linearity, but if every game had an open world, well, we’d have a dump truck-full of terrible open-world games.)The difference with this game is that its linearity serves a purpose: there’s a constant build-up, and just the faintest sense of a ticking clock, of inevitability.Even the cliches add rather than detract; they make the story seem innocent, the adventure seem mild, the characters seem... invincible. They keep things straight-forward, because straight and forward is precisely where the game wants you to go. Even the controls, which will take time to adjust to, are as basic as they get.But for all its simplicity, Brothers doesn’t let you grow bored. There’s never two of the same puzzle, and the settings change regularly. (I have a short attention span, but this game never once lost its magic.) You might ‘die’ a few times, but you’re never really stuck, and even in the few places where a sense of urgency might be felt, there’s never much tension. It’s the kind of game that you can play at leisure, while also being very fun.The setting, mind you, will at some point take an abrupt turn - in literal terms, you’ll start to go downhill instead of up - and from there the mood will start to shift. Just wait.Everything, from the settings to the cliches, will there reveal itself as a tool, a gameplay feature employed by the developer to serve a purpose - but it’s a purpose I shan’t spoil. Even the controller, which you’d spent a decent time mastering, will turn out to have, all along, been a pawn expertly positioned in storytelling.Towards the end every piece will culminate like a well-choreographed dance, a superbly-structured film. And in many ways this game is a film, but it’s the kind of film that the developer goes to lengths to make sure you’re a part of. Enjoy it.Because you may not want to play this game twice. You’ll certainly want others to play it, to experience it with child-like eyes; but you’ll also wish that you could return to when your own eyes were child-like - when, you might say, times were happier. Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is just one of those games that you can never un-play.10/10P.S. I purchased this game on sale (80% off, I think). Whether you think it's worth the full price will depend on if, for the same price, you'd purchase a 3-hour film that you knew would be great to watch.

Positive:- Beautiful scenery (seriously, the character models might not be so impressive but the environment is stunning)- Nice music (a great atmosphere is created in conjunction with the scenery)- Fun and non-frustrating puzzles- Interesting controls- OK storyNegative:- Game is relatively short (perhaps 2-4 hours)- Controls can be tricky to get used to (especially if you're playing alone)- Not much of a challenge - Story is not as fantastic as other reviews seem to make it out to beConclusion:While the storyline is nice and tear-jerking, the scenery, music and game-play is what made this game for me. The world created for the Brothers is the major selling point! The story is OK at best, unfortunately. Not the most creative or mind blowing, but not mediocre either. Furthermore, the controls are creative but also confusing at the same time. When playing with a controller, you control each brother separately using the two analogue sticks and trigger buttons. Sounds simple enough, right? Yes, until you mistakenly let go of the wrong trigger button and one brother goes plummeting to his death. No biggie. However, I played this game twice: once alone and once with my girlfriend. When playing with a friend this becomes a much more enjoyable experience. Each player can take control of one brother by sharing a controller: one analogue stick and trigger button each. This basically nullifies control confusion. So grab your significant other and buckle down for a pleasant few hours!If you want to spend a few hours playing a very casual puzzle-platformer with great scenery then this is the game for you! Having said that, I would NOT pay full price for this game. Wait for a sweet deal and grab it then.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												This game is pretty great. The developers managed to do better characterization without any real dialogue than most games can manage with hundreds of lines of dialogue. The visuals and music are excellent as well, and they give the game a very distinct atmosphere. My only real complaint is that this is a barebones console port. The beatiful graphics would be well served by options to increase the graphics quality, but unfortunately there are only resolution and v-sync settings. Also, although this game does not actually *require* a controller, you don't want to play this with a mouse and keyboard anyway. In the end this game is absolutely still worth your time.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Alright, I read some reviews before I bought it, just now finished it. And I pretty much agree with the positive and the negative reviews ;)Very linear, puzzles rather easy, replayability kinda low, sometimes a bit clunky controls. And the camera is at times very annoying.On the other hand, stunning visuals, especially in the latter part, fascinating and gripping, a bit like a movie, well worth the discounted price in the summer sale imho.It is also true that the game has some disturbing parts that are not exactly that well suited for very little children for example.Anyway, I don't regret getting it, any game that makes me go "woaaah" while I play is good. I mean, if you just shrug away every visual here, you have to be dead inside. Okay, it also had some parts where I just shook my head, but, eh, if you take it for what it is, more like a moviepuzzle-experience, it's certainly worth getting. If, however, you expect a very engaging puzzle-platformer, this is probably not the game for you. Also the plot might not be to everyones liking. Whether good or bad, you'll probably keep this one somewhere in your memory.Good, albeit short experience and definitely worth getting on sale if you are not sure if you'll enjoy the style or expect more freedom and harder puzzles.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is often named as one of the best example of games that use the tools proper of the video game medium in a way that no other does.The main "gimmick" of the game is the fact that you control the titular two brothers at once, using one analog control stick and one "action" button for each. This mechanic, alien at first, quickly becomes second nature, letting you fully enjoy your travels through beautiful scenery following the brothers on a quest to find a cure for their dying father.Talking about storytelling, that's another way Brothers sets itself apart from most other games, as the simple, fable-like story is told using gameplay and rare in-engine cutscenes.You find out the personality and quirks of each brother by the way they interact with each other and with the people and creatures they encounter during the journey. You understand the power of their brotherly bond by the way they help each other out solving puzzles or getting out of difficult situations. All of this without ever having to read or hear a single word.I would 100% recommend Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons if it wasn't already clear enough, as the way the game marries its storytelling to its mechanics is truly fascinating and definitely worth the 2 to 4 hours needed to complete it.
