content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
IntroBrothers - A Tale of Two Sons. This game really touches your heart in many different ways. Before I dive into the specifics of the game, I'll go over the generalities. I'll have a more in-depth review of the ending for the people that have actually completed the game with analysis, themes, meanings, etc.Story:Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a story based puzzle game. The basic story revolves around two sons and their journey to help their father who has been struck with an illness. The brothers are forced to solve some puzzles guaranteed to make you think and help many different characters along the way. In this short 2-4 hour adventure, the game still managed to make me feel a genuine concern for each and every character introduced along the way. Not many games can really do that. Controls/Gameplay:The controls are challenging, to say the least. Depending on whether you use a controller or the keyboard, the left joystick and left trigger control the older brother while the right stick and right trigger control the younger brother. Likewise, on the keyboard, WASD will control one of the brothers and the arrow keys will control another, the space bar and ctrl button taking place of the triggers. Despite these being the only controls in the game for movement and action, I found myself constantly confusing myself on which of the brothers I was controlling. This wasn't really a frustration, but it did allow for some amusing points in the game where both brothers would be running into a wall. As for the gameplay, the game pits you against puzzles throughout your adventure. The puzzle difficulty increases as the game progresses, but I wouldn't say that there were any puzzles that will keep you stuck in the game for more than 2 minutes. Many puzzles require the two brothers to use teamwork, leading to some rewarding moments upon completing a puzzle.Graphics/PresentationThe graphics fit into the games core design and mood very well. Running on the unreal engine, the game runs very smooth and I encountered no significant FPS drops during the game. From being high up in the mountains to running across glacier ice caps, the game looked beautiful throughout. The game won't blow you away compared to games running on the more powerful engines of Battlefield and Crysis, but Brothers does its job very well. The music in this game is also top notch. The music definitely sets the mood and makes the player feel a certain way. Flawless execution there.Final Thoughts:Even though I find many positives to say for the game, I feel that this kind of game wouldn't be fit for everyone. Although it may seem appealing to many people from reviews and video clips, this game is suited towards a more mature audience. If you are a type of person to play games seeking pure entertainment and wants the game to give you more than you put into it, I recommend you not buy it. I also think that the $15 pricing is a bit too steep. I really wanted to play this game for a while, and I only purchased it after it went on sale for $1.50. If you are willing to pay $15 for a 2-4 hour game, then by all means, do so. I do feel that the developers deserve that much, but the game doesn't give you $15 of content. Instead, it gives you a memorable gaming experience with many things to remember and think back on. This is the type of game that people will complete and spend a lot of time thinking about what just happened. What this game lacks in content it makes up for in memorability.Final Rating: 9/10 (missing 1 point from length of actual game)SPOILERS. THIS PORTION IS ANALYSIS FOR PEOPLE THAT HAVE COMPLETED THE GAMEThere will be many people that complete the game and do not see it as I do. However, the ending is a lot more dense then what you actually play through. If you put yourself in the shoes of the younger brother, the game does feel a lot more harder to bear. Your older brother just died. Throughout the whole game, you and your older brother were inseparable. If you went too far off, you would stop and you would call your older brother over. If your older brother went too far off, he would stop and call you over. If there was something that you couldn't do, you could do it with the help of your older brother. Your flaws in strength and inability to swim are gone with the help of your brother. If you couldn't reach something, your brother was there to boost you up. You became perfect. Unstoppable. With your brother by your side, nothing could go wrong. But now, he's dead.You aren't immortal. Your flaws are back. If something goes wrong, you don't have your older brother to turn to. Not only that, you have to dig a grave for your brother and then bury him with your own hands. If you didn't think about this during your first playthrough, I suggest you replay that portion of the game and think about this. Upon burying your brother, you are taken back to your hometown. But you aren't taken back right away. You fly over the glaciers, through the mountains, past the castle. You are shown all the places that you have been to be able to get the medicine to heal your father. Getting through all these places would not have been possible without your older brother. When you arrive back to your hometown, you come across water. You can't swim, how are you going to get across? Normally, you would press the action button for the younger brother and grab onto the older brother. But this time, you press the action button of the older brother. Your brother's voice echos through your head as you swim for the first time across the lake. You come across a switch that you're too weak to pull. Again, you press the action button for the older brother and manage to pull the switch down. You come across a ledge you can't reach. Once again, you make it up while pressing the action button for the older brother. Using the action button for the older brother makes it seem that you are borrowing the strength of the older brother to do things that you normally couldn't. Keeping his older brother in mind, the younger brother is able to do things he would normally be unable to do in order to complete both of their goals: saving their father. The final cutscene shows the father crying over the older brother's grave, but the younger brother stands in silent mourning. The younger brother knows that even thought his older brother is gone, his voice will be with him and empower him to continue to push himself to do things beyond his own power.Quick Last ThoughtsThroughout the whole game, the younger brother is seen to have a close connection with the mother. The opening cutscene shows him mourning over his mother's death, midway through the game, the younger brother has a dream about his mother, and at the end of the game, he gets a vision of his mother who influences him to swim across the water. The older brother is seen to have a close connection with the father. After the initial opening cutscene, the older brother comes to the younger brother and asks for help to get their father to the doctor. Midway through the game, the older brother has a flashback to him and the father fishing. At then end of the game, those close connections are gone. It can be implied that the older brother-mother and the younger brother-father weren't as close as  younger-mother older-father. At the end of the game, the older brother is with the mother and the father is with the younger brother. With that, both bonds can become stronger.Great game. If did not manage to see these connections on your first play through, I suggest going through the ending once more.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												Jesus Christ! This game! It is one of the best visually breathtaking and emotional game I have probably ever played. I felt everything between joy and sadness. I laughed, I cried, I was stunned and I was angry. The set pieces are amazing, the music pulls your heart strings and the characters are compelling even though they speak gibberish (It's a fictional language like the Sims). Don't get fooled by the nonsensical dialog though. Every action and emotions plays out perfectly well and drags you deeper into the game. A message to my 3 brothers. I love you guys. Even though we don't show it to each other. 11/10

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												Everyone knows and most have their constantly growing - especially after a big sale - tower of 'games to play in the future' here on Steam. Most of these games will never be played at all, but sometimes there is a little gem, where you ask yourself, why you waited so long to find it.'Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons' is one of those gems!After a long time I decided to give this game a try, that promotes itself with a very unique co-op gameplay with one controller. Being not that much of a fan of controller based games I was impressed how very well this game uses this advertised feature. After getting that small barrier (for me) out of the way, a very good story (for a 'puzzle platformer') presented in a graphical wonderful world awaited me.The puzzles and platforming parts aren't hard at all, so it is possible to fluently play through this game without getting stuck. Every chapter holds some little secrets, so it encourages you to explore the small world a bit.So if you are not afraid of multitask two players on one controller by yourself, then grab that game.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												*Update 11/2016 - Nominated for Steam Awards; 'I'm not crying, there is something in my eye'* | A wonderful tale with a unique and refreshing gameplay control experience.  The dual character control from one controller is easy to pick up, and the various puzzles and gameplay elements introduced throughout the game keep the control style from getting stale. Many aspects of the journey of the brothers involve helping others, and in return, they help the brothers to advance through the various areas and puzzles, which is delivered wonderfully and seamlessly (no fetch quests).  With a more peaceful overtone to the game, when you do encounter the few “violent” pieces of the game they have that much greater impact and dig a bit deeper into your emotions. The graphics, environment/set design, and audio are all very well done.  On your journey you pass through many beautiful landscapes with perfectly matched gentle music scores and ambience, dark and dreary battlefields with ominous overtones, and magical places with quite a unique and mystical feel.“Brothers” is a wonderful experience, and I would recommend it to anyone who wants to fill 3 hours with a memorable, fun, and sometimes ‘heart-string pulling’, time.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												I have long held the belief that video games can do things that other forms of entertainment cannot, due in part to their interactive nature. I have never seen that belief more actualized than the way it is in Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons. This is the finest example of a video game as art I have ever seen. It's perfectly paced, perfectly challenging, and I have never come closer to crying at a video game in my entire life. And it doesn't overstay its welcome, either; the game only lasts for three hours, tops. Unfortunately, I can’t express exactly what I am talking about without spoiling the game big-time. It is an experience that needs to be played. Buy this game and clear your schedule and just play it in one sitting. It will change the way you feel about what video games are and, more importantly, it will change the way you feel about what video games can do.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Short and sweet, takes about an afternoon to complete.Story and narrative are all but absent. The characters speak but not in any language I know, it may as well have been grunts or whistles. The game is more about the adventure. I found that the premise, a quest to get medicine for your sick and dying Dad, didn't really fit with the tone and pacing of the actual quest. It felt like the game was encouraging me to explore, play and muck around rather than urgently pushing you through the journey to save someone.Aside from this the adventure was pleasant with some elements I wasn't expecting. A word of warning though, despite the screen shots you see on Steam the game is definitely not appropriate for young children, the first half is OK but things start to get very dark, scary and violent after the halfway mark.ControlsI found the controls a little akward. Controlling two charcters on screen at once is very difficult to co-ordinate. I think the game would have lent itself quite well to actual co-op play but sadly there is none to speak of. The game play is fairly simple and there are no areas where you will get stuck trying to figure stuff out which means that you can focus on the story and the beatifully realised game world.Graphics are last gen console quality and it seems as though it was more or les a direct port with no imrpovement on the PC. In saying that though, the graphics are almost flawless and there are some really nice details through out. For example, the shadows in some parts of the game actually enhance the story as the game progresses.Sound and music Fit well with the game and the ambience is nice.All in all a great game especially if you pick it up on special. A good few hours of light entertainment. Aside from the controlls the game is not challenging at all but not in a bad way.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Super intelligent game and an emotional masterclass in story telling. As a game, it is rarely difficult or overly challenging but that 100% doesn't matter as the strength of the game is in its story and the journey of the brothers.  I was hooked and played it from start to finish in a 3 hour session. It might sound a little short but I think the length is absolutely right and you will be amazed at how far you come in that time. It's a really good game and despite knowing the story now I've completed it, I will be playing again. Dual Stick controller recommended to make the most of the innovative control system, though there are keyboard controls. I love the way the game uses camera angles to show you just how far you have travelled or how far lies ahead in the unique and gorgeous fantasy world. I picked it up in the 2013 winter sale, but it is well worth the full asking price. Starbreeze are back on form!

												An emotional rollercoaster played in a 3D painting. This is a beauty, a real beauty.A short but oh so sweet story puzzler about hardship, life and death.The not so deep story does leaves an emotional scar for people with empathy.If the kidsplay versus hardship doesn't get you, the music will. The controlling of two characters at the same time. It really works well and it makes the game an instant classic. I'm begging for more gameplay like this. I like regular gameplay just like the next guy, but anybody who tries something new and pulls it off, always get the cake.Classic

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Good:Stellar graphicsUnique gameplayBeautiful storySoothing scorePacingBad:Not keyboard-friendlyShortSummary:From the dev team that brought us games like The Darkness, Chronicles of Riddick, and Syndicate, Starbreeze Studios have tried something refreshing and much appreciated. Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons keeps the narrative-driven gaming trend going this year with relateable interactions and development in an unforgettable journey.The game starts off showing a flashback of the mother of the two sons' death. Whilst reminiscing on that tragic day, the two brothers' father falls ill. After a trip to the local doctor, the brothers are told about the water from the 'tree of life' which appears to be the only way to save their dad, and so their quest begins.Right off the bat the visuals are phenomenal, making use of the Unreal Engine 3. Vibrant colors shown in various settings such as forests, mountains, dungeons, and small towns, nice cell-shading style, detailed shadows...for an indie-style game, it actually looks on par or even better than some AAA titles. To top it off, the soundtrack sets the tone and brings the world to life, immerseful and always in the back of your mind whilst playing (see video at the top to get an idea).The controls are unlike any I've played before it. You control two characters simultaneously, and whilst there's very few controls to use (movement for either side of analogs, and one button interaction for each brother), how they integrated and executed the controls is brilliant. It takes some getting used to, and you'd tend to forget a finger on a button here or there whilst trying to keep the brothers on track with their mission, but the game isn't punishing. It's simplistic and overall not too difficult to play. The two brothers rely on one another to move forward, both having significant differences to get through various puzzles. However, playing with a keyboard can prove to be frustrating. Definitely recommend a controller (even the Steam page claims it requires a controller to play, although keyboard controls are available).There is never a dull moment in this game. The pacing is perfect. For such simple mechanics with the unique twist of controlling two characters at once, each segment, or well, chapter, is different and utilizes the innovative controls in a variety of ways. And the best part about the pacing is, and this is a debatable point, the simple puzzles keep the game from detouring and ruining its experience.Whilst the gameplay and graphics are integral, very fun parts of the game, what outshines more than anything, what brings all the elements together and shapes it into an extraordinary game, is the growth of the brothers. They have to go through hell and high water in order to save their father, and like any group of siblings stuck together for so long, there's going to be rivalry. Their age and clothing show their typical, rather cliche attitudes well, and we need that to piece their styles together as there's no English in this game. There's voice-acting, but done in a fake language allowing us to detail the characters on our own. The brothers encounter various people and things to interact with, with both reacting their on way to any given situation, further drawing their different personalities to us.Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is an emotional ride. It doesn't just stop with the engaging, roller coaster of a story, it is a well-rounded game with fun controls and beautiful graphics to follow suit. It shows us very, very strong bonds as children, as siblings, as a family...life lessons secretly hidden in this title. This, along with Gone Home, have really set a new mark in gaming today, pushing forward for the better of the industry. And now...I urge anyone who stuck around reading this to try it. We need more games like Brothers. These titles are taking risks and evolving the gaming industry, or have the possibility to, so long as they get more exposure. And even without talking about it, the experience itself is worth the price of admission. A general $15 full retail price for a 3-4 hour game, but there's constant sales and even if you don't catch it during a sale it's still very much worth it. Couldn't recommend Brothers enough. Thank you for reading.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Good:Stellar graphicsUnique gameplayBeautiful storySoothing scorePacingBad:Not keyboard-friendlyShortSummary:From the dev team that brought us games like The Darkness, Chronicles of Riddick, and Syndicate, Starbreeze Studios have tried something refreshing and much appreciated. Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons keeps the narrative-driven gaming trend going this year with relateable interactions and development in an unforgettable journey.The game starts off showing a flashback of the mother of the two sons' death. Whilst reminiscing on that tragic day, the two brothers' father falls ill. After a trip to the local doctor, the brothers are told about the water from the 'tree of life' which appears to be the only way to save their dad, and so their quest begins.Right off the bat the visuals are phenomenal, making use of the Unreal Engine 3. Vibrant colors shown in various settings such as forests, mountains, dungeons, and small towns, nice cell-shading style, detailed shadows...for an indie-style game, it actually looks on par or even better than some AAA titles. To top it off, the soundtrack sets the tone and brings the world to life, immerseful and always in the back of your mind whilst playing (see video at the top to get an idea).The controls are unlike any I've played before it. You control two characters simultaneously, and whilst there's very few controls to use (movement for either side of analogs, and one button interaction for each brother), how they integrated and executed the controls is brilliant. It takes some getting used to, and you'd tend to forget a finger on a button here or there whilst trying to keep the brothers on track with their mission, but the game isn't punishing. It's simplistic and overall not too difficult to play. The two brothers rely on one another to move forward, both having significant differences to get through various puzzles. However, playing with a keyboard can prove to be frustrating. Definitely recommend a controller (even the Steam page claims it requires a controller to play, although keyboard controls are available).There is never a dull moment in this game. The pacing is perfect. For such simple mechanics with the unique twist of controlling two characters at once, each segment, or well, chapter, is different and utilizes the innovative controls in a variety of ways. And the best part about the pacing is, and this is a debatable point, the simple puzzles keep the game from detouring and ruining its experience.Whilst the gameplay and graphics are integral, very fun parts of the game, what outshines more than anything, what brings all the elements together and shapes it into an extraordinary game, is the growth of the brothers. They have to go through hell and high water in order to save their father, and like any group of siblings stuck together for so long, there's going to be rivalry. Their age and clothing show their typical, rather cliche attitudes well, and we need that to piece their styles together as there's no English in this game. There's voice-acting, but done in a fake language allowing us to detail the characters on our own. The brothers encounter various people and things to interact with, with both reacting their on way to any given situation, further drawing their different personalities to us.Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is an emotional ride. It doesn't just stop with the engaging, roller coaster of a story, it is a well-rounded game with fun controls and beautiful graphics to follow suit. It shows us very, very strong bonds as children, as siblings, as a family...life lessons secretly hidden in this title. This, along with Gone Home, have really set a new mark in gaming today, pushing forward for the better of the industry. And now...I urge anyone who stuck around reading this to try it. We need more games like Brothers. These titles are taking risks and evolving the gaming industry, or have the possibility to, so long as they get more exposure. And even without talking about it, the experience itself is worth the price of admission. A general $15 full retail price for a 3-4 hour game, but there's constant sales and even if you don't catch it during a sale it's still very much worth it. Couldn't recommend Brothers enough. Thank you for reading.

												An emotional rollercoaster played in a 3D painting. This is a beauty, a real beauty.A short but oh so sweet story puzzler about hardship, life and death.The not so deep story does leaves an emotional scar for people with empathy.If the kidsplay versus hardship doesn't get you, the music will. The controlling of two characters at the same time. It really works well and it makes the game an instant classic. I'm begging for more gameplay like this. I like regular gameplay just like the next guy, but anybody who tries something new and pulls it off, always get the cake.Classic

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												I'm going to look at 4 aspects of this game. No spoilers.1) Graphics:The visual style of the game is gorgeous: It doesn't aim for realism; it's simplistic yet every scene is like an oil painting. The bright, vivid and sometimes sombre colors and the beautiful lighting are really wonderful to look at. It was a feast to my eyes.2) Sound:The game had beautiful ambient music throughout. It was uplifting at times and heart-wrenching at others. Makes you feel like you are living in fantasy world from an ancient tale. The voices of the characters were kind of annoying to me but it's really not a problem at all. Sound effects added a sense of realism. 3) Gameplay:You play with two analog sticks of one gamepad; left analog controls the older brother, right analog controls the younger one. This was refreshing, nice and challenging at times. At one point I thought: "Well, this might have been better if it had an option for two players where you play with two gamepads." but as the story progresses, you understand why the developers didn't go down that road and why it would actually be worse if they did: I think there are certain emotions that the developers wanted to evoke that wouldn't work if the brothers were controlled separetly.4) Story:My goodness, the story... It was so, so heartbreaking. I particulary liked one thing about it: The game has a made-up language so all of the story is conveyed just through visuals and sound and not through dialog. This stylistic choice was really unique to me and it is one of the things that really make this game what it is. You feel a certain connection to the characters but it could have been better with more flashbacks and a much longer story.In conclusion, I think Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons can be described with only one word: ART. (8.5/10)

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												At the start of the game, I was enthralled with the art style. Through the middle I was continually impressed at the creativity, originality, and storytelling. By the end, I was sure I'd just experienced one of the best games I've ever played. At the risk of getting carried away or sounding too hyperbolic, the question of whether games can be art has been put to rest.It took me about 3 hours to complete. I mention it because, in this case, I consider that the perfect length. It is as long it needed to be; no more, no less. Long enough to be a great experience, with no unnecessary "filler." More importantly, it is short enough that you have no excuse to not see it through to completion.Were I doing a more clinical breakdown, I might mention great choices on the part of the developers, like having no HUD to distract or pull the player out of the experience. Or the fantastic art and sound design. Or the fact that they respected players' brains enough to let us infer the finer points of the story through context and body language, rather than beating us over the head with exposition. Or, perhaps most impressively, the way they use the controls themselves to great effect. (On that note, "Brothers" really deserves the proper playing environment: preferrably a gamepad with dual analog thumbsticks. If you don't have an Xbox 360 pad for PC, but you do own a modern gaming console, consider purchasing it on your console of choice instead. The controls are that important, in my opinion.)Since this ISN'T a clinical breakdown, however, I'll simply say that "Brothers" deserves a few hours of your time.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												Everyone knows and most have their constantly growing - especially after a big sale - tower of 'games to play in the future' here on Steam. Most of these games will never be played at all, but sometimes there is a little gem, where you ask yourself, why you waited so long to find it.'Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons' is one of those gems!After a long time I decided to give this game a try, that promotes itself with a very unique co-op gameplay with one controller. Being not that much of a fan of controller based games I was impressed how very well this game uses this advertised feature. After getting that small barrier (for me) out of the way, a very good story (for a 'puzzle platformer') presented in a graphical wonderful world awaited me.The puzzles and platforming parts aren't hard at all, so it is possible to fluently play through this game without getting stuck. Every chapter holds some little secrets, so it encourages you to explore the small world a bit.So if you are not afraid of multitask two players on one controller by yourself, then grab that game.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												People looking for an exceedingly long game, or something where they can stray off the path quite often and do what they please..this isn't really for you. There are some times where you can stray and earn achievements, which is always rather satisfying and quite often cute or heartfelt, but other than that you're mainly expected to get things done for the main storyline. You're trying to save your ailing father, after all!  Nevertheless, this game has something that I'll call artistic value, not to mention something to say. It's about growing up and the acceptance of death, and learning that life can be difficult at too young of an age, but finding the strength to go on. The gameplay is fun and a bit out of the ordinary, the scenery is gorgeous and the game has no understandable dialogue but manages still to have one; humans say a lot with body language, after all. All in all it was quite an enjoyable experience, and seeing as I picked it up for under five dollars with a sale and some money in my steam wallet from trading cards, I'd say it was worth much more than I paid, despite its short length.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons likely contains the most human story to be told in a video game for the entire year of 2013. Dialogue is absent from the game entirely; instead, there is a tasteful reliance on visuals and sound to tell the tale, and boy oh boy (no pun intended), is this EVER a tale to be told. The gameplay consists of moving two brothers simultaneously through a vivid fairytale. The player must use both brothers for problem solving, whether it is action-related, puzzle-related, or even a boss fight. There is no attack button, so don’t expect a hack and slash. As far as the story goes, what starts out as a typical fairytale progresses into something darkly heartwarming. There should be a bit of real life in every fairytale and this game nails that idea perfectly.

												This was one of the most heartbreaking and most touching and emotional games I've played in 2014.So simple to control, yet so puzzling.You control two brothers on the quest to save their father by using both of the Control Sticks and shoulder triggers at the same time, and the puzzles are all around both brothers doing something, so both can advance further. number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a very powerful and emotional game, which manages to deliver a beautiful and captivating story without any dialogue or written story-telling. All the story-telling is done by the character's body languages or the game simply showing that something is happening in the area. It has a gorgeous art style and some beautifully designed levels, both visually and how you progress through them. They're very linear though, with only some minor exploration leading to a nice view or something to do for an achievement. Your goal in this game is to find some magical tree and bring back some water of the healing well inside of it, in order to cure your ill father.The gameplay is quite innovative, putting the player in control of both characters at once, using only one controller. The left thumb stick and trigger control one character's movement and actions, and the right stick and trigger are used for the other character. Keyboard support has been added some time ago as well, but I can't vouch for how well that works as I only played it with a controller. It's pretty tricky to get used to at first, and I often had to move one character at a time or pause shortly before releasing a character's action button to make sure I wouldn't accidentally let the other character fall to his death. Most puzzles and obstacles require the brothers to work together and make up for each other's weaknesses. The big brother is the strongest one so he will be pulling heavy switches and carrying things, as well as boosting his little brother to higher platforms. The little brother never learned to swim due to being traumatized by seeing his mother drown in front of his eyes, so he clings onto his bigger brother when they need to swim through a river or pond. But because he is more nimble he manages to get to some places where the big brother can't get to and then helps him get past. A lot of the time you will also need to use both brothers at once to move something heavy or interact with two things that are spread apart at once.The ending is very emotional, but obviously I can't talk about that because it would spoil the entire experience for anyone who hasn't played this yet. And if you haven't, I really recommend you do. It goes really cheap during sales, and it only takes about three hours to complete. Despite being so very short, it still delivers a great experience that's really worth your time, especially if you're open to the more artsy and touching games out there. It would be cool to play this game with someone else online, but then that would also take away the innovative controls which are part of what makes this game such a great experience.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons, is very possibly one of the best games I've played purely from the point of it's complete self-integration. The gameplay, the narrative, the atmosphere and scenery all add to the overall experience. Whilst not completely original in idea, it is original in execution.The gameplay done via a controller is nothing short of superb. Both characters are controlled via both directional sticks of a single controller. Whilst it's awkward to get used to at first, I had both brothers running in completely opposite directions on numerous occasions, it adds a co-operative feel to what is essentially a single player game. The mechanics creating and emphasising the co-operation and relationship between the Brothers themselves, as independently controlled but still reliant on the gamer's ambidexterity.The narrative is subtle yet no less emotional for being so. This is achieved by the importance of showing the audience rather than telling, so the distinct choice to remove dialogue and "tell" the story through visual aids (read body language) and integrated cut-scenes of events is nothing short of brilliant. Each interaction and challenge that the two boys overcome leads to greater involvement in their supportive relationship, and even as just a witness to the relationship the player feels involved as the instrumental force behind their achievements.Other characters within the world offset the two brothers, from incidents of being bullied and bullying themselves to acts of compassion and friendship, each additional interaction adds to and assists our understanding of the two boys. Their development as characters and the imaginative world-building adds up to an immersive experience that is thoroughly enjoyable.The fairytale like world itself is fascinating, whilst we witness stereotypes, there are enough non-cliched characters to offset the tale as a whole, and overall the story of loss and grief gains a veneer of the beauty of life for being presented in this format. The world itself is gorgeously rendered, the style adopts a medium between realism and a more cartoonist-storybook style. While the graphics will date, it has enough artistic leeway in not adopting a purely realistic stance that it will still be pleasant if not beautiful to look at in years to come. The game is unfortunately very short. It runs about twice the duration of a movie, and there is little replayability value, as the narrative is self-contained. The only reason to replay would be similar to the reason why we return to a good book again and again. To experience the message and overall story again because it has become a beloved addition to our personal experience.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												It wasn't until the latest Steam Summer Sale that I have heard about this game. I bought it for mere 2 euros then, but after playing the game I can assure you that it is even worth the full price. Throughout my gaming years I have encountered many different games with many different stories, gameplay mechanics, etc. But this game stands out as a unique example of a gaming masterpiece. Why, might you ask yourself?First, the game tells a story that maybe isn't the most original story ever told before, but the way it presents itself is simply amazing. You will almost instantly develop emotional connection with both of the brothers and it will last till the very last moment of the game. I can count with one hand the number of games that had such an emotional impact on me as this game did.Second, the mechanics and gameplay are something I've never seen before. The reason Steam warns you that you need a controller to play is because you control both brothers at the same time. It seems tricky, but in reality is very natural and fluid. You will get a hold of it in minutes. I liked the concept.All things being said, this game is short, but will take you on such emotional rollercoaster in it's 3-4 hours of story that you will never forget. Must play.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Personal Rating: 9/10An emotional adventure not as aesthetically unique as Journey and not as powerful as The Last of Us, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons lies somewhere in between. It is above all a story told with no more than pseudowords and names (I'm thinking it's not really a conlang they speak) and an accurate soundtrack that fits perfectly with each sequence. The plot itself is rather simple. Two brothers must save their father who is terribly ill. For that they have to reach the Tree of Life and harvest the water that springs from its center. A lot happens, and I can just say that the whole journey is unforgettable. The whole artwork and design is at times reminiscent of Shadow of the Colossus and ICO, in which the player journeys into and out of the dreamlike “Forbidden Lands”. The very concept of travel, journey and quest is essential to the whole atmosphere of both games, and it works the same way in Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons. (Also, one can see how the couple's escape in ICO and the wanderer's quest to save his loved one in SotC might have influenced Starbreeze.) As to gameplay, the controls feel very awkward at first, and even by the end of the game I still struggled here and there. But they never get to the point of breaking immersion. On the contrary: for me playing this game feels exactly as it should — you must control both brothers simultaneously rather than alternating between the two as is commonly done. This is especially effective in one particular chapter, in a way which I won’t comment in order to avoid spoilers. I have seen many game reviewers (from ACG to Downward Thrust and Satchbag) discussing the gameplay aspects of adventure games and whether they function more like interactive movies or  proper  games. Indeed this could be argued in cases such as Gone Home or the Telltale games in general. But where these games' mechanics are rather epiphenomenal, the gameplay of Brothers enriches the experience in ways I can hardly explain without spoiling the story.Though the game is short, I strongly recommend it for anyone interested in the  style  of game I vaguely call “an experience”. Indeed, unless you are too impatient with unconventional, inventive controls (in which case you will hate this game), I say this game is definitely worth a try.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2013
												I'll cut right to the chase on this one - this game is amazing. Seriously, like, really good. But if you're still on the fence, or want more details, read on...You play as two brothers, who you control at the same time using one controller (single player co-op, essentially). The left stick and left trigger button control the older brother's movement and all-purpose "action" ability, respectively, and the right stick and trigger similarly handle the younger brother's actions. For the first couple of minutes, controlling both characters simultaneously feels a bit awkward, but it quickly becomes second nature. The game does a nice job of easing you into the controls. Gameplay mainly consists of some basic platforming and solving puzzles using cooperation between the brothers. Brothers is not a challenging game whatsoever, and the path you take from start to finish is pretty much linear. On paper, those two things may seem like negatives. However, in conjunction with the rest of the experience, I felt the mechanics and ease of gameplay worked perfectly. This is not a game one plays for a challenge. It is a journey you take, experiencing the story of these brothers, in their quest to find a cure for their ailing father. This game is all about that journey, and experiencing the amazing sights and sounds of each new area and challenge that the brothers face. To add any significant amount of frustration to that experience would have been a huge disservice to the game. It feels just perfectly balanced exactly as it is. And that is all I am going to say (to get into any more specifics would defeat the purpose of experiencing it for yourself). Brothers can be completed in roughly 3-4 hours. Even though that's not a lot, I felt it was just about right. What you get out of this game is well worth every penny, even with the short length. This is, of course, assuming that you are into these sorts of low key, emotional game experiences. If that's not your cup of tea, you may want to skip it. But for anyone else, if you are at all open to these sorts of games, you absolutely must play this at some point (though I would recommend sooner than later, so as to avoid getting inadvertently spoiled). Technical notes: On the store page for this game, it states that a controller is required. While technically that isn't true (there are settings for keyboard in the launcher options), there IS a reason it says that. I really, really, REALLY do not recommend playing this without a controller. The wired Xbox360 controller works natively with no problem, but I would assume anything with two analog sticks and left/right triggers should be fine. The game was clearly designed around using a controller, and I just don't see how using a keyboard could possibly replicate that "zen" experience of becoming one with the controls well enough. But hey... do whatcha gotta do.

Disclaimer: I have beat the game and have all of the achievements. This was an enjoyable game. The mechanics were interesting and something I haven't seen before. You control two brothers at the same time. They must work together to progress through the game. There is no English, or any known language for that matter, in this game. Surprisingly, this doesn't keep you from fully grasping the story. The brothers set out on a grand adventure, and you watch them grow emotionally, especially Little Brother. This game will give you the feels. It has a very touching story. Another surprise, the game had some pretty dark spots which I very much appreciated. I would highly suggest adding this to your wishlist and grabbing it on the next sale.

												A very charming game, I highly recommend this one to everybody. It requires a controller to play but that is half the fun. The left side of the controller is for the older brother while the right side is the younger brother. This makes the puzzle solving a bit more interesting in that a few times I found myself mixing up the buttons resulting in one brothers unfortunate death. This game has a lot to offer though even in the limited 3-4 hours it takes to complete the game with all the achievements. The story and characters are extremely likable and recognizable even though the language they use is completely imaginary. The art really got me too, there are these benches you can sit down in to observe the surroundings in a wide view; and I often hesitated to move on in the levels just to spend a few minutes taking in the scenery.People of all ages will enjoy this game, so check it out if you ever get the chance.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
   Overview    Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a simplistic, yet provoking game in which you play as two brothers (simultaneously) on a quest to rescue their father from an unknown ailment. The story, character backgrounds and even your mission are shrouded in an unknown (probably gibberish) language, forcing you to rely on what the character's body language and surroundings are telling you. While it may seem difficult at first, the game does a marvelous job of keeping you on track and never feeling truly lost. It's a delicate balance that the game does quite well. I never felt lost, scrambling for what to do next.Without delving too much into the plot (for fear of giving away any spoilers), the story is straight forward, but very powerful. As the game progressed, I couldn't help but feel connected to the brothers, their family and the cast of characters you meet along the way. Without language, you're not so much being told what is happening, but experiencing it first hand, which was a treat.Visually, the game is filled with eye candy. The environments are beautiful and change drastically as you progress, letting you see a plethora of sights - from charming villages to the aftermath of a war zone. It's as visually appealing as it is thought provoking. Overall, the game is enjoyable, albeit short. If you enjoy puzzle games with some emotional storytelling, I would highly recommend this game to you.   Pros    Storytelling - The game has a unique way of guiding you without giving itself away. It's a refreshing alternative to spoken word. Visuals - The landscape is ever-changing, but always enjoyable. It leaves you with wonder and lets you fill in the gaps with your imagination. Interaction - Whether it be with other characters, animals or the environment itself, the game lets you interact with the world around you to let you understand each brother's personality. Music - Simply put, the music is an auditory joy to listen to.   Cons    Game Length - The game is short. I completed it in roughly 3.5 hours in one sitting. Some might be okay with that, some not so much. I was really hoping for more once I became invested in the characters.Difficulty - I found the game to be rather easy. I expected the puzzles to become progressively more difficult as the game carried on, but found they plateaued rather quickly.Overall, the pros heavily outweigh a few cons in my opinion. This one easily goes into my games recommendation list. It's a pleasure from start to finish, but remember to bring a a few tissues with you just in case.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												挺不错的游戏，但是没有手柄很难玩下去。配乐总有一种阴沉的感觉，但是很符合故事主题。角色的配音不知道是什么语言，听不懂，而且没有字幕，完全靠猜测，但是基本无障碍能看懂他们的意思。画面光影感觉还不错，不过由于游戏是卡通风格，建模不算太细致。风景很优美，这点很赞。基本上游戏内容就是解谜跑路，没什么战斗，不得不说的一点是有些谜题很有趣，而且操控哥哥与物品互动和弟弟的完全不一样，哥哥的举动成熟而老练，而弟弟很淘气，充满童真，很符合年龄和性格特征。剧情稍微有点老套，但好在独特的游戏性能弥补这个缺陷。算是不错的游戏，有手柄的玩家可以尝试一下左右开工的感觉。

content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												Nice little gem, Brothers puts you in the shoes of two sons who need to find a special potion for their ill father, and for this they will leave together for a really short adventure (maybe too much short), between fairy locations and great dangers. The game can be described as an adventure platformer, full of environmental puzzles which must be always solved controlling both brothers, like a coop game played alone. Brothers is rather easy, you'll finish the story in about 3 hours, but the developers really nailed every aspect of it thanks to a good level design, nice graphics, very good music and excellent gameplay mechanics...in a certain way it remainded me of a masterpiece like Little Big Adventure from 1994 (20 years old!!!), so if you know or played that game back in the days, you will find a little reminiscence of it here! Good work Starbreeze!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Very inventive controls and really great worldbuilding. The environments were all really beautiful and interesting and the way you move through them was surprising throughout. I wasn't as emotionally invested as some people seem to have been, but the story works nonetheless and the controls and environments were enough to leave me with a very positive impression of the game. The game becomes increasingly surreal as you progress through it, and it made the world this takes place in really interesting. I would absolutely love to get more background information about some of the things I saw in the game. The great thing is that the game doesn't tell you anything through text or dialogue. The dialogue that's there is all in a made-up language, and there's nothing to read. Instead, the game SHOWS everything and it does a very good job at that. Everything is clear enough to get from A to B and solve the puzzles without many problems, but vague enough to remain mysterious.The controls are also a pretty good point about the game. A controller is basically a must. Each brother is controlled by one of the analogue sticks, and each has an interact-button. You control both brothers at the same time, and... it just works really well. All the puzzles are easy enough to grasp within a few seconds but still require some finesse to get right. Even so, the game isn't really about the puzzles so much as about the story and the two brothers from the title. The game takes about 3 hours to complete, perhaps a bit longer if you try to get all the achievements, which are basically just tiny extra bits of story that can be really good in their own right. I would definitely recommend this. It's not a game you can sink countless hours in, but it's definitely worth the trouble of picking up and playing through at least once.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												Every once in a while, the boundaries of modern narratives blend, every once in a while, something shatters and innovates tropes, aesthetics and storytelling, gameplay wise, its value lies in the intangible emotional bonds that you as the player tie between the two characters, that in itself is a stroke of genius, and if you add an amazing art direction, level design and AMAZING camera work, the experience becomes twice as powerful!This "game" pulls just the right cards at the exact moments, things suddenly fall into place, and the full force of the events just hit you like a ton of bircks, I loved every second of my playthrough, the vsuals are great, the music colors with drama every step of the way, and suddenly the journey becomes more important than the destination, a tearjerker for sure, this is a more mature gem, for those that want something extra, a touch of magic in their entertainment.Sure it is short, and I would have wanted more, but ist it always like that when one gets lost in the experience, and is having so much fun?Highly recomended, not for everyone, cynics and emotionally drained individuals, need not apply...

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20
												I'd recommend playing this game. The soundtracks and the in game sounds are fantastic. The game kind of provides all the things that a fan of Prince of Persia, Assassin's Creed, Tomb Raider (and sometimes even Harry Potter!) wants. The story is a heart touching one, you'll love it. The game is fun played alone too, but if you've got a buddy to play with, then it just feels a whole lot different. I agree that the game is short. In fact, it took only about 3 hours to complete (while enjoying the views every now and then). But then, how much can you expect from a game that's just about 1 GB? That's right. 1 GB. You'd think that the game may be around 3 GB or so by looking at the visuals. Don't be disappointed. There are 12 achievements that you can complete, and for that it will take a lot more than 3 hours. Also, I would find it hard to imagine if you said that you wouldn't play the game again.Bonus:Suppose you are really tired at the end of the day and you just want to relax. TV shows are tiring, FPS is a little too much to handle. You can't even go out because you're lazy AF. What to do then? Play the game! The beautiful visuals, places and atmosphere combined with the background music will help you relax. You could just stand or sit on a bench, and just enjoy the view. You can thank me later. ;)

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												Brothers is an adventure puzzle game played thru the actions and interactions of two young brothers as they go on a quest to save their ailing father.  A gamepad is a must for this game, each thumb stick controls one of the brothers, while the corresponding trigger causes each brother to take action.  In order to progress thru an environment you will have to traverse and interact with it, using each brother to manipulate different parts of the environment to move on.  The scheme works much better than I thought it would, rarely did controlling each brother at the same time feel cumbersome and after some practice it felt natural.Visually the game is very pretty, you will explore different scenery like mountains and ice, and come face to face with a vast array of NPC’s in the form of animals, giants, ferries and a host of others.  The sound is appropriate to the fantasy setting, the characters speak in a made up language, so most of the story is told thru gestures and the visuals along with the musical score, it all works together to give the gaming world a unique feeling of life.  It’s a short game, clocking in at 4 hours or so, but its just long enough to feel like you went on an adventure without getting repetitive.  Brothers is imaginative, not very violent & will challenge your brain just enough to feel like you accomplished something without frustrating you, very balanced and enjoyable experience.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
												Set in a Nordic landscape you will follow two brothers in their journey and struggle to find a cure for their sick father. It's a beautiful game with a gripping story to tell rather than giving you a challange. I would recommend you using a controller/gamepad though because you will need to take controll of both the brothers at once so two yoysticks is appreciated. Pros:+ Beautiful and atmospheric enviroment based on nordic mythology.+ Nice graphic+ Fun and not so hard puzzles.+ Fun to controll two characters at the same time and make them help each others.+ It's a cozy little game you may finnish in one sitting.+ Feels like watching a movie (in a good way)Cons:+ Sometimes the "voices" can be kind of disturbing+ A little to shortEven though it's kind of short I still think it's well worth the money I paid. And if your wallet still sadly doesen't agree or you believe around 3-4 hours playtime isn't worth full price be sure to pick it up on a sale later! 8/10

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												An excellent, if short, game. The game is almost entirely story, and is told without the use of words as two brothers travel through a world helping one another to pass various obstacles. The specatcle is largely the point of the game, and the graphics are suitably awe-inspiring to allow it to work. Controls can be slightly awkward sometimes, as one half of your controller controls each brother individually - there will be times where having them on the wrong side of one another will confuse you for a half second or so - but the entire game plays seamlessly and is a wonderful experience that everyone should enjoy at least once.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												This game is easily my game of the year for 2013. What first looked to me like a small-time indie game that probably wasn't worth my time ended up being one of the most phenomenal titles I've ever played.This game tells an engaging story without a single word of spoken English; characters speak complete gibberish yet still convey emotion incredibly. It's only a 2.5-3 hour experience but it doesn't need to be any longer, it's the perfect length to finish in a single sitting and you will never feel that it has outstayed its welcome. The level and puzzle design is perfectly done, you should never need to think overly hard and you should always have a good idea of where you're meant to be going and what you're meant to be doing.Graphically the game really holds its own. I can see this title being one of those timeless games that never quite looks outdated visually; it's bright, colorful and charming. It should also be noted that the control system is unusual but not bad at all, you control each brother with a separate analog stick and bumper and it works perfectly that way. Also, that's me recommending that you play this game with a gamepad, the keyboard controls work but are nowhere near as comfortable.If you have any taste in games at all you should purchase this game, lock yourself away from any distractions, pick up your gamepad and play through this game in a single sitting. You won't regret it.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												TL;DR: Get this game and play it in one sitting. You will not regret it. This is a work of art. 95/100 does not come easily.Plot: Two brothers set off on a journey to find a magical medicine in order to cure their very ill father. This journey throughout this fantastical world takes them to many places, many scenes and environments, and they meet many people in their attempt to find the magic cure.I purchased this game as an afterthought. I had some extra cash and 2 bucks sale price is good for a game I heard was good. Where I heard that, or when, I have no idea. I started off and was immediately impressed at how fluid the controls were. Very simplistic. One analog stick and trigger for the younger brother, and another set for the older brother. I feel the game is best played with a controller, but I won't stop you from using KB + M.  Controls: 25/25The play itself is quite linear. There is a set path to be taken to the set destination. I'm not going to detract many points for linear play, because they pull it off very well and it fits in with the story. The mechanics are fairly straightforward, one button for "Interact." The puzzles were towards the easier side and involved one the brothers doing independent things to advance on their journey. The gameplay was enjoyable and very smooth. Aside from the linearity, there were some 'side quests' that offered no actual benefit, but were fun and felt worth doing regardless.Gameplay: 22/25The graphics and art style are phenomenal. I was blown away by the detail of the enironment and the cutscenes. The plant life, the skies, the clouds, the mountains, the snow. Every bit was very impressive. I don't care if my dude is dangling from a rope several hunred feet in the air, I just really want to look at the mountains. It's not attempting to be hyper-realistic, it's more cartoony, and I feel that it pulls it off extraordinarily.Graphics: 23/25The atmosphere was really engrossing in this title. The music added so much to the tone and the entire soundtrack is amazinga adds so much to the experience. Another part of the atmosphere is the environmental aspects are the fauna and the various background elementS really add to the entire experience. I don't want to name any so as to dampen your experience stumbling upon them, but they are great.Atmosphere: 25/25So in conclusion, I very much enjoyed this game and I think that most everyone will. I strongly recommend that you buy it.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												It has been a very long time since a game managed to make me cry... this one had me sobbing. Prepare yourself for this emotional rollercoaster - this game is both as beautiful and atmospheric as it is heartwrenching. Having just lost their mother to drowning at sea, and now on the verge of losing their gravely ill father, the two titular brothers set off on a surreal journey to obtain the one thing able to cure him. The story unfolds without words (at least, not words that are comprehensible), using body language, music and nuance in a manner that is masterfully handled and pulls you straight in.Gameplay, unfortunately, is where Brothers suffers. Firstly, you NEED to use an Xbox 360 controller. Each brother is controlled individually with each control stick, proving to have a steep learning curve. This essentially gives an illusion of co-op, which while visually interesting and making both of their movements feel organic (rather than an NPC programmed to follow you), it proves to be quite frustrating at first as you frequently lose track of which stick controls which brother. Another downside is that it's also quite short and can be finished in only a few hours.Atmosphere, story and visuals are this game's bread and butter. Despite the frustrating gameplay, if you're fond of games strong on story that tug at your heartstrings and leave you thinking long after the credits have rolled, I can't recommend this highly enough.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												“Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons” is an atmospheric adventure indie game done perfectly. The story is rich and includes a few puzzles too. The main idea of the story shortly - two boys who have already struggled with the loss of their mother, and are now faced with the reality of a sick and dying father, must save him by retrieving "The Water of Life". And so their journey begins.The story is excellent, it immerses you into the world immediately. I've experienced a lot of different emotions - happiness, fear, wanderlust, compassion and grief. The game successfully tells a consistent, intelligible, fulfilling and mature story without the characters saying single word which you could understand because if I'm not mistaken it's in Finnish (which confused me at the beginning, to be honest), but it entirely relies on pure interactive game-play. That genuinely leaves a deep emotional impression on the player.The world is elaborate, charming and spirited, and despite its story being only ~4 hours long, it takes you through a lot  of various environments, every chapter feels fresh, captivating and interesting. There also can be found some mini side-quests that reward you with achievements and extra contents. It would be a sin if I don't mention the brilliance of the soundtracks -  truly atmospheric and moving.You control two individual characters at the same time (the brothers) to solve interesting, varied puzzles in order to progress through the level. Even if it's told that the game is supposed to be single-player, I think that it can be an amazing local co-op too. Playing by myself was unique expierience I have never had before because simultaneously controlling two characters can be quite challenging sometimes. There's a notice that game requires a controller to play - I played with keyboard (wasd, space bar, ctrl and arrows) and I hadn't any problems with that.“Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons” is truly fascinating game. It had captured my heart. This is one journey you will never forget.To be honest, the ending has broken my heart. But it was worth it and I'll definetly play this game again."One must be strong where the other is weak, brave where the other is fearful, they must be... Brothers."

content:
Posted: September 24, 2013
												Ingenious.  Brilliant.  Not many games have had me this immersed or never wanting to stop. This game had it all for me.  Puzzles, adventure.. gorgeous graphics, story and atmospheric music.. all well put together.  The two complaints I have read in general + my retorts on them are: 1) "We are only able to use a gamepad + we have to use it in a non-conventional way, since we have to move both brothers at the same time using each side of the gamepad." ***** Personally,  I found this innovative and not hard to get used to.  And actually FUN when used to it. 2) "The characters speak a made-up language - with no subtitles."  ***** It bothered me in the first 15 mins too, but I understood further on that it was made this way on purpose.  If not, I would had never picked up on the subtle details such as body-language, facial expression, tone of voice, making it an even more personal experience for me! :DEither way, this game has made me smile and get all choked up so often... which is rare and was very unexpected.  I highly recommend it for those of you who like a decent puzzler with a gorgeous immersive story in an equally beautiful setting.  No regrets at all here.  A staple art-piece in game format.  :) Totally underrated. Thank you to my brother for recommending it.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2013
												It's not often I care much about the graphics of a game - being a Nintendo gamer and all, gameplay often comes first (as it should). But this game? This game has changed my opinion.Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons has such a beautiful art style, like Fable: that realistic yet slightly cartoony look. The game is filled with an array of warm colours, gorgeous lighting and an absolutely HUGE sense of scale. Playing as the two brothers in such a lonely yet amazing set of environments, you feel absolutely dwarfed by the sheer scale of it all. This is saying a lot - but I'm going as far as to say this visually looks more impressive than Okami, which if you've played you'll know is one of the best looking games despite its age.Coupled with a superb, chilling soundtrack and a completely unique single-player co-op gameplay style; this is seriously the perfect game. Two hours in and I swear this is game of the year material, if not one of the best games I've ever played if it continues the way it's started.This had better win a multitude of indie game awards. People NEED to play this.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												This is the Steins;Gate of video games. It may not be long, or that much fun actually; however the experiences that you will obtain from letting yourself enter this games world is unparallel to that of any game that I have played in a long time. The only time I can recall having a game feel this fresh and new is when I first started playing games back in grade school fifteen years ago. Moments in this game don’t try to “wow” the player, they don’t try to trigger a dopamine rush; they just make the player have emotion. This game bridges the game between story narrative and player driven activity. Brothers- A Tale of Two Sons shows that video games can in fact become art at its truest from, and must be experienced by all.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Brothers A Tale Of Two Sons is a touching experience.Unlike other games (which i still love) such as "Heavy Rain" or "Life Is Strange", this one is a proper game in the most classic sense of the therm, but it also adds so much to the rather simple gameplay.The player guides two brothers in a quest to find a cure for their illed father; each character is controlled with a half of the controller, so you are often asked to solve short and easy puzzles by moving both characters at the same time with the analog sticks.The thing that makes "Brothers" interesting is the experience.The strongest component of the game is the sense of exploration; you wander through a series of magical and very well designed landscapes, which become really breath-taking towards the end.The game istelf doesn't have an actual narrative, but the music, animation, atmosphere and setting help to create a truly dreamy and oniric experience which captivates the gamer's attention and strikes directly to the heart, also because of some emotionally intense moments.Considering the very low price this game can be found at it's a very well deserved purchase, specially if you want to see what the gaming medium is capable of, from time to time.Pros:- Touching- Dreamy- Amazing Level Design- Spectacular Soundtrack- Charming- Intense- Calming- Cool and easy achievementsCons:- Short

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												     A fun little Indie game that I picked up for 5 bucks during a sale.  A notice on this one as my opinion of this game is based on playing it with an XBox 360 controller.  There are keyboard options but once you see them even the most veteran keyboard-mouse gamer will find the game nearly impossible to play that way.     The game only takes about 3 hours (or less if you don't explore and just tear through it) to complete.  The graphics are very good, and the music was well done, though the wailly singing portions grate after awhile, even though they are used in the right parts of the game.  It is a simple story of go get the medicine for ailing guy.  The fun of the game is the unique gameplay of controlling the brothers at the same time on opposite sides of the controller as you travel across the land to get the healing water.  The puzzles aren't too hard, either, so you will fly through it but if you don't concentrate you will be playing some parts over and over again.  Voice acting?  I still don't know what the hell was said at any point.  And there are some cheesy kidsy moments, but they are minimal.  Overall a good game.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												This must be one of the most visually pleasing and emotionally touching games I have played in recent years. Top that with some very creative controls (though at times confusing) and clever platforming and puzzles and you have the recipe for this game. The only drawback to be found here is the length of the gameplay, which must be considered quite short. But what it lacks in quantity it more than makes up for in quality. It is developed by none other than Starbreeze Studios, the company who brought us games like The Chronicles of Riddick, The Darkness and most recently Payday 2. So it is safe to say that they have had some moderate success already with proven creativity. It is clear to see the Scandinavian influences in this game in the way of backdrop scenery and folklore, and even the folky chants playing in the background.The key feature in the gameplay is controlling the two Brothers at the same time to solve puzzles. Therefore it is highly recommended to use a XBOX controller while playing this. That was also the intention of the developers, seeing it was first released on XBOX Live. I haven't tried playing it on the keyboard, but I feel that would be a bit awkward. Even on the controller it can be awkward at times, especially when the character you control with the left stick is on the right and vice versa. Something just crashes in the brain when that happens.It seems to me that this might be the start of something good. There is a lot of uncovered ground here both in the gameplay idea and in the world it is set in, and hopefully Starbreeze will build on this and release an even bigger title in the future. Short or not, I do not think you can play through this game without being awed in one way or another. Definitely recommend this to anyone who loves games in general and love new experiences within their favored media. Starbreeze certainly deserves your money for making an impact on the gaming scene.I rate this game a solid 9/10!Happy gaming

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2013
A Paladin's Steam Review: Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons. One of my Favorite Tales of All Time.Genre: Short Adventure Puzzler. Developed & Published by: Starbreeze Studios AB & 505 GamesPlatform: Windows and Xbox 360. Business Model: Base Game. Copy Purchased by Myself Overall Gameplay & Story ThoughtsBrothers: A Tale of Two Sons is an adventure title with a unique control scheme. Two boys set out to find a cure for their ailing father and take an adventure across a sweeping landscape to obtain it. Through villages, over frozen lakes, underneath mountains, saving people and creatures alike, Brothers is a game that achieves a cinematic edge to it while making sure the player is involved as much as possible. It's a small, heartfelt yet epic tale that never oversteps what it sets out to do. The brothers don't speak English (none of the characters do) so the entire story is told through the gameplay and what's happening onscreen. And while English is never spoken, you can understand the events going on well enough through their actions and how they talk.  Originally posted by KingIsaacLinksr's original thoughts on the story.:I thought I was much too cynical to get shook up emotionally by a game ever again with such a "simple" story. I was wrong, very very wrong. I smiled, I laughed, I was surprised, I was shocked and I even teared up at one point. I just didn't expect that to ever happen. It's pretty darn rare to get shaken up emotionally and I think the main reason is how connected you are to the characters through the controls. I still stand by what I said. There are only a handful of games that have affected me as Brothers did and I enjoyed it all the more for it.  ControlsThe game has the story and mechanics mix almost perfectly. You control both brothers with the two joysticks on your controller. Which at first wouldn't seem like a big deal, but it forms the basis of the rest of the game and the puzzles. It's a bit janky to control the brothers and can sometimes be a little more difficult than you would imagine. But you eventually get used to it and the game would be worse off without it. Controlling them requires a controller, there isn't any way around that. What surprised me most was that you interact with many of the events in this story that I expect to be thrown into a cutscene. Which makes the emotional impact of some scenes all the harder.  PC Settings & Console NotesSettings are limited due its console roots but overall the game looks rather good, even if it's not going to blow your socks off. There isn't any Steam Cloud (not that it's really necessary) and all the settings are managed in the launcher. All two of them (resolution & v-sync + keybindings). However, the game didn't have any framerate or crashing issues on my end. PCGamingWiki Article[pcgamingwiki.com] Final ThoughtsThis is a game worth the single playthrough you'll get from it. You'll get around 3 hours from the playthrough and it'll leave one hell of an impression. There are few games that leave such a mark in my mind and Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is one of them. The unique control scheme and the game's insistence that the player be involved as much as possible is well done. I have few complaints with Brothers. This was my GOTY for 2013 and it was earned.Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]
