												It is amazing how this game can tell a simplistic (yet touching) story without saying a word, but story is not the only thing Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons has going for it, as this game also challenges your mind to multitask while controlling both brothers, which make the puzzles very interesting (allthough admittedly a little too easy). combine these two thing with great visuals, diverse levels and beautiful music and you have a match made in heaven.A great price for a great game.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												In this day and age, I find myself increasingly frustrated and fed up with the video game industry. Maybe it's the 'ship it unfinished and patch it later' mentality, anti-consumer drm, emphasis on pre-orders with exclusive bonuses, big publishers inability to push anything that isn't a AAA military shooter, micro-transactions, you name it. I find it hard to excited about upcoming titles, and even developers that I previously thought could do no wrong (Blizzard, Bethesda, Bioware, Dice etc) are all dropping the ball in big ways. All of this makes finding a gem like this title all the more appealing. Brothers is an adventure game in which you control two characters at the same time, using both sides of your controller. This immediately makes the game feel fresh - it's almost like playing a coop game with yourself as a partner. It feels weird initially, but it works, and immediately builds a bond with both characters and the player. The controls are tight and movement is fluid and smoothly animated. Graphically, the game is stunning. While not being incredible on a technical level, it combines solid visual quality with a striking, memorable art style that creates a truly immersive and beautiful world. The landscapes are richly detailed and often have a story behind them that you can pick up if you pay attention. The environments are varied and it has an incredible sense of scale that almost reminds me of the God of War games (not that this is a button mashing gore fest, but it has that enormous scope that can make you feel very very insignificant). The characters are memorable, both the brothers and the individuals you meet along the way are loaded with personality, the animation is fluent and they are all wonderfully unique. Interestingly, not a word of English is spoken, but the expressiveness of the voice acting and the animation mean that you understand everything that is happening perfectly. The music is also memorable, the instrumentation is striking and I love the use of space and silence in the score.Initially, the only negative I could think of was the length of the game. I finished it in around 3 hours, and I took my time. I have since changed my mind - I feel that the story being told would have started to drag if it went on significantly over that, and although I wish I could play it more, the amount of gameplay they pack in is fantastic. The areas are varied and interesting, the puzzles and platforming are challenging enough so that you have to pay attention, but never so hard that you get stuck. I was initially going to write about some of the many unique moments that are part of this game, but they are probably best experienced first hand. Definately some suprise moments.Brothers has reminded me of why I love this medium. I cannot recommend this game enough.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2013
												Quite an enjoyable game with a very moving story told in a unique way.Firstly, you *need* a twin stick controller to play this - you *might* be able to kludge your way through with the keyboard, but you really don't want to. If you don't have one, go in to the City and buy an XBox 360 controller right now - I'll wait.... OK, you have one? Good.Now, I love a game with a good story, but let's be honest - in most games the story and gameplay are somewhat disconnected from each other and could just as easily be presented as two separate pieces of art. Heck, there are some games that would have done better to throw away one (or two!) of those pieces altogether!This game is different - the story and the gameplay are both perfectly intertwined. Sure, it still has cutscenes, but the story is largely conveyed while you control the brothers throughout their journey. This game has managed to figure out how to use the unique properties of a video game to tell it's story, rather than relying on techniques from movies or novels like every other game.There is also, no speach - well, at least not English. The characters do use body language and speak some kind of made up language to effectively convey emotion and meaning, without distracting from the story or journey at hand. If you have ever played The Sims or The Singles it's similar to the spoken "language" in those games.The story is very moving - I don't really want to spoil anything, especially as the game is not all that long and I couldn't do anywhere near as good a job as the game itself does. The basic premise is that the two brothers have to go on a journey far beyond their village, past troll mines and Giant's cities to find a tree that produces a healing exiler to cure their sick father (or so I gather - no English, remember?). I won't say anything more - you need to play it.The gameplay is also pretty unique - at it's heart it's really a puzzle platformer where you have to use the strengths and weaknesses of each brother  to manipulate levers to move obstacles to allow both to progress on your journey. None of the puzzles are particularly difficult, but they are still satisfying and there is enough variety that the gameplay never outstays it's welcome.What makes the gameplay unique is that you control both brothers *simultaneousely* with both of the sticks on the controller. This can lead to a bit of brain♥♥♥♥ at times - often coping with that that was more difficult than the puzzles themselves, but it doesn't take long to get used to and is never a serious problem (so long as you remember which button is which brother when you need to let go of a ledge).You can usually pick this up from Green Man Gaming (unlocks on Steam) with whatever 20-25% coupon they have on offer at the time. Check my profile description for my referer URL to earn some store credit if you are interested.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Brothers really is fantastic and one of the stand out games of 2013. It’s an adventure set in a fairy tale world that flows evocatively between moments of whimsy and tragedy.   It’s a coming of age tale, it’s about bonds and friendship and loss, it is a modern Ico, conceptually simple yet beautifully crafted. You control two brothers simultaneously, each half of the controller moving one of the siblings. Interaction with the world is simple, there’s only one interaction button for each boy and there are no menus or magic or combat. Controlling each individual character is simple, but coordinating their actions in order to transverse their world is somewhat akin to trying to pat your head while rubbing your stomach.That’s not to say the game is difficult. While there are puzzles to solve, there’s little in the way of real challenge. But the game isn’t about that, it’s not about getting a high score or finding collectable items. It’s a story waiting to be told and every interaction tells part of the story. The game is essentially wordless, with a simlish like language used. Instead the story is told through the animation. As the two brothers interact with the same object their personality comes through, the care free nature of the youngest brother and the older one trying to be strong and responsible while still being a teenager. The game is only a couple of hours longs, but it’s very lean and takes you on quite a journey in in that time. It’s also a remarkably pretty game with a lovely soundtrack. There’s plenty more that can be told about Brothers but it’s really a game that deserves to be experienced.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												For people who enjoy a great experience and aren't concerned with a playtime:price ratio should certainly check it out.  If you are looking for challenging gameplay or vast amounts of content this might not be for you.As an experience this game is incredible.  It pulls a "Shadow of the Colossus" and tells a wonderful story with little to no dialogue.  The art is beautiful, with benches to sit the brothers on, set in front of some truly great vistas.  The world is fantastical, yet grounded.Looking at it as a game, however, leaves some good and bad. The game does contain an interesting control scheme, in which the player uses the left stick and trigger to control one brother and the right stick and trigger to control the other brother.  Clever utilization of this control mechanic is found throughout the game, with a few moments that really stand out.  The puzzle mechanics throughout the game are never truly challenging, often being pretty straight forward.  The game is also pretty short at 4 hours or less.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												     A fun little Indie game that I picked up for 5 bucks during a sale.  A notice on this one as my opinion of this game is based on playing it with an XBox 360 controller.  There are keyboard options but once you see them even the most veteran keyboard-mouse gamer will find the game nearly impossible to play that way.     The game only takes about 3 hours (or less if you don't explore and just tear through it) to complete.  The graphics are very good, and the music was well done, though the wailly singing portions grate after awhile, even though they are used in the right parts of the game.  It is a simple story of go get the medicine for ailing guy.  The fun of the game is the unique gameplay of controlling the brothers at the same time on opposite sides of the controller as you travel across the land to get the healing water.  The puzzles aren't too hard, either, so you will fly through it but if you don't concentrate you will be playing some parts over and over again.  Voice acting?  I still don't know what the hell was said at any point.  And there are some cheesy kidsy moments, but they are minimal.  Overall a good game.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												La version française se trouve ci-aprèsAs most of the reviews here and there have already said, this is one of the most entertaining and beautiful game in its area. It's a tale where you take a part of it. Take the time to stop by at some of the bench you're going to pass through during the game. That will let you admire the very well done scenery.In the same time, let you invite by the poetry of the music, in every matter, the soundtrack is not just a music, but really a full part of the game. And in the same idea, the language used in the game is as poetic as the rest, so it’s mostly your imagination which will make the scripts ;o).Oh, also, take note that even if Steam (and the developer of the game) tell you that this game require a gamepad, it’s playable with a keyboard. You have to practice and from time to time it's not as perfect as it could be with the gamepad's joysticks but that work.Well, it's worth the full price asked (and in my humble opinion is still cheap even if it's not a long game - about 3 hours) and I think it's a nice pause to take.---------------------Comme la plupart des évaluations présentent ici et là l'ont déjà fait remarquer, c'est un des jeux les plus divertissants et beaux dans son type. C’est un conte dans lequel vous êtes entrainé. Prenez le temps de vous arrêter au niveau des bancs que vous allez rencontrer durant le jeu. Cela vous permettra d’admirer les très beaux points de vue, particulièrement bien fait.Dans le même temps, laissez-vous entrainer par la poésie de la musique, car à tout point de vue, ce n’est pas juste de la musique mais réellement une partie intrinsèque du jeu. Et dans la même idée, le langage utilisé dans le jeu est aussi poétique que le reste, c’est donc votre imagination qui fait le script/les dialogues ;o)Oh, et aussi, prenez note que même si Steam (et le développeur du jeu) indique qu’une manette est nécessaire pour jouer, c’est tout à fait jouable au clavier. Alors cela demande de la pratique et de temps en temps ce n’est pas aussi parfait que cela pourrait l’être avec les joysticks d’une manette, mais cela marche.En tout cas, cela vaut le prix demandé (et selon mon humble avis cela ne reste pas cher payé même si ce n’est pas un jeu très long – environ 3 heures) et je pense que c’est une belle pause à prendre.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
Thumbs Suggested: 2It's not often I've liked a game so much that I've actually been willing to press even more buttons to tell the world how awesome or potentially life-saving something is. Well, I don't know about the latter, but Brothers – A Tale of Two Sons is indeed awesome. Every scene and every image may induce awe-inspiring, jaw-dropping gazes upon its on-lookers thanks to fantastic art direction by Starbreeze Studios. Who'da thunk the makers of The Darkness and The Chronicles of Riddick games could make something so bright and colorful? But then again, maybe we shouldn't assume too much about Starbreeze's new-found love of color just yet. Even in the span of the game's three-hour playtime, there are several instances of “dem feels” to be had.Brothers may also wreak havoc on your thumbs and cranial wiring thanks to its unique control scheme. Each brother is assigned their own analog stick and trigger allowing them to move and carry out context-based actions independently of one another, leading to some pretty hilarious moments. I can't count how many times I've let go of the wrong trigger while one of the brothers dangles precariously from a ledge or chain, only for him to meet an untimely demise. The worst is when you have the brother controlled by the left-side of the controller on the right and vice-verse. It's a bit like trying to do a math problem upside-down. I dunno know, though; I'm pretty bad at math.All these eccentricities of game design culminate into what is one of the best ending sequences in a video game to date. This is one you just have to experience for yourself, so I'll leave it at that. This is the kind of story-telling that the medium has been striving for the past couple of years thanks to a booming indie scene. If Siskel and Ebert were here today, they would have said, “Thanks to a severe case of carpal tunnel, we can't help but give Brothers – A Tale of Two Sons Two Thumbs Up!”

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												After hearing TotalBiscuit praise this game and name it "the best game he has ever played it," I was excited to try it out, if only to have another point by which to compare my tastes to TB's, a figure whose opinions I often admire. Now that I've played it, and given a week for my opinions to potentially cool, I can confidently agree with TB in every way. This is the only game that has ever made me cry like a babby, and it is the best game I've ever played. Tthe controller-requirement is one of its best features. While clumsy, controlling each brother with a separate half of the controller makes this game undeniably groundbreaking, as it is the only example of a game making its physical mechanics part of its thematics and emotional weight. The setting is also incredible. Screenshots will only show you picturesque, ye-olde villages and like scenes, but don't let them mislead you. Without spoiling anything (and please, let NOTHING in this game be spoiled, or you will regret it) many on the set-pieces in the latter half of this game are beautiful, startling, and horrifying. At least within my breadth of knowledge, there is no other game that has taken such a surreal and bold approach to fantasy world-making. When I wasn't in awe of the beauty in this game, I had my hand over my mouth, terrified. Obviously, your own experiences with this title could vary. You might find the story not as enticing or convincing. It's entirely possible that it won't grip you like it did me. But if you let this game in, I promise you'll have an experience unlike anything you've had in video games to date.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												This is an intense experience, albeit a short one. The journey leads you through a quite surrealistic fantasy world which fluctuates between being joyful and depressing, though it clearly drifts towards the latter over the course of the game. There's not that much of a plot actually and as there is neither any on-screen text, nor any spoken language other than the unintelligible fantasy language the characters are using every now and then, the main focus clearly is the emotional impact rather than the actual plot. This is working great, though.This cannot unconditionally be said about the controls, however. Controlling two characters at once with an actually very basic setup (using one analogue stick and one trigger per character, plus two buttons for camera control) is an interesting concept and nicely supports the narrative in certain ways, but it's really easy to get confused, especially in sections demanding that both brothers are simultaneously moved more or less precisely. You can certainly get used to it, but it might take a while and the game might actually already be over at that point ;) You can easily plow through the game in three hours or probably even less. There's some replay value because of several optional parts - in fact, all of the game's achievements are completely optional. Then again, not each achievement is unlocked by an additional puzzle of some sorts, but sometimes simply by interacting with the right object long enough. The puzzles in general might be a bit too easy and for the most part they rather test your patience than your logical thinking. Pretty much all of them make great sense in the context of the journey, though - there's no tacked-on riddle solving that feels out of place.All in all this game does indeed deserve the praise it's been getting ever since its release, and it is very easy to ignore the lack of challenge and the basic nature of the plot as it still delivers some satisfying gameplay and an emotionally impactful and visually beautiful experience.For comparable titles, see Journey (PS3), Papo y Yo, and maybe Limbo.

Posted: January 24
												Let me put it this way... no wait, ♥♥♥♥ that, you have to get this. First of all, it's absolutely immersive. The visuals and the soundtrack (and sound effects) are making the game INCREDIBLY immersive. Second of all, the story is beautiful. It could be made a movie. It's an epic fantasy adventure with a few plot twists and surprises, and LOTS of interesting creatures around. Third, the game's puzzles are p e r f e c t. They are neither too hard nor painfully obvious. You just need to look around for a few seconds every once in a while and the gameplay is still fluid af. And I wouldn't call it a puzzle game either, most of the "puzzles" only revolve around the game's unique mechanics anyway. The last thing I would like to mention is that you will most definitely feel amazing when you finish the game. Even if up to that point you weren't sure whether you like it or not, I can guarantee you that you will love the final part of the game (which is also visually, again, incredible).In short.Pros:- Amazing visuals, best at the final part of the game- Immersive sound effects - Emotional and quality soundtrack (I can't stress how good it is)- Not a single word you can understand, but a very rich and emotional story (IMPORTANT!)- Reasonable length (4-5 hours of gameplay)- Easy achievements (but best collected AFTER you finish the game so they don't distract you)- Fantasy elements (contains all kinds of creatures)- Unique gameplay mechanics- Very fluid puzzles that are neither too complex nor painfully obvious and are barely noticable.Cons:- Quite expensive (although you can get it for $4 on sales)- Short? (depending on what you want, I like them shorter) (I've said earlier, 4-5 hours)Don't be prejudiced because, trust me, you WILL love it.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2013
												Ingenious.  Brilliant.  Not many games have had me this immersed or never wanting to stop. This game had it all for me.  Puzzles, adventure.. gorgeous graphics, story and atmospheric music.. all well put together.  The two complaints I have read in general + my retorts on them are: 1) "We are only able to use a gamepad + we have to use it in a non-conventional way, since we have to move both brothers at the same time using each side of the gamepad." ***** Personally,  I found this innovative and not hard to get used to.  And actually FUN when used to it. 2) "The characters speak a made-up language - with no subtitles."  ***** It bothered me in the first 15 mins too, but I understood further on that it was made this way on purpose.  If not, I would had never picked up on the subtle details such as body-language, facial expression, tone of voice, making it an even more personal experience for me! :DEither way, this game has made me smile and get all choked up so often... which is rare and was very unexpected.  I highly recommend it for those of you who like a decent puzzler with a gorgeous immersive story in an equally beautiful setting.  No regrets at all here.  A staple art-piece in game format.  :) Totally underrated. Thank you to my brother for recommending it.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												This is the Steins;Gate of video games. It may not be long, or that much fun actually; however the experiences that you will obtain from letting yourself enter this games world is unparallel to that of any game that I have played in a long time. The only time I can recall having a game feel this fresh and new is when I first started playing games back in grade school fifteen years ago. Moments in this game don’t try to “wow” the player, they don’t try to trigger a dopamine rush; they just make the player have emotion. This game bridges the game between story narrative and player driven activity. Brothers- A Tale of Two Sons shows that video games can in fact become art at its truest from, and must be experienced by all.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2013
												It's not often I care much about the graphics of a game - being a Nintendo gamer and all, gameplay often comes first (as it should). But this game? This game has changed my opinion.Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons has such a beautiful art style, like Fable: that realistic yet slightly cartoony look. The game is filled with an array of warm colours, gorgeous lighting and an absolutely HUGE sense of scale. Playing as the two brothers in such a lonely yet amazing set of environments, you feel absolutely dwarfed by the sheer scale of it all. This is saying a lot - but I'm going as far as to say this visually looks more impressive than Okami, which if you've played you'll know is one of the best looking games despite its age.Coupled with a superb, chilling soundtrack and a completely unique single-player co-op gameplay style; this is seriously the perfect game. Two hours in and I swear this is game of the year material, if not one of the best games I've ever played if it continues the way it's started.This had better win a multitude of indie game awards. People NEED to play this.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Brothers A Tale Of Two Sons is a touching experience.Unlike other games (which i still love) such as "Heavy Rain" or "Life Is Strange", this one is a proper game in the most classic sense of the therm, but it also adds so much to the rather simple gameplay.The player guides two brothers in a quest to find a cure for their illed father; each character is controlled with a half of the controller, so you are often asked to solve short and easy puzzles by moving both characters at the same time with the analog sticks.The thing that makes "Brothers" interesting is the experience.The strongest component of the game is the sense of exploration; you wander through a series of magical and very well designed landscapes, which become really breath-taking towards the end.The game istelf doesn't have an actual narrative, but the music, animation, atmosphere and setting help to create a truly dreamy and oniric experience which captivates the gamer's attention and strikes directly to the heart, also because of some emotionally intense moments.Considering the very low price this game can be found at it's a very well deserved purchase, specially if you want to see what the gaming medium is capable of, from time to time.Pros:- Touching- Dreamy- Amazing Level Design- Spectacular Soundtrack- Charming- Intense- Calming- Cool and easy achievementsCons:- Short

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												Wow I didn't expect this game would be so much fun.First time I started the game, I thought this game is broken.Conversation language is strange. It is not English and I don't understand the detail of the story at all.Unable to detect my generic USB controller. I had to play with keyboard.No display setting, it only has gamma setting, and the launcher only has language and keyboard setting.But After I ignored those problems and started to play, I found the game is soooo fun.Controlling 2 different characters with 2 different keys (Big brother with W A S D Space, Little brother with Arrow keys and R-CTRL) is somehow challenging and fun, and all the obstacles are brilliantly made. I think it will be more fun to play it solo rather than co-op with your friend.There are many objects that can be interacted, and the brothers have different response to the objects. It is fun to watch their responses.The world design is reaally great and detailed.Fun achievement. Easy to get but all are missable if you don't try things up. There are helpful guides about this.Short gameplay. I have seen people play it less than 3 hours. I prefer shorter gameplay for non RPG games :)Simple and nice UI. Needs more in-game setting though.The downside :The camera is rotating too much, it is already hard to control movement of both characters, and the camera makes it harder.Note : They say that this game needs controller because some keyboard can't detect multiple keypress at the same time. Google "keyboard ghosting" for more information. I don't have this problem so I played it fine with my keyboard.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												An above average game.You play as two brothers trying to save their father and control them simultaneously while trying to work your way around the landscape, which invariably leads to puzzle-solving, platforming, and some parkour.I liked how the game took so many twists throughout the story, as it starts off lighthearted but eventually it takes a turn out of nowhere to some crazy♥♥♥♥♥♥and gets surprisingly dark, which really helps eliminate the tedium and repetitiveness that these puzzle platforming games are often plagued with.However my two main issues with this game are:One, these brothers are ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, and when I say ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s I mean REALLY big ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. Throughout the entirety of the game they harass villagers, break♥♥♥♥♥♥ steal livestock, steal vehicles, PURPOSELY MURDER creatures, DESECRATE the dead, and BATHE IN BLOOD just so they can save their father; how is ANYONE supposed to end up liking these main characters?Two, I can't see why this game is held by a lot of people to be more artistic than any other regular game out there. Sure the game looks nice, but just because a game looks pretty and plays differently than other games DOESN'T make it any better artistically, and I think the games price (about fifiteen dollars) is a tad steep for the game you get. And honestly, the game's premise is very generic. The story is basically "father falls ill, sons go on a quest to find medicine to cure it" and that formula goes pretty much how you would expect it to. Even though the game does take a lot of twists and turns, the ending ends up being very predictable, and the game fails to try and make you care for the brothers other than with its cheap gimmick of controlling both brothers at once.Overall I'd recommend buying this game if you like platformers or like these sort of "fancy" storytelling games, no offense towards those types of games and the people who like them (I am one of them), but acknowledge them for what they are and don't think just because these games have a different style than most other games they're somehow "great art".EDIT: Playing this game with the keyboard is fine, don't let anyone tell you otherwise.

content:
Posted: February 15
												Putting an emotional part and a story aside, this is essentially a old-schoold adventure game where you are playing two characters both at the same time on their quest of finding a medicine for their ill mother. The game uses gamepad in a clever way to let you do a hell lot of complicated moves using a tight-packed control scheme and the whole gameplay is based around it. There is a good dose of exploration, a good dose of scenary porn and a lot of small puzzle solving, where some of the puzzles are based on the physics engine and some require a bit of clever thinking. The game is relatively simple and not really stressfull, and I would say it is a bit cute in a way Undertale was cute or old school adventure games like LBA were.What I like about the Borther is how pixel-perfect it is. It's like a good movie - the perfect length, the perfect directing, a perfect pacing. There is nothing that you wish to add and nothing that you wish to remove.It's a great adventure of surpisingly long length, which never makes you tired,  ends at the perfect time and leaves a bittersweet and satisfactory aftertaste that keeps you remembering it from time to time and smiling.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												A story about how the boy Naiee grows up under the brotherhood of Naia.  The game is unique in that the language spoken is frictional and the players are free to speculate what the characters in the game talk about.  The game's control is divided between the two brothers (LS + LT for Naia, RS + RT for Naiee).  Playing the game encourages you to coordinate between your left and right hands.The scenic and music are both beautiful.  For people with beefy hardware, I encourage you render the game in 4k and see the beauty yourself.The journey ahead of the two brothers is by no mean smooth or without loss.  Often it's when people lose things that they start to realize how precious these things are.  [10/10]

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Beautiful game, with magical atmosphere and fantastic world. Game is focusing on collaboration of two brothers, if they don't help each other they won't get anywhere. Each of them has some unique features, the younger brother is small so he can get to places where the older one can't. On the other hand, the older one is stronger and can lift items which his younger brother can't.There are quite a few puzzles in this game and they are nice, but not challenging at all. But they are still quite fun.I played it with keyboard and mouse and although it's not exactly perfect it works quite well.The only problem this game has IMHO are the clunky animations in some places, it's just look so weird (for example goats in third chapter). And maybe unnecessary long raising platforms, which I don't understand.The story is nice, two brothers working together and trying to find a cure for their father. There are some sad moments, and something what you could call a twist maybe? I just don't think that full price of 14 euros is right for 3-4 hour game.But you should definitely pick it up on sale.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												What a wonderful game!A story telling the journey two brothers undertake to find a cure for their seriously ill father. You control both brothers simultaneously, having to help each other to overcome the many obsticles they encounter.The puzzles can tax your co-ordination, as you try and maneuver the brothers into position and interacting with the correct one - but don't let this deter you; this game is telling you their story and the puzzles are just there to give you the sense of the struggles they come across.The sounds in the game are simplistic, but they work perfectly to set the atmosphere - the game doesn't even need dialogue, the actions of the characters and the random noises they make say all that needs saying to let you understand what is going on and what you need to do.The graphics in the game are beautiful. The art-style I would say is in the same vein as Fable, which again suits it just right, and will leave you wide-eyed at the various environments the brothers must progress through on their journey.The game may be short, but it is an experience you need in gaming. I highly recommend this!

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Buying this game I didn't expect much.  But I'm #1 a co-op junky, and I really enjoy cool off the wall games that I don't have to shoot crap non-stop after I just played some hardcore shooters with a few friends.  This game is rated pretty high.  One of the highest of late.  I watched videos of serious gamers trying to explain why they liked it so much.  I do understand why.This game is pretty interesting.  To be played right it does require a controller (the keyboard/mouse works but not smooth like the controller.) Most hardcore gamers on a PC use keyboard/mouse with a few controller games.  (I for example only use a 360 controller for car driving games)  This game is single player and co-op in one.  But the twist is it requires a controller to control both single player co-op guys at once.  (If that makes any sense?) LOL!  The graphics are great.  It's basically a single player game of 2 players you have to control that you need them both to work together.  They talk but talk nothing that makes any sense but you can understand what they are saying.  It's crazy.  The story is pretty serious.  It's extremely touching the entire time.  Bring a controller, good resolution to see the graphics, a heart of gold to experience the story, and have a great gaming experience.  It's just one you have to see first hand to understand.  You won't be disappointed.  Thumbs up from me.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												It's hard to write a good review of a game like Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons without adding spoilers. But don't be afraid to read any further, no spoilers here.Brothers is a pinnacle of game design. It's a perfect combination of narrative, gameplay mechanics that just "work", and beautiful design both in level design as in general art style. There were numerous moments where I was just blown away by the beauty of this game. It's something you don't expect in the beginning when you see the Unreal Engine logo.They make up for the low polygon count of the characters by beautiful textures, great lighting effects and the best camera positioning you have ever seen.TL;DR:Short but oh oh oh so sweet. Just have a controller handy (unplayable with keyboard and mouse). Definitely worth it.Tip @ any university/college providing a game design course: This game is the perfect use-case of how it should be.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2013
												Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a beautiful top-down puzzle adventure developed by Swedish developer Starbreeze Studios, who are better known for rather action-heavy games such as Riddick, The Darkness, Syndicate or Payback, so it's definitely a surprise that their first non-shooter game ended up being such a lovingly crafted piece of work.The game tells the moving story of two brothers who set out on a journey across the lands to find a cure for their ailing father. While this is a pretty average story, it is presented with so much strength and emotion that it is really hard not to get touched by it. Even more so due the fact that there is no 'real' voice acting in the game apart from bits and pieces in a made-up language, so every bit of feeling and emotion the game tries to convey is is entirely transported through the fantastic soundtrack, the level design and the character acting.Although the game is based on the PC-friendly Unreal Engine, it doesn't really provide many graphics options aside from brightness, resolution and VSync, but that shouldn't hold you off because the game looks absolutely stunning regardless.The level design is fairly linear, so there is usually just one path to get from A to B, but the varying enviroments are packed with so much detail and love that it is a real pleasure to the eye to just wander around and explore all the tiny details Starbreeze has left in the game, such as a squirrel climbing a tree or bunnies hopping around. You can also sit down on any of the various benches in the levels to get a scenic view of some special spots. Absolutely fantastic.An innovation that I haven't seen in any other game yet are the gameplay mechanics as you control both brothers at once, each brother with one thumb stick on your control, so it's basically like playing a two-player co-op game - but alone. This feels extremely weird at first and will definitely put your coordination and multitasking skills to the test, but the further you get into the game the more you get used to it.The puzzles in the game make use of this mechanic in various ways and while the puzzle solutions as such generally are fairly obvious, solving them by controlling both brothers at once provides the actual challenge.PSA: Despite the fact that the store page mentions 'Notice: Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons requires a controller to play', the game can be played with a keyboard just fine and the launcher also lets you rebind the keys (by default you control one brother with WASD and the other one with the arrow keys). I definitely recommend playing the game with a controller, though, as this simply feels better with a game like this.With roughly 3.5 to 4 hours the game isn't exceptionally long by most people's standard, but it has so much depth and emotion that I consider it worth it every single cent if it manages to leave me with both sadness and satisfaction upon finishing it. If I had known what a strong game this is, I wouldn't have hesitated to pre-order it.Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a shiny gem among the games released this year and needs all the attention it can get. Especially these days where games rarely tell such an emotional story - or any story at all.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
A tragedy filled with beauty and a delight for the little things.Brothers: A Tale of Two sons checks off a lot of boxes on my list of things that make a great game: innovative gameplay, great storytelling, gorgeous visuals and a good soundtrack.Controlling both brothers at once is this game's biggest novelty and one that I never tired of in my 3.4 hours with it. One aspect of controlling both that I didn't anticipate is that it aids in making you as the player feel more connected to both of them. Each brother also has a unique personality that shows up in what gameplay actions each one can and can't take. For example, the older brother can boost the younger one up to the top of a tall ledge and then the younger one can drop down a rope. Even in optional environmental interactions (like blowing into a huge horn) each boy has a different response.The inclusion of these little details reminds me of the sense of childlike wonder that Studio Ghibli (Hayao Miyazaki) movies do so well to turn the ordinary into the extraordinary. It's incredible to me how clear of a story and how rich of a world the developers were able to get across entirely nonverbally. There are voices in the game but it is all in a very simplistic, fictional language. Their meaning is conveyed sufficiently through voice tone and body language. The world itself tells its own story and made me feel like I knew plenty of the lore surrounding it, again, all without words.It certainly helps that a game so focused on visual storytelling also has great art design. There are numerous benches throughout the game that you can direct the boys to sit on. When you do the camera pans out to show off some impressive vistas. In most games I couldn't be bothered to go sit on a bench yet here I made it a point to seek out each one. The soundtrack packs an emotional punch during major scenes but can be very quiet or absent during others.With so much positive to say about the game I do have a few negatives. There are a few points where the gameplay gets repetitive. For example you'll climb up numerous cliffs, nets, root balls, etc. and none are particularly challenging or exciting. In general though, they do a pretty good job of changing things up as the game progresses. I also encountered a bug in the PC version of the game where two elevator cranks you'll encounter in the game operate VERY slowly. We're talking roughly 2 minutes for the first one and 3 minutes for the second before you can continue on with the game. You cannot bypass these. Finally, I wasn't much of a fan of the overall tragic tone of the game. I don't mind dark themes but I like them to have a purpose for being a downer besides trying to be different or to tack extra emotional impact to a scene. This is perhaps an area where the nonverbal storytelling is a weakness because I couldn't discern enough purpose to warrant Brothers' somber tone.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												Brothers is the first "single player co-op" game.  There are two characters but you have to control both of them yourself, simultaneously.  Because of this, the game makes for a serious exercise in multitasking and coordination.  It also makes a gamepad almost a necessity, though I believe the game does have keyboard controls as well.The game plays like an adventure game, following a linear path and solving simple puzzles by having the two brothers work together.  The older, taller, stronger brother is needed for some tasks while the younger, smaller brother is needed for others.  It's a very different experience controlling both characters yourself vs a traditional coop game and I believe it was designed this way to give more impact to the story.The story is told silently with no words spoken or written, though characters will speak in a sort of gibberish when interacting.    Any information they provide to the player is given through gestures, indicating where you should proceed to next.  This is generally unnecessary though since the game is very linear.  The story is very moving and is a very strong point for the game.Brothers has some fantastic scenery and provides benches you can use to view scenic points, though the texture quality is very low and this low quality is quite visible in some areas.  As has been shown in other games though, art design is much more important and helps make up for this lack of texture quality.My overall assessment is that Brothers is a great game, though I find it a bit over-hyped.  People talk about it like it's a new revolution in gaming but it is simply a great game, though short.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												This is a beautiful, yet most infuriating game.I read reviews where people complained about the controls, but to be honest I had zero troubles with them as they're super simple (basically just one button and one stick for each, and hardly anything else). Both with a keyboard and with a controller I was able to use both brothers without issue (even if the keyboard wasn't particularly comfortable)... that is, until the game bugged out.This game is beautiful in that it has pretty graphics and (for the first half) a very lovely story. The puzzles are very, very simple, the only time I ever got stuck was because, again, the game bugged out. If you've played Ico (PS2) you might like this one. It reminds you a bit of it, but it's a lot simpler and has a much crappier ending. Besides the ending not being to my taste, the game is, as I said, filled with bugs that made it impossible for me to play properly. When it wasn't crashing with a "P13" error and needing to be re-verified for the third time in the same day, it was a checkpoint bugging out that not even a chapter restart could solve (just to count a few I had: puzzle not working, character disappearing through ground and falling to death, character disappearing, cutscene not playing and thus having to restart chapter to move on, character not jumping though the keys/buttons were pressed and falling to death, character jumping across gap... and then jumping right back and refusing to move forward except to jump forward and jump back again.... all that in less than 3hrs gameplay.)What could improve this game: Besides a completely different ending, this game would be highly improved if they fixed the bugs, and would be even more interesting if it had an option to play real co-op with someone else (that is not on the keyboard next to you) if you wanted to. I love controlling both brothers at once, but I think it'd be slightly more challenging if you had to cooperate with another person rather than yourself. :P There's not enough co-op games where you actually have to plan and co-op with someone, which is why this would be nice.To sum it up: I recommend it for the first part of the story, and because I love these kind of games. I recommend it only if it's on a bundle or super cheap, otherwise don't bother because the bugs are too annoying. And I'd recommend it even more if it weren't because of the bugs (maybe you luck out and have none, or maybe you get the curse I did and have them all.)If you want a really really nice story tho, go play Ico.

												I'm going to start off saying that this game is one of my favorite games of all time. The basic premise is you have to save your father using his 2 sons to overcome obstacles. The 4 hours I played in this game was so worth it. If you want to play this game I highly suggest using a wired controller (has a usb end on it). I think this game has ingame support for controllers but I don't know for certain (google it if you don't know). If is doesn't have ingame controller support download JoyToKey. My highest recommendations for this game.Infinity/10

content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												Starbreeze Studios aren’t well known for their emotional depth. Responsible for the excellent Riddick games (Escape from Butcher Bay and Assault on Dark Athena), the first Darkness (which administered a gut-punch to our soppy bits with Jenny’s death) and the misfiring Syndicate reboot, the Swedish developers have an inconsistent record with both quality and quantity – which puts them in a perfect position to do what many studios can’t: take risks.Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is one such risk. A fairytale adventure set in a whimsical land that seems to be assembled from various bits and pieces of Scandinavian folklore, Brothers tells the tale of the titular siblings as they embark on a journey to save their sick father’s life. The target of their quest is the sap of an enormous, enchanted tree located halfway across the world, which they must find and bring back.Along the way they encounter trolls, both friendly and otherwise, a land of warring giants, a menagerie’s worth of weird creatures and a strange young girl who they rescue from an apparent sacrifice. At the heart of the story, and the gameplay, is their relationship. The boys are tied together not only by the bonds of blood and brotherhood, but also by a mutual desire to save their father no matter how far they have to go or what dangers they have to face.It’s an element that pervades every facet of the game. The brothers are inseparable, and only through teamwork and trust are they able to overcome the challenges of the world. You control both siblings with one pad: the left stick and trigger control Big Brother, and the right control Little Brother. It sounds simple but is surprisingly disorienting. We’re so used to spinning the camera with the right stick and cycling between multiple characters that controlling both brothers with only four buttons requires some retraining of our automatic responses, but the pay-off is great. Puzzles that require the siblings to work in unison are straightforward, but others, where each brother is required to complete a separate task, can throw you, and several times I found myself working Big Brother like a Trojan while Little Brother stood picking his nose.Most of the puzzles are very simple, and in fact the game itself is remarkably easy from start to finish. Of a four-hour runtime, the first two are spent travelling and taking in the scenery, and it’s a fair way in before you’re presented with any real peril and even then, it’s easily overcome. Aside a very creepy moment towards the end, Brothers is quite twee about its dangers. Deaths are never shown, for example, despite the fact that some of Limbo’s shock appeal would have translated well.As you take the boys on their adventure you’ll reunite a Troll husband and wife, navigate the walls of a colossal fortress, fend off wolves, traverse a blood-drenched battleground covered with fallen giants and flee from an invisible ogre. Moments of true tension are exacerbated by the often clumsy controls but lessened by the lack of brutality, leading to an experience that rarely thrills but is always interesting.The world itself is beautiful, and Little Brother’s ability to see wonder in everything lends it a magical, magisterial gravitas. Benches are dotted around at specific vantage points, and perching on them offers a view of the land. The sense of scale at these times is magnificent, and the backdrops – particularly towards the end – are occasionally breathtaking. Sprinting along a cliff-side as the Aurora Borealis dances in the sky, or watching a pod of alien, tentacled killer whales leap and dive through the cobalt blue waters of a frozen river are two stand-out moments, but Brothers offers many.The short lifespan is tempered by an ever-changing gameworld. Yes, Brothers is over quickly, but you’ll see so much in that short time that when it’s over you’ll want to go straight back through it in case you missed anything. Stealing a hang-glider and running it off a cliff, or tethering a rope between themselves so they can swing each other around a sky-scraping castle are moments that highlight not only the Brothers’ sense of mutual trust but also their individual bravery.Little Brother’s phobia of water means Big Brother must carry him across deep rivers, while the older sibling’s penchant for following his impulsive heart leads to trouble more than once. Considering the game contains not a single word of dialogue – spoken or written – it’s incredibly affecting and very easy to follow. Everyone communicates in a kind of broken, hurried Simlish that sounds vaguely European but will require some imagination and attention to understand.The aesthetics are solid and evocative of the Fable series, using muted pastel colours to give the world a fantastical, dream-like quality, whether you’re looking at an abandoned, snow-shrouded village, a midnight forest or a giant’s bedroom. As I said, Brothers packs a hell of a lot of spectacle into just four or five hours.VERDICT: From a hopeful beginning to a heart-wrenching conclusion, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is an endearing and emotional adventure that will resonate strongly with anyone who has a younger or older sibling. It may not be the most exciting or challenging game, and it is certainly over too quickly, but it’s also a refreshing, beautifully-realised attempt to do something new.My Rating: 8/10

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Brothers is a fantastic visual experience and tells a simple but touching story in about 3 or so hours. It's got a fantastictly designed and living world that makes for wonderful exploration.However, the gameplay isn't nearly as good... The "single player co-op" is certainly an innovative design choice, but as it turns out it's a nightmare from controlls perspective. It's confusing and bothersome to controll both characters at the same time... I guess they made the puzzles super easy to make up for that, but really, I think a challenge would have been welcome now and again at least.And for such a linear experience, there's quite a few bugs all arround. Nothing game breaking, but stuff that might force you to restart the chapter...So bottom line, as a visual and narrative experience, Brothers is FANTASTIC! But as a puzzle/adventure game... There are many, many other games that do that better and will last you longer than 3 hours.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												I have over 5000 hours clocked on my Steam account across a variety of genres.The 3 or so hours I spent playing Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons were some of if not the most captivating and incredible hours I've spent consuming any form of media.However I look at this game, it blows me away.The graphics and aesthetics are outstanding. Every area in the game is lovingly crafted for gorgeous views. The animations on the characters are top notch, which is very important because there is no real dialogue in the game - they speak a form of gibberish but through the context, tone of voice, and body language you can generally understand what they're saying.I'm a heavy book reader, but the story and environment in this game rivals some of my favorite works. The feelings that this game invokes put to rest the debate on whether or not games can truly be an art form.The gameplay is very novel and innovative and quite fun also. It's not lacking at all in that department - as a puzzle/adventure game, it goes where no other games have gone before and for that alone is worthy of being played.This may not be my favorite game of all time - I may not be able to sink loads of time into it. I've got thousands of hours in Counter Strike, nearly 700 in Dark Souls, etc. But dammit this is definitely up there, and one of the most important games you can play this generation.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Simply brilliant adventure-story telling game.Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons offers a unique experience of its own and delivers it thru incredible graphic details. When you journey, you'll see the intrinsically beautiful game world and level designs. The OSTs just add more to the awesomeness, so atmospheric and fitting.Gameplay is quite simple as you only need to move around and solve simple puzzles. There's a bit annoying boss battles but it's nothing anyway if you play many more of challenging games nowadays like Bastion. Though, really, the major strength of the game lies not in its gameplay but in its storyline - despite the voice actors speak in made-up language (no English caption sorry!), it can convey the story with the body language and display. Following the story is also another great experience. You'll see the value of your sibling, or brotherhood, through how the two brothers here work together and lend a hand to to each others. Sometimes we forget about that siblings are wonderful gift, eh?Checkpoints are scattered throughout the game so suppose you die from accidental glitches - yes, happened to me - or die in boss battles you don't have to retrack your steps too far. The game offers chapter to chapter selection so you can easily replay the chapter you want to rewatch.While the controller is recommended (xinput based works flawlessly while dinput requires x360ce to play), you can also use keyboard to play the game. Heck, you can coop using gamepad for first player and keyboard for the second player, though it's a bit awkward to play coop in a game like this. That said, controlling two brothers using gamepad, which is recommended, can be a bit awkward at first as usually we use the right stick to aim or shoot not to move.If you want to have a perfect achievements, it's not hard. Basically everything can be done in one playthrough - and that also makes the game quite limited in replayability. zero reason to replay the game unless you just want to remember the story.I myself got this from Amazon with Editor's Choice Coupon 2014 enabled, around 2.5 USD in total. At this price, it's a bargain. Paying full price is, for me, rather not recommended as the game's too short. You can finish the game in one sitting, 4 hours total gameplay. 5 hours if you backtrack to get the achievements you missed.But overall, an excellent game to be added to your library AND to be played. Believe me, it's a good game right from the concept, storyline and implementation. Looking forward to the next game of Starbreeze Studios AB.

Posted: March 11, 2014
												Played on PS3Personal rating - MUST play. Do it now.Traditional rating - 98/100I'm going to get this out of the way up front: In my opinion, this is hands-down the best game from 2013, and one of the best games I have ever played. Stop reading this and go play it right now. I will try my absolute hardest not to give anything away, but as with other story-based games, 99.99% of the enjoyment is in the journey, and having absolutely no idea what to expect next. I BEG you to just take my word on faith and go play it before you read or watch anything else about it. I mean it. Right now. Set aside 3 hours, close your door, put on some headphones or turn the volume up, and enjoy the ride.If you're still reading, then here is what I thought: Never before have I seen a game so flawlessly accomplish every single thing it sets out to do. The control scheme works perfectly, the graphics are breathtaking, the story brought tears to my eyes, and the puzzles were just the right amount of tricky. The pacing of the game is definitely on the slow side, but just remember, the game is called "A Tale of Two Sons." It's telling you a story, and boy what a story it is.It starts off with the younger brother (named Naiee) kneeling at his mother's grave, and then immediately cuts to a flashback where the mother is drowning in a lake, but Naiee is not strong enough to pull her into the boat. We see her slip beneath the surface, and fade into the darkness. Back in the present, the mother's spirit appears to Naiee and comforts him with a kiss, vanishing into thin air just as he reaches out to her. The peace of the moment is broken by Naiee's brother Nyaa calling for help. Turns out their father has come down with a serious illness, and it is up to the brothers to bring him to the doctor, and ultimately trek across a gorgeous, fantastical world straight out of a Grimm fairy tale.This of course is where you, the player, step in. It is up to you to control both brothers at the same time, controlling their movements with one analog stick each, and making them interact with things by pressing and holding the trigger buttons. That's it, no jump, no inventory, no flashlight, no skills, no nothing. If you groaned when you read that, I completely understand. When I first heard about the control scheme and basic premise, I was immensely skeptical as well, but it is astounding how well everything works. This is essentially a single-player co-op game, and it just might be the most intuitive control schemes I have ever seen in a game.The true cleverness of the controls goes much deeper than just giving you the ability to solve 2-person puzzles by yourself though. The real beauty of the control scheme is that as the two brothers are adventuring and exploring, you are quite literally the glue holding them together. You are pulled into this story world and tasked with being the relationship between the brothers. I didn't really put words to it until the game was over, but it is an unbelievably powerful gameplay mechanic, and it plays a monumental part in how involved you are with the story. Plus, it is used later on in the game in arguably one of the most meaningful and touching ways I have ever seen in any storytelling medium, let alone video games.I am not at all ashamed to admit that this game made me cry, more than once, and for extended periods. No game has ever done that to me before. This is a monumentally important thing, and what it says to me is that video games can be art every single bit as much as any movie, book, painting, sculpture, or live performance. This is not just one of the most emotionally powerful video games I've ever experienced, it is one of the most emotionally powerful THINGS I have ever experienced.It is worth mentioning that there is no understandable spoken dialog in the game at all. The characters speak a completely made-up language, and while the structure of the language itself is familiar, you will never know exactly what's being said. You can always understand based on context and body language, though. This is far from the first game to ever employ such a tactic, but it is pulled off so well throughout the entire game that there was never a spoken moment where I didn't fully understand what was going on.It may seem like I'm gushing, but I'm really not. There are certainly a few things wrong with the game. For instance, other than a few little distractions and side-achievements, it is completely linear, so there is no replayability, and $15 for 3 hours of gameplay might seem expensive to some (it is worth every single penny). Also, sometimes it hurt my brain trying to control both brothers, but the game does a very good job of always lining them up to match the analog sticks. Nyaa is the left stick and is kept on the left side, and Naiee is the right stick and is kept on the right side. I found it instinctually easier to keep them that way the entire game anyway, so I hardly noticed the game's insistence on placing them that way during cutscene moments.The only REAL complaint I have about the game is that some of the puzzles have tricky timing. There are some puzzles where you're holding R2 to grip onto a ledge and you have to point the analog stick in a direction, release R2 to launch, and then press R2 again to grip the new surface. It is very easy to mess up those R2 presses. I found it much easier to immediately re-press R2 after releasing, and the brother in question would simply grab the new surface as he came up to it.The puzzles in general are very pleasant, feel very organic, and are all very satisfying. The solutions were not immediately apparent for many of them, but it never took very long before things started to click. New elements and ways of solving puzzles are slowly introduced along the way as well, so they do get fairly complex near the end of the game. Thankfully, even if you are stuck on a puzzle, the environments never open up TOO much, so you don't have to scour through a mansion looking for a switch or lever. The solution is always close, and always clever. In fact, there is one section in particular where the brothers are attached by a rope that had me smiling and laughing out loud.That right there hits home on why this game is so important. Sad stories are easy. Funny stories are easy. What is NOT easy however, and what the greatest stories of all time have been able to hone in on, is the whole range of emotions. The rollercoaster, if you will. Throughout the course of this game I felt everything. I was sad, then hopeful, then annoyed, then happy, then cautious, then in awe, then nervous, then freaked-out, then disgusted, then horrified, then laughing, then heart-broken, and then hopeful again.I can not stress enough how badly everyone needs to play this game. The graphics are gorgeous and fit the fairy-tale style perfectly, the music is touching and evocative, the controls are perhaps the most cleverly-done thing I've ever seen in a video game, and the story will pluck at your heartstrings even if you thought you didn't have any. Most so-called "emotional" games are very ham-fisted. They show you things and tell you how you should feel. This game is very subtle. It is never forceful and it is never pandering. I'm even hesitant to say that the game tells you a story or shows you things. The story is just there. Things are just there. YOU are just there, holding hands with the brothers, experiencing everything.It is weird, it is harrowing, it is beautiful, and it is so perfectly put together that I'm going to beat myself up later for not giving it a 100. I'm pretty harsh on most games, but I honestly can not think of even one significant improvement that could be done.I really could go on for 10 more pages about why I'll remember this game on my death bed, but all that really needs to be said is that I got it free with PS+, and then gladly paid full price for it.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is basically Ico, except you control both Ico and Yorda at the same time. It features similarly well-designed puzzles that utilize an impressively intuitive control scheme as you run through a world that manages to tell a completely wordless story.I haven’t tried to play this game with a keyboard but I probably wouldn’t recommended it. On a 360 pad you control each brother with one analog stick, and each trigger serves as an “interact” button for each of them. Through this, Brothers puts you through what is every bit the classic adventure game in the Ico, Another World, and Prince of Persia tradition.Each brother has different abilities -- the older brother is stronger and can swim but the younger brother can fit in smaller places. Through this, Brothers manages to give you puzzles that are surprisingly ingenious despite not being very complex. None of the puzzles took me more than a few seconds to work out, but at the same time none of them felt stupid. I’m still not sure how Starbreeze struck that balance. You can see a similar balance in the storyline.The game’s Sims-style gibberish manages to communicate that two brothers -- one in the midst of adolescence and the other reaching the end of childhood, must go on a quest to find a legendary medicine for their ailing father. There’s a lot of other interesting and well-told stuff in there as the brothers meet ever-wilder characters on their journey.Similar to Team Ico’s games, Brothers also takes you through environments that immediately feel like they have stories of their own, like the aftermath of a battlefield or the wake of a natural disaster. Furthermore, the game doesn’t even tell you the full story of what’s transpired in front of you, it just let’s you infer things.The art direction in Brothers serves all these environments and characters well despite it being quite modest in the technical area -- no fancy effects or anything and the system requirements don’t list any recommended settings, only minimum. Everything is in a sort of round, chunky aesthetic which seems to play to the Unreal 3 Engine’s strengths similarly to Gears of War 3.Brothers is a very tightly-put-together little adventure game that hits the hallmarks of what it’s probably trying to evoke: inspired fairy-tale locales, smart-but-intuitive gameplay, and an emotional storyline that doesn’t rely too much on cut scenes or any text, though the whole game will last you no more than three hours.

												I was extremely surprised as to just how much I would like this game. Ever since it was released I was interested in getting it, now that I have it I don't regret it in the slightest. It's not extremely difficult to play, the controls kind of take some time to get use to. I would HIGHLY recommend using a controller for this game. You have to control both characters the big brother with the left analog stick/left trigger and the younger brother with the right analog/right trigger. The way you control the two characters to get through the puzzles gradually gets more... intricate. It is a pretty entertaining game. Usually when I start off playing a new game like this I only play it to try it out but I started it and haven't put it down yet. The graphics aren't bad at all and i find myself enjoying the scenery. They speak... sim type language.. so you kind of have to interpret whats going on but its not too difficult to figure out. I'm not sure if I would have liked more dialog in this game or not, probably not. I think it would subtract from the actual experience of the game. If you haven't played this game and have even the slightest interest in trying it out, I would highly suggest you do so.

Posted: January 28, 2015
												I don't think I could say anything about this game that hasen't been said in the other 13,700 positive reviews at the time of writing this. This is an absolutely beautiful and atmospheric game. If you think there is any chance you might enjoy this type of game, just get it, you won't regret it. It's a little short at 4 to 5 hours, but it's worth it.The game was designed for an xbox 360 controller. You can play with a keyboard, but you will have a problem at 2 parts in the game. You can get through these parts, but you will have to hold a button down for a few minutes at those 2 parts instead of about 10 seconds. You can use other dual stick controllers (I used a PS2 controller), but you will probably need to use a small free program called x360ce which is an xbox 360 controller emulator. This will tell the game you are using an xbox controller and the program will let you map the keys on your controller. If you are using a PS2 controller and the right stick doesn't map correctly, search online and there is a patch that will fix it.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												I recommend that you subject yourself to this game, because its like come along once in a very long time, and usually on consoles.Visually stunning and with a soundtrack that is perfectly pitched to compliment those visuals, Brothers is an amazing game from a purely technical perspective. That doesn't really matter however.Brothers is an amazing tale, conveyed almost without words in a way reminiscent of Ico and Shadow of the Colossus. The charazterization of the characters is also in itself simple, but strong. You will love these brothers and sympathize with their struggle just as you'll stand amazed at the detail and imagination invested into this fictional world, and that's part of the tragedy. The game KNOWS what you think it is. It knows what you expect. It's masterfully directed and built to get you emotionally invested in its story.Saying any more than that would spoil the surprises you'll have along the way, but fair warning: the game is not a happy-go-lucky fairy tale and it will shock you, scare you and ultimately make you cry your soul out.10/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												As it stands right now, I was able to beat Brothers in less than 3 and a half hours. A game has to be REALLY REALLY good to be that short and still hold a reccomendation from me at a market price of 15 dollars, but yet here I am, with two thumbs up for this artistic masterpiece of a game. From a gameplay standpoint, Brothers is quite simple at the basic level - no puzzles were too advanced and the platforming is simple and doesn't require any button presses. Where the golden mechanic lies is the fact that you control the brothers simultaneously, a feat achieved by assigning a brother to one stick of a joypad (which is mandatory for play). While disorienting at first, eventually you pick up the pace and find it an enjoyable and innovative mechanic to work cooperatively with... yourself. Very ingenious. But where the game lacks in length and puzzles, it REEAAAALLLY picks up in atmosphere, visuals, and story. To begin, the story is just that two sons are finding a liquid that will restore their sick dad's health, by following a map. Yeah, not much there, but it's interesting in that the entire story is conveyed without a single line of dialouge, but rather with hand gestures and the context of the envrionment. What I find best about the atmosphere is that it is beautiful, one of the most beautiful platofrmers since Trine 2 (which I found really enticing). I found myself staring at the villages, dark forests, snowy mountaintops, and rainy rivers simply for their aesthetic value, not really for their gameplay. The atmosphere is only further enhanced by a somber and dramatic soundtrack, which always accomponies the narrative in a guiding way and really caps off the sad ending. Overall, I'd recomend it if you are in the mood for a short but magnificently beautiful work of art, perhaps one of the most mature video games on the market as we speak.

												"Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons" shows video games can reach the level of art. The mechanics are the gameplay and the story itself. The game has no need for shoehorned quests or NPC's to dole out backstory. You simply play it, and the world emerges as you go. The game is extremely easy, but that doesn't necessarily detract from it in any way. This is not the sort of game you would play if you want a challenge. It is the sort of game you would play if you want an experience of beauty.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												*me screaming at game* HOW COULD YOU DO THIS TO ME?*ahem*Okay, let me give this game a more satisfactory review.(Mild spoilers below)When I was a film student in college, my film professor loved hammering in this idea to his students: sound is everything. And lack thereof. He prefers silent films for this reason: visual storytelling should not rely on sound to create the story. Sound should be a suppliment to that story, not a crutch. And, when done right, the right sound effects in the right place can drastically heighten emotional impact.Good sound design is one of those things that often goes unnoticed in film and game critique. And Brothers has good sound design. The lack of understandable dialogue actually makes the story better because it forces us to discern the story from simple action alone. Oftentimes I found myself rationalizing the actions of the brothers and other NPCs by determining their emotions from their actions. Such as the crying forest giant- context allowed me to discern that someone he loved was gone. That was just one example of many I found myself thinking as I played the game. Don't give your audience 4: give them 2+2. Let them figure it out. That's why this game doesn't need dialogue.The music only has a discernable melody and composition when in emotionally intense situations. Otherwise, it is atmospheric, indecipherable sounds. This is effective because if a musician relies too much on bombarding our senses with fantastic melodies at all times, we will not be able to appreciate a moment when it truly calls for some riveting emotions. So, when you're just wandering the land, accomplishing small tasks, the music remains quiet, pensive, and ambient. When something big is going on... it's spine-chilling. Contrast is everything!The sound effects are immersive because they draw from the environment, and you can often hear things coming before you see them. This is effective because when you are traveling around in real life, out in the woods or even on city streets, oftentimes you will hear things before you see them coming. This is something we have tended to take for granted, but you can tell this was intentionally designed in the game.Of course, the art direction was gorgeous. I especially love the fact that the characters are not rendered in an attempt for photorealism like many triple A titles these days. You simply don't need that. Stylized, abstracted forms are more pleasing to the eye IMO. Attempting photorealistic characters in a video game is just too uncanny valley for my tastes. The *colors*, man. The light and shadows. The composition. It's a visual masterpiece. And the ending. I don't have to explain why it's so chilling and amazing. What are you waiting for... buy this game!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Truly an amazing game in every aspect.The mechanics of the game are good, and it's a bit of a new concept for me to play 2 characters at the same time.Amazing artwork, great music.The story is something you could make a fantasy book out of, a good one.Not much to say for voice acting as the game uses a made up language, which is my only criticism as well.I feel that this game would've gotten way more emotion from me if it had actual English voice acting, assuming the voice acting was good.I also think they could've at least added a few more voice-lines, even though it is just balderdash hearing the exact same voice-recordings over and over is off-putting. A lot of people do not properly appreciate the world, the art in games.This game is a true reminder to those people that there is a very creative, and talented team behind the world you are in.The soundtrack coupled with the world you are in is just fenomenal, at some points I got chills, some points I sat back and took a sip of my coffee to just take it in.The actual gameplay mechanics are great, and I personally feel like they nailed the 'play co-op with yourself' concept, it was done in a way where it wasn't too overwhelming, and I got used to it after the first 10-20 minutes of playing.But I do admit the first minutes it felt very alien and a little off-putting. But yes, I got used to it and I imagine most people will. I can't see a person quitting the game because they got frustrated from controlling 2 characters at the same time.If there are people like that they do not deserve any attention in my opinion.*Please keep in mind that this game has to be played with a controller.The puzzles in the game are fairly simple, nothing you haven't seen before.The premise of the game is simple. You are 2 brothers who's father is sick, you must go out on an adventure to find a potion, of sorts, to save him.But this game is more dark and grim than it may seem on the surface. It has some unexpected, and indeed dark, turns in the story.I belive everyone should go into this game blind, spoiling something may very well ruin the entire game for you.Whether you buy this game on sale or not; it is worth it.3-4 hours of gameplay with an amazing, powerful story, good game mechanics, a beautiful world filled with fenomenal music is worth it to me.It almost feels like that the lower expectations you have going into the game will leave you more and more amazed at the end.
