content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												I was extremely surprised as to just how much I would like this game. Ever since it was released I was interested in getting it, now that I have it I don't regret it in the slightest. It's not extremely difficult to play, the controls kind of take some time to get use to. I would HIGHLY recommend using a controller for this game. You have to control both characters the big brother with the left analog stick/left trigger and the younger brother with the right analog/right trigger. The way you control the two characters to get through the puzzles gradually gets more... intricate. It is a pretty entertaining game. Usually when I start off playing a new game like this I only play it to try it out but I started it and haven't put it down yet. The graphics aren't bad at all and i find myself enjoying the scenery. They speak... sim type language.. so you kind of have to interpret whats going on but its not too difficult to figure out. I'm not sure if I would have liked more dialog in this game or not, probably not. I think it would subtract from the actual experience of the game. If you haven't played this game and have even the slightest interest in trying it out, I would highly suggest you do so.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is exactly what a short indie game should be.  The game is short (approximately 2-3 hours) but what it does in that time is more than some games try to do in 30 hours.  The puzzles and the controlling brothers mechanic are used exretemely well and there really isn't a great deal of repetitiveness in those puzzles.  Each puzzle is a short unique puzzle to solve and then move quickly to the next puzzle/story element.There is not a lot of fluff or down time in the game.  It is paced exteremly well, moving from puzzle to story to puzzle to story.  It's not that the game can be beat in one sitting, it's that the game is so well paced that you want to finish it in one sitting.  There's no big down boring parts or excessively frustrating puzzles, just small simple well excuted game play that makes you want to keep moving on.  The world that the developers created to tell their story in was beautiful.  There was some really unique areas with some unique characters as well.Everything comes together in one great package to make one of the best indie games that I have played.  Highly recommend the game to anyone looking for a great indie experience.

												I was skeptical. I had hear quite a few things about this game so I finally decided to pick it up and give it a shot. To be honest, I went in with low expectations. Boy was I wrong. Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons, tells an incredibly powerful story of two bothers who go out seeking a special cure for their father, who has fallen ill, and it tells this story all without the characters saying a single word. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												A beautiful platformer.Brothers- A Tale of two sons is a 3D platformer developed by starbreeze studios. The story is simple, yet it is conveyed perfectly. You play as two brothers who are tasked to retrieve some medicine for their sick dying father. In order to do so, they will have to cross giant bridges, bloody graveyards, giant oceans and meet a variety of colourful characters. Through out the story you will feel a variety of emotions including joy, happiness, wonder, fear, amazement and sadness. There is no voice acting in the game, and honestly there doesn't need to be as you can understand what the characters are saying through their actions. The game will last you 3 hours or a bit more if you want to collect all achievements and explore a bit. There isn't much replayability to be had here.Gameplay revolves around a mix between platforming and puzzle solving. Bearing in mind that you NEED A CONTROLLER to play this game, the controls are quite good. You control the movement of one brother with the left analogue stick and another with the right stick. It might seem tricky at first, trying to control both the brothers at the same time, but after a while you will get the hang of it.The graphics are cartoony and good to look at. The lighting does a great job at making the colours more attractive to the eye. There are also p[enty of scenes that look so good that you want to take  screenshot of as well.I highly recommend this game to people you want to a rememberable adventure with a few platforming and puzzles thrown in.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Hello everybody,today i wan`t to show you an interesting game.No, more than a game. It`s a journey you will never forget, if you play this game.STORYThis is the story of two Brothers on a journey to help their father.At the beginning of the story the father got ill and his sons bring him to a healer.The problem is, he know a way to heal the father but it will take a very long journey.The sons already lost their mother and don`t wan`t to loose their father, too, so they started the Journey.GAMEPLAYI never saw a gameplay like this before. You MUST have a controller.With it you controll the 2 Brothers at the same time. One with the right half and the other with the left half of the Controller. The same time! Most of the parts of this game you must do Teamwork with the Brothers to get through the game. That sounds a little bit complicated, but it is very easy to control.At the beginning it may be a little bit complicated, but after a short time you´re in and you can enjoy the game and it´s story.GRAPHICSThe Graphics are really awesome. At the beginning it is nothing special. You are in a small village, with some people, normal village life. But the more you play, the Settings gets better and better and you can see how much work it`s in this game. I don´t wan`t to spoil, that is something you must see by yourself. The World of BROTHERS got many nice details and all the characters are very well animated.  MUSICThe music is wonderfull and fits great into the Game Scenes. It also supports emotional moments very, very well.ACHIEVEMENTSYes, Brothers have his Achievements, but these are special ones. Each one stands for a little situation you must find. For example, you have to make a special person dancing, or helping a Turtlemom to get her Babys back. Very nice Achievements.PERSONAL CONCLUSIONYes, this game did it. I`ve had some tears in my eyes and i´m not ashamed of it.This is more than a game. It´s like a movie or like a book. You follow the story and you laugh and cry with them. Each chapter you wan`t to know how it is going on. You can`t stop. And at the End of the Game you sit there, thinking about what you have experienced. Thanks to the Developer and publisher of this experience.It was awesome.TO YOUIf you like great storys with great graphics and music, this is for you.If you are really emotional, don´t forget the tissue. You will need it.This is really a game that should be in every collection. GreetingsWyvern

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Perfect game.I enjoyed every minute of this. I was drawn into the world and the story completely while I played. I felt like I was on an epic adventure, and I was truly invested into the 3 main characters. Now that I'm finished I can appreciate things in finer detail.Gameplay is certainly unique, but that's not the main take-away here. I think -everything- comes together to make a truly memorable experience.The unique gameplay mechanic (driving both brothers with one controller) is certainly notable and memorable by itself, and something else will use this mechanic in the future and I'll think of this game. But that doesn't give the full picture. The atmosphere created by the design and the music and the story all- is a new benchmark for me. I'm sure I'll think of it often.You can run through this world, taking the shortest path to your goal, and enjoy yourself thoroughly I think. But you don't have to. Despite the epic adventure vibe, you're not at all rushed, and you can stop to smell the roses of this wonderful environment (and you get an achievement for doing so). There are other characters in the world that you pass in your travels, and you can often play some part in their lives. Looking at the achievments screen now that I'm done reveals that I missed some of this myself, but I don't feel like I missed anything really.I was emotionally spent after completing this game. I took a lot from the experience and that might stick with me longest. As an experience, I think it rates with the best movies I've ever seen. I don't usually get this quality from games, and that probably intensified it for me, but it's excellent to be sure. I took some minutes to bask in it after I was done.It's not a difficult game, although the very first time you come across a new puzzle aspect (particularly at the start of the game) you will be confused until you get it, I think that as a whole, that aspect was good for the game. It doesn't take long to pick up really.Find some quiet hours and throw yourself into this game completely and you ought to get twice as much out of it.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												My thoughts on Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons:What an amazingly beautiful game! I picked this up quite a while a go during a sale and only because I heard YouTube personality TotalBisquit say this was his favourite game.After playing (and finishing) it, I can understand why.You follow the two Brothers on their quest to find a rare medicine to cure their father and help them climb mountains, fly across valleys, make their way through villages and castles, across devastaded battlefields and frozen rivers. The level design is just awesome and so beautiful I couldn't help but wish to be living there. The soundtrack too is great and fits the game and the mood perfectly.While it takes some time to really get used to the controls (Xbox controller is required) - you control both brothers at once, using both sticks - it never gets frustrating or annoying as the game helps you out a lot and never really is too hard to be blamed on the controls.There are no fights or puzzles, just some smal objectives like having to pull a lever with one brother while hangling across a pit with the other, in order to create a path for the big brother once you reached the other side. May sound boring, but the landscapes and the characters somehow get you entertained anyway. Plus, the game is easily beatable in under two hours, so there isn't much time to get bored anyway.Biggest highlight of the game however is how it makes you like the characters in a way only few other games do, and the ending deserves a special mention too as it is just beautiful and really really really well made. Did I already mention how beautiful the landscapes are?Highly recommended for anyone, especially during a sale!Also, vote for it as best game to make you cry!

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												This game is an amazing achievement. A game that creates an innovative, entertaining yet intuitive control system is rare. A game that creates a consistent deeply moving emotional experience in its players is rare. A game that does both? Epic. I will not go in depth into the detailed mechanics or the story itself because doing so would ruin your individual experience. I am not referring only to story spoilers, but your experience and growth in using the "single-player co-op" control system. Don't watch a video. Don't read commentary. I started playing this game on a whim in my office when my family was asleep. Speakers on low, door open, lights on, email up on my second monitor. 30 minutes into the game I had headphones on, door was closed, lights and second monitor turned off. It commanded a degree of attention and immersion that I have rarely experienced. Buy it now and play it. I give it an 11/10. No kidding.In fact, you owe it to yourself to play this game. It is well worth the $15, and certainly worth the $3 it is right now on the Steam Fall Sale when this review was written. Please play it. You will never forget it.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												TIME: 3 - 4 hoursDIFFICULTY: Low - IntermediateCONTROLLER: RequiredRECOMMENDED: YesA wonderful fairy tale; it hit all the right notes for me from whimsical to surprisingly dark. Visually it feels like it draws from Fable TLC with a touch of Shadow of the Colossus. I'm not a huge fan of the music by itself, but in the context of the game world, I think it does a great job at setting the mood of different set pieces.This game does have a learning curve, mechanically - both brothers are controlled simulaneously using the R/L sticks and triggers, which can get a little confusing. The gameplay itself isn't anything revelatory, but that "dual control" mechanic provides some interesting coordination puzzle opportunities. The only downsides were some technical shortcomings: choppy framerate that occasionally dropped to +/- 20 (but was stable at 30 enough to keep me satisfied) and texture popping can sort of take you out of it. I paid $3 for this on sale, but I think it's worth the full asking price of $15, even as a shorter experience.

												It's a fairy tale come to life, about the length of a long movie and just as epic. content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												"Brothers" tells a story of beauty and cruelty that explores areas of human experience overlooked or mishandled by the vast majority of games. Not only that, but the mechanics are intertwined with the narrative on a fundamental level, inseparable and symbiotic. The final passage of the game (no spoilers) is particularly powerful, forcing the player him/herself to engage physically and, as a result, emotionally in the events that have come to pass.It's an experience that will stay with you long after it's over and will colour how you view interactice narratives in future.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
Product received for free
												Before I start to try to write a review, I want to give you two points that may give you a better approach to this game:1) It doesn't really need a controller. Keyboard works fine and, probably just for this game, is better than a controller.    You'll understand why, I'm sure of that. Basically, don't use the controller. 2) It is a short game, so I recommend you to buy it at 75% or 90% discount. Before you read (As my review could not appear as interesting nor helpful) Buy it, while keeping in mind those two points I wrote.Shall we start now?This game is enchanting. A fable. Entrancing landscapes reminds me of paintings, a game of lights, strong yet soft colors that you probably dream about when listening to yes, a fable.The music is another turmoil of emotions that blows with the story, the hills, the water, the grasslands. It's the wind itself that lifts leaves and sighs, smiles and tension.Their own language doesn't need to be truly understood. You won't need to understand their words to bond with their footsteps and their story.I used the word "Fable" Because is what I truly saw and wanted to believe to when I played this game.As such then, it has a moral: how harsh is not life itself, but living.You'll see how places of sadness and slavery can't suffocate hope and love, you'll live while the past haunts you, growing over a guilt that shouldn't exist.You'll see how mischiefs and purity of a child, even when on a journey to save your father's life, wins against all odds.You'll see that the bright life of your village is a deep contrast to what lies behind its gates, among rivers of blood and vultures.And you'll understand that the only way through everything is to keep pushing forward: it doesn't matter if you are half of what you were when everything began. It doesn't matter if you were a bit spoiled; because life gives and pretends you to give her the same and a bit more, even if you don't smile anymore. Even if you're alone (Although you never are truly alone).

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												Before i start the review, I'll explain a little bit about my experience playing this game:I first played the first few minutes of this game at a friend's house. He got me interested in the game and a few days later i bought it when it was on sale. Because this game is about 2 brothers, i took the oppertunity to play this game with my little brother (10 years younger than me). We ended up finishing the entire game together, playing at the same time or occasionally taking turns when one of us was about to die of sleep deprivation. This game is meant to be single player, but you can technically make it a co-op if you share the controller. So grab your brother (or better yet, 2 misbehaving siblings you want to teach a lesson about taking turns and co-operating with one another) and start the game up!Regarding myself and the little brother i played it with, we're 10 years apart. I'm nearing my 20's and he's still in elementary school at the time of this review. I wouldn't reccomend playing this game with a younger brother whose uncomfortable with themes of death and darkness. If you decide to play with a younger brother who doesn't understand the concept of death yet or is slowly learning the concept of death, this game may be a good way to introduce them to those themes, but this game CAN GET DARK. The game has many themes of death and it's very much a coming of age story for both brothers. In the game you'll encounter dead bodies, scary graveyards, nature coming to life trying to kill you,  SPIDERS , and an NPC 'tempting his own fate' to put it lightly... So just use your own judgement regarding your experience with your little brother of choice. As for the adorable child i played with, he can tolerate most things and only flat out refused to play the game in one section because he witnessed some gore he wasn't expecting but easily shook that off and played with me again immediately after that section was over. We played the game up until the end, wtinessed the ending together and he is not psychologically scarred by it in any way. We only used a walkthrough ONE time and even after the game was over we jokingly call eachother what the Brothers call eachother in the game.Ok, now onto the review:Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is a puzzle/adventure game similar to the likes of ICO and Shadow of the Collasus for the PS2. The world Brothers takes place in is GORGEOUS to look at and feels incredibly massive but dangerous at the same time.  If you love RPGs and puzzles with huge worlds you'll love the way this one looks and feels. Unlike ICO and Shadow, the controls for brothers are extremely simple. You move with the analog sticks and interact with R2/L2. You can play solo controlling both titular brothers or grab any male sibling you get along with and each of you can share the controller, controlling 1 brother each. Both brothers are also very balanced. Big Brother (Maya?) is strong and tall but he doesn't jump very high or run as fast as Little Brother (Maii?), who is weaker and shorter but can jump higher. They can help eachother around the enviornment by picking eachother up, helping eachother up ladders, solve puzzles together in ways renimicent to ICO and Yorda and they're enjoyable to play as despite speaking a nonsense language (also very similar to the language spoken in ICO).The story: a simple fetch quest. The boys' father gets sick and they must retrieve an antidote from a tree hidden up in the mountains. And that's it. The story doesn't get more complex than that save for the fact their mother has died by drowning and Little Brother is also trauamtized by that event and unlike Big Brother, he can't swim. The game isn't so much about a story, it's more about a journey. The landscapes are beautiful and while wandering the world i couldn't help but want to know more about the lore of the world they're travelling through. It feels very Scandinavian in nature, what with all the giants, the beautiful snowscape, the water and the beautiful castles. I can't get over how wonderfult he game looks. At first glance, this looks like one of those games that'll look better than it actually is but in the case of Brothers, i say the looks are just a bonus for the journey. As for the journey is self, all the puzzles are solveable. If you play with a friend or a brother of your own, niether of you will get too frustrated. One thing that prevents me from buying most adventure/puzzle games is if the puzzles will be solveable. It's what makes or breaks a puzzle game. And thankfully despite the occasional camera wonky-ness all of the puzzles are solveable without a walkthrough. For myself and my brother, we only used a walkthrough for one puzzle we were confused on and after 10 minutes of testing theories we gave up and resorted to youtube. But other than that small experience, you could easily get through all the puzzles and they can all be solved without ripping your hair out trying to retrace your steps. Everything you need is always in the right place, where you need to go is always hinted at, you sometimes just need to look from a new perspective or look a little more carefully. For me at least, i enjoyed that the puzzles weren't too complex. If the puzzles are too complex that's usually the point where i give up on the game. And the puzzle layout is especially useful if you plan on playing with your younger brother.This is one of those rare occasions where i can say nothing bad about this game. Maybe 1 thing i can complain about the is the normal price which is 14.99, but i bought this game on sale and ended up getting is for around 3.75 (something like that) and completed the whole game in about 5/6 hours spanning a few different days because i was playing this with another person. Had i played the game solo, i likely would've finished it a lot faster. I'm one of those gamers who wants alot of gameplay for their money. Because i got this on sale i'd say i'm pretty lucky but the normal price may be a bit high if you value how many hours you'll get out of a game, but thankfully this game ain't 60 bucks, so 15 isn't that much of a bad price in my opinion.Yeah, i have ABSOLUTELY NOTHING BAD TO SAY. It's very surprising 0_0;This is just one of those games where you love the journey and can't see much bad about it.It was an especially good bonding experience playing this game with my own brother, as we discussed how different puzzles could be solved, helped eachother progress through the journey and occasionally have mom yell at us when we were yelling at the brothers on screen. I can't imagine playing this game alone save maybe for the occasion where you've already beaten the game and wanna play it for nostalgia, gawk at the beauty of the setting or just wanna get all the achievements. I wholly suggest playing this game with another person (especially a brother).I give Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons 10 sets of brothers out of 5!

												I simultaneously love and hate this game at the same time. Even with a controller, this game feels wonky as hell trying to control both brothers at the same time. And by the end of the game, I don't think my skills controlling them had gotten much better, either lol. That being said, there's something about the game that makes you want to keep playing. As the player, you want to see how the story progresses, and part of you just wants to see the what the next area will look like because this game is so damn pretty. You also feel invested in what's going on, and I think if I had to use one word to descibe this game, it would be 'feel'. The game does make you feel, and that's why I said I somewhat hated it. I wasn't expecting to feel anything. I thought I would just play the game to and be able to say that, "yeah, I played through it, it was a pretty cool story", and leave it at that. However, I got much more out of it than I anticipated. This game literally has no replayability, but that's ok. I feel like I got my money's worth. Overall, I give this game a solid recommendation. I went into it with quite a bit of skepticism, even with all of the positive reviews I've heard about it. The story and the ending are as good as everyone says they are, though.

												This game deserves every glowing review it has ever received. The quality of design here is absolutely mind-blowing. The character design, the voices, the 'script', the music and all of the ambient sounds and world design that bring this beautiful fantasy planet to life; everything is knitted together so tightly that you will fall in love with this game within the first 5 minutes.This is a short game, but it does more in 3 hours than most games can do in 10. content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
Product received for free
												Before I start to try to write a review, I want to give you two points that may give you a better approach to this game:1) It doesn't really need a controller. Keyboard works fine and, probably just for this game, is better than a controller.    You'll understand why, I'm sure of that. Basically, don't use the controller. 2) It is a short game, so I recommend you to buy it at 75% or 90% discount. Before you read (As my review could not appear as interesting nor helpful) Buy it, while keeping in mind those two points I wrote.Shall we start now?This game is enchanting. A fable. Entrancing landscapes reminds me of paintings, a game of lights, strong yet soft colors that you probably dream about when listening to yes, a fable.The music is another turmoil of emotions that blows with the story, the hills, the water, the grasslands. It's the wind itself that lifts leaves and sighs, smiles and tension.Their own language doesn't need to be truly understood. You won't need to understand their words to bond with their footsteps and their story.I used the word "Fable" Because is what I truly saw and wanted to believe to when I played this game.As such then, it has a moral: how harsh is not life itself, but living.You'll see how places of sadness and slavery can't suffocate hope and love, you'll live while the past haunts you, growing over a guilt that shouldn't exist.You'll see how mischiefs and purity of a child, even when on a journey to save your father's life, wins against all odds.You'll see that the bright life of your village is a deep contrast to what lies behind its gates, among rivers of blood and vultures.And you'll understand that the only way through everything is to keep pushing forward: it doesn't matter if you are half of what you were when everything began. It doesn't matter if you were a bit spoiled; because life gives and pretends you to give her the same and a bit more, even if you don't smile anymore. Even if you're alone (Although you never are truly alone).

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												One of the games which are about the experience, not challenge.Story has a simple premise and the gameplay is easy to handle which allows you to focus on the experience all the more, especially in the second half of the game (some parts near the end utilize the control mechanics in a way which adds a lot to the story - but I don't want to spoil it for you).Level design is one of the best in the last 5-10 years. There are some puzzles but they're all very easy and you shouldn't have trouble with any of them.The overall art style is stunning. Beautiful visuals (with many small events which happen in the background) and original score create a mesmerizing world which feels very much alive.The game is quite short (~3-3.5 hours) so you will not spend a lot of time with it (recommended for those with huge backlogs).Get it and play it, this game is definitely worth your money and time.Recommended input method: Gamepad all the way. Controlling each character with one half adds a lot of depth, especially later on. Vibration capability further more extends the experience.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Brothers is one of the most beautiful and elegant games I've played in a long time. The gameworld's stunning, expansive vistas hold equal measures of breathtaking views and clever puzzles, along with a dozen charming little moments of storytelling in each of the game's hidden achievements. The controls are a fascinatingly simple yet challenging ambidextrous controller configuration which manages to keep you strikingly engaged with what both of your characters are doing at any given moment. The story is short, sweet, and wonderfully crafted. The ending made me cry real human tears. This is a marvellous videogame, and it only takes about three hours out of your day to clear it. Pick it up when you've got the chance.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												As it stands right now, I was able to beat Brothers in less than 3 and a half hours. A game has to be REALLY REALLY good to be that short and still hold a reccomendation from me at a market price of 15 dollars, but yet here I am, with two thumbs up for this artistic masterpiece of a game. From a gameplay standpoint, Brothers is quite simple at the basic level - no puzzles were too advanced and the platforming is simple and doesn't require any button presses. Where the golden mechanic lies is the fact that you control the brothers simultaneously, a feat achieved by assigning a brother to one stick of a joypad (which is mandatory for play). While disorienting at first, eventually you pick up the pace and find it an enjoyable and innovative mechanic to work cooperatively with... yourself. Very ingenious. But where the game lacks in length and puzzles, it REEAAAALLLY picks up in atmosphere, visuals, and story. To begin, the story is just that two sons are finding a liquid that will restore their sick dad's health, by following a map. Yeah, not much there, but it's interesting in that the entire story is conveyed without a single line of dialouge, but rather with hand gestures and the context of the envrionment. What I find best about the atmosphere is that it is beautiful, one of the most beautiful platofrmers since Trine 2 (which I found really enticing). I found myself staring at the villages, dark forests, snowy mountaintops, and rainy rivers simply for their aesthetic value, not really for their gameplay. The atmosphere is only further enhanced by a somber and dramatic soundtrack, which always accomponies the narrative in a guiding way and really caps off the sad ending. Overall, I'd recomend it if you are in the mood for a short but magnificently beautiful work of art, perhaps one of the most mature video games on the market as we speak.

It is the sort of game you would play if you want an experience of beauty.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												After been hinted by it of Totalbiscuit, I decided to buy it last year. After seeing Totalbiscuit and [AReV]BavarianGod and having them already pointing out their arguments in their respected videos, I wondered if any review would be adding any additional insight. So after some thinking, I thought: lets discuss what the game did for me.To me, the game was a joyous experience, with a twist. Due to the tone of the game being about hefty themes like love, companionship and fear. The hefty themes suggest that the game wants to have those themes be taken very seriously, and for me it did, though not in the extend it happened to the previous mentioned people.One note should go to my favorite (and often overlooked) part of a game is sound: Though it forgoes the use of speech, Brothers does a damn fine job to fill up this gap by using gibberish talks, hand and feet communication and an awesome soundtrack (which you should buy btw) to provide the wholesale immersion.This game felt like a game again, not someone who has set some knobs regarding which few game mechanics should be in a game, press 'create' and voila: a triple-a title.No, this game seperates itself from that, in which it succeeds really well: its gameplay really let you immerse into the world, even though you're not seeing it from a first person view.All in all, I think that this game is for people who dare step off their beloved franchise game, try a single game and find this one.Ups:+ Good Narritive+ Heartfelt Story+ Unique Game mechanics+ SOUND!+ MUSIC!Downs:- Short Story- Difficulty

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is basically Ico, except you control both Ico and Yorda at the same time. It features similarly well-designed puzzles that utilize an impressively intuitive control scheme as you run through a world that manages to tell a completely wordless story.I haven’t tried to play this game with a keyboard but I probably wouldn’t recommended it. On a 360 pad you control each brother with one analog stick, and each trigger serves as an “interact” button for each of them. Through this, Brothers puts you through what is every bit the classic adventure game in the Ico, Another World, and Prince of Persia tradition.Each brother has different abilities -- the older brother is stronger and can swim but the younger brother can fit in smaller places. Through this, Brothers manages to give you puzzles that are surprisingly ingenious despite not being very complex. None of the puzzles took me more than a few seconds to work out, but at the same time none of them felt stupid. I’m still not sure how Starbreeze struck that balance. You can see a similar balance in the storyline.The game’s Sims-style gibberish manages to communicate that two brothers -- one in the midst of adolescence and the other reaching the end of childhood, must go on a quest to find a legendary medicine for their ailing father. There’s a lot of other interesting and well-told stuff in there as the brothers meet ever-wilder characters on their journey.Similar to Team Ico’s games, Brothers also takes you through environments that immediately feel like they have stories of their own, like the aftermath of a battlefield or the wake of a natural disaster. Furthermore, the game doesn’t even tell you the full story of what’s transpired in front of you, it just let’s you infer things.The art direction in Brothers serves all these environments and characters well despite it being quite modest in the technical area -- no fancy effects or anything and the system requirements don’t list any recommended settings, only minimum. Everything is in a sort of round, chunky aesthetic which seems to play to the Unreal 3 Engine’s strengths similarly to Gears of War 3.Brothers is a very tightly-put-together little adventure game that hits the hallmarks of what it’s probably trying to evoke: inspired fairy-tale locales, smart-but-intuitive gameplay, and an emotional storyline that doesn’t rely too much on cut scenes or any text, though the whole game will last you no more than three hours.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												It was famously said that "[y]ou'd be hard pressed to find 10 games better [than Brothers] this year" and it was lauded by some as the best game they’ve ever played but I went into Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons with a fair dose of scepticism.What started as a confusing system of solo cooperative play turned into a master class of environmental storytelling as I followed the titular brothers’ quest to find a cure for their stricken father. The journey that started in a quintessential village quickly gave way to the fantastical; each new area tells a story of its own through its presentation and together they are woven into the lore of this new world to explore.Not approaching the game as a puzzle or adventure game greatly enhances the experience. It felt more akin to an 3 hour epic. While it has some minor issues that I can’t mention without spoiling the game, I enjoyed the game overall and would highly recommend it. The last 30 minutes is when the magic happens.PS: play with a gamepad

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												If you're looking for a quick game to play, get Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons. It works best with a controller, but can be played with a keyboard. The gist of it is that you control two brothers simultaneously to solve puzzles and complete action sequences. It gets awfully clever on you, and there are only very minimal cues in the game. That is, it rarely tells you what buttons you need to press. In fact, you've only got the movement controls for each brother and a button to make each of them separately interact with stuff in the environment. There's dialogue but it's audible only in gibberish and only serves to convey character emotion and build on the personalities of the cast. Through the journey you come to know the characters by the quirky way you control them, i.e. you'll probably end up paying more attention to one brother, while the other larks off in some other direction (keeping track of two characters at once is deceptively difficult.) It's only a few hours long, but the price is right. It's almost criminal that during the last steam sale I was able to get it for something like $2.50. Normal price $15, it's actually on sale for $7.50 right now. Get it.

												7/10A very short interactive story unfolds as two brothers explore a linear landscape with a few scenic stopping points along the way.The various elements come together nicely - the world is well realised, the game wonderfully directed, and the storyline will surprise you. The puzzle/platforming gameplay is fairly sparse, so it rarely provides a gameplay challenge. This can be completed in 3 hours and doesn't have much replay value beyond achievement hunting or showing to friends. Pick it up during a sale one day as it's a nice change fom the norm.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												I dont know whether whimsical thumbstick adventure is a genre or a thing or whatever, but to say that Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is just that would be an injustice towards the title. Its minimalistic yet rich storytelling draws children of all ages in and while it offers little replay value and only lasts for an afternoon, it still qualifies as a gem. Lush, vibrant summits surround the two brothers gone on a quest to heal their father. The puzzles are pretty simplistic and the only initial difficulty will probably be struggling to teach your brain which thumb is which character, but the streamlined journey is less about overcoming challenges and more about watching the plot unfold.BUY it if you:- Own a controller- Value storytelling and polished art direction over all other aspects of a game - Would like an indie (alternative) structure with a high-end art direction.DO NOT BUY it if:- You expect long hours out of every dollar you spend on games.- You cannot abide a lack of replay value / violence / difficult puzzles- Your eyes may feel abused and slightly inflamed after exposure to Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons. This may especially be a problem if you wear contact lenses or big horse blinkers. Ask your video game dealer to suggest some less visually demanding entertainment immediately.

												This game... oh my god....I have cried out my heart soul and mind. I have never expirenced a game so emotional in my life. And I belive they did this so the player can focus more on the story. I would not reccomend this to people who have lost a family member unless your able to handel it. Cause the stuff thats on here is pretty touching. Other then that. This is a pretty extrodinary game and you should just buy it right now its well worth $15 bucks. Enjoy the ride!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Plot/setting: This game places you in the shoes of two brothers who take it upon themselves to find a cure for their father. This adventure will take them across a vast land filled with various kinds of fantasy characters and settings. The story and setting are absolutely the main attractions of this game. The plot  starts off as the run of the mill story, but once the game gets going you will run into some interesting situations that makes this game what it is. One gripe I had early on is that all of the characters speak in some sort of gibberish, and while the animations of the characters convey their feelings adequately it can feel like you are missing out. That said the lack of actual dialogue grew on me and I actually prefer it.Gameplay/constrols: This game is unique as you control both brothers using a stick and bumper button for each brother. This is the reason a controller is highly recommended for playing. I did not try using KB and mouse so I cannot compare, but I imagine it is difficult. For the most part the control scheme works with only the occasional mixup in my coordination of controlling the brothers. The game is filled with puzzles that consist of one borther using one strength to do one task like fitting through small areas and the other brother pulling big heavy levers. There are also some puzzles and platforming aspects that require both brothers to work together. Overall the puzzles will not be challenging at all, but they are entertaining nonetheless.Length/replayability: This game is very short and only clocks in at around 3 hours. There are no sidequests, only little interactions with the world you can have; most of which are acheivements. Once you have completed the game and got all of te acheivements though there will be no reason to replay this game for a long time.Overall: The price of $15 for this game is steep considering it's length, but despite that I absolutely recommened this game especially if it is on sale.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												"Brothers" is a beautiful game with a simple story. Their dad fell sick, and the two brothers were told that the water from a fountain far away could save him. And that's how their adventure begins.Both brothers have different personalities, which you can see for yourself when you interact with the both of them.The scenaries are beautiful. Every so often, there's a bench that the brothers can sit and take a minute to absorb the breath-taking view before them.The brothers help and get help from creatures they met on their adventures too.Would recommend this game to everyone.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Brothers is one of the most beautiful and elegant games I've played in a long time. The gameworld's stunning, expansive vistas hold equal measures of breathtaking views and clever puzzles, along with a dozen charming little moments of storytelling in each of the game's hidden achievements. The controls are a fascinatingly simple yet challenging ambidextrous controller configuration which manages to keep you strikingly engaged with what both of your characters are doing at any given moment. The story is short, sweet, and wonderfully crafted. The ending made me cry real human tears. This is a marvellous videogame, and it only takes about three hours out of your day to clear it. Pick it up when you've got the chance.

												I was extremely surprised as to just how much I would like this game. Ever since it was released I was interested in getting it, now that I have it I don't regret it in the slightest. It's not extremely difficult to play, the controls kind of take some time to get use to. I would HIGHLY recommend using a controller for this game. You have to control both characters the big brother with the left analog stick/left trigger and the younger brother with the right analog/right trigger. The way you control the two characters to get through the puzzles gradually gets more... intricate. It is a pretty entertaining game. Usually when I start off playing a new game like this I only play it to try it out but I started it and haven't put it down yet. The graphics aren't bad at all and i find myself enjoying the scenery. They speak... sim type language.. so you kind of have to interpret whats going on but its not too difficult to figure out. I'm not sure if I would have liked more dialog in this game or not, probably not. I think it would subtract from the actual experience of the game. If you haven't played this game and have even the slightest interest in trying it out, I would highly suggest you do so.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												I don't speak Swedish, but without understanding a word, Brothers left me with lingering emotions long after I completed the game. Brothers is mechanically simple - the puzzles aren't very difficult and there aren't any complex gimmicks. The story is straightforward and progresses at an easy pace. The primary reason for playing this game is the story anyway. It's more than just the plot, I think, that made the largest impact on me and made it stick. The little details peppered throughout the levels tell stories on their own (i.e. complete the achievements!). The landscapes are utterly gorgeous (reminds me of The Lord of the Rings, actually), and vivid as well. It's a game worth playing but don't expect to just casually burn through it like any other - this is one to savor for the details and the storytelling. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												A beautiful platformer.Brothers- A Tale of two sons is a 3D platformer developed by starbreeze studios. The story is simple, yet it is conveyed perfectly. You play as two brothers who are tasked to retrieve some medicine for their sick dying father. In order to do so, they will have to cross giant bridges, bloody graveyards, giant oceans and meet a variety of colourful characters. Through out the story you will feel a variety of emotions including joy, happiness, wonder, fear, amazement and sadness. There is no voice acting in the game, and honestly there doesn't need to be as you can understand what the characters are saying through their actions. The game will last you 3 hours or a bit more if you want to collect all achievements and explore a bit. There isn't much replayability to be had here.Gameplay revolves around a mix between platforming and puzzle solving. Bearing in mind that you NEED A CONTROLLER to play this game, the controls are quite good. You control the movement of one brother with the left analogue stick and another with the right stick. It might seem tricky at first, trying to control both the brothers at the same time, but after a while you will get the hang of it.The graphics are cartoony and good to look at. The lighting does a great job at making the colours more attractive to the eye. There are also p[enty of scenes that look so good that you want to take  screenshot of as well.I highly recommend this game to people you want to a rememberable adventure with a few platforming and puzzles thrown in.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												*me screaming at game* HOW COULD YOU DO THIS TO ME?*ahem*Okay, let me give this game a more satisfactory review.(Mild spoilers below)When I was a film student in college, my film professor loved hammering in this idea to his students: sound is everything. And lack thereof. He prefers silent films for this reason: visual storytelling should not rely on sound to create the story. Sound should be a suppliment to that story, not a crutch. And, when done right, the right sound effects in the right place can drastically heighten emotional impact.Good sound design is one of those things that often goes unnoticed in film and game critique. And Brothers has good sound design. The lack of understandable dialogue actually makes the story better because it forces us to discern the story from simple action alone. Oftentimes I found myself rationalizing the actions of the brothers and other NPCs by determining their emotions from their actions. Such as the crying forest giant- context allowed me to discern that someone he loved was gone. That was just one example of many I found myself thinking as I played the game. Don't give your audience 4: give them 2+2. Let them figure it out. That's why this game doesn't need dialogue.The music only has a discernable melody and composition when in emotionally intense situations. Otherwise, it is atmospheric, indecipherable sounds. This is effective because if a musician relies too much on bombarding our senses with fantastic melodies at all times, we will not be able to appreciate a moment when it truly calls for some riveting emotions. So, when you're just wandering the land, accomplishing small tasks, the music remains quiet, pensive, and ambient. When something big is going on... it's spine-chilling. Contrast is everything!The sound effects are immersive because they draw from the environment, and you can often hear things coming before you see them. This is effective because when you are traveling around in real life, out in the woods or even on city streets, oftentimes you will hear things before you see them coming. This is something we have tended to take for granted, but you can tell this was intentionally designed in the game.Of course, the art direction was gorgeous. I especially love the fact that the characters are not rendered in an attempt for photorealism like many triple A titles these days. You simply don't need that. Stylized, abstracted forms are more pleasing to the eye IMO. Attempting photorealistic characters in a video game is just too uncanny valley for my tastes. The *colors*, man. The light and shadows. The composition. It's a visual masterpiece. And the ending. I don't have to explain why it's so chilling and amazing. What are you waiting for... buy this game!

												Brothers- A Tale of Two Sons is a beautifully crafted journey of Naiee (Little brother) and Naia (Elder brother) to find a cure to their fathers disease. Even without understanding anything that the people say, the emotions and situations are greatly expressed thru the brothers reaction, music and visuals. It was an amazing experience to play and share it.9/10

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												This game felt very complete to me. It was not particularly complex in any of its aspects, the individual challenges were very straightforward, the music was appropriate yet inconspicuous, and the dialogue (intentionally unintelligible) was also consciously, and sparingly included, but all of the aspects were synthesized perfectly. I was quite impressed with both the art and the controls, but more than anything, this game is about the story and the emotional connection to the characters. This game focuses on experiences that everyone has experienced and is concerned with expressing those experiences honestly, rather than ideally. I have to say it is one of my games of the year (though I probably play fewer games than many) and I highly recommend it to everyone.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												This game. This game is one of my all-time favorites.  Not only does it have breathtaking artwork and scenery, flawless character design, and quirky humor, but it also has moments that inspire sheer wonder. One moment you're flying on the back of a gryphon, another you're reuniting trolls, but all the while the game makes you feel as if you truly are a part of the experience. I often found myself talking to Big Brother and Little Brother as if I was both of them in one being; when one was in trouble, I assumed the role of the other. The game pulled my hopes so far up that I truly thought nothing could go wrong. I won't spoil any endings, but having just completed this game moments ago I find myself unable to function. This was the first time that I ended a game crying. This game is very truly a 10/10.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Plot/setting: This game places you in the shoes of two brothers who take it upon themselves to find a cure for their father. This adventure will take them across a vast land filled with various kinds of fantasy characters and settings. The story and setting are absolutely the main attractions of this game. The plot  starts off as the run of the mill story, but once the game gets going you will run into some interesting situations that makes this game what it is. One gripe I had early on is that all of the characters speak in some sort of gibberish, and while the animations of the characters convey their feelings adequately it can feel like you are missing out. That said the lack of actual dialogue grew on me and I actually prefer it.Gameplay/constrols: This game is unique as you control both brothers using a stick and bumper button for each brother. This is the reason a controller is highly recommended for playing. I did not try using KB and mouse so I cannot compare, but I imagine it is difficult. For the most part the control scheme works with only the occasional mixup in my coordination of controlling the brothers. The game is filled with puzzles that consist of one borther using one strength to do one task like fitting through small areas and the other brother pulling big heavy levers. There are also some puzzles and platforming aspects that require both brothers to work together. Overall the puzzles will not be challenging at all, but they are entertaining nonetheless.Length/replayability: This game is very short and only clocks in at around 3 hours. There are no sidequests, only little interactions with the world you can have; most of which are acheivements. Once you have completed the game and got all of te acheivements though there will be no reason to replay this game for a long time.Overall: The price of $15 for this game is steep considering it's length, but despite that I absolutely recommened this game especially if it is on sale.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												I recommend that you subject yourself to this game, because its like come along once in a very long time, and usually on consoles.Visually stunning and with a soundtrack that is perfectly pitched to compliment those visuals, Brothers is an amazing game from a purely technical perspective. That doesn't really matter however.Brothers is an amazing tale, conveyed almost without words in a way reminiscent of Ico and Shadow of the Colossus. The charazterization of the characters is also in itself simple, but strong. You will love these brothers and sympathize with their struggle just as you'll stand amazed at the detail and imagination invested into this fictional world, and that's part of the tragedy. The game KNOWS what you think it is. It knows what you expect. It's masterfully directed and built to get you emotionally invested in its story.Saying any more than that would spoil the surprises you'll have along the way, but fair warning: the game is not a happy-go-lucky fairy tale and it will shock you, scare you and ultimately make you cry your soul out.10/10.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												A nice looking platformer. Pretty landscapes. Colourful graphics. Might get the kids to play it. That's what I thought when I saw this game. I was wrong. Yes, this game looks fantastic and plays well. Some beautiful landscapes and scenery. But this game is DARK! I mean that in a good way, but don't let the cutesy look of it fool you. I was pleasantly suprised. It's a brilliantly realised fantasy world (that I hope Starbreeze will visit again). The game mechanic of controlling 2 characters at once is challenging enough and doesn't get cumbersome. The game is a nice length, a lot of fun to play, and the story has heart. It really doesn't pull any punches. Only downside is the PC version seems to be very glitchy. I had to restart a couple of chapters to get around potentially game-breaking bugs. But I think only a minority of people have had these issues. This game is well worth investing a few hours in.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Wow, was not expecting that! I picked this up in a sale for $3 and even though its short the experience is easily worth $20. I finished it in 3.3 hours but was captivated from the start until the end. The art style is absolutely gorgeous and at certain points in the game there are benches where you can sit and just look at the beautiful vistas and usually get an overview of where you'll be heading next.With a control scheme that works perfectly there's no need for any HUD elements so you can totally immerse yourself in the game. Auto-save system worked well. The puzzles aren't going to strain your brain but they're fun enough to work out. Controller rumble effects are used sparingly and are saved for moments that suit the effect.Sound effects are decent and the musical score fits well to enhance what's happening in the game at any moment. I think the decision to have the dialogue is in what I assume is a made up tongue actually benefits the story as everything else comes together so well that you know what they're saying even though you don't know what they're saying.Solid 9/10Note: A controller is not technically required but playing on keyboard is a much lesser experience. Basically, if you already have a controller; buy this game.If you don't have a controller, buy one, then buy this game.

Posted: December 29, 2013
												This game had a lot to live up to - if it's near perfect reviews weren't enough, the fact that it'd touch on such a personal and subjective experience as brotherhood left me doubting that it could live up to it's name.The core of the game revolves around two brothers, that set out in search for an elixer that will save their father from a deadly illness. While this seems like a rather weak call to action, the world really is so beautiful that you won't care. A playthrough lasts about three hours, and the story really flourishes in the second half of the game, once you've had time to get your head around the mechanics.The brothers are unique and lovingly crafted, each with his own personality and flaws. And the world itself cuts no corners; reminiscient of the beautiful (and sometimes dark) lands of fairy tales that we grew up with.If you're on the fence, don't be. It's one of the best three hour experiences that you can have for under five dollars. Buy this now and play it through like a movie. You definitely won't regret it.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2013
												Buy? Likely. I was convinced to buy this game thanks to TotalBiscuit - I didn't know this game existed until I saw his video. Is this a great showpiece of gaming that made me cry? Honestly, no. I didn't cry. Whether that's the fault of the game or if I'm too emotionally unresponsive is impossible for me to answer, but you do have a good story based puzzler with a clever mechanic of controlling two characters with a separate analogue stick and trigger. I don't think that the tale alone of a random father who is on his deathbed thanks to an undescribed condition as well as the ending is enough to make me cry - gaming has desensitized me to death.There is some gameplay contrivance, such as why is there a funky, switch activated bridge just to get to one family's house? Puzzles are cleverly implemented in my opinion, but all are simple to solved - you'll rarely if ever be stumped. This game has plenty of photogenic moments as shown by my screenshot library, and this can be completed by most around 3 hours. It's arguably pretentious, but I don't think it's trying to force some abstract artistic or literary vision.Brothers - AToTS looks like something Pixar could do if they weren't limited to doing purely "Disney friendly" content. I enjoyed the game, but I was not as moved as many people said - I will no longer let people's fawning over a story experience influence my buying habits.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												Brothers is a perfect example of where I think video games should be going. More than anything else, I am incredibly impressed by Brothers' ability to integrate gameplay mechanics and storytelling in such a way that each complement each other. The thing is, despite video games being an interactive medium, few games seem to take full advantage of this fact. I've played games with great mechanics. I've also played games with great stories.  Hell, I've even played games with both great mechanics and great stories. But Brothers is even more than that. What this game manages to do is give emotional weight to gameplay mechanics. By doing this, Brothers takes full advantage of the agency of the player, deepening the emotional bonds produced over a relatively short few hours. I hope developers take a close look at this game.

												This game had a lot to live up to - if it's near perfect reviews weren't enough, the fact that it'd touch on such a personal and subjective experience as brotherhood left me doubting that it could live up to it's name.The core of the game revolves around two brothers, that set out in search for an elixer that will save their father from a deadly illness. While this seems like a rather weak call to action, the world really is so beautiful that you won't care. A playthrough lasts about three hours, and the story really flourishes in the second half of the game, once you've had time to get your head around the mechanics.The brothers are unique and lovingly crafted, each with his own personality and flaws. And the world itself cuts no corners; reminiscient of the beautiful (and sometimes dark) lands of fairy tales that we grew up with.If you're on the fence, don't be. It's one of the best three hour experiences that you can have for under five dollars. Buy this now and play it through like a movie. You definitely won't regret it.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												This game is wonderful. The graphic style is outstanding leading to some truly beautiful in game areas. The gameplay is a relatively easy puzzle platformer style, but controlling one brother with each of the controller joysticks makes for a bit of a learning curve. The narrative tugs at your heartstrings throughout even though the characters don't speak an understandable language. It is a short game, coming in at around 3 hours. As such I would recommend getting it on sale, but I would absolutely recommend giving it a try.

Posted: December 6, 2013
												Without a doubt the most beautiful and touching game that I've ever played. I've never smiled so much while playing a game and I've never cried so much while playing a game. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												If you're reading this, do yourself a favor and just buy Brothers - A tale of Two Sons right now.Brothers, for lack of a better term, is a masterpiece IMHO. Somehow, Brothers delivers an emotional, compassionate story, without a single word of dialogue in the whole game. Charcaters do speak, but their language is Simmilar to Simlish (The Sims) I suppose. Although you cannot understand the language, You will still understand what is going on. You will have to prepare yourself for many emotions throughout the game. I will list a few I've experienced: Sadness, joy, wonder, curiousity, horror, excitement, and despair. Sounds a bit over the top? Well go see for yourself. You may experience emotions you never new existed.Brothers perfectly marries Story with Game Mechanics. The best way i can explain it is that you play the story. Again, for lack of a better term, Brothers is a Singleplayer Co-op game. If you were not aware, You control two Brothers independently using the joysicks of your controller (Provided you use a controller). Contrary to the Notice above, The game will work with a keyboard, But I would not recommend it. Seperately controlling the two siblings, you traverse the game working together. I would not classify Brothers as a Puzzle Platformer, however. It's simply a journey. Which brings me to the final point.Brothers took me roughly 3 hours to complete. I would say there is some replayability, but thats only because there are achievements you will miss and areas you may have skipped. So maybe 5 - 6 hours will be all you get out of Brothers, unless you play through games several times. I know that so few hours may not warrant the price for some people, but I promise you'll remember this game for as long as you live. I know I will.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												A really great game that speaks it's story brilliantly.Not a single word is spoken through all of it yet it still gets it's message out better than any game I've played so far.Thw controls may feel a bit wonky at times but the two brothers are never too hard to handle and you get used to it quickly as they made it really well.It works for keyboard but the story is actually enhanced through use of a controller at times so it is the best control method for this game.You will learn to love the brothers, and your trigger buttons, as the story progresses.Easily Game of the Year and a moving and memorable piece of gaming art.

												Play this game.  Do it.  It will cost you about as much as a movie and you'll have a much more meaningful experience.  The story affects you in such a way that, despite never understanding a word spoken in the game, it is nearly impossible to avoid a deep connection with the story and its players.  The highs are rollicking and fun, the lows shred your emotions, and in the end a very simple game mechanic can both break your heart and give you chills at the same time.Play this game.

The rest of the sound settings however, are nothing short of amazing and really accompanies the visual settings that is what together makes this journey so special.It is a rather short game, around 3 hours for me. But I absolutely love this, the fact that it is not longer makes sure that it doesn't feel like it's dragging out. And as a parent with somewhat limited play time I have a chance to play it through in a sit down or two.4/5

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												This is a coming of age tale where two brothers embark on an epic journey to retrieve medicine to save their dying father.The game play is unique because you control both brothers at the same time.  For this reason, the game requires a gamepad an cannot be played with a mouse and keyboard.  Each brother is controlled by an alalog stick and each brother has an action movement that is controlled by a trigger.   It takes a little getting used to controlling two characters with one controller, but since the game play is pretty simple, it's not too difficult to pick up.   The visuals in this game are beautiful and the story is captivating.  And most importantly, the game is fun.Overall, this was a great game and I highly recommend it.  My only complaint is that it's pretty short.  I beat it in about 3 hours.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Wow. This game... just wow.Brothers was an absolute joy to play. The largest reason being that Brothers is extremely immersive, connecting the player to the game better than almost any other game I have played. This can be attributed to the unique "single-player co-op" mechanic whereby the player uses a single controller to control two in game players. Just as the controller cannot be ripped in part at will, nor can these Brothers. As a player you are connected to the brothers immediately and that connection only becomes stronger over the next two an a half hours as you travel the stunningly beautiful lands, solving puzzles, meeting other creatures, and exploring the world, all in search for the elixir to save your ill father.While the game is short, and the gameplay is very easy, Brothers as an overall experience is beautiful, immersive, heart-wrenching, and pleasurable. I highly recommend this game, it is fantastic.Pros:• Well written and rich story. • Simple, elegant presentation.• Stunning visuals.• Extremely immersive controls.Cons:• Graphical fidelity suffers at points, mainly close ups.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Though people are no longer with us, that does not mean that they are gone forever. We do not need to have the person next to us to have them influence us. And this game portrays that idea perfectly. It is a simple story of two brothers and their journey together to help find a cure for their father. You control one brother with the left thumbstick and the other brother with the right thumbstick. And throughout the journey, they have to rely on each other to get past certain obstacles. The story is very moving and portrays life and death in an interesting way through its cutscenes. The game is not all doom and gloom though. There are many beautiful moments that depict the beauty of life, whether you're stopping a man from committing suicide or reuniting a mother turtle with its children. Although those are optional tasks, it is left to the player to make those decisions and make this tough journey bearable.The game can get a little glitchy from time to time but it left such an impact on me that the negatives did not bother me so much. It is a fairly short game but this is definitely something that is going to stick with you.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I have seen and read reviews about this game that give credit to how this game uses the controller in a ingenious way but I have been, for some reason, sceptical about how a controller could be used in a "ingenious way" in a game. Now, after completing the game, I understood what they meant and I can only agree. Without saying too much I must at least say that this is one of the most cleverest ways to actually make the controller a part of the game and it's story to the point where it made an emotional impact on me.Although I got to admit that the controls can be confusing for the brain at times but it only caused me problem at one point in the game.In short: Brilliant use of the controller, touching story and beautiful landscapes to visually explore.Highly recommending buying this for a 3-4 hour experience.

												This game is completely amazing. Don't read or watch anything about it, just set aside 3 hours and play through the whole thing. The controls remain somewhat difficult throughout since you use each thumbstick to control a different person (you need a 360 controller) but that should not get in the way of playing through this fantastic game. The music, story, art, and gameplay (even with control difficulties) are all superb, unique, and beautiful. Gameplay is mostly simple to moderate platforming puzzles with unique twists throughout. Nothing is given time to get old or repetitive due to great variety to gameplay and scenery, and the relatively short length. Just play it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2013
												An incredibly powerful short story about 2 brothers on a quest through a dangerous and fantastic land to find a magic water with healing powers that can save their dying father.The mechanics play just as big a part in the story as the story itself.The design is nothing short of masterful. Every new puzzle is simple yet never easy and always rewarding to complete. Challenges are explained without the use of specific audio or textual direction; only pantomime and vocal tones without the use of a dechiperable language. I do think I knew the brothers' names by the end of the story, only because throughout the game each brother calls out to the other ever so often, each always repeating a specific word (similar to how you as a player come to grasp the name of the hero's horse in Shadow of the Colossus). Every dangerous situation with a new puzzle mechanic had always already been taught to the player in a safe sandbox area so that they are always prepared for when a situation called to re-use that mechanic in an unsafe part of the world. Never was anything similar to what you might call a "modern tutorial" was ever needed.One particular moment near the end of the game must be recognized. In this moment, the designers pull off one of the most amazing feats of creative direction I've ever seen. There is a very specific set of challenges with an ostensibly new mechanic that is not explicitly explained in the ways most of the previous ones have been... but the designers know from your experiences in the game, you will naturally try to solve it in a very specific way. To "count on" a player to not only figure something like this out but to also grasp WHY they made this decision usually is a bad idea or requires a tutorial or some sort of cookie to let you know why some choice was made, but in this specific instance, the magic moment you understand what was trying to be done would have been shattered if you were not given the chance to figure it out yourself.This might sound a bit confusing, but that moment, even if you aren't worried about spoilers, is indeed a hard moment to explain. I hate to refer to a specific trope often used for hyperbole, but the only comparison I can think of in a similar medium is that of trying to explain what "The Matrix" is. No one can show you what it is, you just have to see and experience it for yourself to understand it. That near-end game scene in Brothers is like that. Someone explaining it to you won't impact you the same as experiencing it.To those planning on playing this masterpiece, do NOT read anything about this game's story or watch any playthroughs. The game will always challenge you to think, but will never prove frustrating. And the best part of it is discovering the answers to the questions it asks you on your own. Looking up anything on it will surely lessen your experience. The achievements should be discovered and completed naturally as you play. I recommend holding off trying to follow any walkthroughs or guides in an effort to conquer every single one of the game's hidden side quests until after you complete the game at least once.Speaking as someone who has an older half-brother, and a younger brother, if you have any siblings, you need to play this. You will be moved beyond words.Oh, and buyers who tend to collect and not play, don't let this sit on your "wall of shame" either. It's really short. Only about 3 hours to complete. Set aside a few hours and do it all in 1 or 2 sittings. It is an important game that marks a point in gaming history when designers were able to evoke a feeling in a way that no other medium could do. Other designers will be talking about and trying to understand and mimic this perfect execution of this moment for years to come.If this still isn't enough to convince you to buy the game, then listen to a much bigger game critic celebrity, TotalBiscuit, call the game "the best game I've ever played in 25 years."

The music, story, art, and gameplay (even with control difficulties) are all superb, unique, and beautiful. Gameplay is mostly simple to moderate platforming puzzles with unique twists throughout. Nothing is given time to get old or repetitive due to great variety to gameplay and scenery, and the relatively short length. Just play it.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Wow. This game... just wow.Brothers was an absolute joy to play. The largest reason being that Brothers is extremely immersive, connecting the player to the game better than almost any other game I have played. This can be attributed to the unique "single-player co-op" mechanic whereby the player uses a single controller to control two in game players. Just as the controller cannot be ripped in part at will, nor can these Brothers. As a player you are connected to the brothers immediately and that connection only becomes stronger over the next two an a half hours as you travel the stunningly beautiful lands, solving puzzles, meeting other creatures, and exploring the world, all in search for the elixir to save your ill father.While the game is short, and the gameplay is very easy, Brothers as an overall experience is beautiful, immersive, heart-wrenching, and pleasurable. I highly recommend this game, it is fantastic.Pros:• Well written and rich story. • Simple, elegant presentation.• Stunning visuals.• Extremely immersive controls.Cons:• Graphical fidelity suffers at points, mainly close ups.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												A nice looking platformer. Pretty landscapes. Colourful graphics. Might get the kids to play it. That's what I thought when I saw this game. I was wrong. Yes, this game looks fantastic and plays well. Some beautiful landscapes and scenery. But this game is DARK! I mean that in a good way, but don't let the cutesy look of it fool you. I was pleasantly suprised. It's a brilliantly realised fantasy world (that I hope Starbreeze will visit again). The game mechanic of controlling 2 characters at once is challenging enough and doesn't get cumbersome. The game is a nice length, a lot of fun to play, and the story has heart. It really doesn't pull any punches. Only downside is the PC version seems to be very glitchy. I had to restart a couple of chapters to get around potentially game-breaking bugs. But I think only a minority of people have had these issues. This game is well worth investing a few hours in.
