content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												To be honest, the first thing that caught my eye was the ability to control two characters at a time. Then after I got the game, I started the game and I have to say the atmosphere and surroundings are simply beautiful accompanied by soothing background music which is relaxing to my ears. There are bits of puzzles here and there to solve as you proceed with the story and fun part sometimes you get to do some mischieve with the little brother, for instance breaking someone's flower pot, ruining someone's garden or ruining a kid's day by throwing her ball away somewhere he/she can't reach. Its fun to be mischievious once in a while~ Although I don't do it IRL but sometimes I am pretty sure I am not the only one who thinks about doing these once in a while >:]Anyways, a short bit about controls. The controls are simple, just movements and one button to interact, BUT it might take a little time to get used to since you are using 2 characters SIMULTANEOUSLY to solve puzzle etc etc. It is not a must to use a controller but you really should as recommended on steam as  it makes controlling a whole lot easier (I tried on the keyboard first, even though its doable its rather hard and unnatural(?) on the fingers). The controls are simple but might take a little time to adapt to but once you get used to it its pretty cool.There's only one problem I have with this game, I can't understand a single word they are saying cause there are no options for subtitles. Still it doesn't change the fact that this is a really good game and you can interpret what they are saying quite easily.If you are someone like me who enjoy games with good atmostpheres, good background music, and a nice steady paced story/plot, this is a game I will recommend to you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Wow, was not expecting that! I picked this up in a sale for $3 and even though its short the experience is easily worth $20. I finished it in 3.3 hours but was captivated from the start until the end. The art style is absolutely gorgeous and at certain points in the game there are benches where you can sit and just look at the beautiful vistas and usually get an overview of where you'll be heading next.With a control scheme that works perfectly there's no need for any HUD elements so you can totally immerse yourself in the game. Auto-save system worked well. The puzzles aren't going to strain your brain but they're fun enough to work out. Controller rumble effects are used sparingly and are saved for moments that suit the effect.Sound effects are decent and the musical score fits well to enhance what's happening in the game at any moment. I think the decision to have the dialogue is in what I assume is a made up tongue actually benefits the story as everything else comes together so well that you know what they're saying even though you don't know what they're saying.Solid 9/10Note: A controller is not technically required but playing on keyboard is a much lesser experience. Basically, if you already have a controller; buy this game.If you don't have a controller, buy one, then buy this game.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
A game, so masterfully crafted, it's breathtaking;Brothers: A tale of two sons puts you in the shoes of two young brothers (hence the name of the game), trying to help their father by finding a cure.You venture out into the mysterious and strange lands, populated by creatures you'd not expect to exist.Brothers is a game made solely for the purpose of telling a good, interesting story, which would be more than good enough to sell as a book.The artwork and music are both ingenius and although the visuals may be outdated, they immerse you anyways.At this point I'd like to point out the following things:This game is ONLY playable via a compatible controller!The visuals are not top notch, please view ingame-screenshots or watch a short video to see, if you're okay with that!The story is VERY short. If you calculate achievement hunting into the mix, you'll barely scratch the 3 hour mark!If you can look past all that, I'd say, that you should go pick it up. Otherwise I'd advise to wait for the game to be in sale!I hope you found my review helpful and that it aided you deciding, wether or not to buy this product!

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												I held off playing this game for a long time because it claims to require a controller, which I can't stand using most of the time, and because it was published by 505, who published Payday 2 and How to Survive - neither of which I enjoyed.  This game was quite the pleasant surprise, though.  First off, a controller is not required; using a keyboard can be a bit awkward at times, but will work just fine.  Second, unlike How to Survive, there were no game-breaking bugs, meaning I actually got to finish the game, and I'm glad for it.  This was an amazingly innovative platformer with beautiful artistic design and a well-told story.  It's brief, but it doesn't need to be any longer than it is - in fact, trying to stretch things out to pad the length would have hurt the overall experience.  The puzzles aren't too complicated, and are all very logical - the challenge comes in controlling 2 characters at the same time, who need to work together to solve the puzzle.  It's one thing to play a game like Portal 2, where you and a friend have to work together, but having to work both brothers at once takes some getting used to.  It's a completely unique mechanic I don't recall ever seeing before now, and it was a fascinating way to play the game.  The entire story is told without a single line of dialog - there is a language being spoken, but it's gibberish and you're not meant to understand it.  Everything is conveyed via gesture and inflection, the mood is set through the music, and it's all done very well.  It helps that the story is very simple and straigtforward - this game is about the journey, the bonding and the loss, and the spectacle of it all, and to that end it was very well crafted.  I'd say it's definitely worth a playthrough.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												This was a fairly enjoyable game.The story is nice and simplistic.The speech is mainly random gibberish but the actions makes what their saying obvious and the characters are actually portrayed quite well and there is even a little bit of character development.The gameplay and controls is interesting and original, although it is ultimately very simple.I think what really makes the game shine is the story telling and the world itself. They had pretty good ideas for the world and the atmosphere changed really well with the music, background details and other things.You go through each area relatively quickly though and it almost feels like just a snapshot of what could have been,At the end I couldn't help but feel this entire game was simply a prologue for a bigger game.  You can see how the little brother develops and becomes stronger both physically and mentally after his elder brother's death, and I sortof thought this game would work as a good prologue story for a story where the little brother grows up to be a hero or something. This is all just personal opinion and has nothing to do with what the developer intended. Ultimately, its a very simple but beautifully made game with alot of heart put into it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												Brothers is a perfect example of where I think video games should be going. More than anything else, I am incredibly impressed by Brothers' ability to integrate gameplay mechanics and storytelling in such a way that each complement each other. The thing is, despite video games being an interactive medium, few games seem to take full advantage of this fact. I've played games with great mechanics. I've also played games with great stories.  Hell, I've even played games with both great mechanics and great stories. But Brothers is even more than that. What this game manages to do is give emotional weight to gameplay mechanics. By doing this, Brothers takes full advantage of the agency of the player, deepening the emotional bonds produced over a relatively short few hours. I hope developers take a close look at this game.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2013
												Modern videogames struggle with the idea of marrying gameplay to narrative. More often than not, modern game stories end up feeling very detached from the core gameplay elements, making the overall experience feel unbalanced. Brothers manages to avoid this pitfall, leading by example and making its control scheme an  entirely integral piece of the overall narrative. Rarely does Brothers ever rip control away from the player for a flashy cutscene. You're free to experience the game's world, full of breath takingly beautiful and surreal sights and positively gorgeous musical cues, at your own pace. The size and scope of Brothers' adventure is astonishing in and of itself. There's an honest sense of childlike wonder and fairy tale adventure seeping out of every locale and setpiece the game offers, and you're often encouraged to take your time and let the world and characters around you breathe, as evidenced by all the game's achievements being tied to simply exploring the world. Without ever saying a comprehendable word in any language at all, Brothers is able to communicate all it needs to the player without ever resorting to dialog boxes or tutorials. The world around you and characters' interactions with one another always provides enough context for you to know what's going on or what you need to do next. As trite and silly as it may seem to say, Brothers is one of the truest examples of how to create expressive and emotionally engaging interactive fiction without sacrificing either side of the equation. Wholeheartedly recommended.

One of the most touching games out there.One of the most beautiful,touching and relaxing video games out there.Brothers-A Tale of Two Sons is a co-op adventure game wich is played by a single person,simultaneously controlling the two characters.The game itself is not very long,but it's totally worth it.Here are the things I liked the most about the game.The visual style is very appealing and colourful.Great soundtrack and little bit of humor.A story that is not complicated at all,but will leave you sad for eternity. :DThe two characters have different skills wich you often have to combine to traverse trough the level.Puzzles wich are hardly challengeing,but fun to solveFive or six environments through wich you travel,all very different than the previous one.Although the controls are not very bad on keyboard I strongly recommend playing with a controller,your expirience will be much better.These are the things I liked the most.The game is fantastic and although small,I'll always remember it as one of the best games I've played.

Posted: July 7, 2016
												This was a fairly enjoyable game.The story is nice and simplistic.The speech is mainly random gibberish but the actions makes what their saying obvious and the characters are actually portrayed quite well and there is even a little bit of character development.The gameplay and controls is interesting and original, although it is ultimately very simple.I think what really makes the game shine is the story telling and the world itself. They had pretty good ideas for the world and the atmosphere changed really well with the music, background details and other things.You go through each area relatively quickly though and it almost feels like just a snapshot of what could have been,At the end I couldn't help but feel this entire game was simply a prologue for a bigger game.  You can see how the little brother develops and becomes stronger both physically and mentally after his elder brother's death, and I sortof thought this game would work as a good prologue story for a story where the little brother grows up to be a hero or something. This is all just personal opinion and has nothing to do with what the developer intended. Ultimately, its a very simple but beautifully made game with alot of heart put into it.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												The good:*  The gameplay is innovative.  Controlling both characters is neat.*  The puzzles are fun, if a bit simple.  *  The world is fantastic and exciting.  Beautiful art and interesting setting.*  For the most part I was on the edge of my seat waiting to see what would happen on the next part of their adventure.The bad:*  The main storyline is aweful.  Extremely cliche, and where the designer expects the player to feel emotional impact there is none, because he never bothered to develop the characters in a meaningful way.  The last 15 minutes of the game were painful to paly through because of how forced it felt.  Luckily through most of the game the main story stays out of the way.*  The controls are cludgy when they work, and I had to edit a .ini file burried in the games configs in order for it to use my controller correctly (the left sticks Y was flipped, and the game's built in menus don't have ways to change things like that)*  The game is very slow to start (and slow to end)  The first 15 minutes of the game feel like pointlessly running around a town.*  The game is very short.  All of it high quality but it wont last you very long.Despite my gripes I found the game to be a lot of fun to play, and well worth the price of admission if you can pick it up on sale.  Just don't expect a deep story, and be willing to deal with some wonky controls.  8/10

content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
												Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is an adventure/puzzle game with a unique control scheme, and an outstanding story that is one of the best around. This game is set in a somewhat fantasy world, boasting stunning vistas the brothers adventure forth in. The fantasy nature isn't as heavy as in games that make it a huge focus, since this game is more realistic in its graphical approach with well designed nature scenes. The fantasy elements pop up with some of the things the brothers interact with. Each of the characters are stylized with a less realistic style, but do stand out from the beautiful landscapes. As for the music, there are some instrumental and vocal tracks, but they are sparsely played throughout the game. They do put the mood when a song starts playing, and they do help emphasize some key parts of the story very well.What makes Brothers one of the most well recieved games is its story. This is one of the games you want to have no spoilers before playing. Two brothers, an older and younger brother, must recieve a special healing liquid from the Tree of Life to save their ill father. The story is driven in the game mainly by gestures and actions, as the people in Brothers speak in a fictional language.The other reason that Brothers is a great game is its unique gameplay. Players control both brothers at the same time in a kind of single player co-op game. Each brother can move around in all directions and have a context specific action button, making this game best played with an Xbox 360 controller or equivalent. The brothers mainly explore around and climb things. For some parts, both brothers have to work together in tandem or do specific tasks with each brother. The older brother is stronger and can pull levers and give a boost, while the younger brother can move between bars. The puzzle aspects of this game by using each brother in specific uses is great, along with the general idea of using two characters at once.This game is pretty short though, so expect the game to last about 3-4 hours. The difficulty isn't too hard as most puzzles can be self-explanitory, save for some parts that may be unclear as to what to do. The achievements take some exploring and thinking to complete, but they are optional side quests and not part of the main story.Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons has its strong story along with a unique control scheme. Well recieved by many to recieve various awards, this game will certainlly enthrall players with a good emotional story and an interesting adventure with puzzles controlling two brothers at once.

												This is a fantastic game but it's quite hard to justify what makes it that good.* The story is decent but not as good as people make it look like. It's simple and it does the job but that's about it.* The controls (I'd recommend a controller) are simple, can be obnoxious at times but you get used to them.* The game is really easy when you get past the controls, there is hardly any challenge and the few challenges you face are quite easy to beat.* The world and graphics are great. Everything works together and the mediocre elements of this game, since they are so well implemented, instead of dragging the game down make it better. This game wanted to tell a story and everything in the game worked towards that objective.This is trully a different game and a must play.

content:
Posted: January 24
												This is a rather unique game. There is no dialogue really, everything is in another language. The story is told through actions such as pointing, showing objects, nodding etc. The characters and locations are well designed and give a genuine fantasy setting which oozes history and lore. But this isn't really where the game excells, it's the control method and puzzles that shine the most. You control both characters in the story with individual controller sticks and triggers. It can get a little confusing, especially if the characters move across the screen and you get confused about which stick controls which character. That said, the puzzles require you to move each character quite precisely at times, rotating objects held at each end by the two brothers or pushing a lever one way whilst pulling it another. The puzzles aren't hard, they aren't really there to tax the mind but when combined with the control method, it can provide a fun little challenge of timing and precision. The game is a couple of hours long but it's very high quality. Perhaps wait for a sale if you want your money's worth in terms of time spent but if you're looking for a good story and neat little challenge, this is worth the asking price.Some gameplay:

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												A masterpiece; that's what Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is.It's emotionally gripping with the storytelling as you watch the two brothers bond while adventuring to find healing water for their ill father. Straight from the beginning, you can tell that this isn't exactly a game suited for kids, as you watch your mother drown to her death in flashback cutscene, when the younger son, Naiee tragically tried to save her, but isn't able to do so in time. I don't wanna spoil anything, but the game is an adventure game that is charming, creepy and lastly, heartwrenching.The gameplay starts when Naiee and his elder brother Nyaa carry their father to a doctor, and from there the doctor has them embark on an epic quest to find the healing water. During the epic quest, you encounter folk in the village, farmers, sheep, rabbits, mountain goats; friendly trolls, evil trolls, whales, invisible monsters; giants that fought to their death, wolves, griffins, and much more.While you don't fight any of these beings, and really, only some of them are evil, (the mean trolls, a giant spider, wolves, and some angry cultists), you avoid them by controlling the two brothers. The game plays like a twin stick fighter or shooter, but as a 3rd person, over head view, and puzzle solving, one stick for each brother, and a trigger to interact with objects.The game really is epic with the interactions, as you climb, swim, swing, fly, use torches, use various gears and handles; there's a large number of puzzle/interacting; but it's pretty straightforward. The graphic style is reminiscent of Fable and Ico, but in its own way, and it works well as the game is gorgeous. The audio is perfect, the music and atmosphere really add to the charm of the game, as well as to the creepiness of certain areas (like the guy who tries to hang himself and you have to choice of stopping him, or the bloody rivers where the giants fought to their death, or the children whose bodies are hanging in the forests).I managed through the game pretty well, but I have to say that the ending is f*cking depressing. It leaves an emotional impact unlike any game I've ever played.10/10

Posted: July 11, 2016
												A tag that should be higher for this game is 'platformer'.  Fortunately, the game guides your character and does most balancing, jumping, etc for you so you don't have to worry about falling off ledges.  But there are quite a few instances of skill jumps.  They aren't particularly difficult, but aside from the minipuzzles of figuring out where to stand your characters to activate the next thing, it's the primary game element.I recommend this game, but it's a minor recommendation.  It's an easy platformer/puzzle game with a unique control scheme, controlling 2 characters at once.  Finished in about 5 hours.The scenes are cool looking.  There is an overarching storyline, but 90% of the game is "here we are, in this room, how do we get out...oh there's a thing we can push/pull/lift/activate...click on that' cue cutscene leading the characters to the next room, "ok, now how do we get out of here...".I would not purchase at full price.  But on sale 80% off or something, sure go for it.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												"Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons" is an amazing indie puzzle storytelling with beautiful graphics and a touchin' plot mixed with funny moments. It's game control mechanic is creative and transmits a powerful message: you need to control both brothers together to progress through the game. If they don't work together correctly, you'll fail and will be stuck. They need to work together properly during all the game - and isn't that what a good brotherhood is all about? Also, it can be played as a local co-op game with a friend - each one of you controlling one brother.The world is detailed, charming and vibrant. Despite the game story being only 3-4 hours long if you have good coordenation (I've a pretty bad one, so I've suffered a lot and spent like 10 hours to full complete the game and get all the achievements), it takes you through a multitude of environments and a rollercoaster of feelings. Every chapter feels fresh, compelling and interesting.Sometimes in a adventure, we grow stronger but there is so much that we lost along the way... "Brothers" showed us how immensely powerful a game can be, when it's gameplay and story complements each other perfectly.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Within a span of three hours, Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons manages to build a world more engulfing and tell a story more compelling than some of the most expensive 40-hour-gameplay titles created by big studios, and does so without the use of any real spoken language the players can understand. You won't know where you are going until you get there, but the journey to the brothers' destination is beautiful and fascinating to see unfold. Although there is a notice saying that the game requires a controller to play, I did so with a regular keyboard. Just use WASD and spacebar for the elder brother Naia, and arrow and Ctrl keys for younger brother Naiee. Whatever you do use, controlling the two brothers simultaneously can be a bit disorienting, and I recommend keeping each brother on the side of the screen that corresponds with the side of the keyboard/controller where their buttons/joysticks are located. It is pretty fun to figure out the little puzzles along the way, as much of the game requires the boys' cooperation to move the story along.Even though it is short, Brothers is worth every penny. If you can catch it on sale, as it is at the moment of this review being written, you really have no reason not to buy it. If you find yourself frustrated occasionally, give yourself a break and pick up the game again soon. You will want to play it through to the very end. (And grab a hanky when you get there.)

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												Increible and charming game. The control scheme allows for a set of unique and very creative puzzles. Although they are fairly easy and straightforward, they are well thought and entertaining. The fact that they where designed with the brothers cooperation in mind makes them quite unique and you won't see anything like it in any other single player experience. Contrary to what the store page says, it appears that the game CAN be played without a controller. The excellent and yet simple storytelling in this game is yet another proof that well-designed videogames can be a form of art. Through a made up language the characters interact with each other and is up to the player to decipher what's going on by paying attention to the characters' body expressions and gestures. The game is obviously designed so that the story and emotions are easy to understand without the need of explicit dialogues, allowing the players to immerse themselves in this beautiful story by their own interpretations.The game makes good use of the Unreal Engine, creating a fantasy-like universe with consistent elements  with the overarching story and interactions between the Brothers. But it doesn't stop at that, as the game manages to create different environments for each chapters that are one more breathtaking than the other. From the remnants of a giants' battlefield to a glacial landscape filled with singing whales, every path the Brothers traverse was meticulously designed to resemble the syle of a pop-up storybook. This manages to convey the huge scale of the world that surrounds the characters and the significance of the journey of the two Brothers.I can't find words to describe how much this concept is enhanced by playing the game in 3D. Making the game work with a 3DTV is fairly easy with some software like Tridef 3D (I guess Nvidia's 3DVision should work aswell). And I must say, it looks like the environment objects and the camera angles were designed specifically with 3D in mind (and I suppose it wasn't like that, seeing as the game does NOT natively support 3D). This was easily one of the best 3D gaming experiences I ever had, and I look at the 2D screenshots I took while playing and unfortunately they feel extremely underwhelming compared to the sense of scope I felt during those parts.Overall, this game is a must-buy/must-play. Even if you can't find a way to experience it in 3D, the art design is strong enough to stand on its own and the beautiful story of the two Brothers may still be something to catch you by surprise and actually make you feel for the characters. The lenght of the game is approximately 3 hours. Maybe more if you decide to go for a second run in order to get the achievements you may have missed, but they weren't much an incentive to me.One detail (Spoilers?): I still can't figure out if this game was designed for kids, or if it was made for grown ups. It begins as a colorful and charming game, but it quickly turns dark and gritty, full of scenarios I'm not sure how a kid would respond to. The easy puzzles also trew me off. But either way, the game is still something that should be experienced from beggining to end, even by adults.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												"Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons" recounts the story of two brothers whose mother has passed away, on their journey to save their dying father. And it does so in a beautiful and sometimes surprisingly dark way. Brothers owes much of its magic to the wordless storytelling that plays to your emotions, perhaps more than an old fashioned narrative could, accompanied by a soft background music. Not even the few glaring glitches* or the simple graphics (the settings are breathtaking nonetheless, even if the characters aren't) can hinder the game experience. While the controls may freak you out in the beginning, learning to move and play both characters simultaneously will eventually come easier as you practice some hand coordination. I must say I didn't feel like this game *required* a controller, although I can see how it could make for better gameplay.There was no boring moment - although I must admit there were times so troublesome and frustrating that I contemplated Alt+F4ing the whole thing (only for a brief second). It was the proximity with the young brothers and their quest, and the will to see them through this painful and exciting journey that kept me going until the very end, by which I dried off a tear and gathered what pieces I could of my just broken heart.Beautiful, 8/10.*Regarding glitches:In chapter 2, if the gate does not open, restart the whole chapter. Restarting from last checkpoint will not work, and although it is possible to open the gate (with a lot of work) without doing this, it will give you trouble later on and you won't be able to finish the chapter without restarting it anyway. Just do it!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												Usually if a game moves me from inside and makes me cry... That's a good sign.. I think I can dare to say that Brothers is, without any contest, one of the most beautiful and touching game I played those last years, if not THE most beautiful and touching. And beautiful not only by the Art Direction. The soundtrack, with that imaginary language made so comprehensible through the staging and the scenes direction. The plot, that how so strong bound between the characters, the magic of this universe lulled with Nordic references, that constant cinematographic feeling that makes the transitions between game phases and cutscenes very smooth, without any clashes. That inventive gameplay, that kindly forces you to use both of your brain hemispheres as if you were playing an instrument.I can't find the words to describe such a masterpiece... This game is simply formidable and extremely touching, in a similar way to the excellent Papo & Yo, but with... something better. If a notation was possible, I'd give it without any doubt a 20 outta 20. Yes. It's that good.------------------------------------------------------------En temps normal, si un jeu me remue de l'intérieur et me fais pleurer... C'est souvent bon signe.. Je pense pouvoir m'avancer et dire que Brothers est sans aucun doute l'un des plus beaux jeu auquel j'ai eu l'occasion de jouer ces dernières années, sinon le plus beau et le plus touchant. Et beau non pas seulement en termes de DA. La bande son, avec cette langue imaginaire mais pourtant si compréhensible grace à la mise en scène et à la direction des scènes, le récit, le lien si fort qui uni les personnages, la magie de cet univers bercé de références Nordiques, le côté cinématographique constant faisant que les transitions entre les phases de jeu et les cinématiques se font tout en douceur, sans heurts. Cet inventif gameplay, vous forçant gentiement à faire travailler vos deux pôles du cerveau, comme si vous jouiez d'un instrument. Les mots me manquent pour décrire un tel chef d'oeuvre... Il s'agit tout simplement d'un jeu formidable et extrêmement touchant, au même titre que l'excellent Papo & Yo, mais avec... quelque chose en plus. Si une notation était possible, je lui donnerai sans aucune retenue un 20. Eh oui. Il est bon à ce point.

Posted: April 6, 2015
												There are games that you enjoy to play. There are games that you love to watch. There are games that make you feel special. But when you manage to combine all that together you get Brothers A tale of two sons. A game that makes you aprreciate one of the most important things you have in life and that is a family that loves you. From the beginning till the end this game is a testament to the hardships of life, the importance of family and the grandeur of the human will and soul. A story so simple and yet so grand that makes you understand how great it is to have sm1 you can love and support unconditionaly. In the end of the game you will feel exactly as the the protagonists do and you will glimpse for a moment why the people you have around are the most important thing to you.  There are literally no flaws in this game whether is the story, the graphics, the music everything works in harmony and balance. One of the best games i have ever played and one i can say without a doubt i will remeber for a long time. 10/10 Masterpiece

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
AUDIOSoothingVISUALBeautifulDIFFICULTYChild's PlayVIBEMelancholyCRAVINGJourneyON SALEConstantPROS: There is a good chance you will finish this game in one sitting. It is easy to get invested very quickly. Gameplay is incredibly creative, and battle is not solely evasion tactics like you'd expect. Each level presents a new challenge, so there is no repetitiveness. You would think it would be hard to control two characters at once, but within minutes it was second nature. The story is told with no words, making it powerfully-poignant. CONS: It is almost nauseating how desperate the game is to tug at your heartstrings. If forced emotional investment through kicked puppies and weeping, legless orphans irritates you, don't bother installing; The game starts on a low note, and ends on a low note. It's got great artistic value, but that may make it a real drag. It is also very short, if you are purchasing for elapsed gameplay time, you will want to wait for this to go on sale. (My hours were racked up through completionist play.)WORTH: Brothers goes on sale all the time at a whopping 90% off! Wishlist it and wait for a sale to get it for $1.50 USD!OVERALL: I certainly believe that games can be art, but I've often questioned whether or not art can be a game. Brothers proves that there are successful marriages between the two worlds that don't land you in the "walking simulator" zone. It is reminiscent to the works of Team ICO, which I feel is a fitting description and the highest compliment I can pay a game.SCORE: 10/10                                                                     Full Review Coming Soon

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												This is probably my favorite game of all time. It is a relatively short game, but the pacing of the game means you are encouraged to explore and interact with your surroundings (necessary if you want to get all of the achievements). The storyline is compelling, taking full advantage of the whimsical world you play through. The characters speak a made up language which I personally feel only enhances the experience as it means you're forced to pay attention to what the characters are doing, how they interact with others, and the tone of their voices. The game takes you through a series of environmental puzzles which are generally rather simplistic in solution, but the control mechanisms are challenging enough to keep it interesting. As soon as you've mastered the controls in one area you move on to another puzzle which introduces new mechanics. This game is an emotional journey- you encounter situations which bring the player in touch with feelings such as playfulness, fear, jealousy, joy, and grief.  I personally think that by making the controls so challenging and making them operate in such a way that you really have to pay attention to what you're doing, it makes the storyline all the more powerful and the ending that much more poignant. You don't always realize what you have and how much you rely on it until it is gone, and this game captures that experience beautifully. Basically, brace yourself for some major feels.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												While playing this game I had this feeling of fairytale and adventure and hardship that was so familiar to me. I kept wondering, what does this remind me of?? It was "The Neverending Story" book. It is my favorite story of all times and the game, as the book, will take you in places full of wonder where you will face dangers and magical creatures. You will help and be helped along the way, face treason and face LOSS. Heartbreaking, soul-wrenching loss. Now, if you experienced loss of loved ones in real life, you will know what I mean. It will take you back. But in this game, just like in life, you learn to cope and you learn to accept that life is what it is. However deeply wounded you get, you will heal, whether or not you feel this is fair. Emotional-rollercoaster aside, the game has beautiful screenshot-material scenery, a gorgeous soundtrack and a gameplay that I like to call " a brain exercise" :), cause you need to control both brothers at the same time, one with your left hand and one with your right. I recommend this with all my heart, but bring some tissues :)

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Brothers uses a very interesting control mechanic, where either analog stick controls one of the two brothers. All levels are designed and take full advantage for this.But that's not why you should play this game.Brothers has no real speech throughout, and what music there is is perfectly matched to the levels. The art design is also beautiful, at times as if you're in a LOTR-kind world. You move through several environments here from villages to high mountains to a frozen world, yet all belong to the same world clearly and it is a wonderful journey. But that's not why you should play this game.So many games try to touch emotion and portray a feeling of loss, but few succeed as well as Brothers does. One of the most impressive games ever made. Play it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons had some of the best gameplay elements I'd ever seen! It's just like a "regular" RPG, but as you probably already know, instead of just controlling just one character, or brother, at a time, you control both at the same time. The puzzles that were designed around this gameplay mechanic are awesome and really fun to do, along with the immersing story and well developed atmosphere.The main plot is set around two brothers, or two sons, that are on a quest to save their father, who is deathly ill. Their mother had drowned previously and the brothers don't want to lose their dad as well, so they set out to find the special liquid from a magical tree, which is the only thing that can save him. There are absolutely no distinguishable words throughout the whole game, apart from some basic instructions on how to control both brothers at the very start, but the story is still super smooth and easy to follow, so the lack of words won't mess up your understanding of what’s going on. No spoilers here, but the story of the brothers and their “adventures” is really good, you might even cry.There are enough levels included in the game to make it long enough. It's only around 3-5 hours, but I reckon it's just the right length to keep a story as this one interesting. Every level is a new experience and there are always new things to do, even with the basic controls, (you only use the triggers and thumb sticks). Hang gliding, throwing balls down wells, riding mountain goats and sitting on benches and looking at the view are only some of the things you can do to keep yourself entertained in this amazing game.So, the real question is, should you buy this game? Absolutely, I guarantee you'll have a great time with it. It's a little short, but don't let that stop you from getting it. There a many memories to be made as you play this.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												I understand if you are reading these reviews as you are sceptical on whether to buy this game or not.  I was once like you.  I originally witnessed this game release on Xbox LIVE Arcade on the Xbox 360 and soon after a media storm ensued - praise was given everywhere from nearly every major gaming outlet.  I still didn't bite.Roll around Steam Winter Sale 2013, I buy Brothers for £3.  Yep, £3.  Possibly the best £3 I have ever spent, on anything.To truly experience this game you will need a controller as this is a "Single player co-op" experience, you will be controlling the two brothers on the one controller - One brother using the Left analog stick and trigger and the other brother using the right hand side.  It is difficult to get used to, it is very unfamiliar, at times uncomfortable and it is absoloutley incredible. The way the controls are mapped and how they are used in gameplay tell a narrative that you are probably thinking is impossible, especially when the characters speak a kind of "Simlish" language.  Without spoiling anything, these controls are mapped in an EXTREMELY smart way - Please think, if you play this game, why each brother is mapped to that specific side of the controller. Hint: It was not done on accident.Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons takes so many conventions we have become used to in gaming and completely flips them on their head, and then some.  Take nearly everything you know/have learned about modern games and throw it away before heading in to this.The audio is great, the visuals are near perfection.  I can not say any more without spoiling this experience... Just buy and play this game, It will be like nothing you have ever experienced.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												Pleasantly surprised.The non-verbal storytelling was completely unique, with every character speaking an imaginary language.  If you get stuck somewhere, you have to glean clues from the pointing cues of the brothers on where to go next. The scenery was amazing.  It's a shame the art of the characters themselves wasn't as polished, because some of the settings in this world were genuinely beautiful.  The game, while short, has a fantastic main plot with a lot of optional side content that you can explore to develop interactions with additional characters.  I said I was pleasantly surprised at the start of this review because somehow I hadn't heard more about this game.  It's a great Indie title, and I feel like I should have heard more about it sooner.  Pick this up, especially when it's on sale, as it's well worth your own review.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												A moving story with an interesting control system held together primarily by a strong artistic vision and creative story-telling mechanics. You learn a lot about the characters without ever understanding a word they say to one-another. Unfortunately, I felt that the gameplay didn't really grip me fully until an hour or so in, and even then it had a lot to do with the feel of the environments evolving to become truly magical. The last half of the game is arguably its strongest in terms of both story and gameplay.Perhaps I sound cynical, but in the end my expectations based on reviews and recommendations from friends had probably been too high, as I felt like I had been given a mere taste of a full game, rather than the complete, satisfying product. I do recommend the game, but I don't think I'd play full price as it clocks in at barely 3 hours, and replay value is rather limited in my opinion - I'd return to experience the beautiful world, as the story and puzzles hold no more secrets after one play-through.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												Brothers is one of the best games I've ever played. It was instantly memorable, immediately engaging, and impossible for me to put down once I had begun. The single player co-op design is unlike anything I've experienced in a videogame - playing on a dual analog stick controller is practically a necessity as you are controlling the titular brothers independently using the left & right analog sticks & shoulder buttons. There is a learning curve to this ambidextrous design, as you'll be getting the brothers to work together to solve puzzles and navigate a variety of terrain from separate locations. Being able to play an instrument that requires independent hand movement helps, though most players should get the hang of it relatively quickly. The difficulty is very consistent, steadily increasing without ever being too easy or too hard, and the puzzles are remarkably intuitive & creative. They are close to perfect in design, and solving them is sublimely gratifying - there are many "Eureka!" moments in which a lot of varied elements suddenly gel together like clockwork, and never once did I find myself needing to look online for a solution or getting stuck on a puzzle long enough for it to be an annoyance. Equally compelling is the immersive world in which you play - for such a short game (taking my time, I finished it in a single 3 hour sitting), you traverse a vast variety of settings, including idyllic farmlands, haunted forests, snow-covered hills & icy rivers, and an enormous castle near a battlefield littered with the bodies of dead soldiers hundreds of times your size. Brothers' art design & score draw from Swedish, Nordic, and Scandanavian influences, and much like its dialogue (delivered in a fictional language in which the characters' feelings & motivations are expressed entirely by how they emote the gibberish they speak), they help tell a story, create a densely detailed world, and establish a strong, emotionally-driven narrative. Brothers manages to do a lot with very little and never overstays its welcome; it really feels like a labor of love from developer Starbreeze Studios.This game is special to me in the way my favorite books, movies, and records are; the level of wonder and intrigue I felt playing it is largely unrivaled in the world of videogames, even in many titles that were made by bigger developers working with a much larger budget. Its art design and music are staggeringly beautiful and creative, it has some of the most unique and fun gameplay I've ever experienced, and the journey undertaken is filled with high emotional peaks and analogous of the journey of life itself. The final ten minutes in particular moved me to tears with a climax that utilizes the unique core control mechanic to express the completion of a character arc - something I've never seen prior or since. This game comes with my highest recommendation as an unforgettable experience and work of fine art. A+ (10/10)(My nomination for "I'm Not Crying, There's Something In My Eye" in the 2016 Steam Awards)

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												Epic in every sense, a true fantasy adventure.  Not only is the concept amazing, telling a story about brotherhood in both plot and mechanics, this game delivers on every level. The art direction hits home its fantasy roots, and the score is wonderful, enhancing every moment. However, perhaps the most impressive is the cinematography. Yes, cutscene cinematics are great, but Brothers is one of the first games I've played where the in-game cinematography is more nuanced than a pre-rendered camera. The third person perspective does a fantastic job of highlighting objectives and story details, while providing a fantastic frame of the gorgeous set pieces, all without obstructing gameplay in the slightest. I could go on and on about the details, but the best way to see it is just to play for yourself. The player camera is expressive yet functional, and few games can claim such. If I was to get critical, the only drawback is the gameplay. The mechanics are solid, ingenious really, and I was impressed with just how much of the world I could interact with (even if such interaction weren't always meaningful). However, it is simplistic. A couple of puzzles made me smile out of sheer ingenuity, but most, if not all, can be solved without much thought. If anything, I'd say that the greatest puzzle lies in the controls itself, as controlling two characters simultaneously on a single gamepad is quite the mental obstacle, and the game highlights this throughout. Still, there were a few moments where I wish the designers had pushed mastery of the controls further, as you can stumble your way through every chapter without much problem. However, providing such a challenge could possibly distract from the experience itself, so it's hard to fault the creators for going with accessibility over difficulty. The bottom line is this; if you want a great story where gameplay enhances the user's experience, play this game. Brothers is a great glimpse into the possibilities games present in the narrative arts.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												I don't get the love for this game.  It's an ok game, but that's about the best that can be said for it.  The story is pretty straight forward, nothing wrong with it, but nothing that interesting about it.  The world is somewhat interesting, but nothing is explained or expanded.  It's simply go here, look at this new area, ok we're done here, now look at this new area, and repeat over and over.  The graphics are pretty, but I'm not a graphics ♥♥♥♥♥ so that doesn't matter much to me.  The game is short and linear, lasting around 2 1/2 hours, and you spend a lot of that time walking on straight paths to get to the next puzzle.  The puzzles are way too simple, there wasn't a single one that took more than 2 seconds to look at and figure out, and they are often repeated.  If they had spent a little time making some puzzles that took some thought, the game probably would've been more enjoyable.  Controlling each of the brothers seperately is an interesting concept, but it's not used to the full extent that it could've been.   The dual movement also results in occasional moments where you lose track of your control on the brothers and send them running off in random directions until you stop and think about what you're doing.  It's not a big deal but might explain why they went with very simple puzzles.Overall, there's nothing really wrong with the game, but I feel like I wasted my time.  The game doesn't do anything particulary well and there's no challenge to be found here.  Why people seem to enjoy it so much, I'll never know.  I guess people are mesmerized by no challenge games, pretty graphics, and pushing arrows impaled on some dead bodies for the third time.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												I have not yet finished the game, but if the first level is any indication it may be heading to my list of favourite single player games. This game has caught me by surprise (much like XCOM: Enemy Unknown did). However, unlike the technical praise I might give XCOM:EU, I found the story and simplicity of the game to be a refreshing change of pace.The interface to the game comes in the form of a "unique single player cooperative experience". That description is quite accurate but I would not label it as the biggest selling point of the game. Although the experience is very unique, it can at times be a bit overwhelming. The unique controls are not enough to detract from the presentation of the story. I've found many of the puzzles challenging enough without being impossible. But the interface to the game is not what draws me to it, rather it is the presentation that gives it a special place in my collection.We live in a time where all forms of media are pushing the boundaries of privacy, violence and sex. Rarely do we see anything from music videos to video games that can't succeed without a healthy dose of one or all of the above. I only point out this fact because this game is presented with what you might call a traditional sense of innocence. It reminds me of simpler times when movies like Milo and Otis and Homeward Bound would provide enough escape from the oft-times drab realities of our daily lives. Don't get me wrong the game does have violence, so did Milo & Otis and Homeward Bound. There's a vast difference between the violence presented in those movies (and in the game) and the kind we see on HBO's latest "adventure" TV show.This game doesn't replace those more adult-themed shows, movies and games that I do enjoy. Rather this game is something apart from them, it strikes that simplistic adventure nerve just right to keep me coming back for a little more every night.Do I recommend the game? Absolutely, just remember to hang your cynicism at the door and bring your heart and a sense of humour and you'll love it. :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Honestly, what can I say... I never cried so much in my life. This is not a game for very sensible persons (like me). I just finished the game and I need to hug my teddy bear really long to get over the story.In terms of gameplay, I actually have nothing negative to report. The controls are simple but can still confuse as you go on in the adventure. The puzzles are quick to understand and can be solved without experiencing much frustration. Sometimes, I think it might be a little bit too easy. There is no part where you can get stuck or that is really challenging in my opinion. Still, I don't see it as a problem since the game is not about feeling awesome after solving a hard puzzle or bypassing a large obstacle and more about telling the story of the brothers. Difficult puzzles would maybe ruin this experience.The narrative of the story is just fantastic. Even without using an acutal understandable language (the characters in this game speak some a made-up language + there are no subtitles), it is always clear what the characters in the game are saying or what they are talking about (also because they use gestures which helps out a lot). The story and (if existend) the relation of the individual characters is easily understandable.Sure, the game is pretty short (it took me two hours to finish it without having all achievements) but I think it's the right length. Since the gameplay is simple, you can only do so much to keep it fresh and entertaining. Maybe one level more wouldn't have hurt but I don't think it's necessary either.All in all, Borther - A Tale of Two Sons is an entertaining, small and also emotional experience. If you're looking for a quick and fun game and you're not the most sensible person out there (*sob*), definitly check out this game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is exactly as the title suggests, the story of two boys, connected by the bonds of brotherhood, unified in their quest to find a cure for their dying father (this is relayed to the player in the first minute or so of the game).  From the moment we pick up the controller (more on this later), we too, are tied to these boys.  We guide them forward, facing the adventure that lies ahead.Brothers is in every way an experience refined to its most vital, leanest, core.  There is no dialogue to read, no complexity or depth to the controls, or even mindblowing technical detail to the environments.  What we have instead is not by many standards an objectively better game, but one which utilizes its design choices to create an incredibly engaging and meaningful experience.Brothers’ story is “told” to the player through an almost primal but ultimately simple and refined manner.  No English nor any known language is spoken (as far as I know) in the world in which our fated brothers inhabit.  Instead, the intonation of the voice and the expressions displayed by the characters serve as the primary method of narration.  In this way, engaging our senses without having language and words to get in the way, we begin to empathize at a core emotional level with the brothers and the people around them.  Wanting to smile at the sound of their laughter; tensing at moments of stress, tearing at moments of pain.  Without “telling” us anything, Brothers makes us feel.  And that in itself is an achievement.Upon recommendation, I was told to play Brothers using a controller.  After playing through Brothers, I can understand why such a recommendation was made.  The controller is split in half, one action button, a camera button, and an analog movement stick for each brother.  In this way, each brother feels like an extension of the self.  As you struggle to coordinate the movements of your own hands, you watch as they too, struggle to work together.  As you improve, so do they, traversing the terrain with the ease of a well oiled machine.  In this way, running, tiptoeing, sneaking around, moving in general just feels good in analog, as it should.And while Brothers is by no means a technically impressive game, it does pull off awe inspiring spectacle.  The terrain is highly varied, puzzles never overstay their welcome, and moments of pure exhilaration and smile inducing giddiness play at odds with true moments of adversity, rounding out the experience as a whole.  In this way, the variance of the environments reflects the range of emotion that occurs in Brothers.  Wrapped in what in hindsight looks like a 2-3 hour rollercoaster ride, but in the moment, felt like days of adventuring, Brothers is an experience worth having.  Not to watch someone else experience, or to even read about, but to have and experience and live yourself.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												This is one of the best games I have ever played. The story, the gameplay, and the setting! All of it blew me away!This is my reaction to this game: http://media.tumblr.com/tumblr_m08mhdrcxs1rqfhi2o1_400.gifWARNING: CONTAINS SOME SPOILERSThe plot is that you have to travel a large distance to get a special medicine for your sick and dying father. The two brothers help each other on this quest to save thier dad. An example is the Blue Brother helping the Gold Brother swim as the Gold Brother is too scared to swim because of his mother drowning infront of him. Also the interesting characters you meet on the way gave life and also feeling to the story. The two brothers' bond gets you really sucked in and it is what made the ending even stronger.The setting of the story will leave you speakless. I loved looking off the hills and mountains and seeing the valleys or towns below. The game had a warm and bright feeling for most of the game. The setting also being able to be manipilated with interaction was another fantastic feature. Some of the interative setting was as simple as moving gates or making a bridge. You could make a path and continue with the story.The gameplay was simple using control sticks to move the charactors and triggers to interact. It was simple and easy but still a great experence. Only problem for me was I kept confusing myself with which character I was trying to control with the stick. I often made them walk into walls trying to remember who is controlled by which stick. Overall this is a fantatic game and I want to play it over and over.If I had to rate this game it would be a 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Brothers - A Tale Of Two Sons is an amazing game. Maybe it should be considered more as an interactive story than anything else, since it is very linear and lacks a challenge in itself. The interest lies without a doubt in the emotion conveyed by the story, the rather original gameplay with the two brothers, and in the observation (or should I say contemplation) of the environment. For the graphics are gorgeous (the unreal engine together with Nvidia Physics do wonders) with breath taking sceneries and superb light effects, not to mention an impressive depth of field. Other than that, the music is really beautiful and contributes greatly to the atmosphere of the game. As for the story... well it is a simple one, but very well told (it sometimes feels like an old tale). And extremely emotional...Overall, the game is not hard at all, and it is very short: less than four hours to complete the story, even if you do the secondary actions. It is the only negative thing I could point out, but I paid it 3 euros so I sure cannot complain. And I believe you can take great pleasure in playing to the game more than once. Anyway, an amazing indie gem, which is definitely worth a try and offers a rather unique experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												As someone who loves story-driven game, I had always had my eye on Brothers, just wanted to wait for it to go on sale. Now I've finally played it and I have to say it was everything I had hoped and more. As you probably know, you play as two brothers, each being controlled with a seperate hand on eithert he controller or (as I played it) a keyboard. Either brother has different tasks they can preform, the older being able to pull heavy levers while the younger can get into small spaces or between bars. All this leads to a very unique experience as your brain tries to tell either hand to do different tasks for ither brother or maybe the same task but in reverse, etc. The game never gets terribly difficult, and in all I beat it 100% (for achievements) in about 3 hours, which includes re-playing a few sections I had missed an achievement in. It's not a game for those who want to grind, or have hours of questing adventures. It's an experience, you play through a story, a tale of two sons, if you will. So in the end, it all comes down to, do you wnat to have a fun and heart-wrenching experiene with a game? Then I say definately play this game. If you're not really into that, then don't bother, this games not for you.So lets get down to the story - oh wait... spoilers incoming, I recommend playing before reading more, or if you don't intend to play it but wnat to know some critical points about the story, read on.The story is amazing! It starts light, then gets very dark pretty quickly, to the point where I think I yelled "WTF!" at my screen. I felt like the game took me for a ride through a series of emotions from a sense of adventure, fun and mayhem to a somber mournful reality. All these emotions did not happen at individual times, they are interwoven throughout the story, character or people off to the side will die or live or love will blossom. Not all lives are caught up in the boys story, and thus have their own endings while you're still playing. Even a simple silly thing of two bird they you set free finnding love is tucked away in a corner of the game you would easily miss, and less them 10 minutes later a new beloved creature will pass away from starvation and exhaustion as you finally gave it it's last flight from it's brutal cage. You'll have to side-step giants corpses or cut off their limbs to make it to the next path, bathing yourself in the behemoths blood and feeling nothing but pity and sadness for your actions. Or be thrilled and delightled only a short time later as silly sea-turtles coo at their mother.But nothing stung me as the ending, the final series of events you play as only one brother. Feeling as if one of my hands had been cut off, I pressed on with only the right pressing buttons. It was so strange how to game made me feel wrong about a way I would play most games. The younger brother is afraid of water, and would alwyas hold onto the older brother shoulders to help him swim. But now, without his brother, he wouuld have to swim to the final area to hel his father. So I spend like 2-3 minutes just trying to get the kid into the water, but he wouldn't do it until I just instinctivly began pressing buttons with my other hand again and felt a huge gut-wrenching bundle of emotions when he began swimming using the keys which in my mind where reserved for his brother. A game has never made me felt os many things, with it's controls alone. The younger brother has to do a few more tasks with his brothers 'help' or just the left hands keys, however you wnat to think about it. Which is so odd and painful and moving at once. This game is not perfect, I wouldn't even say I liked the overall ending. I felt hollow and just sad when it was done. Yet, it made me feel all these things, and more, throughout the game. So do I think it's good, heck yeah, like I said it's an experience. But not if you just to just play something light.I try to tell people to think of some games like movies. You don't want to watch A clockwork orange or 2001: A Space Odyssey when you're not in the right mood for it. Games like this are very similar in that regard. You need ot be in the right kind of mood. Sometimes I just want to turn off my brian and watch a dumb action moive, or play minecraft and mine for a hour of non-brain requiring fun. This is not a game to play when you're in that kind of mood.Okay I've rambled enough, I hope thaat helped some. Love the story, very neat controls, very effective ending.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												This. This is what I like. This is what I want. Right in the feelers. This game is simply amazing. 2.5-3 hours of high quality and gorgeous game play, great interaction with the game's mechanics, and an emotionally charged ending.This game has solid game mechanics while only making use of 6 total buttons. There is literally no dialog comprehensible past "mama" as the characters speak in their own made up language and the story was reeeeallly good. Graphics were solid and the artwork was gorgeous.You play as 2 brothers, each half of your controller (L/R trigger and analog sticks) control each one. You traverse a fantasy filled world looking for the "Tree of Life" to heal your sick father. The game has simple puzzles to solve, but the real joy of this game is the game mechanics and the constant enjoyable scenes, my personal favorite was the goat scene.I highly, highly recommend this game. Please... PLEASE take 2-3 hours out of your day to play it!!*I want to add- due to the way the story and game mechanics are weaved together, a controller is required to fully experience this title. I personally recommend the Xbox 360 for Windows controller which retails for about $33 on Amazon.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is no ordinary game. Unlike most puzzle/platformer games, repetetive themes feel minimal and always tastefully done. As the game progresses, it forces you to adapt and learn how to make the brothers interact in a challenging though intuitive way, through visual clues and forgiving reminders that each brother has their own set of special skills. In addition to the challenging and fun puzzles, the environments in the game were beautiful. I owned this game for months before I played it, because although my friend gifted it to me, I wasn't fond of the art style of the game at the time. After deciding to bite the bullet and play through the game, I realized that the relatively simplistic art style was necessary and helpful in creating an environment in which the progression of difficulty of the puzzles flowed naturally, as mentioned previously. Additionally, the relatively simple environment became an art masterpiece as new setpieces consistently increased in scale, depth of interaction, and danger/wonder. A sense of awe comes over the player as they sit at the benches in the game which give you a chance to take a moment and admire the environments in the game.Finally, Brothers is not just a game, it's a cinematic experience aided by the control scheme. Per the recommendation of my friend who gifted me the game, I played with a wired Xbox controller. This is definitely the preferred method of playing the game, though it is forgiving enough to be suitable on keyboard/mouse as well if you prefer or lack access to a wired Xbox controller. The control scheme, though as simple as an interact button and basic movement for each of the brothers, started off clumsy and hard to maintain, but as the game progressed, the simplicity of the scheme showed itself as a marvel of modern game design as the story was translated not only through the actions of the brothers and various supporting characters on screen, but also of the control scheme. When one brother could not complete a task another brother could, you could feel the difference in the way each brother completed each task in front of them, and you could really feel the strengths of each brother being properly utilized in a way that made each brother feel equally important to gameplay, not just one being overall better. The end of the game left me reeling as I discovered how well thought out each combination of buttons was for the story, and how the interaction between the brothers transcends their physical strengths and accentuates their emotional bond as well. 10/10, this game is quite literally perfect.

												This game... This game is excellent. I'll do my best not to spoil it. Also, to those who may be wondering, it does NOT require a controller but it's certainly better with a controller.The game uses its mechanics to tell a story, a relationship even, between two brothers. A lot of the platforming is very fun and feels quite good to play and a lot of the levels have interesting puzzles, although most aren't too difficult to solve.Now, yes, this game is short and has little replay value, but you'll certainly get $15 worth out of it, or just pick it up in a sale for $3. Definitely worth it then.All in all, buy this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												A beautiful little game in which two brothers go on a quest, initially presented almost like a child's storybook where bad guys are defeated with poofs of smoke and the world is detailed in a manner that almost look painted. Despite the content of the introduction, this sets the tone which makes many of the later discoveries hit so much harder than they otherwise might. While only about the length of a movie, that also makes sure that nothing ever overstays its welcome and the pacing is consistently spot on.Thankfully, it takes a gameplay route somewhere between The Adventures of Cookie and Cream and Ico, giving it a proper feel of interaction and exploration without saddling itself with half-baked and overdone combat as many cinematic games are wont to do. Perhaps not as remarkable as similar games such as Another World and Journey, it nevertheless certainly deserves a playthrough for fans of that style.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Wow. Just wow.Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is an absolute gem of a game. The mechanics and controls of the game are very simple, giving you control of two brothers with each half of your game controller and presenting you with various puzzles to solve within a beautifully vibrant world. Different puzzles and obstacles manage to keep the gameplay fresh despite its simplicity and allows you to focus on the true power of this game, the story.Told through a majestic combination of sound and emotion, the game is an absolute rollercoaster of feelings that you will never forget. Completion time is around 3-4 hours depending on your playstyle. Video and audio options are somewhat lacking from the game, but I have a feeling that this was intentional from the devs, giving you no distractions from the experience this game provides.In my opinion, this game is a masterpiece!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Brothers is an interesting short title which showcases innovative controls and an enjoyable story. The main draw is the 'single player co-op' mode of play, each joystick controlling a character (this is most certainly a game made with joysticks in mind) and the gameplay revolving around a series of puzzles exploiting the use of both characters. Whilst it's undoubtedly enjoyable, I left with a slight feelingt that there could have been a lot more to this game. The story line was good but it was played very straight. There was a lot more to develop on, both the controls and gameplay were interesting but lacking in variation and there was no growth at all.Still, for a short game it's alure is plain to see, and although perhaps leaving some room for growth, it's a good story and a good few hours entertainment.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Brothers - Adventures of Big and Little T-wat.Gameplay is aggravating at time. Left stick / Right stick action can be difficult to get used to. At times it felt like someone was inside my brain with a chainsaw trying to buzz away at my corpus callosum, and at other times it felt like trying to choreograph two cocker spaniels to trance music. The game gives you a long time to figure all this out with a seemingly endless opening sequence where you have to outwit this♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥bag with a wooden sword. The story is really the key here. Little T-wat is afraid of water and can’t swim, so Big T-wat has to carry him around on his back when there’s water around. Obviously, Little T-wat isn’t going to learn to swim being carried around all the time (the whole give a guy a fish and he’ll only beg for fish kind of reasoning). The two brothers have a bit of a falling out over spider tail, and mystical stagnate tree sap water doesn’t heal those kind of wounds. Finally Little T-wat is set to try swimming on his own. Can he do it? Play the game and find out.All that aside, this was an enjoyable game with slightly above average fanciful graphics. For $2.24, I can’t complain too much. It was worth the money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I have only played 48 minutes of this game so far and I can already tell this is going to be a rich ride. The game mechanics are really fresh; requiring the player to manage both brothers with the analog sticks is a really neat idea. I can not recall the last game I played that had the player do this. The graphics are serviceable and the sound is of a high quality. The general mood at the beginnig of the game is mixed with some drama and light-hearted exploration. There is an undertone of gloom that has me worried that there may be some heart-tugging moments later down the line.I would like to go into a little detail about the brothers themselves. When you start the game they are fairly blank pages using "Sim-speak" to convey some of the plot. As the game progresses, there are little nuances that really bring their personalities to the light sans actual dialogue. From the older brothers stoic demeanor, to the little brothers practical jokes, you get a sense that the two have a great deal of depth; more depth than I have seen in full blown AAA titles. I nearly died laughing along with the younger brother after he slapped a bent over villager in the butt. I am looking forward to seeing how they interact with the rest of their world.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Without doubt the most stunningly beautiful "short" game currently out there.  The landscapes and ambience, paired with the game's music make it such an immersive and emotional journey.  It is an incredibly brief game in terms of overall gameplay time but I highly recommend at least one play through for every PC gamer.  The way the devs have set-up the achievements is also a nice touch, with no achivements given for in-game milestones or 'checkpoints.'  Rather, achievements are awarded for going off the beat and track and sometimes doing unconventional things.  By this I in no way mean the environment is open sandbox, it is extremely linear with little scope for exploration.  An excellent gaming experience that is definitely worth the money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												A really memorable and well-crafted experience. It's one of the few experiences that actually reminded me of how I remember my childhood: it started with a strong fairy tale feel where something is not quite right, and gradually grew progressively grim as the brothers were thrust into a world where children are not immune to hardship. Before playing it, I was concerned it would be another recycled story about annoying/sad/bratty stock-character kids, but I'm pleased to say that it's one of the more balanced and mature portrayals of children that shows them as human beings with an actual personality.In terms of gameplay, the way they combined it with the story development makes Brothers one of gaming's gems: all the story is told through the environment and the interactions the player has with the world, and there is no (comprehensible) dialogue. The best story moments are twists based on how you control both brothers in different situations. One of my favorite examples is an area where you need to avoid detection from a monster by hiding in specific positions behind frozen statues. Another is a battlefield for giants, where navigating the environment becomes a nice twist. All the areas you explore are filled with little contextual interactions that will make you will feel like you "toy"with this unforgiving world and its inhabitants, just like a child would. Complementing this approach is a truly special and stylized art direction, the kind that makes me stop and take screenshots every minute or so.The amount of soul & care put in the details of this game, from memorable story moments to little interactions in the world, is rare to find in games nowadays. Very short but very sweet.
