content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Brothers – A tale of two sons tells a well-crafted story in a short time frame. I finished the game in about three and a half hours. Despite the game being so short, it is worth your money and time. The control scheme is simple. You control the older brother with the left analog stick, and the younger brother with the right analog stick. You use the Left trigger to interact with the older brother, and the right trigger to interact with the younger brother. The controls are awkward at first, but you’ll get used to it in no time.Although there is spoken dialog it’s a made up language. Meaning you won’t understand a single word of what the characters are saying. However, the game will still create an emotional response from you just based on gameplay. It’s just fun to interact with objects and people with both brothers to see a glimpse into their personalities.The puzzles are fairly easy, but make great use of the control scheme.It is recommended that you have a controller before purchasing this game, as it would be fairly difficult trying to control both brothers using the keyboard.Overall, this game deserves to be experienced by everyone.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												This is an excellent game that drives home the “game experience” more than anything else. Not many games can portray a story as successfully as Brothers without a single line of dialogue. As a player you become quickly immersed in the story and sucked into the game. You start empathizing with the characters throughout the emotional events you encounter. The entire experience—the duality of controlling two characters, the puzzles involved with the control setup, the beautiful environment artwork, and the music that brings it all together is something that will stick with me for a very long time. I highly recommend this game and greatly encourage players to support game studios that create games with this high-level of game design.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Brotherhood and adventure overwhelmed me as I ventured through this vast land of giants and folklore. The sheer scale of the world and its beautiful intricacies are enough to be worthy of your time playing, but the pure originality and phenomenal game mechanics are the true gems of this game. You progress through the land controlling both brothers simultaneously, which at times is tedious and would steer many away from playing. However, once you get the hang of handling your characters, you will become emersed in a realm that you've likely never experienced before. Certain points along the storyline possess genuinly original puzzles that will leave a lasting impression of "Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons," inspiring a sense of accomplishment as you discover their secrets on your own.I highly reccomend this title to anyone looking for an emersive experience in a game unlike any you've ever played. The story is told without dialect and the challenging mechanics cannot be copied, which draws in your focus and at times makes you feel as the characters do -- in sadness, joy and accomplishment alike.Graphics - 10Story - 8Cutscenes - 9Gameplay - 10Overall - 9.5

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												This is, without a doubt, one of the most well-designed games I have ever played. I'm talking about this on a purely technical and gameplay point - the puzzles and gameplay in this is astounding, and it alone is reason enough to purchase this game. It is worth well more than 6$. I was amazed at how intelligently the game was built and how amazing everything is presented to you with subtle hints, progressive learning, and incredible pacing.Going beyond this, A Tale of Two Sons has a fantastic storyline which is delivered clearly without the use of a single word throughout the entire game. You don't /need/ to understand the characters to know what's going on - this is a feat rarely achieved in /any/ medium, and is incredibly rare among video games.I cannot recommend this game enough. It is, without a doubt in my mind, one of my favorite games I have ever played.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												Although it's relatively short, clocking in at around 5 hours of gameplay by time I finished it, this is one of my absolute favorite games. It has an extremely well-written storyline and it had me hooked from the moment the game started.I've always loved adventure games and this one certainly was quite the adventure, taking you through many dangerous terrains and trials to reach your ultimate goal. But, I think one of the most charming aspects of the game is that they don't speak a real language. And although you don't understand the words being said, you still understand what's going on and what you have to do. It really gives you the feeling that you're in a world vastly different from (and yet similar to) our own.I'll have to stop myself or I'll ramble on forever, but this really is a great game and I'd definitely recommend it to anyone that loves a good adventure!

												An emotional story, told without words.OK, so this isn't newest and hippest game in the market. But it should be a game played by everyone with the means to do so. Even if you aren't a 'Gamer'. Its such a great and heartfelt experience. Seriously, go and play it. Its downloadable on PC, PSN and XBOX Live.I finally got around to this gem after spending months going through my backlog of games. I am disappointed in myself for waiting so long to play it now. The controls are very awkward, but simple. A controller is more or less a must for this game, as you control one brother with stick and another brother with the other stick. Trigger buttons to interact with the environment and shoulder buttons for camera rotations. That it! Simple. You will immediately think that the game will be boring with such limited controls, but you would be wrong. The level design and mechanics of the game turn the simple controls into a story of its own. The artwork is breathtaking. The game is one of the most gorgeous around. And that story...﻿

												Brilliant art direction, nice music, unique "single player coop" gameplay.I definitely would recommend it, with a few exceptions. Since it is difficult to talk about the game at all without spoiling the story, I highly advise spoiler-sensitive people to stop reading and just try the game for themselves.****MILD SPOILERS AHEAD********MILD SPOILERS AHEAD********MILD SPOILERS AHEAD********MILD SPOILERS AHEAD********MILD SPOILERS AHEAD********MILD SPOILERS AHEAD********MILD SPOILERS AHEAD********MILD SPOILERS AHEAD********MILD SPOILERS AHEAD********MILD SPOILERS AHEAD****I honestly think the first cutscene was unnessecary. And, on a more general note, I do not recommend this game to people who are depressed (or even think they are depressed). This is not a happy game. Which may come as a surprise because of all the bright-colours, fairy tale-like style. It's more of a sad (realistic?) story. Frankly speaking, it's outright dark and macabre in some places. Sort of reminded me of "A Song of Ice and Fire" - there are fantasy elements, but "life happens" still.An interesting, interactive 2-3 hour story with beautiful visuals and unique mechanics. As long as you're OK with the story also being sad and realistic, do give it a try.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This review refers to my experience with the game using the Xbox 360 Controller. I have no idea how the game runs on the keyboard.At first, I felt hindered by my inability to multitask by controlling the two brothers using the two thumbsticks on one controller. I would get confused and try to move one brother using the wrong thumbstick and feel infuriated by it. After a while, however, I get used to the controls by assigning each brother's color to the side of the controller. Once you get passed that, the game unfolds into a wonderful journey. Great use of the Unreal Engine makes this game beautiful and optimized so you should be able to enjoy the sceneries even on mid-range computers. The only video setting in this game is a gamma slider and the resolution picker, so it isn't that great a game for the lower range computers, possibly, should you wish to lessen the ambient occlusion and rays for the sake of performance.The levels are lovely to go through and the puzzles are easy, so even casual gamers should enjoy this. For the more hardcore gamers, there are some hidden puzzles to be found that are slightly harder (but not by much.). Ultimately, this game is for those who enjoy discovery and stunning vistas as well as a story that reaches the heart.This game is about loss, and about sacrifice. Without spoiling the story, it would be hard to say much except that its moving. Most players should be able to complete the entire game and get every hidden puzzle under 2 hours, but it is a good 2 hours, with a great storyline that doesn't drag on more than needed. If you loved games like "To The Moon", this is a game for you.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												This is a game where the story packs a real emotional punch right from the opening scene. Prepare to be invested in the fate of the characters to an extent that I wouldn't have thought possible. You will care about what happens to them. That there is a real sense of the individual personalities of the two main characters, and that the story is clealy and sensitively told is a real tribute to the developers given that this is all achieved without any real dialogue at all. The main characters use simple sounds and gestures to convey meaning and emotion.There are events and twists throughout that give a real depth to the storytelling. The control system is both simple and innovative.  The world that the characters inhabit is beautifully drawn,  and the atmosphere is completed by a fabulous score. And whilst the overall length is fairly short that is more than compensated for by the whole wonderful experience which leaves a lasting impression. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												I gotta say that all those great reviews kinda ruined the game for me because my expectations where very high. If you want to play it purchase the game with "I heard it's all right, i should give it a try" attitude and you will not be disappointed.Now to the game itself. It's simply beautiful and touching. Graphics are minimalistic and simple but the designers managed to create astounding sceneries spiced with norse tales and mythology. The gameplay brings a new element where you control both brothers at the same time with different analog sticks on your gamepad (in my case on keyboard since I didn't manage to make my trust gamepad work in this game, not even with x360ce) and one interaction button for each character. Then you have to use both brothers to solve simple yet clever puzzles like climbing a rock tied to each other using swinging to reach otherwise unreachable areas. The game is not hard in any way but that is not what it is aiming for.The main aim is to deliver a touching story about two brothers who lost their mother and in fear of losing their father as well they set up on a dangerous journey to find a cure for their sick father. First it feels like a fairy tale when you meet a troll who lost his wife and is trying to help you but later on it turns into more like a horror atmosphere.To sum up this game is great yet I had slightly bigger expectations since everyone has been calling it the game of the year. The only negative I found is that the game is pretty short. It took me 3 and a half hours to complete and when it ended I was hoping for some more material which didn't come. Well but since I bought it on sale for 4,12 euros I don't give a damn. Buy it because this is a one of a kind game even though it could be longer and imo it has a lot of dormant potential.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												This game is a fable.It tells you a story, and it's a familiar one.  There's hardship in the home, and two young boys do what they feel they must.  They set off on a quest together, inseperable and interdependent.They journey through a world they find familiar - but as the player sees more of it, the world reveals its surreal and magical bits and pieces.  The journey shows glimpses of grand scope and mysticism, but don't forget: your two young heroes have a task, and they journey on to succeed.But... As soon as you think you have a handle on things, the game begins to test your resolve.  Mechanically, what you do isn't difficult: two analog sticks, two triggers and timing.  Emotionally? ... Well, if you feel any investement in the characters you encounter, the game might make you FEEL things.There is no intelligible speech in the game; the inhabitants of this world speak their language just fine, but the player has no idea what is being said.  Of course, the body language/mimeography reveals just enough for one's imagination to take off and run with all sorts of meanings.There is no comat in this game, but there is a measure of challenge.  It's a story that asks you to try in order to reveal more of itself.  The trial may be more one of morbid curiosity and courage.While playing it, I got strong memories of Neverending Story, that same feeling of discovery and adventure, as well as the realization that every fantastical element in this world is matter-of-fact to its inhabitants and serves as allegory to something more familiar, mundane.Over the course of 4 hours or so, I saw this story through to its conclusion, encountering a few of the side-stories within (optional activities and further glimpses into the world).  The levels are linear and well-paced, but this pace is slower; the game is meant to be savored rather than devoured.I love this story.  It is so very simple in its idea, so old in its roots; the pace is natural and doesn't offer (nor require) handholding.  Buttery smooth and saccharine-sour, this delicious morsel is worth sampling, then pausing to savor and reflect; then, should the mood strike again, perhaps coming back for a second helping.I love a good fable.  This is a good one. Come see for yourself.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2013
												If you have the smallest shred of a heart you will appreciate the beauty of this game. The art, sound and storytelling are astounding. The lack of voice-over, apart from the minimalist Germanic-gibberish, perfectly evokes the characters' personalities and feelings.Then you get to the gameplay. This is a game where simply watching gives you only 3/4 of the story. The controls, especially when using a 360 or PS3 (with motioninjoy) controller, provide a sense of closeness to the characters and at times give meaning to the situation.You control each brother independently with the analog sticks and interact with the world for each with the left and right triggers. Those are the controls. Contextually, each brother will react to the current situation and positioning (which is extremely forgiving).I finished the game in one sitting. It took me about two to two and a half hours. Do not let this deter you from this wonderful experience. I didn't spend as much time in the world my frist playthrough as I intend to the next. I simply cannot recommend this game enough. It is easily the most powerfully moving game I have ever played.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												A stunning game which I highly recommend.  It is short (3 - 5 hours gameplay) but it makes up for it in the engaging storyline, the characters, the beautiful graphics and the way in which you control both brothers at the same time.You do need a controller to play this game as it makes controlling the two brothers easy and intuitive.  The storyline whilst reasonably simple takes you into a number of different lands where you will meet several other characters.  Throughtout the game the graphics are visually stunning, perhaps the best I have experienced in a game (watch the shadows of not just your own characters but those of others you interact with, even those you can see a long way down the mountains you climb).  The colours are superb and the whole experience is one of quality.  The puzzles are relatively straightforward but nonetheless satisfying to complete and the added bonus of unlocking achievements adds both game time and an element of fun.Above all I felt the game was a very fulfilling experience (yes I wish it was longer) and I have never felt so engaged with a character in a game.  A real emotional gaming experience, one which I can not recommend highly enough.  A game I have already returned to, go buy it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Borthers A Tale of Two Sons is providing us a unique gaming experience. It is adventure platforming game with coop gameplay that you control the big brother with your left analog (or WASD if you use keyboard) and right analog for the little brother (directional buttons in keyboard). You will control both of the character at the same time to cooperatively solve the puzzle throughout the gameYour father is dying sick, and your mother has died prior of the game. You, the two brothers, begin the quest to find the magical ancient tree that believed to have the cure of the disease. And the adventure begin. You will journey the beautiful world that's so believable. Every detail in this game is really well made, imaginative and even your adventure is short, you will still find something surprising in your journey. The story itself, it's simple, really simple that you won't struggle to understand what's going on. But not predictable and will arouse your emotion. Even they speak in "not an actual language" like how The Sims character speak and the animation is not like L.A. Noire that motion capture the expressios of the actors, you will still able to feel the emotion of the character, amazed by how the thing turned out. Playing this game is like you read very good pop up fairy tale books but with the story development that is not like usual fairy taleThe gameplay is simple, just movement, rotate the camera, and interact but can be quite entertaining. You need to do a combination of the older and little brother to solve the puzzle and do the platformer in this game. The elder brother is bigger and stronger, capable to handle heavier task like pick up a sheep or pull the heavy lever. And the little brother is smaller and lighter, so he can pass the fence or being boosted by his big brother to reach a high platform. Each character has it's role and the cooperative combination of them make an solid puzzle solving adventure. The puzzle itself is simple and relatively easy to solve but not boring, entertaining and unique in every encounter you will face. Don't expect to see a same puzzle in a different place in this game. Every stage has it's own unique puzzle and platformingBut this game has zero replayability, except you want to look achievements that you may overlooked in the previous playthrough. But despite of that, there are no reason to play it in the second time. And people who seek for challenge in their gaming experience will be dissapointed in this game. This game is very easy and not gave me a hard time at all. And off course the game is really short. Four hours to finish it including some exploring or interacting with some of the NPC'sMy score is 8 out of 10. The game is short, really short but so enjoyable. Fear not, with a cheap price tag this game is worth your money. If you like some simple and emotional story with unique and easy gameplay but can be very entertaining. This game is maybe for you. If you are someone who want a challenging puzzle platformer or someone who want more complicated story telling, I don't recommend you to play this game

content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												A new take on story walkthroughs, as this can only be a story walkthrough with the incredibly linear design with puzzles too simplistic to garnish thought. The design choice of simultaneously controlling both brothers with analog controls (controller based) works well, however the abilities of the characters are minimised to a simple 'action' key (toggle) and nothing more outside of movement.Graphically the scenery is well design and provides a thoughtful environment. On the opposite side of the coin, character interaction with objects and characters themselves leaves much to be desired.The game/story is relatively short (2.5 to 4 hours), however the story is what makes this game worth playing. Without spoiling any of the story, it can be said the story is akin to one found by the original Brothers Grimm.Overall an interesting take on story playthrough and the control mechanism is something different, I would recommend waiting for this one to be on sale before picking it up for a run.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Before playing this game i'd seen a lot of praise for it and having played it i can say it exceeded my expectations. The story see's two brothers set off to find something to help there very ill father.  It's a really original platformer with you controlling the two brothers at the same time. While this sounds like a difficult process at first it's actually handled quite well. The left joystick is used to move the older brother with the right trigger used to make him interact with things while it's the right side for the younger brother. The simplicity of it makes controlling the two at the same time quite  easy.The games environment is quite a beautiful one with some great scenery and the world it takes place in is amazing with you encountering all different kinds of fantasy creatures and animals with some brilliant settings for the different levels. The puzzles you encounter in the game aren't very difficult but they still manage to be fun and there's some great use of the fact your controlling two characters at once. The games story while seeming basic at first has a very powerful ending which i loved. I'm going to add my voice to the clamour of praise this game has gotten and say buy this game if you can. A 9.5/10 from me.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												In Brothers – A Tale of Two Sons you control two brothers at the same time with an analog stick each. You use this creative control scheme two solve puzzles where you need to do two things at the same time while being a bit clever. The two brothers set of on a journey to find medicine for their sick father. As you play you'll visit several beautiful and unique environments which really creates a great mood while you solve the fun and unique puzzles.I recommend Brothers to anyone who enjoys puzzle games that both pretty and creative.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												Absolutely amazing. Easily one of the greatest experiences I've ever had with a game. I don't think a game has ever evoked so many personal emotions from me. I am a younger brother and my elder is 6 years apart from me. This game truly touches me on a deep level with the utilization of sound, music, lighting, voicing, expression, and atmosphere. Although the characters speak in an indistiguishable language (mostly, apart from the brothers' names), their vocubulary leaves nothing to be desired and is communicated flawlessly. I believe this was intentional and means to give the player the ability to fill in the blanks with what (s)he feels appropriate, which is likely something personal and easy to connect with.The characters themselves are easy to relate to and offer excellent development as characters. The story is extremely simple, but communicated in such a beautiful way, I can't help but be floored this game lasted me nearly 3 hours. I already want to play it through a second time and find if there was anything I missed (other than achievements which are very satisfying and well hidden) which would give more richness to the world itself. The character models may not suit my taste, however, the art style makes up for any personal issue I have with the models themselves. I've taken a handful of screenshots from this game and am one right-click away from setting one as my desktop background.The game itself offers many puzzles and challenges which are never frustrating, yet still require thought and patience to accomplish. The flow of the gameplay has never once been interrupted for me and leaves very very little room for criticism. I'm greatly impressed with how the developers managed to keep such a simple mechanic of using two joysticks to control each brother sp fresh and entertaining even while repeating some puzzles over again. The game continually gets easier as the player becomes accustomed to the mechanics, but there are plenty of instances where I've had to stop and rearrange the brothers because I had trouble keeping the two moving naturally. This is not the game's fault at all, rather it is my own and the game should be praised for continuing to challenge me with such a simple and logical mechanic, but still retaining its challenge by requiring constant attention. Excellent puzzles and mechanics; they offer many challenges.I highly reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys puzzles, challenging multitasking, rich worlds with deep story, has an appreciation for music and environment, and especially anyone with a brother (hell, even a sister) who they care deeply for. You will not regret this purchase or the time you invest into it.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												This is a game where the story packs a real emotional punch right from the opening scene. Prepare to be invested in the fate of the characters to an extent that I wouldn't have thought possible. You will care about what happens to them. That there is a real sense of the individual personalities of the two main characters, and that the story is clealy and sensitively told is a real tribute to the developers given that this is all achieved without any real dialogue at all. The main characters use simple sounds and gestures to convey meaning and emotion.There are events and twists throughout that give a real depth to the storytelling. The control system is both simple and innovative.  The world that the characters inhabit is beautifully drawn,  and the atmosphere is completed by a fabulous score. And whilst the overall length is fairly short that is more than compensated for by the whole wonderful experience which leaves a lasting impression. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												quite easily one of the best games i ever played (and i played a lot of games so far). the rare combination of a deep and atmospheric world to dive into and unique, never-played-before gameplay mechanics are comparable to portal (2) quality wise, eventhough it has nothing to do with that sinister, sarcastic humour of the valve series. "brothers" is a downright honest and moving fairytale that reminds the (adult) audience of how wonderful simple yet heroic stories can still be, without the need of zynicism, sex or ultraviolence. but dont get me wrong here: its not a fluffy, happy world to stroll around in. its an emotional very challenging journey about fear and death and grieve and eventually trust and love and courage. it should be said however, that its a very short game. i took me less than 3 hours to finish. but instead of being sad or angry about it, i started wondering why i have to spent hours and hours of repetetive gameplay in other games without ever reaching an emotional experience that might be somehow comparable to the journey of the 2 sons. thats how good it is.i am looking forward to play this game again someday or even watch a friend play it and i think when you even read that, because you think this might be something for you, than you should definitely buy it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												This is the first game that I bought and played on steam. Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a marvel of storytelling and clever gameplay and a must buy for players who enjoy such.The first thing that I should say is that unlike what the notice says on the store page, this game does not require a controller to play. Gameplay and story:During the game you control these two characters with the arrow and wasd keys as the camera adjusts itself to the area that you are playing. The game itself is relatively simple and linear, requiring the player to overcome easy obstacles in the way of the protagonists' journey to save their ill uncle. In the course of their quest, they assist others in need and grow closer as brothers. It is slightly challenging to get ahold of controlling the brothers simultaneously at the start of the game but becomes much more fluid and easy as you progress through the levels even with a keyboard. Complement to the controls, the challenges along the way begin to require more ingenuity as you learn to control the brothers.Graphics:The areas themselves are beautifully designed and the game pauses every once in a while to allow you to enjoy it. From climbing crumbling ruins to scaling massive caves the game uses every area to show you just how beautiful and well crafted it is. Sound:There is no major dialogue so to speak but everything in the game is clear without it using too many words. What the lack of dialogue gives way to is a wonderful soundtrack that captures the emotional range of the story in ways that dialogue would never have. As the game becomes darker the longer you play, the sounds and music mature likewise.Overall: On the front, Brothers may look like a simple, light hearted puzzle adventure for a casual player. Playing it, I've come to appreciate the subtle and fine ways that this game was made elevating it in quality above many of the other games that I play. The story and gameplay are simple, the music complements the graphics excellently, and the entire experience is an emotional journey as two brothers enter dark and dangerous worlds to save their family. I cannot recommend this game enough and constantly badger anyone who would listen. It is a quick (approx 6 hr) playthrough and the ending left me sobbing. I have to say, this is a different caliber of gaming. I've never experienced anything like it10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Brother - A tale of Two Sons is both a well written story and well thought puzzles! You learn pretty much all of the control mechanics within the first 10 minutes but it's the clever way in which the game implements them that keeps you thinking throught the 5-10 hour campaign. The game starts off very much as a light hearted fairy tale, albeit with a sad back story. Yet half way through it shift's very much from a pleasant, whimsical fairy tale and follows the path more akin towards Brothers Grim. This sombre tone compliments the soundtrack beautifully, which overall is really quite enchanting. The puzzles themself never feel overly taxing which allows the story to flow nicely. As for the controls they can be a little tricky to start with even for the most ambidextrous of people. Big brother is controled with the left analog stick whilst little brother is the right. The respective back buttons are used to control the brothers action and the trigger buttons rotate the camera angle. The end result is a game that allows you to experience a really moving story and also lets you attempt puzzles that will still give a sense of saticfaction when you complete them. Worth looking at if you have an interest in puzzle games :)

content:

												This. This is what I like. This is what I want. Right in the feelers. This game is simply amazing. 2.5-3 hours of high quality and gorgeous game play, great interaction with the game's mechanics, and an emotionally charged ending.This game has solid game mechanics while only making use of 6 total buttons. There is literally no dialog comprehensible past "mama" as the characters speak in their own made up language and the story was reeeeallly good. Graphics were solid and the artwork was gorgeous.You play as 2 brothers, each half of your controller (L/R trigger and analog sticks) control each one. You traverse a fantasy filled world looking for the "Tree of Life" to heal your sick father. The game has simple puzzles to solve, but the real joy of this game is the game mechanics and the constant enjoyable scenes, my personal favorite was the goat scene.I highly, highly recommend this game. Please... PLEASE take 2-3 hours out of your day to play it!!*I want to add- due to the way the story and game mechanics are weaved together, a controller is required to fully experience this title. I personally recommend the Xbox 360 for Windows controller which retails for about $33 on Amazon.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												First and foremost, I'd like to start off by clarifying one thing. This game does NOT require a controller to play. It is a bit tricky to get used to the keyboard controls at the very beginning, but after a while it shouldn't be too difficult to get the hang of. I've personally only played this game on keyboard and have only had one or two experiences where it was kind of tough to pass a point in the game because of the keyboard controls. I'm not sure why the game's store page says having a controller is a requirement. Yes, a controller would probably make the game more enjoyable as it would be easier to control both brothers, but not having a controller doesn't make playing the game anywhere near impossible. If the only reason you're hesitating to get this game is because of the "controller requirement" on the store page, get this game. Especially when it hits around $1.5 during sales, there really isn't any reason not to get it.Moving onto the game itself, it's a nice little adventure game that you can apparently finish in 4-5 hourse (I don't know how I managed to squeeze 13 hours out of it on a single play-through). The artwork is visually stunning. Really nice soundtrack. Gameplay is fun. Provided there is virtually no comprehendable dialogue between the characters, the story was also fairly good. The story gets even better near the end. The ending itself is really nice (won't go into any details to avoid spoilers). Somebody dies and unlike the million other videogame deaths you've experienced, the game makes sure that you're really affected.Overall, I'd say this game is a must-play, especially because it doesn't even take that much of your time to finish. I don't know if the full price is really worth it considering the amount of content you get, but on sale at a bit over a dollar or as part of a bundle, this game is a must-grab.Taking all things into consideration, I'd give the game a 9/10.The biggest thing that really drawed me in was it's artwork. The game even has benches where you can just sit down and enjoy the view. Another reason I loved it was the ending. The only reason I didn't give it any higher is because I think they could've worked on the story a tad bit more and also make it longer. But again, like I already said, there isn't any comprehendable dialogue that goes on between the characters, and I understand that by doing this the game-makers wanted to show you the story and make you see it for yourself rather than have the characters tell you about it. Taking that into regards, the story doesn't dissapoint.If this game has just been sitting in your library and collecting dust, or you've been eyeing it every sale but haven't decided on actually getting it because you aren't sure whether you'll actually enjoy it, give this game a chance. I promise you it'll be a very unique experience from what other games have to offer.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												There are not enough superlative adjectives to properly describe this game.This game is the best emotional experience I have ever had. This is a more impressive work of art than any book I have read, any music I have heard, any movie that I have seen. And I'll try to dive into why and try to explain it.First of all - while a lot of the story and emotions are told with graphics and music and gestures and gibberish dialogue, this game manages to make you emotionally invested in the characters both because you play them both at the same time, and you constantly have to cooperate and interact, but also because you develop your feeling for them as the mechanics of the game develop and changes. The real experience of this game lies in holding that controller in your hands. In fact, if you as a PC gamer don't have a controller, this game alone should be motivation enough for you to get one.Second - the game has gorgeous, fabulous, amazing, stellar, fantastic graphics design. It is cute and incredibly well made when it comes to the characters, they present their personality through an amazingly well developed series of animations and articulations of their own emotions and thoughts, and use plenty of body language. The environment is a gorgeous watercolour-style and you even have a specific game mechanic just to watch the surroundings in the form of benches to sit on. The game progresses through a diverse set of environs that are very vertical, which gives you an amazing world to look at in addition to the nearer parts you can actually go to and through, which are just as good looking. Waterfalls and rock trails and town environments and mountains and battlefields and castles and woods, the game is fantastic in every aspect. I would say maybe half of the entire game time, you are looking at a view that would very well deserve to be a dektop screenshot, because it just looks that good.Third - the game is full of interesting interactions with the world, of characters and items that build the atmosphere, and who reacts to what you do in a way that really fleshes out and makes everything feel more immersive. And when things get tense and your controller starts rumbling, it enhances an emotion and setting you are already feeling from what the game has already managed to express to you.Fourth - Brothers has an amazing atmospherical sound design, from the gibberish language that makes dialogue work entirely through how things are said rather than any content of what the character say, to the ambience that makes the settings and environs feel amazingly well developed, from wind to waterfalls to strange mechanical apparatus to characters in the background, to the soundtrack that couldn't be a better fit to the emotions of the moment.Fifth - the game lets you tell the story, cutscenes are only used for telling story in amazingly small and short bursts, the vast majority of the storytelling is made by you, on the controller, guiding Naiee and Nyaa through the world.Sixth - while the aesthetics of the game are nothing short of stellar, the mechanics are solid and very well put together. Animations and actions are snappy and the characters' movements are very much not only well connected to what you do, they also tell some of the story in the form of changing slightly to adjust to you for example swimming, or holding two ends of an item, to one of the brothers being hurt, or even his emotional state.Seventh - when it comes to storytelling and world building, this game has it all. When you play it, it will be the most immersive piece of storytelling you have ever experienced. The setting goes from cute and wondrous to tense and dangerous to playful to sinister to somber to gross to harmonic to bereavement. It tells a story of a fantasy world where the sinister and the playful live side by side, where carefree happy life is just a stone's throw away from wizards turnings armies into snow sculptures, giants waging war, wolves hunting you and sinister trees trying to kill you.To categorise, this game is a single player cooperative 3D puzzle platformer adventure game. It is not long, but it is meaningful. It is a piece of art.This is the single best piece of storytelling, the most emotional of all works of art, the most immersive game I have ever experienced, and I do not doubt that if you play it the right way, undisturbed and undistracted from the game and the controller in your hands, you will feel the same. I cannot praise it enough. This is the best game I have ever played. It is the first game that has made me cry from the emotions it conveyed. And I want you to experience that too.Don't watch it being played on youtube or twitch. Don't watch a friend play it beside you. Don't play it in an environment full of distractions and sounds and people that interupt you. Play it where you can fully enjoy it, find a time and room free of distractions, put headphones on and take the controller in your hands, and just play it. When in the game, don't rush through it. Take the time to sit on the benches, view the environments, interact with the people and animals and items, immerse youself in the world and the setting, and you will be rewarded with a highly emotional and beautiful experience in a way I don't think any other game does.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2013
												Working with award winning Swedish director Josef Fares, Starbreeze Studios presents us with a downloadable story-driven adventure game. Question is can the influence of a movie director provide a fulfilling narrative and satisfying gameplay without sacrificing one or the other? Let's take a look.The premise is simple. Two brothers must find an specific object located on a map in order to cure their father of a life threatening illness. Whilst the plot itself is pretty barebones, all the subtle nuances make up for it. From the different ways the brothers interact with objects to the interchanges between them both “Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons” is firmly under the implication that actions speak louder than words, which is further accentuated by the characters speaking in gibberish which relies a lot on body language to get the exact emotion or exchange across. Thankfully the game gets this right and later on in the game hits some truly dark and morose moments that’s sure to make most people choke up slightly.The gameplay provides what can best be described as a single player co-op experience. You control both characters with each individual stick and triggers which can be difficult to wrap your head around at first but once the player is accustomed to the play style then it becomes a unique scenario where the gameplay works in tandem with the story so that these brothers feel more connected. This is especially used well in the later sections when the tone shifts and segments are given much more weight and power. Visually the game holds up great with its simple painted story book style to create some impressive looking scenes, the only drawback is that the animations can sometimes be a little jerky which is only a minor blemish on an otherwise stellar visual package. The only other major issue is the game’s length which only provides about 2-3 hours of playtime which could be a turn off for some. However this shorter length makes the game keep a steady pace and avoids any filler that could have otherwise bogged down the experience so it’s a decent payoff.Some may want to hold off until the game is cheaper but be assured that it’s definitely worth recommending. By providing a grim fairytale and unique gameplay Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons creates a memorable, albeit brief experience that is sure to stick with you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is a co-op game in single player mode in which you control two brothers at once. I saw this a perfect opportunity for my 8 y.o. little sister who wanted to play "serious games" like this so I gave her the control of the right thumbstick of the controller. Naturally, we were screaming at each other within the first 15 minutes.The puzzles are not that hard, if you are playing alone the challenge comes from coordinating both of your fingers. I had someone else so it wasn't a big deal for me (she just sometimes tend to wander a bit and do her own thing). Also, the puzzles were never boring, the obstacles are pretty varied so there was always something to enjoy.So there we are, pretending to be the two protagonists in the game who must find the magic pool of water to heal their father. We enjoyed the scenery and the music, thanked the trolls, laughed at goats, and gradually enjoyed working with another for real. We were both engrossed as the story progressed. Consequently, the yelling and the pointing of fingers stopped. The two siblings in the game, like us, had to rely on each other, despite not being equal in terms of strength or skill. It was a very obvious lesson but nonetheless it’s still something always forgotten by most people.The main theme of this game is about the importance of family. It was extra special for me because I shared the experience with another family member. My sister said she would cry so hard if the sad ending happened to us. It was a ridiculous thought, but still, it was the nicest thing she has ever said to me.  If you have a sibling or not, or a family, I still recommend this game. It has this quality that makes it impossible to put down.Overall:Gameplay and visuals are good, and the story is sweet, captivating, and moving. If you are being economical though, buy it during a sale. With its short length it’s just like going to the movies, except this one is much better than watching a movie.

												4/5This game is quaint, refreshing and beautiful. Everything from its soundtrack, to its visual design, its unique mechanics, and its cathartic and original story telling makes this game a must play.You play as two brothers, journeying across a beautiful, unfamiliar and often hostile land as they search for the waters of the mystical tree of life, in an effort to save their dying father. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												"Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons" is a quiet, magical adventure. It's more of an experience as a actual game. Although it has mechanisms, puzzles, levels, chapters and opponents, but it is mainly a journey into the unknown. And on this trip you will experience an amazing range of emotions: excitement, exuberance, shock, sadness, triumph and amazement. And all this happens without words are spoken.The game puts you in the role of an unequal pair of brothers - somewhere in an idyllic fantasy world in the style of Scandinavian myths. The big brother is strong, brave and experienced. The little one is a bit hesitant. He can't swim, for example. But his size is a clear advantage. He has no trouble squeezing through small gaps. You control both guys at the same time - with the two analog sticks of your gamepad. The keyboard control is pretty ♥♥♥♥ed up, so don't waste your time on that. With a pad in hand, however, "Brothers" turns quickly as clever finger exercise in game design.The adventure starts quite slowly. First, you explore the local village but later you will meet Fable figures, explore a mine full of strange equipment, crosses creepy forests, and visit the scenes of past battles. I took some of my personal best screenshots, while playing "Brothers". Feel free to check them out.I would really like to describe the brillant moments now, but to enjoy the game right, I will stay with suggestions. Also: "Brothers" is moving, surprising, unique and for me one of the most thrilling games of the last years.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												If you were dismayed that you were never able to play Journey because it was a Playstation exclusive, or played it and wanted more, look no further: Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is the Journey for the PC platform.The characters are silent but expressive. The environments colorful and vibrant, yet at times dark and twisted. The path is straightforward, but full of hidden secrets along the way. This is not a game of reflexes and precision - there is no user interface to distract the player from everything that goes on. This is one of those fancy shmancy 'all about the experience' games; if you're not the type of player who likes a slower paced game, Brothers will not appeal to you. However, if an odyssey through gorgeous unknown lands with a silent storytelling scheme sounds like your kind of game, Brothers is the kind of game where you can get lost in.The game is played from the perspective of the two Brothers, controlled simultaneously. Despite the label, you do not need a controller to play this game; keyboard alone will work fine, though a controller will feel more natural. The two brothers have only two actions: moving, and a context-sensitive action button. It may not seem complex, but when you coordinate the two brothers at once to navigate puzzles, a single action button per brother is plenty. The brothers may move in similar fashion, but you soon learn they have their own strengths, which I will not spoil as some of them are story-centric.And did I mention the environment is astounding? There are countless hidden secrets and interactables, with the two brothers reacting differently to most of them. Everything in this game is hand-crafted and visually stunning. No lens-flare, no blood-on-the-camera, just luscious amounts of scenery porn. If you're packing a good graphics card, this is where you'll be happy to have it.You would think a game where one controls two characters independently to be confusing, but it successfully creates a challenge rather than an annoying gimmick. Imaginative and inspiring, melding gameplay with adventure, Brothers is going to be a must-have for most people. If one wonders whether or not gameplay is art, wonder no longer - you'll be too engrossed in this game to care.The only criticism is the stupid lever at the start of the game. God damn that lever.The game is also pretty short; there's no doubt it's thorough, well-paced, and end at a good time, but it does leave one wanting to find more....P.S.: As a side note, the game can also be crudely played with two people, one controlling each brother. While it may take away from the mechanical challenge of having to control two entities, it throws in a fun teamwork element and allows you to enjoy the game with a second person. We played with one person on keyboard and another on controller, but having two people on keyboard is also possible. Since the game is not 'meant' to be played this way, you may find some parts easier or more difficult than normal, but I can attest that the game will still be satisfying to play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
www.suchgameshame.com For my first game of 2015 I decided to give Brother AToTS the time it so rightfully deserves.I have had this game sitting in my library since the summer sale on steam in 2014. Truth be told I tried to play it before, only committing 23 minutes to it before stopping and subsequently never playing it again. THE SHAME.But now, I am delighted to say I have finished it and oh my days, what an emotional roller coaster! The notebook which I used to jot down important moments or feelings I had it filled with tear stains and smiley faces. This game is of the standard of The Last of Us... WITHOUT using any bleedin' words!! :/  WOW.The very first thing I wrote in the note book was - "Brothers begins with kicking you full force in your emotional testicles."And the last thing I wrote in the notebook was - " : ( " (sad face)I feel ashamed I haven't played this already! It took only 2 hours of my time, but left a bigger impact than any other game I can think of (except for TLOU). This game goes for €2.79 during the sales.  BUY IT, AND PLAY IT.The story is about 2 brothers who set out on an adventure to save their father from an illness. You are given a map and sent on your way to find a cure for him. The game play is interesting, I used a DualShock 4, my left analog was the older brother and the right analog was the younger. It took some getting use to, and I had to stop every now and again to switch the brothers back to their left and right side respectively because my brain couldn't cope with them being on the opposite sides to their positions on the controller. I think that's a problem with my brain though, maybe some people wouldn't have any issues here.The game uses simple platforming and puzzles to allow you to traverse the environments. I was never frustrated by any of them and I think they were used to the best of the developers abilities to include interesting game mechanics that supported the player experiencing the story and world and never becoming bogged down my the controls themselves.The aesthetics's in the beginning bored me...I'll be honest. I thought they where child like and fable-ish. Maybe that's why I stopped my first play through. But let me tell you the game quickly grows into itself and within the first half an hour you encounter creatures and vista's that genuinely make you smile, you know like that smile your dog does when you come home from work. That sort of silly smiley, dopey in a way but utterly infectious and it instantly makes everything better? YEAH, this game does it to you every couple of minutes. :OThe world is filled with some many interesting concepts and creatures, from Giants to crazy Cults, Griffins to Orca creatures. I was captivated and kept in the lore of the world. You'll explore desolate spider dungeons and mountains where Giants fight. The game is engrossing and adorable. It has a charm that I was not expecting at all, I found myself invested in the world and I loved every second.Music is top notch and would frequently gave me chills & thrills depending on what was happening. I was certainly not left wanting by it in anyway shape or form.Ok so I'll wrap this up with listing off  the order my emotions and feelings during my playthrough :Emotional kick to the nuts,Adorable,Exciting,Haunting,Lighthearted,Fun,Devastated,Speechless,Whimsical,SPIDER BABY,♥♥♥♥ No,Stupid Spider Baby FUUU,Incredible Magic Tree,Chills,Relief,Distraught,Can't Even, :(.And that's just what I could make out on my tear stained pages. lol. If you have this game and haven't played it then stop being a Procrastinating Gamer and do it already you won't regret it. If you don't own it... GO BUY IT.... and then play it... RIGHT NOW!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Brothers is a game where two brothers embark on a quest to bring back water from a giant tree far away from home to cure their father. I didn't really expect anything when I bought and played this game, and boy I was in for a treat. The cinematography in this game is amazing, there are many times you would have that urge to just stop for a moment and take a screenshot of where you are.In this game, you have to rely on what you see to understand what is happening. The characters do speak, but you won't really understand much since they speak a fictional language. This does raise a few questions here and there, but overall they do a fantastic job at painting the tone of the world. The gameplay is unique, and I recommend using the controller for the best experience. Storywise? Amazing. There are several memorable moments, some of joy while others of somber and they sure know how to hit them feels. During my initial playthrough I had mixed feelings about the story. But upon rethinking I can appreciate how they did the story. This is a story of two brothers, travelling in a beautiful but harsh world. They live in a world where there is love and kindness, but they must also be cautious and prepared for the dangers hiding in every corner.The only thing I would complain is that the playtime is a bit short, but other than that it's a 10/10 to me. Highly recommended game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												A beautiful game.  A Narnia-esque world accompanied by a musical score that accents all the emotional moments, as well as utilizing silence in some of the best ways I have seen in video games.  A modern twist on a side-scrolling platformer, 'Brothers' has you controlling two separate characters with each joystick (or opposite sides of the keyboard), and I recommend keeping each brother on the side of the screen that corresponds to his control side.  This control scheme works brilliantly and I am sure will be copied for years to come.All I will say about this game is that it is a must play.  The collision detection can be off, some pop-in may occur and your character might not do exactly what you want on occasion, but to let any of these minor flaws deter you from playing this game would be a shame.  It manages to bring together ideas from games like Uncharted, God of War, Journey and Heavy Rain all into a 3 hour storytelling masterpiece.Worth it at full price, easy, and the biggest steal ever when it goes on sale (80% off on occasion!). Do yourself a favor, buy this game.  Take your time.  Explore off the beaten path, when you can, and just enjoy it.  Do your best to avoid spoilers and you will be handsomely rewarded.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is a neat little game with a well-structured plot that is interwoven rather well with its novel control scheme. Unfortunately, however, it leaves much to be desired in terms of core gameplay.Despite the presence of weak puzzling and platforming elements, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is little more than a “press forward to win” game albeit one with a somewhat interesting, but often derpy, control scheme. I used a gamepad on my playthrough and found the controls to be quite intuitive for the most part. If Lefty/Righty finds his way to the right/left of his sibling, however, what was once practical quickly becomes a derpfest of wrestling with the controls. It's not particularly bothersome but it does serve to emphasise how, with a duration of just two to three hours, I barely had time to get comfortable with the controls. Yet, in this short time, I still found many elements of gameplay tedious and repetitive. Expect to slog through the same “puzzle” several times in quick succession and spend most of your time moving forward unchallenged by NPCs or the environment.Without any sense of challenge or urgency, I felt like I was just going through the motions and waiting for the climax. I believe the pay-off in the final stages of the game was fantastic but the larger experience left me unsatisfied. The story itself was fine and characterisation was done quite well, and rather innovatively, despite the short play time. The use of a gibberish non-language throughout, however, really detracted from what might otherwise have been emotive moments. I laughed when my characters were frustrated, upset or afraid and I urged them to STFU when they expressed their anguish.Looking back on some of the screenshots I took, there were many areas that struck me visually and I thought the art direction was beautifully executed. One visual gripe I have with the game is that every time there is a cutscene, a substantial portion of screen real estate is wasted on black bars. This was a design choice and one that audiences, as I certainly did, may find jarring throughout their time with the game. The intended audience of this game is a little murky; I kept thinking the gameplay might be well-placed in a game for children but that notion just doesn't sit well with the game's many grim tonal shifts.Overall, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is a technically polished game with a lot of potential but it's hard to recommend it on the basis of anything but its fleeting novelty.Unidimensional, unchallenging, mercifully short.Still worth a look.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
A Tale of Twin Sticks I recently got hooked up with a 360 controller for my PC and a buddy of mine said "man you gotta play this game now that you have a controller!" I always considered myself Mr. "PC Master Race" keyboard/mouse guy, so I thought to myself, "yea yea whatevs...I'll give it a shot". Within 2 minutes of firing up this gem I was hooked. The art design is absolutely gorgeous. The environment and scenery are lush and beautiful. The character animations are mind blowing. Little touches, like stopping to pet a kitty, or messing with an old curmudgeon...things that don't forward progress, yet they took the time and effort to give the animations such care and character. True art. The puzzles are quite unique as well. Not difficult, but because of controlling two characters at once, they are unusual. Trapping the ogre in the cage...and then getting to taunt him! Classic stuff! Above and beyond all else though, the story is universal subject matter that most everyone can relate to, and will gloriously pull at your heart strings. Heavy moments, coupled with all the cute and clever moments, make it one you will remember forever.Playing this game feels like living out a childrens book. I truly believe we have a timeless classic here. The kind of game that won't age, or become obsolete over time, like most video games do.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												Absolutely amazing. Easily one of the greatest experiences I've ever had with a game. I don't think a game has ever evoked so many personal emotions from me. I am a younger brother and my elder is 6 years apart from me. This game truly touches me on a deep level with the utilization of sound, music, lighting, voicing, expression, and atmosphere. Although the characters speak in an indistiguishable language (mostly, apart from the brothers' names), their vocubulary leaves nothing to be desired and is communicated flawlessly. I believe this was intentional and means to give the player the ability to fill in the blanks with what (s)he feels appropriate, which is likely something personal and easy to connect with.The characters themselves are easy to relate to and offer excellent development as characters. The story is extremely simple, but communicated in such a beautiful way, I can't help but be floored this game lasted me nearly 3 hours. I already want to play it through a second time and find if there was anything I missed (other than achievements which are very satisfying and well hidden) which would give more richness to the world itself. The character models may not suit my taste, however, the art style makes up for any personal issue I have with the models themselves. I've taken a handful of screenshots from this game and am one right-click away from setting one as my desktop background.The game itself offers many puzzles and challenges which are never frustrating, yet still require thought and patience to accomplish. The flow of the gameplay has never once been interrupted for me and leaves very very little room for criticism. I'm greatly impressed with how the developers managed to keep such a simple mechanic of using two joysticks to control each brother sp fresh and entertaining even while repeating some puzzles over again. The game continually gets easier as the player becomes accustomed to the mechanics, but there are plenty of instances where I've had to stop and rearrange the brothers because I had trouble keeping the two moving naturally. This is not the game's fault at all, rather it is my own and the game should be praised for continuing to challenge me with such a simple and logical mechanic, but still retaining its challenge by requiring constant attention. Excellent puzzles and mechanics; they offer many challenges.I highly reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys puzzles, challenging multitasking, rich worlds with deep story, has an appreciation for music and environment, and especially anyone with a brother (hell, even a sister) who they care deeply for. You will not regret this purchase or the time you invest into it.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												I played this game with an xbox controller so this is how I am reviewing it. It was really interesting and challenging to control both of the brothers at the same time. One half of the control controlled the younger brother and the other half controlled the older brother. The controls, however, weren't difficult to understand since only the 2 scroll buttons and the triggers are used. Past the controllers, there was absolutely no dialogue which kind of threw me off at first, but once I played a bit more, I realized the game didn't need dialogue. The story was pretty straight forward, however twisty it DOES get at the end, and it gives you exactly what you need as you go through it. The graphics and artwork in this game are absolutely astounding. I'd play this game over and over again just so I could get a look at the scenery. There are little benches all over so if you see them, PLEASE sit down and scroll around you really will not regret it, it's amazing. The story isn't very long, but it still makes you feel very attached to the characters. This is much more like a visual story game than anything, even though you control the brothers, because there is only one ending but the story is so interesting that it's worth it. I didn't really find anything I disliked about the game. I mean, yes, it was a bit difficult to control both of the brothers at the same time, but I think that added to the interest level. I feel like if I was only playing one of the brothers, it wouldn't have been so imersive. This also made me feel connected to the two brothers because I was able to see how most of the things you needed to do, came with the reliance of the two brothers. You wouldn't have been able to finish the story if you didn't have both of them...

												10/10 would bawl like a baby again.Seriously though, this game isn't so much of a game as it is a story. It features some puzzles, so it's a bit of a puzzle game, but you don't feel like the characters are you; more like you are watching them live their lives even though you control them.I bought it for $1.49 during the Steam Summer Sale 2016 and that was a steal to say the least.The worst part for me wasn't when the older brother died, nor when it made you bury him, but when you watch a man try to hang himself after his house and family burned in a fire. content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												This is a beautiful story that really helped me grieve the death of my grandfather.  It is short: about 2-3 hours, but the art, music and story are as good as a movie.  The gameplay is fun and makes your brain engage more in what's happening (uses a controller).  Get the game on sale and enjoy a truly touching tale of the love of two sons that causes them to risk their lives to save their father.  And if you don't like reading or hearing a lot of dialogue, this game is for you.  I spent 10 minutes trying to turn on the subtitles.  How does pointing communicate so much? I guess love is truly a universal language.I will play this again just like I'll watch all the Miyazaki films again.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												No words can describe how amazing this game is. You are fully immersed in this game from begining to end. The simple motivation of two brothers wanting to save their dad is an honest goal in itself, but for these two to go above and beyond to continue. With no dialog (thats understandable) what so ever, you feel deep down what is driving these two. Other people might not see it as I do, but the younger brother continues out of fear; the fear of losing a father, not knowing the fate they are to be left in without a watchful protecter- while the older brother acts out of love; love for his little brother, to show him not all is lost, that their is always hope. Well not those words exactly, but whatever.Replay value is high especially when you want to show an incredble adventure to others who have never played. The game is bitter sweet so if you can't handle feels you should brace yourself. This game will forever be in my top 10 Favorite games, atleast as indie games go.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
WARNING: SPOILERS WILL BE COVERED BY BLACK BOXES LIKE THIS. IF YOU DO NOT WISH TO SEE THEM, DO NOT MOUSE OVER THEM.After replaying through this game again a few nights ago, I realize that I still haven't written a review for it. Well, better late than never (holy crap, it's already been almost a year?!).If I were to run into you on the street, and (for God only knows what reason) you wanted my overall thoughts on the game in a single sentence, I'd tell you, "I don't know why you're talking to me and not playing this game." I'm not exaggerating when I say that Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is the best indie game and possibly the greatest game I have ever played. Honestly, if you're just reading this to see if the game's worth $15, take my word for it. I would refuse to pay a cent less for such a fantastic game.For those who don't know, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is a short adventure puzzle platformer in which each half of your controller (or keyboard, as I hear does work, but I'd imagine it's a bit wonky) controls a separate character - brothers Naia (older - left half) and Naiee (younger - right half). As far as I'm aware, the game is virtually glitchless, although I did have an instance where Naiee fell through the floor and died while picking up a turtle for a sidequest. Speaking of the quest, it's actually incredibly linear, but not in a bad way. The game's layout could not be better suited for the story. Not EVERY game has to be "like Skyrim with guns" as the saying goes. The gameplay is innovative and even plays a crucial role in the story. SPOILER TAG: "A friend is one soul in two bodies." -Aristotle When the creator tried getting companies to publish the game, he said it's a singleplayer experience in the guise of a co-op game. Thank God Starbreeze came along and took interest in the game, else we wouldn't have this masterpiece to talk about. However, personally I played this with a friend sharing a controller the first time through, and I would have to disagree. It's equally as great either way. With a friend, it's easier to manage, having to only focus on one character, and the storyline immerses you into creating almost brotherly bonds. However, it's just as good to play alone, because you can experience the story the way it was intended - by not fearing to shed your manly tears in front of your comrades.Speaking of which, the story is written by Josef Fares, a Swedish film writer who had a really rough childhood. SPOILER TAG: Remember the ending burial scene? Of course you do. How the hell could you forget something as touching as that? It turns out that was a childhood memory of Fares'. He always wanted a little brother, so when his mother went into labor, he was so excited. In the end, the baby died, so Fares had to bury it himself. Try thinking about that next time you play that part and try not to cry. For those who haven't played the game and are avoiding the spoiler tag, I apologize for tempting you with the enormous spoiler box. Needless to say, Fares' past experiences had a huge impact on his works, so despite what you may think, it may look cute, but there is a monster hidden within. With several instances of morbid scenes and scenery hardly scattered throughout, this game rightfully deserves its rating of T for Teen.The graphics are some of the best I have ever seen in any game ever. Screw Battlefield 4, Skyrim, or any other stereotypical games with "realistic" graphics. Despite having a cartoonish feel to it, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons has the most atmospheric landscape of any game I have ever played. Water, foliage, shadows and sunlight, everything looks absolutely incredible. But every aspect of this game has something morbid or sad, and the graphics are no exception. Have you ever played an FPS and thought about how unrealistic blood looks? In this game, blood looks disgustingly realistic. I gagged a little bit in the land of the giants. At one point, you have to push a corpse holding an axe to chop an arm off that is blocking your path. It's incredibly morbid, and you should expect nothing less from this game.And finally the soundtrack. Whether the mood of a scene is sad, happy, epic, or scary, the music is always there to accompany it in perfect harmony (see what I did there?). With its orchestral, cinema quality soundtrack, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons uses music to make you feel the emotions that characters would feel as if these scenes had happened to you. In a story driven game like this, a fitting soundtrack is essential, because unless you are like Fares, you can't relate to all these dark and depressing events, and an emotional soundtrack can give you a push. Obviously, this feeling is nothing close to how it would be if these things actually happened to you, but it's probably as close as we would ever want to be.TL;DR: The game's graphics, soundtrack, gameplay, and most of all storyline are all phenomenal. Don't be fooled, this game is dark. It's a bit short at around 3 hours, but it's fun to replay and reexperience the overwhelming emotions it will give you.Overall rating: 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Honestly, what can I say... I never cried so much in my life. This is not a game for very sensible persons (like me). I just finished the game and I need to hug my teddy bear really long to get over the story.In terms of gameplay, I actually have nothing negative to report. The controls are simple but can still confuse as you go on in the adventure. The puzzles are quick to understand and can be solved without experiencing much frustration. Sometimes, I think it might be a little bit too easy. There is no part where you can get stuck or that is really challenging in my opinion. Still, I don't see it as a problem since the game is not about feeling awesome after solving a hard puzzle or bypassing a large obstacle and more about telling the story of the brothers. Difficult puzzles would maybe ruin this experience.The narrative of the story is just fantastic. Even without using an acutal understandable language (the characters in this game speak some a made-up language + there are no subtitles), it is always clear what the characters in the game are saying or what they are talking about (also because they use gestures which helps out a lot). The story and (if existend) the relation of the individual characters is easily understandable.Sure, the game is pretty short (it took me two hours to finish it without having all achievements) but I think it's the right length. Since the gameplay is simple, you can only do so much to keep it fresh and entertaining. Maybe one level more wouldn't have hurt but I don't think it's necessary either.All in all, Borther - A Tale of Two Sons is an entertaining, small and also emotional experience. If you're looking for a quick and fun game and you're not the most sensible person out there (*sob*), definitly check out this game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												I have not yet finished the game, but if the first level is any indication it may be heading to my list of favourite single player games. This game has caught me by surprise (much like XCOM: Enemy Unknown did). However, unlike the technical praise I might give XCOM:EU, I found the story and simplicity of the game to be a refreshing change of pace.The interface to the game comes in the form of a "unique single player cooperative experience". That description is quite accurate but I would not label it as the biggest selling point of the game. Although the experience is very unique, it can at times be a bit overwhelming. The unique controls are not enough to detract from the presentation of the story. I've found many of the puzzles challenging enough without being impossible. But the interface to the game is not what draws me to it, rather it is the presentation that gives it a special place in my collection.We live in a time where all forms of media are pushing the boundaries of privacy, violence and sex. Rarely do we see anything from music videos to video games that can't succeed without a healthy dose of one or all of the above. I only point out this fact because this game is presented with what you might call a traditional sense of innocence. It reminds me of simpler times when movies like Milo and Otis and Homeward Bound would provide enough escape from the oft-times drab realities of our daily lives. Don't get me wrong the game does have violence, so did Milo & Otis and Homeward Bound. There's a vast difference between the violence presented in those movies (and in the game) and the kind we see on HBO's latest "adventure" TV show.This game doesn't replace those more adult-themed shows, movies and games that I do enjoy. Rather this game is something apart from them, it strikes that simplistic adventure nerve just right to keep me coming back for a little more every night.Do I recommend the game? Absolutely, just remember to hang your cynicism at the door and bring your heart and a sense of humour and you'll love it. :)

												Rating: 4.5/5Brothers is a relatively short game, but is rich in story and art.  The single-player co-op experience is handled very well: the puzzles challenge your multi-tasking ability without seeming too unfair.  There are plenty of checkpoints so it's never stressfull.  The world's scenery is simplistic, yet stunningly beautiful; the accompanying music sets each scene's tone perfectly.One aspect that I like about the game is that the brothers can interact with the world around them - even if it doesn't add to the story; it makes them seem a lot more human than a lot of other linear games I've played.The only part that I didn't like too much was the end.  While I get the reason for the ending, the way the scene is shot before the credits roll conflicts with the rest of the narrative.Once you've played through the whole game, there isn't much other replay value besides collecting all the easy achievements.
