number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												"Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons" is a quiet, magical adventure. It's more of an experience as a actual game. Although it has mechanisms, puzzles, levels, chapters and opponents, but it is mainly a journey into the unknown. And on this trip you will experience an amazing range of emotions: excitement, exuberance, shock, sadness, triumph and amazement. And all this happens without words are spoken.The game puts you in the role of an unequal pair of brothers - somewhere in an idyllic fantasy world in the style of Scandinavian myths. The big brother is strong, brave and experienced. The little one is a bit hesitant. He can't swim, for example. But his size is a clear advantage. He has no trouble squeezing through small gaps. You control both guys at the same time - with the two analog sticks of your gamepad. The keyboard control is pretty ♥♥♥♥ed up, so don't waste your time on that. With a pad in hand, however, "Brothers" turns quickly as clever finger exercise in game design.The adventure starts quite slowly. First, you explore the local village but later you will meet Fable figures, explore a mine full of strange equipment, crosses creepy forests, and visit the scenes of past battles. I took some of my personal best screenshots, while playing "Brothers". Feel free to check them out.I would really like to describe the brillant moments now, but to enjoy the game right, I will stay with suggestions. Also: "Brothers" is moving, surprising, unique and for me one of the most thrilling games of the last years.

												After coming off fresh from playing this game, I will go ahead and say, I thought this game was gorgeous.  Granted, the puzzles weren't too difficult, but then again, the game is called A Tale of Two Sons, not A Puzzle of Two Sons.  In its essence, this game is more of an interactive story.  However, to really get the full enjoyment and characterization out of this game, you really need to go out of your way to explore and interact with your environment.  For example, through interactions I discovered  that the younger brother is better with animals than the elder but the elder is more liked by adults .  Some take issue with the story the game tells but I found it enjoyable and enough to tug at my heartstrings at moments.  Periodically throughout the game, there will be benches that allow you to see the carefully sculpted vistas that give you a sense of the magical world these brothers live in.  Granted, the game may not have too much replay value, but you definietely owe it to yourself to play it once.  Even if you have to wait until it goes on sale to be able to do it, buy this game when you have the chance.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												A very outstanding game. The mechanic is very simple. Control two brothers simultaneously using a twin stick control scheme. One brother is right stick and interacts via right trigger, while the other brother is left stick and interacts via left trigger. The game manages to come up with a lot of creative ways for the two brothers to work together to overcome various types of situations. I'd like to go into specifics about all the ways the cooperation between the brothers is used, but I'm afraid it might be too spoilery to do so. Discovering each cooperation scenario is part of the discovery and fun.If there were any aspects of the game I did not like, I would say these small---very small---nitpicks:1) There were two or three spots where what I was supposed to do in a particular situation was not clear or an object that was supposed to be a handhold was not super apparent. I killed one of the brothers a few times just on account of not understanding what the game was trying to signal to me. But these moments were tiny and few.2) This is more of a peeve than an actual problem with the game but---while I typically don't mind when creators use their own made-up languages for character dialogue in a work (e.g. Ico, SotC, Ewok, Klingon, Elven, etc)---something about the made-up language in this game was sort of irritating to me. I don't know how to describe it other than to say that it was just too obviously gibberish. There was no illusion of it being an actual language. But language study/analysis is sort of close to my heart in a way that it probably won't be for most players, so this is most likely just an idiosyncrasy of mine.The game is a tad bit on the short side (about 3 hours), but it is fun and VERY beautiful to look at. I don't just mean the graphics, I mean just artistically. The composition of some of the vistas and area changes are just masterfully done.Using my own scale below, I give Brothers the full seven.7) A classic, essential, and/or must-buy game that is worth full price.6) A good game that is worth the full price.5) A pretty good game worth checking out--especially if discounted.4) A pretty good game, but I would recommend buying it discounted.3) Worth checking out, but I would recommend buying it heavily discounted.2) Only worth checking out if you are dangerously curious.1) Avoid at all costs.

												Beautiful game. I was describing it to someone and rather liked my comparison to Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time. This game is an adventure/puzzle game where you control two charming young boys as they make their way through the world on a simple quest. The game is linear and the puzzles are fairly easy, but nevertheless I find myself falling in love with the game. After crawling your way through a cave and scaling the walls of a cliff, you'll find yourself with a breath-taking view of the landscape, part of which you just traversed and part of which you've yet to delve into. It's very well-polished, controls intuitively, doesn't scream in your face or break immersion with pointless tutorials. No worrying about rpg-grind elements to pad those numbers, just pure joy as you explore a world made with care. This is the kind of game that hipster gamers point to when extoling the virtues of indie gaming.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
												I have always wanted a video game to make me cry. It is mostly my own fault as I tend to be a mechanics first, narrative second kind of player. I think it's rational enough considering that the medium should focus on the degree of interactivity first and then supplement that with a strong narrative. I wish that would happen more often. When a game focuses solely on its mechanics, the story tends to seem like an afterthought. This model has evolved over the years with new technology and larger budgets, but the primary problem is still present: there has yet to be a video game that has the perfect marriage of both. Like what Don Quixote is to books and Citizen Kane is to movies, there must be a game that can single-handedly shift this paradigm and create a new precedent. And in the most unexpected of places, I believe that I have discovered one of the most compelling narrative experiences of all time: Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons. Brothers was created by Starbreeze Studios, a developer who is not typically known for small, story-driven games sold at a $15 dollar price point. In fact, the majority of their most popular titles are first person shooters with the phenomenal Chronicles of Riddick: Assault on Dark Athena and PAYDAY: THE HEIST leading the charge. In addition to Starbreeze's development, Brothers was aided by visionary Swedish film director, Josef Fares. It was an unusual and ambitious notion to consider a film director to help create a video game, but Starbreeze felt it was necessary, and they were right. Brothers tells the story of two brothers, one young and one old, working together in an epic journey to save their dying father by obtaining the waters at the Tree of Life. The dialogue between these brothers is done through utter gibberish as opposed to recognizable language. I wouldn't call it gibberish in the traditional sense, though, as there are some common words, such as the names of the brothers, Naiee and Nyaa, which are words heard consistently throughout the story. However, at no point does the game try to translate the language that is being spoken. It does not rely on intelligible language to tell the conventional tale; you know what you have to do even if you do not understand what you are told, either through gestures or the way that the environment presents the problem. It tells a coherent and recognizable story through complete ambiguity, and that is a remarkable achievement. On a fundamental level, Brothers is a single-player cooperative adventure game. As dichotomous as it sounds, this cooperative mechanic is true as you control each brother individually. It’s remarkably simple. The older brother, Nyaa, is controlled by the top left analog stick of the Xbox 360 controller, whereas young Naiee is by the bottom right analog stick. I have never seen a controller used in such an unconventional manner. Most games have to adapt to the interface technology; they have to build games around the way the controller works. And, of course, Brothers does that as every game has to do that to some extent. However, what Brothers manages to do is create a game that is perfectly suited to its controls and takes full advantage of what that controller has to offer.The core mechanics of Brothers exist in its platforming, puzzle solving, and control of two characters at once. The puzzles in particular are a testament to Starbreeze’s mastery of the genre. They never overstay their welcome and are always supplemented with more challenging and varied obstacles. They are not necessarily difficult puzzles, but they are satisfying ones that take advantage of the game’s unique controls. For instance, there was one sequence in which both of the brothers are tied together by a long rope. Unlike the normal freedom of movement presented throughout the game, the rope creates a unique restrictive dynamic to many of the usual tasks in the game. It makes the usually-mundane act of movement a more alien and onerous undertaking. Brothers consistently shows that it is not afraid to challenge the traditional gameplay approach in hopes for a more engaging experience.Brothers delivers the most emotionally charged stories I have ever experienced within a video game. Have I cried at the movies before? Sure. Have I cried when reading a book? Absolutely. However, I have never felt such a powerful emotional reaction with any video game until I played Brothers — and I am thrilled to admit that. I not only cried, I experienced a full breadth of emotional responses including sadness, happiness, wanderlust, horror, and most importantly in a game about family, compassion. And all of these emotions are delivered in a fantastic and mature way that at no point ever feels forced. Everything feels genuine; and it elicits all of these emotional responses without ever telling you to feel in a certain way. It does not tell its story through exposition-laden cut scenes or a bunch of celebrity voice acting. It did it by simply showing you this thematically beautiful world and allowing you to get immersed and involved in it, and many games struggle to achieve that. Brothers, unfortunately, suffers from some problems. There is no real question about that. Most of the time it comes from the game’s rigid adherence to the physical location where each brother must stand when taking part in an action. The game requires that each of those characters stand in a set position, and if you are standing in the opposite position it will awkwardly swap them over and rotate the characters. To see such unnatural movements within a mechanically focused game like Brothers is jarring, and unfortunately it made for a less immersive experience at times. I would also heavily criticize the aesthetic of the game. While its art direction is serviceable, the actual graphical fidelity leaves something to be desired. There were a few textures that looked outright hideous, and the design of many of the character models felt uninspired. It then became glaringly obvious that Starbreeze allocated most of its resources to the design of the brothers rather than the fidelity of the world in which they inhabit. Nevertheless, in those spellbinding moments before the games conclusion, it is hard to remember what, if anything, was wrong with the game in the first place.The culmination of the Brothers experience lies in its masterfully presented ending.  It doesn’t just show you this powerful ending moment and expect an emotional response; it lets you play it. It lets you conduct this horrifying moment in its entirety. And suddenly, you realize that this game was never telling you a story; you were playing the story. Your journey was the story. And that’s when I cried.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												Beautiful, Emotional, cinematic and at all times engaging.  This is a fine example of what can be acheived when film creators make the effort with a game.  Battlefield it is not and I love it for that very reason.  In a world where the same format keeps repeating itself year after year, Brothers stands apart.The graphics are simply stunning, not because of any amazing high resolution claims or because it has super high FPS but because the designers made sure that every step looked correct, flowed properly and added to the atmosphere and emmersion or the players experience.Brothers is the very essence of a game, it does not take long to complete (approx 3 hours) but you feel like you could play it for days.  In fact it has left me wanting more from this team.A must purchase for all serious gamers and fantasy loving film buffs.  Do you want to loose your sense of reality for a few hours?  Forget the cinema, give this your attention and you will wish for more.I should add that I had the luxury of playing this on three 27" Dell Screens in true widescreen format (FOV 143.30) and it is without doubt the best multi display game that I have played.  The game felt huge and very emmersive.  So if you want to WOW your friends with your three screen gaming rig, put this on and watch their faces. (Remember to setup the correct FOV for your setup first or everything will look too big and close up)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												This game proves that a game doesn't have to be made by some big publisher or need to have hours of gameplay. This game shows that a game just needs to have a good story as well as some good gameplay and "Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons" does just that.The story follows two brothers - the younger brother Naiee and the older brother Naia, the story begins with Naiee praying at his mother's grave who drowned at sea while he was unable to save her. Naia then calls upon Naiee to help carry his ill father to the village doctor. Upon arriving to the doctor, the doctor informs them that he cannot save their father unless they collect the magical water of a mystical tree in a far away land. The story then follows them on their adventure to retrieve the water to cure their father with them facing many challenges and meeting many interesting characters while on their adventure. The story is very immersive and emotional even though the idea is very simplistic and gets enjoyable right after the first 5 minutes.In terms of gameplay, the game is very innovative when it comes to its gameplay where both brothers are controlled by one half of your controller at the same time and requires coordination by the player to pull off the brothers "teamwork" to overcome various obstacles and puzzles. Even though the gameplay only lasts for 2-3 hours, the game is very satisfying and I doubt that anyone will be dissapointed about its length after finishing the game.The music and sounds are one of the strongest points of the game as it is the key immersion factor of the game and it does a good job in adding the right sound track at the right time. The dialogue may be debatable, since the game has no dialogue and the vocals are like those in Sims where the game tries to show everyone as incapable of producing actual words and can only grunt or make obnoxious sounds. I feel that it added to the emotion since it was mainly expression and kind of made it as though you could decide how happy or sad the characters were but that is just my opinion and some people may dislike this factor.Overall I would say this game is a must buy for those who love immersive and emotional stories and would give this game an overall of 8.75 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												A really memorable and well-crafted experience. It's one of the few experiences that actually reminded me of how I remember my childhood: it started with a strong fairy tale feel where something is not quite right, and gradually grew progressively grim as the brothers were thrust into a world where children are not immune to hardship. Before playing it, I was concerned it would be another recycled story about annoying/sad/bratty stock-character kids, but I'm pleased to say that it's one of the more balanced and mature portrayals of children that shows them as human beings with an actual personality.In terms of gameplay, the way they combined it with the story development makes Brothers one of gaming's gems: all the story is told through the environment and the interactions the player has with the world, and there is no (comprehensible) dialogue. The best story moments are twists based on how you control both brothers in different situations. One of my favorite examples is an area where you need to avoid detection from a monster by hiding in specific positions behind frozen statues. Another is a battlefield for giants, where navigating the environment becomes a nice twist. All the areas you explore are filled with little contextual interactions that will make you will feel like you "toy"with this unforgiving world and its inhabitants, just like a child would. Complementing this approach is a truly special and stylized art direction, the kind that makes me stop and take screenshots every minute or so.The amount of soul & care put in the details of this game, from memorable story moments to little interactions in the world, is rare to find in games nowadays. Very short but very sweet.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												A very moving game. This is an example of gameplay mechanics blending with the story to create something more. Powerfully moving, I would recommend this game to anyone who things that games are nothing but shooty shooty wartime shooters. The mechanic to move both characters is unique, and also very intuitive. I didn't find it as difficult or uncomfortable as I thought it would be. It's an idea that I had never thought of and haven't seen before. It creates a feeling of attachment to both of the characters, preventing the dreaded, "escort quest" feel. Their lives are in my hands as a player and I feel comfortable taking responsibility. This game does deal with mature themes in a way that doesn't completely digest or resolve them. The setting and atmosphere starts "safe" and somber. Then, through advancing the story the game gets into some very dark and twisted themes that are real, and also unpleasent. I am very happy I bought it. I'm very happy I stayed up all night playing it. I'd go through it again for the very first time if I could. Unfortunately I can't. So I'd ask that you do it for me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a rather unique, very charming 2-3 hour adventure. It has some great art direction and some truly imaginitive areas. In an industry where some studios believe the only colours are brown and grey, it's great to see a game with such a rich colour palette. It impressivly also manages to tell a compelling and personal story without uttering a single word of dialogue, at least none that the player is meant to understand.Brothers does unfortunally have some adjusting when it comes to the controls. Using an Xbox controller you move both brothers with each analog stick, which is often confusing, but this is okay after about a half an hour or so. This problem isn't too bad and doesn't affect the expierence too much but is still a minor annoyance. Other than that Brothers controls only use two buttons to interact (one for each brother). It's a beautifully simplistic system and dispite there only being one button it always does what you expect it to thanks to clever design.Still Brothers to me is all about the journey, it creates some jaw dropping environments and contains some of the most memorable moments for me all year. You'll start off in a simple village with your dying father and go to places that seem right out of a fairy tale. It consistently introduces new gameplay mechanics and does away with them before they get stale or repetitive. Same can be said for the environments and the entire game as it's well paced and designed. As David Cage of Quantic Dream would say the game makes you feel emotion and it understands what it needs to do in order to achieve this (now if only he knew how to do that in his games). It's not for everyone, gamers who like a lot of content for their money will undoubtedly be disappointed as Brothers is quite a short expierence which really only needs to be played once for the non-completionist and it's not exactly the hardest game in the world. On top of that the game has a slow start, which is mainly used to get immeresed in this world, but may cause those who want instant gratification to be put off. Assuming that these things don't put you off then Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is an easy reccomendation.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
												If you don't believe videogames can be art, play this game and then come back and try to make that argument. You can't. Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is profoundly beautiful and adventurous and packs an emotional punch that will take you a while to come back from, and all with just two thumbsticks and two action buttons. This is a great story that isn't relayed by just stringing a bunch of cutscenes together, like some sort of interactive movie where you control the action parts. In fact, not one real word is spoken or written in the entire game: all voices are a sims-like babble. The emotional impact comes from, and is deeply tied to, the interaction with you the player. It's a story that would lose something vitally important if it was told in any other medium than a video game, like trying to translate an opera into flip-book form.It's short for a video game, about two hours or so, but that's because it's pared down to almost perfection, every chapter a delight with surprises and adventures, and never overstaying it's welcome. There are no doodads to collect, and no achievements for just completing a chapter. All the achievements are just little interesting moments added to the main storyline, that you might miss the first time around. One of them involves just ignoring the urgency of the main quest to get a magic elixir to save your dad, and going to the beach and skipping stones.Play this game if you haven't already, it's great, and I doubt you could find better entertainment more worth your two hours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												I think it’s easy enough to skim through the other reviews and know that Brothers is a fresh, innovative, beautiful game with very few elements capable of being considered a flaw so instead I want to do my best to explain how it feels to play this game. Additionally, all of my game time was with a 360 pad and I cannot recommend enough that you use a controller when playing Brothers.The controls are about as straight forward as controls can be; left stick and left trigger move and interact respectively for one brother, right stick and right trigger controls the other brother. That’s it. Yet with only 4 controls this game pulls you in and makes you feel like a part of the world in a way I have not seen in a game before. I think because of the simplicity of the controls, your mind has more attention to invest in the story, the emotions and the world stretching out before you. I wish I could explain one of the most impacting moments of the story without giving any spoilers, but there comes a point late in the game where the controls change in a very deliberate way and there are not enough words on this earth to explain how heavy of an emotional impact that change made.Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons is one of the finest adventures in gaming that I’ve been on, but when you combine the game with the absolute masterpiece of a control scheme it’s no longer an adventure I played.. it’s a memory that I lived.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												Spoiler free review:Gameplay was so tedious and the co-op is unplayable; there was even more co-op between prisoners and captors in a concentration camp. Characters were completely flat and void of any depth, soundtrack was subpar and at times misplaced, and the art design was so poorly done it could only have been the work of an individual suffering late stages of glaucoma. Each puzzle was so simplistic it essentially boiled down to a game of walking around holding down the interact button, but, the platforming was revolutionary; it combined the best platforming aspects of Deadly Premonition, Osu! Tatakae! Ouendan, and Typing of the Dead (Dreamcast 2001 Edition). The stories depth was written so well to the view of a child that it makes the entire game irrelevant.It would appear that the writer took too much creative freedom in developing the story of two childhood friends travelling through a world in which the writer could not settle on a genre. The story begins in a beautifully set middle earth world as we follow the tale of two roommates whose landlord suddenly falls ill. To the great guidance of the town drunk, these work colleagues set out on a journey through a village of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, to a steampunk cathedral where we meet a cage dancer and rescue her from her pimp. The game then takes a grisly turn when it delves into animal cruelty as these two civil partners kidnap, abuse, mutilate, and mount a majestic griffon to death. It soon becomes clear that these two felons are completely void of any human decency; corpse mutilation, limb ripping, decapitation, blood bathing, these are all of a few of the satanic rituals they conduct. When the two scholars save a poor woman from being sacrificed to the giant gods with seemingly no ulterior motives, she offers them a place to rest, and even shows them her vulnurable motherly form; creating a nice web of love to keep them warm in the night. To repay in kindness, they quickly remove each of her eight limbs and leave her to die. In her dying throes she attempts to hug the two tenants one last time as an act of love. The most sadistic of the two proceeds to impale himself on one of her limbs to let her know that she's nothing but a monster in her last moments alive. She then dies in anguish as the two revel in her death. The kouhai (TN Note: kouhai is korean for junior) shows no signs of remorse as he digs a hole and throws his senpai's newly mutilated body into a ditch on the side of the path. He fills the hole with various scat that he can find. He then finds the elixir of life and selfishly pours it onto his senpai's body; mocking him that he is void of life. The story ends when he returns to his landlord with the rent (the elixir). This tale was truly an enthralling adventure that teaches us the dangers of technology abuse. It's commentary on social media is a clear cut warning to us all.10/10, would not recommend.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												This game is pretty interesting. You control two brothers at the same time using, preferably, a gamepad, but it plays ok with a keyboard. I can say that moving both characters can be a bit awkward, but eventually I kind of got used to it. I found a way to lessen the confusion by aways leaving the brother controled with my right hand on the right side of the screen and the other on the left side. The story is simple, your father is really sick and the only way to save him is to go find the tree of life, but of course the path to the final objective is a lot trickier. Along the way you'll find many interesting characters, stories, vistas and casual puzzles that require the use of both brothers, each with their own set of skills. I would say that the most interesting aspect of this game, besides you having to control two characters at once, is how well the controls are tied to the story telling and when the moment comes you'll know that. Saying anything else would ruin the fun, so if you are courious don't miss out on this quite unique experience. For those who are interested, this game is short (four to six hours) so you may want to wait for a sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												I have played many games in my lifetime. So many, that it is too easy to see similarities between games, storylines, gameplay mechanics, and themes. I have gotten used to being amused - but not surprised - by pretty environments and clever controls. Brothers takes what at first seems like a novel way of using a controller and turns it into a powerful storytelling device in itself. Coupled with awe inspiring scenery and a compelling journey with just enough 'game' mixed in makes for an amazing experience that is hard to classify as either a fun experience or a deeply emotional art appreciation. I have to say, however, that it took me about 30 minutes to get into the game. I'm so glad I stuck with it until it hooked me...the beginning of the game, while pretty and somewhat interesting, belies the amazing and truly incredible oddyssey that lies ahead.

I was really drawn into this game. I really liked the ending, and the fact that this game was made by an indie film director made the game feel like an immersive film a lot of the time. I really liked it.It's cheap, it's fun, and it's something really different to the usual. I really recommend you try this game out :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												I was skeptical of this game at first: single-player co-op; controlling two characters simultaneously. My fears were dispelled within 20 minutes of play time, as the controls are simple and fluid enough that there is never any real problem controlling separate characters.The gameplay is casual; nothing is terribly difficult to figure out. Some would say it is too easy, but I think it lends well to the progression and design of the game. This game is about the story, and should place higher priority on forward progress than challenging puzzles.This is not to say that the flow of progression is too quick: it is right where it needs to be. When combined with the artistic style, story and atmosphere of the game the whole thing comes together as a relaxing, heartfelt and thoroughly enjoyable experience.This game is worth every dollar you pay for it. You might even have a laugh at yourself when you try to control one character and move the other.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												I used a Logitech F310 for this game. I also have bad joints, so holding down the trigger buttons (and there were lots of those!) was uncomfortable. Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is a beautiful game, nonetheless. Even though I have completed the game, I still confused the controls for each brother toward the end. It tells a good story, and it was darker than I thought it would be. I thoroughly enjoyed the unexpected more sinister parts of the game. I bought it on sale, but it's definitely worth the full price, even with only about 4 and a half hours of gameplay. Achievements were easy to obtain because I could go back and revisit each chapter.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												For such a short game, with dialogue you can't even understand I spent quite some time questioning what was so great about this game while trying to get a feel for the controls (keyboard yo). It was actually quite funny to watch how my brain could not comprehend the controls if the character controlled by the set of movement keys located on the right side of the keyboard was walking on the left and vice versa. Total mind♥♥♥♥ right there and it never went away completely to be honest. However, I got better with the controls and the puzzles became a piece of cake, fun even. As the game progressed I started to understand this funny, little language they spoke quite well and through the characters and the environment; began to perceive the world they lived in through their eyes. Pretty things became beautiful, jokes became heartfelt and emotional moments became ♥♥♥♥ing heartbreaking. For such a small game that's a lot to achieve and thus deserves another + from me.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												I've no words to describe how emotionally involved I became with this little gem when playing it. I finished it in one single playthrough.  The atmosphere, the story, the music, the visuals, everything is perfect.  The gameplay is fun and involving, although the puzzles are a bit too easy sometimes, they are still very satisfying to complete.   Replayability is low, except to complete your achievements, and perhaps come back to i t from time to time, perhaps once a year.  I wish more game studios did games like this. A true piece of art.  10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												I'm not really sure how exactly should I review this game. But I want to do it anyway.What is this game?It's an adventure game where you play as two brothers who are on an important quest.First of all, the controls... they are a bit confusing at times, but interesting - you control each brother with a separate trigger and analog stick on the controller.Something... as if you played some coop adventure game like the Lego games, but by yourself, controlling both players at the same time. Yeah, it is as confusing as it sounds at first (at least this game has no attack or jump buttons, or it would've been insane and mind breaking).And yes, the game REALLY requires a controller, since without it the whole concept of the game breaks and some "qte's", such as spinning two valve handles with the analog sticks are just not possible with a keyboard.Still, the game was insanely overhyped for me, the gameplay was repetitive and the puzzles were obvious. The game really is easy and I don't know if it's even possible to die from something in it.As it goes for the story... nothing really unusual, but it's nice and rather relatable. And it doesn't get boring for 3+ hours it takes to beat this game.The graphics and music are often really good and they create a really nice atmosphere at times.Overall, it's a nice little adventure game that brings something unique and interesting to the table. It might not be worth it for its full price tag for somebody, but as it goes for the sale price, it's definitely worth two or three dollars (depending on your region).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												This game is amazing, but imagine how much better it would have been if it could pass the bechdel test!!!!All jokes aside, this game is sublime. Even though the theme is somewhat dark, you'd be hard pressed to find a game with more "make you smile" moments. The way the two brothers interact differently with different people and objects is a joy. The way the brothers work together and care for each other without the use of words. The game compels me to want to be a good person to the people I come across, even if it's not always an option. The puzzles themselves are usually pretty obvious, without the use of any cheap visual hints. They typically aren't very difficult either, but they never lose their novelty as the game goes on. But they're really only a stepping stone to get to what the game is really about. If you want a game that will make you smile, make you sorrowful, and take you on a truly amazing adventure, this game nails it.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												A very short but fantastically paced game, moving from local shenanigans to exploring desolate castles, assisting trolls, barren battlefields filled with dead giants and giant invisible yetis in the snow. All this contained in a wonderful visual style and fleshed out with (what appears to be) interesting Nordic lore. Mechanically fascinating due to its two character system, taking something that could be multiplayer but maps it all to one pad. Due to the mechanical reliance of the characters with one another it enhances the story's impact.Possibly one of the most fantastic short game experiences I've had in a very long time. If you were a fan of games in the style of team Ico's this is very highly advised.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												A stunning game which I highly recommend.  It is short (3 - 5 hours gameplay) but it makes up for it in the engaging storyline, the characters, the beautiful graphics and the way in which you control both brothers at the same time.You do need a controller to play this game as it makes controlling the two brothers easy and intuitive.  The storyline whilst reasonably simple takes you into a number of different lands where you will meet several other characters.  Throughtout the game the graphics are visually stunning, perhaps the best I have experienced in a game (watch the shadows of not just your own characters but those of others you interact with, even those you can see a long way down the mountains you climb).  The colours are superb and the whole experience is one of quality.  The puzzles are relatively straightforward but nonetheless satisfying to complete and the added bonus of unlocking achievements adds both game time and an element of fun.Above all I felt the game was a very fulfilling experience (yes I wish it was longer) and I have never felt so engaged with a character in a game.  A real emotional gaming experience, one which I can not recommend highly enough.  A game I have already returned to, go buy it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Brothers is a very pretty game. It is definately charming with its lack of a discernable dialogue and gorgeous graphics that look hand painted at times. The story is 'touching' I suppose, but it's nothing you can't see coming from a mile away.The control scheme has you controlling one brother with a left analogue stick, and the other with the right. Each trigger controls a contextual action each brother can take, making the controls very simple, but you can get yourself tied in knots trying to control each brother, which is kind of amusing. You'll feel good when pulling off certain tasks in tandem though.On the downside is the fact that the game is around three and a half hours long, and there is little reason to play again unless you really want those achievements. I think the $15 price tag is ridiculous for such a short experience, good as it is. Pick it up for $5 if you can, $10 if you really enjoy these 'games as art' joints.Overall I recommend Brothers to everyone, even to family members that you want to try to get into gaming. Barring that though, get it on sale to take the sting off the price.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												If the characters can be made loveable, rememberable and relateable without any words, something has been definately done right.Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is an adventure with great visuals and beautiful sceneries. The benches that have been placed around the routes you travel give you a nice little pause and another angle to look at the world around you. Technically the game does not amaze you, but how the gameplay immerses you into the story is quite an achievement. Play with a controller.Once in the first chapter I ran into a glitch where the younger brother fell through the sand on the river shore. Nothing game breaking, but little funny atleast.I played the game through in a little less than 3 hours. But those were really, really good 3 hours.Video games are an art. And this is a fine example what it can be at it's best.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												wow, this game really got me. ill probably never play it again but the story was an emotional rollercoaster that really touched me and left me with an experience i wont soon forget. some people have mentioned how short the game is. i beat in about 6 hours spread over 2 sessions. some say 3 hours and i could see that (i took it pretty slow, thoroughly enjoying the environments and soaking in the beautiful and artistic settings). let me say this though, would you spend $10-15 to see a major motion picture in theatres? i guarantee this will last longer and be far more satisfying and touching than anything youll see on the big screen. the controls and interactivity really have a way of drawing you in and getting you emotionally involved. a couple notes on the subject of controls. i have a 3rd party controller that wasnt supported by the game (actually it really only seems to support the xbox 360 controller period). however using x360ce solved all my problems and the game ran fine (though it does require the extra stuff beyond just the base program). also, i would recommend using the same setup as with the default 360 layout as the controller layout is relevant to the story and how it affects you. either way keyboard also works fine without any controllers.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												I have played many games in my lifetime. So many, that it is too easy to see similarities between games, storylines, gameplay mechanics, and themes. I have gotten used to being amused - but not surprised - by pretty environments and clever controls. Brothers takes what at first seems like a novel way of using a controller and turns it into a powerful storytelling device in itself. Coupled with awe inspiring scenery and a compelling journey with just enough 'game' mixed in makes for an amazing experience that is hard to classify as either a fun experience or a deeply emotional art appreciation. I have to say, however, that it took me about 30 minutes to get into the game. I'm so glad I stuck with it until it hooked me...the beginning of the game, while pretty and somewhat interesting, belies the amazing and truly incredible oddyssey that lies ahead.

												One of the best games I've played. It was pretty small, and I managed to complete the game in just over three hours, but the immersion and story was a big seller. Not only that, but the game mechanics brought something new to the table. I am a fan of puzzle games, but being able to control 2 characters at once in a way that made sense to solve puzzles was something entirely new to me, and a really fun way to immerse yourself in the game. I was really drawn into this game. I really liked the ending, and the fact that this game was made by an indie film director made the game feel like an immersive film a lot of the time. I really liked it.It's cheap, it's fun, and it's something really different to the usual. I really recommend you try this game out :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												In terms of replay value, Brothers - A Tale of Two Sons is not a good buy. It's only got one main storyline with a few sub-objectives, and once that's over, that's it.However, in terms of overall worth, it is by far worth the buy at any reasonable price.The narrative of the game follows two brothers (no duh) traveling to a great tree in a far away land in order to save their sick father. While it starts off alright, with the player (namely myself) thinking "Why exactly am I playing this game?" That feeling actually remains for the next hour or so. However, as the story progresses and one sees more of the characters and who they are, the story gradually becomes gripping and emotional; while it is a short game (roughly 3 hours), it holds themes and motifs that are easily worthy of high quality movies, and it takes the player on a proper emotional rollercoaster that leaves him or her thinking about it afterward.The gameplay is kind of intuitive--controlling two separate characters with your analog sticks (controller only, I don't know how the keyboard works) is unique and compelling for a bit, but it wouldn't last long. Luckily, as I said before, this game is short and therefore its gameplay remains fresh throughout the first playthrough, which is a valuable component to any game. It even consistently switches things up and introduces variations of its few mechanics so that by the end of it, the player doesn't feel bored or underwhelmed.Along with the side quests and absolutely beautiful world design, this game is a must-buy. I can't recommend it enough if you have a couple of hours to spend.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Finally purchased and played through this game after hearing rave reviews from sources I trust.  A simple game really, two brothers going on an epic quest to save their father.  No combat, minor puzzles, and most of the game isn't even sensitive to timing/controls.  Those pieces that are are exceptionally forgiving.  Gameplay isn't what makes it great, and realistically not even the visuals, even though they are stunning.  The story is key here.  No dialog, no text, just a few voiced nonsense words in a language that's never translated.  It conveys emotion, and that's all it needed to do.  Most of why this game was something special for me is going to be in a spoiler section at the end, but I'll go ahead and break down the rest.So a quick breakdown:ControlsSo basically the controls were a touch frustrating.  I don't do that well with dual stick and keeping things straight as I just don't spend much time with a gamepad in my hand.  That said, gamepad really is the way to play.  Thankfully the gameplay was forgiving enough that I could get past it.GraphicsTop notch.  Visuals were stunning.  Don't pass up the park benches.  Sit down, take a minute or two and just enjoy the awesome vistas they put together.  The artists deserve incredible credit for what they did.GameplayIt's a really simple game with a few puzzles to keep the journey interesting.  They serve to give you a sense of each brother's personality and to give you some challenge so you're not just walking through.  Nothing special, but servicable for what they needed it to do.  The game is short, but I'd actually say if it wasn't it just wouldn't work.Story CommentHere's the heart of it.  The story is also a simple one, and one that has been told before.  The difference here is in the telling.  They've told in a way only a video game could do.  It's impressive, and because of that they've earned every bit of praise this game will ever receive.  The rest of my thoughts on the story are in the spoiler below.The whole game you go through working with the two brothers, one stick and one button each.  They set off to save their father from an illness by seeking magic water.  It quickly establishes their characters despite the minimal ways the game can based on it's design.  The older, more serious, more goal focused.   The younger more prone to playing around, joking, and causing mischief.  As the story goes on there are some aspects of the two working together that reminded me of myself and my own older brother.  Details are unimportant on the rest of the journey until just before the end.  You encounter a dangerous creature and the older brother is badly injured.  The magic water is in sight and the younger brother goes to get it.  Unfortunately, the older doesn't make it until you return.  The game continues with having to move the body into the grave and bury your brother.  You stand at the grave for a time, then head for home to save your father.  When you're close enough you can see where you need to be you encounter obsticals that throughout the game were only solvable using the older brother, not the younger.  As the younger alone you still can't solve it.  The moment I realized I had to hit the trigger that was assigned to the older brother actions to get around the obsticals was pure magic, touching, but also extremely sad.  After reaching for a tissue, I finished up and started thinking about my own brother and times when we were younger.  That is something I 'm not sure any game I've ever played has done quite like this.  So final thoughts.  It's an understatement to say I recommend it.  I may not call it one of the best games I've played, because if the gameplay is all that was there I wouldn't have enjoyed it.  Brothers is almost feels more like something you have experienced than as a game.  That said, it's well worth a few bucks and a few hours of your time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												This is the proof that games can be more than mere "games". B:ATTS  is precisely that, a tale, a tale that, unlike reading a book or watching a movie, you can experience yourself. You quickly feel invested with the main characters and grasp the innovative control mechanics, that allow you to control both brothers at once in a very fluid way. The game is beautiful with a very artistic façade, at times gorgeous. The plot is both heartwarming and heartbreaking, but you need to experience it yourself.
